{"pertussisnum_articles": "270", "pertussis": [{"archive_id": "8144942", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update: Canada (NT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8144942", "date": "2019-10-27 17:19:12", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (10): AMERICAS (USA, CANADA)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nAmericas\n---\n[1] USA (New York)\n[2] USA (Kentucky)\n[3] USA (Nevada)\n[4] USA (New York)\n[5] Canada (Alberta)\n\n******\n[1] New York (Jefferson County)\nDate: Thu 10 Oct 2019\nSource: WWNY TV [edited]\nhttps://www.wwnytv.com/2019/10/10/whooping-cough-outbreak-strikes-jefferson-county-health-officials-say/\n\n\nThere's a pertussis outbreak in Jefferson County. Public health officials say there have been 23 confirmed cases of the disease [pertussis], also known as whooping cough, since 1 Jun [2019]. People who caught the disease range in age from 5 months to 15 years.\n\nOfficials say older children, adults, people who've been vaccinated, and those who've had whooping cough before may experience a milder illness but can still spread it to others.\n\nWhooping cough is spread by coughing or sneezing, or coming in direct contact with respiratory secretions of people who are infected, health officials say. The most common symptom is uncontrollable coughing spells often followed by a characteristic \"whoop\" sound. An infected person can spread the disease starting when symptoms begin to 3 weeks after the coughing begins. Coughing frequently lasts for several weeks. County Public Health Director Ginger Hall says pertussis is highly communicable and can be prevented by the vaccine known as Tdap, which protects against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jefferson County, with a population of 116 229 residents in 2010, is on the northeastern border of the U.S. state of New York, adjacent to Lake Ontario and the St. Laurence River; its county seat is Watertown (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson_County,_New_York). A map that shows the location of Jefferson County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Jefferson+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky\nDate: Wed 16 Oct 2019\nSource: WPSD Local6 [edited]\nhttps://www.wpsdlocal6.com/news/whooping-cough-cases-linked-to-decreased-vaccinations-in-adults/article_ca8f8570-f056-11e9-969b-0b4893e1cf6f.html\n\n\nWhooping cough can be deadly for babies and tough on adults, too. In Kentucky, there have been 8 confirmed cases this year [2019].\n\nData from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show a rise in cases in Kentucky and a decrease in vaccinations. The latest CDC data show that from 2017 to 2018, the number of Tdap vaccinations decreased by 1.4%. The number of cases of whooping cough increased to more than 10 cases per 100 000 people.\n\nKnight [a nurse at the Purchase District Health Department] said the lack of vaccines for adults and a false sense of security [are] contributing to this increase. \"If your child was the one that couldn't have the immunization, you would want everyone else around them to have it,\" Knight said. \"And to keep them in mind that you're doing it for your child, because you don't want them to get this disease.\"\n\n[Byline: Abisola Adeyemo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kentucky is a state (actually a commonwealth) located in the east south-central region of the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky). A map showing the location of Kentucky can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Kentucky. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Nevada (Washoe County)\nDate: Tue 22 Oct 2019\nSource: U.S. News & World Report [edited]\nhttps://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/nevada/articles/2019-10-22/whooping-cough-outbreak-closes-private-reno-high-school\n\n\nA whooping cough outbreak has prompted the closure of a private high school in Reno [Nevada] until next week. The Washoe County Health District says it has confirmed 4 cases of whooping cough at Bishop Manogue High School. Additional cases are probable.\n\nDistrict officials say the Catholic school is cooperating with an investigation into the highly contagious respiratory disease and agreed to close the school until Monday [28 Oct 2019] to protect students and staff.\n\nDistrict Health officer Kevin Dick said late Monday [21 Oct 2019] that the outbreak is \"very serious.\" He says it underscores why all students are required to be vaccinated for the disease, which is called \"pertussis\" and is known for uncontrollable, violent coughing that makes it hard to breathe.\n\nWashoe County School District officials say no other cases have been confirmed at any other schools in the Reno-Sparks area.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Washoe County, with an estimated population of 465 735 residents in 2018, is located in the northwestern portion of the US state of Nevada; there are 2 incorporated cities within the county, Reno and Sparks, which are 4 miles apart (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washoe_County,_Nevada). Bishop Manogue Catholic High School is a Catholic high school in Reno, Nevada (https://www.bishopmanogue.org). A map showing the location of Reno and Sparks can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Reno,+Nevada/Sparks,+Nevada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New York (Sullivan County]\nDate: Sat 26 Oct 2019\nSource: The Daily Freeman [edited]\nhttps://www.dailyfreeman.com/news/sullivan-county-issues-whooping-cough-advisory/article_5a363f6e-f80b-11e9-a36f-27221984eceb.html\n\n\nSullivan County Public Health Services confirmed that 3 cases of pertussis -- also known as whooping cough -- have been identified in children of varying ages in the county this week.\n\nPublic Health Director Nancy McGraw called this an important advisory. \"As recently as 2016, Sullivan County had a pertussis outbreak of nearly 30 cases, and dozens of additional probable cases were investigated, interviewed, and individuals treated,\" she said.\n\nMcGraw said that if you or your child has been around someone with pertussis, you may become sick with it, especially if you or your child has not received all of the pertussis vaccine shots. Sometimes, even if your shots are up to date, you may still get pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sullivan County, with an estimated population of 75 498 in 2018, is a county in the southern part of the U.S. state of New York. It is separated from the U.S. state of Pennsylvania along its southwest boundary by the Delaware River, and its county seat is the city of Monticello (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sullivan_County,_New_York). A map showing the location of Sullivan County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sullivan+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] Alberta (South Zone)\nDate: 16 Oct 2019\nSource: CTV News [edited]\nhttps://calgary.ctvnews.ca/health-officials-declare-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-southern-alberta-1.4641826?fbclid=IwAR1ebNkeYH3oS7yXMFRCjYhj2JgZXmhzi_KWA1pgyG0_hx5kkdeLuqeiBvs\n\n\nAlberta Health Services [AHS] has confirmed over a dozen new cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, in a number of regions, including Lethbridge, Letbridge County, and Raymond.\n\nOfficials say 15 new cases of the illness have been discovered in the past 2 weeks, bringing the total number of confirmed illnesses to 42 for the whole year [2019]. There is a particular concern about the newest cases, AHS told the media on Wednesday [16 Oct 2019].\n\n\"They are locally acquired,\" said Dr. Vivien Suttorp, Medical Officer of Health, South Zone, \"Whooping cough, as I mentioned before, is underreported. There's a spectrum of illness. Little kiddies and infants have the most severe disease, and adults might just have a milder cough or chronic cough, but they are infectious to others.\"\n\nAs a result, special restrictions are in place for visitors to the neonatal intensive care unit at the Chinook Regional Hospital as well as the labour and delivery, pediatrics, and maternity units. Under these rules, those under the age of 16 will not be permitted, and there will be only 2 visitors per patient allowed. Anyone with symptoms such as a cough or runny nose are reminded not to visit.\n\nAccording to AHS, an outbreak is called when 2 or more cases of illness are identified that have a common epidemiological link, such as same location, unit, floor, caregiver or transmission within the unit of the facility.\n\nThere were 58 cases of pertussis in the South Zone last year [2018].\n\n[Byline: Michael Franklin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lethbridge is the 3rd largest city in the province of Alberta, Canada, southeast of Calgary. Alberta is divided into 5 health zones; a map showing the location of these zones can be found at https://www.albertahealthservices.ca/ahs-map-ahs-zones.pdf. The cities of Lethbridge and Raymond are located in the South Zone. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nCanada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12]\nSee Also\nPertussis update (09): Americas (USA) 20190918.6677444\nPertussis update (08): Americas, Europe, Australia, corr. 20190725.6586026\nPertussis update (08): "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7491247", "date": "2019-10-27 17:19:12", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (10): AMERICAS (USA, CANADA)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nAmericas\n---\n[1] USA (New York)\n[2] USA (Kentucky)\n[3] USA (Nevada)\n[4] USA (New York)\n[5] Canada (Alberta)\n\n******\n[1] New York (Jefferson County)\nDate: Thu 10 Oct 2019\nSource: WWNY TV [edited]\nhttps://www.wwnytv.com/2019/10/10/whooping-cough-outbreak-strikes-jefferson-county-health-officials-say/\n\n\nThere's a pertussis outbreak in Jefferson County. Public health officials say there have been 23 confirmed cases of the disease [pertussis], also known as whooping cough, since 1 Jun [2019]. People who caught the disease range in age from 5 months to 15 years.\n\nOfficials say older children, adults, people who've been vaccinated, and those who've had whooping cough before may experience a milder illness but can still spread it to others.\n\nWhooping cough is spread by coughing or sneezing, or coming in direct contact with respiratory secretions of people who are infected, health officials say. The most common symptom is uncontrollable coughing spells often followed by a characteristic \"whoop\" sound. An infected person can spread the disease starting when symptoms begin to 3 weeks after the coughing begins. Coughing frequently lasts for several weeks. County Public Health Director Ginger Hall says pertussis is highly communicable and can be prevented by the vaccine known as Tdap, which protects against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jefferson County, with a population of 116 229 residents in 2010, is on the northeastern border of the U.S. state of New York, adjacent to Lake Ontario and the St. Laurence River; its county seat is Watertown (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson_County,_New_York). A map that shows the location of Jefferson County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Jefferson+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky\nDate: Wed 16 Oct 2019\nSource: WPSD Local6 [edited]\nhttps://www.wpsdlocal6.com/news/whooping-cough-cases-linked-to-decreased-vaccinations-in-adults/article_ca8f8570-f056-11e9-969b-0b4893e1cf6f.html\n\n\nWhooping cough can be deadly for babies and tough on adults, too. In Kentucky, there have been 8 confirmed cases this year [2019].\n\nData from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show a rise in cases in Kentucky and a decrease in vaccinations. The latest CDC data show that from 2017 to 2018, the number of Tdap vaccinations decreased by 1.4%. The number of cases of whooping cough increased to more than 10 cases per 100 000 people.\n\nKnight [a nurse at the Purchase District Health Department] said the lack of vaccines for adults and a false sense of security [are] contributing to this increase. \"If your child was the one that couldn't have the immunization, you would want everyone else around them to have it,\" Knight said. \"And to keep them in mind that you're doing it for your child, because you don't want them to get this disease.\"\n\n[Byline: Abisola Adeyemo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kentucky is a state (actually a commonwealth) located in the east south-central region of the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky). A map showing the location of Kentucky can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Kentucky. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Nevada (Washoe County)\nDate: Tue 22 Oct 2019\nSource: U.S. News & World Report [edited]\nhttps://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/nevada/articles/2019-10-22/whooping-cough-outbreak-closes-private-reno-high-school\n\n\nA whooping cough outbreak has prompted the closure of a private high school in Reno [Nevada] until next week. The Washoe County Health District says it has confirmed 4 cases of whooping cough at Bishop Manogue High School. Additional cases are probable.\n\nDistrict officials say the Catholic school is cooperating with an investigation into the highly contagious respiratory disease and agreed to close the school until Monday [28 Oct 2019] to protect students and staff.\n\nDistrict Health officer Kevin Dick said late Monday [21 Oct 2019] that the outbreak is \"very serious.\" He says it underscores why all students are required to be vaccinated for the disease, which is called \"pertussis\" and is known for uncontrollable, violent coughing that makes it hard to breathe.\n\nWashoe County School District officials say no other cases have been confirmed at any other schools in the Reno-Sparks area.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Washoe County, with an estimated population of 465 735 residents in 2018, is located in the northwestern portion of the US state of Nevada; there are 2 incorporated cities within the county, Reno and Sparks, which are 4 miles apart (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washoe_County,_Nevada). Bishop Manogue Catholic High School is a Catholic high school in Reno, Nevada (https://www.bishopmanogue.org). A map showing the location of Reno and Sparks can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Reno,+Nevada/Sparks,+Nevada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New York (Sullivan County]\nDate: Sat 26 Oct 2019\nSource: The Daily Freeman [edited]\nhttps://www.dailyfreeman.com/news/sullivan-county-issues-whooping-cough-advisory/article_5a363f6e-f80b-11e9-a36f-27221984eceb.html\n\n\nSullivan County Public Health Services confirmed that 3 cases of pertussis -- also known as whooping cough -- have been identified in children of varying ages in the county this week.\n\nPublic Health Director Nancy McGraw called this an important advisory. \"As recently as 2016, Sullivan County had a pertussis outbreak of nearly 30 cases, and dozens of additional probable cases were investigated, interviewed, and individuals treated,\" she said.\n\nMcGraw said that if you or your child has been around someone with pertussis, you may become sick with it, especially if you or your child has not received all of the pertussis vaccine shots. Sometimes, even if your shots are up to date, you may still get pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sullivan County, with an estimated population of 75 498 in 2018, is a county in the southern part of the U.S. state of New York. It is separated from the U.S. state of Pennsylvania along its southwest boundary by the Delaware River, and its county seat is the city of Monticello (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sullivan_County,_New_York). A map showing the location of Sullivan County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sullivan+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] Alberta (South Zone)\nDate: 16 Oct 2019\nSource: CTV News [edited]\nhttps://calgary.ctvnews.ca/health-officials-declare-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-southern-alberta-1.4641826?fbclid=IwAR1ebNkeYH3oS7yXMFRCjYhj2JgZXmhzi_KWA1pgyG0_hx5kkdeLuqeiBvs\n\n\nAlberta Health Services [AHS] has confirmed over a dozen new cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, in a number of regions, including Lethbridge, Letbridge County, and Raymond.\n\nOfficials say 15 new cases of the illness have been discovered in the past 2 weeks, bringing the total number of confirmed illnesses to 42 for the whole year [2019]. There is a particular concern about the newest cases, AHS told the media on Wednesday [16 Oct 2019].\n\n\"They are locally acquired,\" said Dr. Vivien Suttorp, Medical Officer of Health, South Zone, \"Whooping cough, as I mentioned before, is underreported. There's a spectrum of illness. Little kiddies and infants have the most severe disease, and adults might just have a milder cough or chronic cough, but they are infectious to others.\"\n\nAs a result, special restrictions are in place for visitors to the neonatal intensive care unit at the Chinook Regional Hospital as well as the labour and delivery, pediatrics, and maternity units. Under these rules, those under the age of 16 will not be permitted, and there will be only 2 visitors per patient allowed. Anyone with symptoms such as a cough or runny nose are reminded not to visit.\n\nAccording to AHS, an outbreak is called when 2 or more cases of illness are identified that have a common epidemiological link, such as same location, unit, floor, caregiver or transmission within the unit of the facility.\n\nThere were 58 cases of pertussis in the South Zone last year [2018].\n\n[Byline: Michael Franklin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lethbridge is the 3rd largest city in the province of Alberta, Canada, southeast of Calgary. Alberta is divided into 5 health zones; a map showing the location of these zones can be found at https://www.albertahealthservices.ca/ahs-map-ahs-zones.pdf. The cities of Lethbridge and Raymond are located in the South Zone. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nCanada: "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6969310", "date": "2019-10-27 17:19:12", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (10): AMERICAS (USA, CANADA)\n*********************************************\nA [edited]\nhttps://www.wwnytv.com/2019/10/10/whooping-cough-outbreak-strikes-jefferson-county-health-officials-say/\n\n\nThere's a pertussis outbreak in Jefferson County. Public health officials say there have been 23 confirmed cases of the disease [pertussis], also known as whooping cough, since 1 Jun [2019]. People who caught the disease range in age from 5 months to 15 years.\n\nOfficials say older children, adults, people who've been vaccinated, and those who've had whooping cough before may experience a milder illness but can still spread it to others.\n\nWhooping cough is spread by coughing or sneezing, or coming in direct contact with respiratory secretions of people who are infected, health officials say. The most common symptom is uncontrollable coughing spells often followed by a characteristic \"whoop\" sound. An infected person can spread the disease starting when symptoms begin to 3 weeks after the coughing begins. Coughing frequently lasts for several weeks. County Public Health Director Ginger Hall says pertussis is highly communicable and can be prevented by the vaccine known as Tdap, which protects against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jefferson County, with a population of 116 229 residents in 2010, is on the northeastern border of the U.S. state of New York, adjacent to Lake Ontario and the St. Laurence River; its county seat is Watertown (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson_County,_New_York). A map that shows the location of Jefferson County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Jefferson+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky\nDate: Wed 16 Oct 2019\nSource: WPSD Local6 [edited]\nhttps://www.wpsdlocal6.com/news/whooping-cough-cases-linked-to-decreased-vaccinations-in-adults/article_ca8f8570-f056-11e9-969b-0b4893e1cf6f.html\n\n\nWhooping cough can be deadly for babies and tough on adults, too. In Kentucky, there have been 8 confirmed cases this year [2019].\n\nData from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show a rise in cases in Kentucky and a decrease in vaccinations. The latest CDC data show that from 2017 to 2018, the number of Tdap vaccinations decreased by 1.4%. The number of cases of whooping cough increased to more than 10 cases per 100 000 people.\n\nKnight [a nurse at the Purchase District Health Department] said the lack of vaccines for adults and a false sense of security [are] contributing to this increase. \"If your child was the one that couldn't have the immunization, you would want everyone else around them to have it,\" Knight said. \"And to keep them in mind that you're doing it for your child, because you don't want them to get this disease.\"\n\n[Byline: Abisola Adeyemo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kentucky is a state (actually a commonwealth) located in the east south-central region of the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky). A map showing the location of Kentucky can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Kentucky. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Nevada (Washoe County)\nDate: Tue 22 Oct 2019\nSource: U.S. News & World Report [edited]\nhttps://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/nevada/articles/2019-10-22/whooping-cough-outbreak-closes-private-reno-high-school\n\n\nA whooping cough outbreak has prompted the closure of a private high school in Reno [Nevada] until next week. The Washoe County Health District says it has confirmed 4 cases of whooping cough at Bishop Manogue High School. Additional cases are probable.\n\nDistrict officials say the Catholic school is cooperating with an investigation into the highly contagious respiratory disease and agreed to close the school until Monday [28 Oct 2019] to protect students and staff.\n\nDistrict Health officer Kevin Dick said late Monday [21 Oct 2019] that the outbreak is \"very serious.\" He says it underscores why all students are required to be vaccinated for the disease, which is called \"pertussis\" and is known for uncontrollable, violent coughing that makes it hard to breathe.\n\nWashoe County School District officials say no other cases have been confirmed at any other schools in the Reno-Sparks area.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Washoe County, with an estimated population of 465 735 residents in 2018, is located in the northwestern portion of the US state of Nevada; there are 2 incorporated cities within the county, Reno and Sparks, which are 4 miles apart (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washoe_County,_Nevada). Bishop Manogue Catholic High School is a Catholic high school in Reno, Nevada (https://www.bishopmanogue.org). A map showing the location of Reno and Sparks can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Reno,+Nevada/Sparks,+Nevada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New York (Sullivan County]\nDate: Sat 26 Oct 2019\nSource: The Daily Freeman [edited]\nhttps://www.dailyfreeman.com/news/sullivan-county-issues-whooping-cough-advisory/article_5a363f6e-f80b-11e9-a36f-27221984eceb.html\n\n\nSullivan County Public Health Services confirmed that 3 cases of pertussis -- also known as whooping cough -- have been identified in children of varying ages in the county this week.\n\nPublic Health Director Nancy McGraw called this an important advisory. \"As recently as 2016, Sullivan County had a pertussis outbreak of nearly 30 cases, and dozens of additional probable cases were investigated, interviewed, and individuals treated,\" she said.\n\nMcGraw said that if you or your child has been around someone with pertussis, you may become sick with it, especially if you or your child has not received all of the pertussis vaccine shots. Sometimes, even if your shots are up to date, you may still get pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sullivan County, with an estimated population of 75 498 in 2018, is a county in the southern part of the U.S. state of New York. It is separated from the U.S. state of Pennsylvania along its southwest boundary by the Delaware River, and its county seat is the city of Monticello (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sullivan_County,_New_York). A map showing the location of Sullivan County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sullivan+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] Alberta (South Zone)\nDate: 16 Oct 2019\nSource: CTV News [edited]\nhttps://calgary.ctvnews.ca/health-officials-declare-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-southern-alberta-1.4641826?fbclid=IwAR1ebNkeYH3oS7yXMFRCjYhj2JgZXmhzi_KWA1pgyG0_hx5kkdeLuqeiBvs\n\n\nAlberta Health Services [AHS] has confirmed over a dozen new cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, in a number of regions, including Lethbridge, Letbridge County, and Raymond.\n\nOfficials say 15 new cases of the illness have been discovered in the past 2 weeks, bringing the total number of confirmed illnesses to 42 for the whole year [2019]. There is a particular concern about the newest cases, AHS told the media on Wednesday [16 Oct 2019].\n\n\"They are locally acquired,\" said Dr. Vivien Suttorp, Medical Officer of Health, South Zone, \"Whooping cough, as I mentioned before, is underreported. There's a spectrum of illness. Little kiddies and infants have the most severe disease, and adults might just have a milder cough or chronic cough, but they are infectious to others.\"\n\nAs a result, special restrictions are in place for visitors to the neonatal intensive care unit at the Chinook Regional Hospital as well as the labour and delivery, pediatrics, and maternity units. Under these rules, those under the age of 16 will not be permitted, and there will be only 2 visitors per patient allowed. Anyone with symptoms such as a cough or runny nose are reminded not to visit.\n\nAccording to AHS, an outbreak is called when 2 or more cases of illness are identified that have a common epidemiological link, such as same location, unit, floor, caregiver or transmission within the unit of the facility.\n\nThere were 58 cases of pertussis in the South Zone last year [2018].\n\n[Byline: Michael Franklin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lethbridge is the 3rd largest city in the province of Alberta, Canada, southeast of Calgary. Alberta is divided into 5 health zones; a map showing the location of these zones can be found at https://www.albertahealthservices.ca/ahs-map-ahs-zones.pdf. The cities of Lethbridge and Raymond are located in the South Zone. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nCanada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12]\nSee Also\nPertussis update (09): Americas (USA) 20190918.6677444\nPertussis update (08): Americas, Europe, Australia, corr. 20190725.6586026\nPertussis update (08): [], "event_date": ["2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 {"location": "South Zone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6868270", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (01): USA, Canada", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6868270", "date": "2019-10-27 17:19:12", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (10): AMERICAS (USA, CANADA)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nAmericas\n---\n[1] USA (New York)\n[2] USA (Kentucky)\n[3] USA (Nevada)\n[4] USA (New York)\n[5] Canada (Alberta)\n\n******\n[1] New York (Jefferson County)\nDate: Thu 10 Oct 2019\nSource: WWNY TV [edited]\nhttps://www.wwnytv.com/2019/10/10/whooping-cough-outbreak-strikes-jefferson-county-health-officials-say/\n\n\nThere's a pertussis outbreak in Jefferson County. Public health officials say there have been 23 confirmed cases of the disease [pertussis], also known as whooping cough, since 1 Jun [2019]. People who caught the disease range in age from 5 months to 15 years.\n\nOfficials say older children, adults, people who've been vaccinated, and those who've had whooping cough before may experience a milder illness but can still spread it to others.\n\nWhooping cough is spread by coughing or sneezing, or coming in direct contact with respiratory secretions of people who are infected, health officials say. The most common symptom is uncontrollable coughing spells often followed by a characteristic \"whoop\" sound. An infected person can spread the disease starting when symptoms begin to 3 weeks after the coughing begins. Coughing frequently lasts for several weeks. County Public Health Director Ginger Hall says pertussis is highly communicable and can be prevented by the vaccine known as Tdap, which protects against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jefferson County, with a population of 116 229 residents in 2010, is on the northeastern border of the U.S. state of New York, adjacent to Lake Ontario and the St. Laurence River; its county seat is Watertown (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson_County,_New_York). A map that shows the location of Jefferson County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Jefferson+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky\nDate: Wed 16 Oct 2019\nSource: WPSD Local6 [edited]\nhttps://www.wpsdlocal6.com/news/whooping-cough-cases-linked-to-decreased-vaccinations-in-adults/article_ca8f8570-f056-11e9-969b-0b4893e1cf6f.html\n\n\nWhooping cough can be deadly for babies and tough on adults, too. In Kentucky, there have been 8 confirmed cases this year [2019].\n\nData from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show a rise in cases in Kentucky and a decrease in vaccinations. The latest CDC data show that from 2017 to 2018, the number of Tdap vaccinations decreased by 1.4%. The number of cases of whooping cough increased to more than 10 cases per 100 000 people.\n\nKnight [a nurse at the Purchase District Health Department] said the lack of vaccines for adults and a false sense of security [are] contributing to this increase. \"If your child was the one that couldn't have the immunization, you would want everyone else around them to have it,\" Knight said. \"And to keep them in mind that you're doing it for your child, because you don't want them to get this disease.\"\n\n[Byline: Abisola Adeyemo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kentucky is a state (actually a commonwealth) located in the east south-central region of the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky). A map showing the location of Kentucky can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Kentucky. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Nevada (Washoe County)\nDate: Tue 22 Oct 2019\nSource: U.S. News & World Report [edited]\nhttps://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/nevada/articles/2019-10-22/whooping-cough-outbreak-closes-private-reno-high-school\n\n\nA whooping cough outbreak has prompted the closure of a private high school in Reno [Nevada] until next week. The Washoe County Health District says it has confirmed 4 cases of whooping cough at Bishop Manogue High School. Additional cases are probable.\n\nDistrict officials say the Catholic school is cooperating with an investigation into the highly contagious respiratory disease and agreed to close the school until Monday [28 Oct 2019] to protect students and staff.\n\nDistrict Health officer Kevin Dick said late Monday [21 Oct 2019] that the outbreak is \"very serious.\" He says it underscores why all students are required to be vaccinated for the disease, which is called \"pertussis\" and is known for uncontrollable, violent coughing that makes it hard to breathe.\n\nWashoe County School District officials say no other cases have been confirmed at any other schools in the Reno-Sparks area.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Washoe County, with an estimated population of 465 735 residents in 2018, is located in the northwestern portion of the US state of Nevada; there are 2 incorporated cities within the county, Reno and Sparks, which are 4 miles apart (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washoe_County,_Nevada). Bishop Manogue Catholic High School is a Catholic high school in Reno, Nevada (https://www.bishopmanogue.org). A map showing the location of Reno and Sparks can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Reno,+Nevada/Sparks,+Nevada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New York (Sullivan County]\nDate: Sat 26 Oct 2019\nSource: The Daily Freeman [edited]\nhttps://www.dailyfreeman.com/news/sullivan-county-issues-whooping-cough-advisory/article_5a363f6e-f80b-11e9-a36f-27221984eceb.html\n\n\nSullivan County Public Health Services confirmed that 3 cases of pertussis -- also known as whooping cough -- have been identified in children of varying ages in the county this week.\n\nPublic Health Director Nancy McGraw called this an important advisory. \"As recently as 2016, Sullivan County had a pertussis outbreak of nearly 30 cases, and dozens of additional probable cases were investigated, interviewed, and individuals treated,\" she said.\n\nMcGraw said that if you or your child has been around someone with pertussis, you may become sick with it, especially if you or your child has not received all of the pertussis vaccine shots. Sometimes, even if your shots are up to date, you may still get pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sullivan County, with an estimated population of 75 498 in 2018, is a county in the southern part of the U.S. state of New York. There is a particular concern about the newest cases, AHS told the media on Wednesday [16 Oct 2019].\n\n\"They are locally acquired,\" said Dr. Vivien Suttorp, Medical Officer of Health, South Zone, \"Whooping cough, as I mentioned before, is underreported. There's a spectrum of illness. Little kiddies and infants have the most severe disease, and adults might just have a milder cough or chronic cough, but they are infectious to others.\"\n\nAs a result, special restrictions are in place for visitors to the neonatal intensive care unit at the Chinook Regional Hospital as well as the labour and delivery, pediatrics, and maternity units. Sometimes, even if your shots are up to date, you may still get pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sullivan County, with an estimated population of 75 498 in 2018, is a county in the southern part of the U.S. state of New York. It is separated from the U.S. state of Pennsylvania along its southwest boundary by the Delaware River, and its county seat is the city of Monticello (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sullivan_County,_New_York). A map showing the location of Sullivan County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sullivan+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] Alberta (South Zone)\nDate: 16 Oct 2019\nSource: CTV News [edited]\nhttps://calgary.ctvnews.ca/health-officials-declare-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-southern-alberta-1.4641826?fbclid=IwAR1ebNkeYH3oS7yXMFRCjYhj2JgZXmhzi_KWA1pgyG0_hx5kkdeLuqeiBvs\n\n\nAlberta Health Services [AHS] has confirmed over a dozen new cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, in a number of regions, including Lethbridge, Letbridge County, and Raymond.\n\nOfficials say 15 new cases of the illness have been discovered in the past 2 weeks, bringing the total number of confirmed illnesses to 42 for the whole year [2019]. There is a particular concern about the newest cases, AHS told the media on Wednesday [16 Oct 2019].\n\n\"They are locally acquired,\" said Dr. Vivien Suttorp, Medical Officer of Health, South Zone, \"Whooping cough, as I mentioned before, is underreported. There's a spectrum of illness. Little kiddies and infants have the most severe disease, and adults might just have a milder cough or chronic cough, but they are infectious to others.\"\n\nAs a result, special restrictions are in place for visitors to the neonatal intensive care unit at the Chinook Regional Hospital as well as the labour and delivery, pediatrics, and maternity units. Under these rules, those under the age of 16 will not be permitted, and there will be only 2 visitors per patient allowed. Anyone with symptoms such as a cough or runny nose are reminded not to visit.\n\nAccording to AHS, an outbreak is called when 2 or more cases of illness are identified that have a common epidemiological link, such as same location, unit, floor, caregiver or transmission within the unit of the facility.\n\nThere were 58 cases of pertussis in the South Zone last year [2018].\n\n[Byline: Michael Franklin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lethbridge is the 3rd largest city in the province of Alberta, Canada, southeast of Calgary. Alberta is divided into 5 health zones; a map showing the location of these zones can be found at https://www.albertahealthservices.ca/ahs-map-ahs-zones.pdf. The cities of Lethbridge and Raymond are located in the South Zone. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nCanada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12]\nSee Also\nPertussis update (09): Americas (USA) 20190918.6677444\nPertussis update (08): Americas, Europe, Australia, corr. 20190725.6586026\nPertussis update (08): [], "event_date": ["2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 "locations": [{"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sullivan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liberia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jefferson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "District Health", {"location": "South Zone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6814919", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (12): Americas (Canada, USA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6814919", "date": "2019-10-27 17:19:12", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (10): AMERICAS (USA, CANADA)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nAmericas\n---\n[1] USA (New York)\n[2] USA (Kentucky)\n[3] USA (Nevada)\n[4] USA (New York)\n[5] Canada (Alberta)\n\n******\n[1] New York (Jefferson County)\nDate: Thu 10 Oct 2019\nSource: WWNY TV [edited]\nhttps://www.wwnytv.com/2019/10/10/whooping-cough-outbreak-strikes-jefferson-county-health-officials-say/\n\n\nThere's a pertussis outbreak in Jefferson County. Public health officials say there have been 23 confirmed cases of the disease [pertussis], also known as whooping cough, since 1 Jun [2019]. People who caught the disease range in age from 5 months to 15 years.\n\nOfficials say older children, adults, people who've been vaccinated, and those who've had whooping cough before may experience a milder illness but can still spread it to others.\n\nWhooping cough is spread by coughing or sneezing, or coming in direct contact with respiratory secretions of people who are infected, health officials say. The most common symptom is uncontrollable coughing spells often followed by a characteristic \"whoop\" sound. An infected person can spread the disease starting when symptoms begin to 3 weeks after the coughing begins. Coughing frequently lasts for several weeks. County Public Health Director Ginger Hall says pertussis is highly communicable and can be prevented by the vaccine known as Tdap, which protects against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jefferson County, with a population of 116 229 residents in 2010, is on the northeastern border of the U.S. state of New York, adjacent to Lake Ontario and the St. Laurence River; its county seat is Watertown (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson_County,_New_York). A map that shows the location of Jefferson County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Jefferson+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky\nDate: Wed 16 Oct 2019\nSource: WPSD Local6 [edited]\nhttps://www.wpsdlocal6.com/news/whooping-cough-cases-linked-to-decreased-vaccinations-in-adults/article_ca8f8570-f056-11e9-969b-0b4893e1cf6f.html\n\n\nWhooping cough can be deadly for babies and tough on adults, too. In Kentucky, there have been 8 confirmed cases this year [2019].\n\nData from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show a rise in cases in Kentucky and a decrease in vaccinations. The latest CDC data show that from 2017 to 2018, the number of Tdap vaccinations decreased by 1.4%. The number of cases of whooping cough increased to more than 10 cases per 100 000 people.\n\nKnight [a nurse at the Purchase District Health Department] said the lack of vaccines for adults and a false sense of security [are] contributing to this increase. \"If your child was the one that couldn't have the immunization, you would want everyone else around them to have it,\" Knight said. \"And to keep them in mind that you're doing it for your child, because you don't want them to get this disease.\"\n\n[Byline: Abisola Adeyemo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kentucky is a state (actually a commonwealth) located in the east south-central region of the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky). A map showing the location of Kentucky can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Kentucky. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Nevada (Washoe County)\nDate: Tue 22 Oct 2019\nSource: U.S. News & World Report [edited]\nhttps://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/nevada/articles/2019-10-22/whooping-cough-outbreak-closes-private-reno-high-school\n\n\nA whooping cough outbreak has prompted the closure of a private high school in Reno [Nevada] until next week. The Washoe County Health District says it has confirmed 4 cases of whooping cough at Bishop Manogue High School. Additional cases are probable.\n\nDistrict officials say the Catholic school is cooperating with an investigation into the highly contagious respiratory disease and agreed to close the school until Monday [28 Oct 2019] to protect students and staff.\n\nDistrict Health officer Kevin Dick said late Monday [21 Oct 2019] that the outbreak is \"very serious.\" He says it underscores why all students are required to be vaccinated for the disease, which is called \"pertussis\" and is known for uncontrollable, violent coughing that makes it hard to breathe.\n\nWashoe County School District officials say no other cases have been confirmed at any other schools in the Reno-Sparks area.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Washoe County, with an estimated population of 465 735 residents in 2018, is located in the northwestern portion of the US state of Nevada; there are 2 incorporated cities within the county, Reno and Sparks, which are 4 miles apart (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washoe_County,_Nevada). Bishop Manogue Catholic High School is a Catholic high school in Reno, Nevada (https://www.bishopmanogue.org). A map showing the location of Reno and Sparks can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Reno,+Nevada/Sparks,+Nevada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New York (Sullivan County]\nDate: Sat 26 Oct 2019\nSource: The Daily Freeman [edited]\nhttps://www.dailyfreeman.com/news/sullivan-county-issues-whooping-cough-advisory/article_5a363f6e-f80b-11e9-a36f-27221984eceb.html\n\n\nSullivan County Public Health Services confirmed that 3 cases of pertussis -- also known as whooping cough -- have been identified in children of varying ages in the county this week.\n\nPublic Health Director Nancy McGraw called this an important advisory. \"As recently as 2016, Sullivan County had a pertussis outbreak of nearly 30 cases, and dozens of additional probable cases were investigated, interviewed, and individuals treated,\" she said.\n\nMcGraw said that if you or your child has been around someone with pertussis, you may become sick with it, especially if you or your child has not received all of the pertussis vaccine shots. Sometimes, even if your shots are up to date, you may still get pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sullivan County, with an estimated population of 75 498 in 2018, is a county in the southern part of the U.S. state of New York. It is separated from the U.S. state of Pennsylvania along its southwest boundary by the Delaware River, and its county seat is the city of Monticello (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sullivan_County,_New_York). A map showing the location of Sullivan County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sullivan+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] Alberta (South Zone)\nDate: 16 Oct 2019\nSource: CTV News [edited]\nhttps://calgary.ctvnews.ca/health-officials-declare-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-southern-alberta-1.4641826?fbclid=IwAR1ebNkeYH3oS7yXMFRCjYhj2JgZXmhzi_KWA1pgyG0_hx5kkdeLuqeiBvs\n\n\nAlberta Health Services [AHS] has confirmed over a dozen new cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, in a number of regions, including Lethbridge, Letbridge County, and Raymond.\n\nOfficials say 15 new cases of the illness have been discovered in the past 2 weeks, bringing the total number of confirmed illnesses to 42 for the whole year [2019]. There is a particular concern about the newest cases, AHS told the media on Wednesday [16 Oct 2019].\n\n\"They are locally acquired,\" said Dr. Vivien Suttorp, Medical Officer of Health, South Zone, \"Whooping cough, as I mentioned before, is underreported. There's a spectrum of illness. Little kiddies and infants have the most severe disease, and adults might just have a milder cough or chronic cough, but they are infectious to others.\"\n\nAs a result, special restrictions are in place for visitors to the neonatal intensive care unit at the Chinook Regional Hospital as well as the labour and delivery, pediatrics, and maternity units. Under these rules, those under the age of 16 will not be permitted, and there will be only 2 visitors per patient allowed. Anyone with symptoms such as a cough or runny nose are reminded not to visit.\n\nAccording to AHS, an outbreak is called when 2 or more cases of illness are identified that have a common epidemiological link, such as same location, unit, floor, caregiver or transmission within the unit of the facility.\n\nThere were 58 cases of pertussis in the South Zone last year [2018].\n\n[Byline: Michael Franklin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lethbridge is the 3rd largest city in the province of Alberta, Canada, southeast of Calgary. Alberta is divided into 5 health zones; a map showing the location of these zones can be found at https://www.albertahealthservices.ca/ahs-map-ahs-zones.pdf. The cities of Lethbridge and Raymond are located in the South Zone. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nCanada: {"location": "South Zone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6749235", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (10): Americas (USA, Canada)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6749235", "date": "2019-10-27 17:19:12", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (10): AMERICAS (USA, CANADA)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nAmericas\n---\n[1] USA (New York)\n[2] USA (Kentucky)\n[3] USA (Nevada)\n[4] USA (New York)\n[5] Canada (Alberta)\n\n******\n[1] New York (Jefferson County)\nDate: Thu 10 Oct 2019\nSource: WWNY TV [edited]\nhttps://www.wwnytv.com/2019/10/10/whooping-cough-outbreak-strikes-jefferson-county-health-officials-say/\n\n\nThere's a pertussis outbreak in Jefferson County. Public health officials say there have been 23 confirmed cases of the disease [pertussis], also known as whooping cough, since 1 Jun [2019]. People who caught the disease range in age from 5 months to 15 years.\n\nOfficials say older children, adults, people who've been vaccinated, and those who've had whooping cough before may experience a milder illness but can still spread it to others.\n\nWhooping cough is spread by coughing or sneezing, or coming in direct contact with respiratory secretions of people who are infected, health officials say. The most common symptom is uncontrollable coughing spells often followed by a characteristic \"whoop\" sound. An infected person can spread the disease starting when symptoms begin to 3 weeks after the coughing begins. Coughing frequently lasts for several weeks. County Public Health Director Ginger Hall says pertussis is highly communicable and can be prevented by the vaccine known as Tdap, which protects against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jefferson County, with a population of 116 229 residents in 2010, is on the northeastern border of the U.S. state of New York, adjacent to Lake Ontario and the St. Laurence River; its county seat is Watertown (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson_County,_New_York). A map that shows the location of Jefferson County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Jefferson+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky\nDate: Wed 16 Oct 2019\nSource: WPSD Local6 [edited]\nhttps://www.wpsdlocal6.com/news/whooping-cough-cases-linked-to-decreased-vaccinations-in-adults/article_ca8f8570-f056-11e9-969b-0b4893e1cf6f.html\n\n\nWhooping cough can be deadly for babies and tough on adults, too. In Kentucky, there have been 8 confirmed cases this year [2019].\n\nData from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show a rise in cases in Kentucky and a decrease in vaccinations. The latest CDC data show that from 2017 to 2018, the number of Tdap vaccinations decreased by 1.4%. The number of cases of whooping cough increased to more than 10 cases per 100 000 people.\n\nKnight [a nurse at the Purchase District Health Department] said the lack of vaccines for adults and a false sense of security [are] contributing to this increase. \"If your child was the one that couldn't have the immunization, you would want everyone else around them to have it,\" Knight said. \"And to keep them in mind that you're doing it for your child, because you don't want them to get this disease.\"\n\n[Byline: Abisola Adeyemo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kentucky is a state (actually a commonwealth) located in the east south-central region of the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky). A map showing the location of Kentucky can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Kentucky. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Nevada (Washoe County)\nDate: Tue 22 Oct 2019\nSource: U.S. News & World Report [edited]\nhttps://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/nevada/articles/2019-10-22/whooping-cough-outbreak-closes-private-reno-high-school\n\n\nA whooping cough outbreak has prompted the closure of a private high school in Reno [Nevada] until next week. The Washoe County Health District says it has confirmed 4 cases of whooping cough at Bishop Manogue High School. Additional cases are probable.\n\nDistrict officials say the Catholic school is cooperating with an investigation into the highly contagious respiratory disease and agreed to close the school until Monday [28 Oct 2019] to protect students and staff.\n\nDistrict Health officer Kevin Dick said late Monday [21 Oct 2019] that the outbreak is \"very serious.\" He says it underscores why all students are required to be vaccinated for the disease, which is called \"pertussis\" and is known for uncontrollable, violent coughing that makes it hard to breathe.\n\nWashoe County School District officials say no other cases have been confirmed at any other schools in the Reno-Sparks area.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Washoe County, with an estimated population of 465 735 residents in 2018, is located in the northwestern portion of the US state of Nevada; there are 2 incorporated cities within the county, Reno and Sparks, which are 4 miles apart (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washoe_County,_Nevada). Bishop Manogue Catholic High School is a Catholic high school in Reno, Nevada (https://www.bishopmanogue.org). A map showing the location of Reno and Sparks can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Reno,+Nevada/Sparks,+Nevada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New York (Sullivan County]\nDate: Sat 26 Oct 2019\nSource: The Daily Freeman [edited]\nhttps://www.dailyfreeman.com/news/sullivan-county-issues-whooping-cough-advisory/article_5a363f6e-f80b-11e9-a36f-27221984eceb.html\n\n\nSullivan County Public Health Services confirmed that 3 cases of pertussis -- also known as whooping cough -- have been identified in children of varying ages in the county this week.\n\nPublic Health Director Nancy McGraw called this an important advisory. \"As recently as 2016, Sullivan County had a pertussis outbreak of nearly 30 cases, and dozens of additional probable cases were investigated, interviewed, and individuals treated,\" she said.\n\nMcGraw said that if you or your child has been around someone with pertussis, you may become sick with it, especially if you or your child has not received all of the pertussis vaccine shots. Sometimes, even if your shots are up to date, you may still get pertussis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sullivan County, with an estimated population of 75 498 in 2018, is a county in the southern part of the U.S. state of New York. It is separated from the U.S. state of Pennsylvania along its southwest boundary by the Delaware River, and its county seat is the city of Monticello (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sullivan_County,_New_York). A map showing the location of Sullivan County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sullivan+County,+NY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] Alberta (South Zone)\nDate: 16 Oct 2019\nSource: CTV News [edited]\nhttps://calgary.ctvnews.ca/health-officials-declare-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-southern-alberta-1.4641826?fbclid=IwAR1ebNkeYH3oS7yXMFRCjYhj2JgZXmhzi_KWA1pgyG0_hx5kkdeLuqeiBvs\n\n\nAlberta Health Services [AHS] has confirmed over a dozen new cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, in a number of regions, including Lethbridge, Letbridge County, and Raymond.\n\nOfficials say 15 new cases of the illness have been discovered in the past 2 weeks, bringing the total number of confirmed illnesses to 42 for the whole year [2019]. There is a particular concern about the newest cases, AHS told the media on Wednesday [16 Oct 2019].\n\n\"They are locally acquired,\" said Dr. Vivien Suttorp, Medical Officer of Health, South Zone, \"Whooping cough, as I mentioned before, is underreported. There's a spectrum of illness. Little kiddies and infants have the most severe disease, and adults might just have a milder cough or chronic cough, but they are infectious to others.\"\n\nAs a result, special restrictions are in place for visitors to the neonatal intensive care unit at the Chinook Regional Hospital as well as the labour and delivery, pediatrics, and maternity units. Under these rules, those under the age of 16 will not be permitted, and there will be only 2 visitors per patient allowed. Anyone with symptoms such as a cough or runny nose are reminded not to visit.\n\nAccording to AHS, an outbreak is called when 2 or more cases of illness are identified that have a common epidemiological link, such as same location, unit, floor, caregiver or transmission within the unit of the facility.\n\nThere were 58 cases of pertussis in the South Zone last year [2018].\n\n[Byline: Michael Franklin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lethbridge is the 3rd largest city in the province of Alberta, Canada, southeast of Calgary. Alberta is divided into 5 health zones; a map showing the location of these zones can be found at https://www.albertahealthservices.ca/ahs-map-ahs-zones.pdf. The cities of Lethbridge and Raymond are located in the South Zone. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nCanada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12]\nSee Also\nPertussis update (09): Americas (USA) 20190918.6677444\nPertussis update (08): Americas, Europe, Australia, corr. 20190725.6586026\nPertussis update (08): "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6677444", "date": "2019-04-03 17:29:40", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (03): AUSTRALIA (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Apr 2019\nSource: Camden Haven Courier [edited]\nhttps://www.camdencourier.com.au/story/5984322/health-warning-after-whooping-cough-outbreak/\n\n\nThe Port Macquarie-Hastings local government area has recorded a staggering 11 cases of whooping cough over the past 4 weeks. That is just under half the 23 cases for the Mid North Coast.\n\nThe Mid North Coast local health district has issued an urgent warning for all pregnant women and parents to be aware of the symptoms of whooping cough and to ensure they and their children are vaccinated on time. Children with symptoms should see a doctor. If a doctor diagnoses whooping cough in a school-aged child, parents should let their school know and keep their child at home until they have taken 5 days of antimicrobials.\n\n\"Keep coughing children away from babies. Whooping cough vaccines give good protection against infection, but immunity fades. If your school-aged child has younger siblings, it's a good idea to check they are up-to-date with their vaccines,\" said Greg Bell, acting director, North Coast Public Health Unit. Public health units can provide advice to schools managing whooping cough outbreaks.\n\nSymptoms can start like a cold, followed by a worsening cough that occurs in bouts; this may be followed by vomiting or \"whooping\" breaths. The cough can last for many weeks and can be worse at night. Some newborns may not cough at all but may stop breathing or have difficulties feeding. Small babies can get very sick and may need treatment in a hospital.\n\n[Byline: Letitia Fitzpatrick]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in pertussis cases in many areas around the world is no doubt multifactorial, relating to the up-and-down nature of pertussis over the years, the waning immunity of the currently used acellular vaccine, the selection of _Bordetella pertussis_ strains less protected by the current vaccine, and the presence of non-vaccinated children. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNew South Wales, Australia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284]\nSee Also\nPertussis update (02): Liberia, USA, Canada, Australia, fatal 20190305.6349721\nPertussis update: USA, Panama, fatal {"archive_id": "6586026", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (08): Americas, Europe, Australia, corr.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6586026", "date": "2019-04-03 17:29:40", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (03): AUSTRALIA (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Apr 2019\nSource: Camden Haven Courier [edited]\nhttps://www.camdencourier.com.au/story/5984322/health-warning-after-whooping-cough-outbreak/\n\n\nThe Port Macquarie-Hastings local government area has recorded a staggering 11 cases of whooping cough over the past 4 weeks. That is just under half the 23 cases for the Mid North Coast.\n\nThe Mid North Coast local health district has issued an urgent warning for all pregnant women and parents to be aware of the symptoms of whooping cough and to ensure they and their children are vaccinated on time. Children with symptoms should see a doctor. If a doctor diagnoses whooping cough in a school-aged child, parents should let their school know and keep their child at home until they have taken 5 days of antimicrobials.\n\n\"Keep coughing children away from babies. Whooping cough vaccines give good protection against infection, but immunity fades. If your school-aged child has younger siblings, it's a good idea to check they are up-to-date with their vaccines,\" said Greg Bell, acting director, North Coast Public Health Unit. Public health units can provide advice to schools managing whooping cough outbreaks.\n\nSymptoms can start like a cold, followed by a worsening cough that occurs in bouts; this may be followed by vomiting or \"whooping\" breaths. The cough can last for many weeks and can be worse at night. Some newborns may not cough at all but may stop breathing or have difficulties feeding. Small babies can get very sick and may need treatment in a hospital.\n\n[Byline: Letitia Fitzpatrick]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in pertussis cases in many areas around the world is no doubt multifactorial, relating to the up-and-down nature of pertussis over the years, the waning immunity of the currently used acellular vaccine, the selection of _Bordetella pertussis_ strains less protected by the current vaccine, and the presence of non-vaccinated children. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNew South Wales, Australia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284]\nSee Also\nPertussis update (02): Liberia, USA, Canada, Australia, fatal 20190305.6349721\nPertussis update: USA, Panama, fatal {"archive_id": "6584396", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (08): Americas, Europe, Australia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6584396", "date": "2019-04-03 17:29:40", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (03): AUSTRALIA (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Apr 2019\nSource: Camden Haven Courier [edited]\nhttps://www.camdencourier.com.au/story/5984322/health-warning-after-whooping-cough-outbreak/\n\n\nThe Port Macquarie-Hastings local government area has recorded a staggering 11 cases of whooping cough over the past 4 weeks. That is just under half the 23 cases for the Mid North Coast.\n\nThe Mid North Coast local health district has issued an urgent warning for all pregnant women and parents to be aware of the symptoms of whooping cough and to ensure they and their children are vaccinated on time. Children with symptoms should see a doctor. If a doctor diagnoses whooping cough in a school-aged child, parents should let their school know and keep their child at home until they have taken 5 days of antimicrobials.\n\n\"Keep coughing children away from babies. Whooping cough vaccines give good protection against infection, but immunity fades. If your school-aged child has younger siblings, it's a good idea to check they are up-to-date with their vaccines,\" said Greg Bell, acting director, North Coast Public Health Unit. Public health units can provide advice to schools managing whooping cough outbreaks.\n\nSymptoms can start like a cold, followed by a worsening cough that occurs in bouts; this may be followed by vomiting or \"whooping\" breaths. The cough can last for many weeks and can be worse at night. Some newborns may not cough at all but may stop breathing or have difficulties feeding. Small babies can get very sick and may need treatment in a hospital.\n\n[Byline: Letitia Fitzpatrick]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in pertussis cases in many areas around the world is no doubt multifactorial, relating to the up-and-down nature of pertussis over the years, the waning immunity of the currently used acellular vaccine, the selection of _Bordetella pertussis_ strains less protected by the current vaccine, and the presence of non-vaccinated children. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNew South Wales, Australia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284]\nSee Also\nPertussis update (02): Liberia, USA, Canada, Australia, fatal 20190305.6349721\nPertussis update: USA, Panama, fatal {"archive_id": "6520307", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (07): Europe, Americas", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6520307", "date": "2019-04-03 17:29:40", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (03): AUSTRALIA (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Apr 2019\nSource: Camden Haven Courier [edited]\nhttps://www.camdencourier.com.au/story/5984322/health-warning-after-whooping-cough-outbreak/\n\n\nThe Port Macquarie-Hastings local government area has recorded a staggering 11 cases of whooping cough over the past 4 weeks. That is just under half the 23 cases for the Mid North Coast.\n\nThe Mid North Coast local health district has issued an urgent warning for all pregnant women and parents to be aware of the symptoms of whooping cough and to ensure they and their children are vaccinated on time. Children with symptoms should see a doctor. If a doctor diagnoses whooping cough in a school-aged child, parents should let their school know and keep their child at home until they have taken 5 days of antimicrobials.\n\n\"Keep coughing children away from babies. Whooping cough vaccines give good protection against infection, but immunity fades. If your school-aged child has younger siblings, it's a good idea to check they are up-to-date with their vaccines,\" said Greg Bell, acting director, North Coast Public Health Unit. Public health units can provide advice to schools managing whooping cough outbreaks.\n\nSymptoms can start like a cold, followed by a worsening cough that occurs in bouts; this may be followed by vomiting or \"whooping\" breaths. The cough can last for many weeks and can be worse at night. Some newborns may not cough at all but may stop breathing or have difficulties feeding. Small babies can get very sick and may need treatment in a hospital.\n\n[Byline: Letitia Fitzpatrick]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in pertussis cases in many areas around the world is no doubt multifactorial, relating to the up-and-down nature of pertussis over the years, the waning immunity of the currently used acellular vaccine, the selection of _Bordetella pertussis_ strains less protected by the current vaccine, and the presence of non-vaccinated children. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNew South Wales, Australia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284]\nSee Also\nPertussis update (02): Liberia, USA, Canada, Australia, fatal 20190305.6349721\nPertussis update: USA, Panama, fatal "PERTUSSIS UPDATE (03): AUSTRALIA (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Apr 2019\nSource: Camden Haven Courier [edited]\nhttps://www.camdencourier.com.au/story/5984322/health-warning-after-whooping-cough-outbreak/\n\n\nThe Port Macquarie-Hastings local government area has recorded a staggering 11 cases of whooping cough over the past 4 weeks. That is just under half the 23 cases for the Mid North Coast.\n\nThe Mid North Coast local health district has issued an urgent warning for all pregnant women and parents to be aware of the symptoms of whooping cough and to ensure they and their children are vaccinated on time. Children with symptoms should see a doctor. If a doctor diagnoses whooping cough in a school-aged child, parents should let their school know and keep their child at home until they have taken 5 days of antimicrobials.\n\n\"Keep coughing children away from babies. Whooping cough vaccines give good protection against infection, but immunity fades. If your school-aged child has younger siblings, it's a good idea to check they are up-to-date with their vaccines,\" said Greg Bell, acting director, North Coast Public Health Unit. Public health units can provide advice to schools managing whooping cough outbreaks.\n\nSymptoms can start like a cold, followed by a worsening cough that occurs in bouts; this may be followed by vomiting or \"whooping\" breaths. The cough can last for many weeks and can be worse at night. Some newborns may not cough at all but may stop breathing or have difficulties feeding. Small babies can get very sick and may need treatment in a hospital.\n\n[Byline: Letitia Fitzpatrick]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in pertussis cases in many areas around the world is no doubt multifactorial, relating to the up-and-down nature of pertussis over the years, the waning immunity of the currently used acellular vaccine, the selection of _Bordetella pertussis_ strains less protected by the current vaccine, and the presence of non-vaccinated children. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNew South
