{"archive_id": "6349721", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (02): Liberia, USA, Canada, Australia, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6349721", "date": "2018-05-09 16:25:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (06): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\n[2] Oregon\n[3] North Carolina\n[4] New Mexico\n[5] Wisconsin\n[6] South Carolina\n\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018, 8:42 PM PDT\nSource: KTVZ [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvz.com/news/redmond-whooping-cough-cases-prompt-letters-to-parents/734169668\n\n\nFour Redmond School District (RSD) students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, also known as pertussis, prompting letters to parents from district schools, advising of possible exposure and symptoms to watch for.\n\nSchool district spokesman Rainier Butler said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that Deschutes County Public Health had advised of the cases and \"recommended with notify all RSD families about possible exposure, symptoms and prevention.\"\n\nFamily Choice Urgent Care physician Dr. Terri Mucha said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that for the most part, immunizations have gotten rid of the disease. \"Whooping cough is caused by the pertussis bacteria, so antibiotics do treat it. It can be serious in the young kids or the elderly,\" Mucha said. \"It is something that is part of our childhood immunization, so it is something we have successfully eradicated for a while now.\"\n\n[Byline: Lauren Melink]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Deschutes County, with a population of 157 733 residents in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Bend (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deschutes_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Deschutes County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Deschutes+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n\n******\n[2] Oregon\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: KLCC [edited]\nhttp://klcc.org/post/public-health-officials-warn-whooping-cough-outbreak-eugene\n\n\nLane County Public Health has confirmed 10 cases of whooping cough, or pertussis, at Sheldon High School in Eugene [Oregon].\n\nDr. Patrick Luedtke with Lane County Public Health says pertussis can spread quickly among those who are not vaccinated. Luedtke: \"We are not the best vaccinated state and Lane County is not the best vaccinated of Oregon's 36 counties, so we are clearly at risk. So this is a preventive measure to say, it's out there, go get protected, and practice respiratory etiquette.\"\n\n[Byline: Rachael McDonald]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lane County, with a population of 351 715 residents in 2010, is located on the Pacific coast of the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Eugene (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Lane County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Lane+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] North Carolina\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018, 10:54 AM\nSource: WITN [edited]\nhttp://www.witn.com/content/news/Ten-confirmed-cases-in-Carteret-County-whooping-cough-outbreak-480817891.html?ref=891\n\n\nHealth officials in one Eastern Carolina county are warning parents to be on the lookout for whooping cough.\n\nThe Carteret County Health Department says so far there have been 10 confirmed cases of the highly contagious respiratory disease. The health department says the victims in the outbreak are between the ages of 9 and 14 years old and they continue to see an increase of cases in school age children.\n\nState health officials say for the first 3 months of the year, there were 79 whooping cough cases statewide. Their figures showed Carteret County for 3 cases each in January and February [2018], while Craven County has 3 cases in February [2018].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Carteret County, with a population of 66 469 residents in 2010, is located on the Atlantic coast of the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is Beaufort (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carteret_County,_North_Carolina). An adjacent county, north of Carteret County, Craven County, with a population of 103 505 residents in 2010, is also located in the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is New Bern (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craven_County,_North_Carolina). A map of North Carolina counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New Mexico\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/pertussis-outbreak-reported-mckinley-county-new-mexico-79087/\n\n\nNew Mexico health officials are reporting a pertussis, or whooping cough outbreak in McKinley County in northwest New Mexico. As of [Wed 25 Apr 2018], there are 17 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough and an additional 43 probable cases.\n\nWhen the New Mexico Department of Health first announced this outbreak on [14 Mar 2018], there were 8 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough, with 15 probable cases. These cases continue to be primarily occurring in school-aged children and their close household contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[McKinley County, with a population of 71 492 residents, is located in the northwestern section of the U.S. state of New Mexico; its county seat is Gallup (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McKinley_County,_New_Mexico). A map of New Mexico showing the location of McKinley County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/McKinley+County,+NM. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Wisconsin\nDate: Fri 4 May 2018\nSource: Burnett County Sentinel [edited]\nhttp://www.burnettcountysentinel.com/news/siren-school-alerted-of-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-polk-county/article_67b3bd32-4e3a-11e8-9f50-33c94e316a11.html\n\n\nLast week Burnett County Health Department sent a letter to Siren School about a pertussis outbreak in Polk County. \"Polk County Health Department is actively investigating an outbreak of pertussis that started with the first reported case on [28 Mar 2018],\" said Anna Treague, nurse for Public Health in the letter. \"There are currently 12 lab-confirmed or epi-linked cases in this outbreak. All of the cases are high school students in the St. Croix Falls school district in Polk County. All have been fully immunized with pertussis containing vaccines.\"\n\nSiren School nurse Karen Vanek, said on [Tue 1 May 2018] that there were still no cases of pertussis in Siren School [Burnett County].\n\n\"Polk County is working closely with the school district in an effort to distribute information to parents and to assist in isolating symptomatic students who may need testing or who are awaiting test results,\" Treague said. \"Some close contacts may attend other schools in Polk County or neighboring counties. We will be notified if we have contacts or suspect cases in our county.\"\n\nThe best way to prevent whooping cough is to get vaccinated for it. Children need 5 doses of DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis) vaccine. The series of shots is given at ages 2, 4, 6 and 15 months with a booster between the ages of 4 and 6. Teenagers should get the Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) vaccine around age 11 or 12. Pregnant women are advised to get one Tdap dose during [each of their pregnancies] and other adults should also get the vaccine once in their life.\n\nThe Bureau of Communicable Diseases also suggests keeping babies and other high-risk people away from people who are sick.\n\nPeople with questions can contact Burnett County Public Health at 715-349-7600.\n\n[Byline: Jonathan Richie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Polk County, with a population of 44 205 in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Wisconsin; its county seat is Balsam Lake. Burnett County is an adjacent county north of Polk County and St. Croix County is an adjacent county to the south of Polk County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polk_County,_Wisconsin). Burnett County's seat is the city of Siren (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burnett_County,_Wisconsin). A map of Wisconsin showing its counties can be found at https://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] South Carolina\nDate: Tue 8 May 2008, 11:15 AM EDT\nSource: Fox Carolina [edited]\nhttp://www.foxcarolina.com/story/38139185/four-students-at-2-schools-sickened-with-whooping-cough-in-spartanburg-county\n\n\nA spokesperson for Spartanburg District Five Schools said a total of 4 students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, although the Department of Health and Environmental Control said only 3 cases had been confirmed.\n\nMelissa Robinette said the ill students attend Abner Creek Elementary and Beech Springs Intermediate School. Robinette said DHEC sent a letter to parents on [Mon 7 May 2018] warning them about signs of whooping cough and what to look for.\n\nStudents are required to have the vaccine, called the Tdap vaccine, before beginning school in South Carolina and must have a booster shot before entering the seventh grade, Robinette said. \"However, South Carolina is one of many states that allows exemptions to vaccinations for religious reasons,\" Robinette stated.\n\n[Byline: Dal Kalsi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The city of Spartanburg, with a population of 37 013 residents in 2010, is the most populous city in and the seat of Spartanburg County, South Carolina, United States,[3] and the 12th-largest city by population in the state (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spartanburg,_South_Carolina). A map showing the location of Spartanburg can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Spartanburg,+SC. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\nDate: Tue 8 May 2018, 9:51PM\nSource: The South Western Times [edited]\nhttps://thewest.com.au/news/south-western-times/big-spike-in-whooping-cough-brings-warning-ng-b88828007z\n\n\nBunbury parents are being urged to check their children for signs of whooping cough after a surge of reports of the disease in the city.\n\nWA Country Health Service South West acting director of population health Sharlene Abbott said a total of 75 cases of whooping cough had been reported to the South West Population Health Unit as of [1 May 2018], compared to 28 cases at the same time last year [2017].\n\n\"Cases have been reported predominantly in the Greater Bunbury area, but also from other South West towns,\" she said.\n\n\"Whooping cough is a cyclical disease, with epidemics occurring every 3 to 4 years, even in highly immunised populations. The last epidemic in the South West was in 2015 when there were over 400 reported cases.\"\n\n[Byline: Michael Philipps]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Western Australia (WA) is Australia's largest state, which occupies the entire western 3rd of Australia. The state has about 2.6 million residents - around 11 percent of the national total; 92 percent of residents live in the southwest corner, 73 percent of the population living in the area of the state capital, Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Australia).\n\nBunbury, with a population of 75 628 residents in 2015, is a coastal city in Western Australia, approximately 175 km (109 mi) south of Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bunbury,_Western_Australia). Greater Bunbury includes 4 local government areas (the City of Bunbury and the shires of Capel, Dardanup, and Harvey). - Mod.ML]\n\n[HeathMaps:\nUnited States: Carolina\n[4] New Mexico\n[5] Wisconsin\n[6] South Carolina\n\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018, 8:42 PM PDT\nSource: KTVZ as pertussis, prompting letters to parents from district schools, advising of possible exposure and symptoms to watch for.\n\nSchool district spokesman Rainier Butler said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that Deschutes County Public Health had advised of the cases and \"recommended with notify all RSD families about possible exposure, symptoms and prevention.\"\n\nFamily Choice Urgent Care physician Dr. Terri Mucha said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that for the most part, immunizations have gotten rid of the disease. \"Whooping cough is caused by the pertussis bacteria, so antibiotics do treat it. It can be serious in the young kids or the elderly,\" Mucha said. \"It is something that is part of our childhood immunization, so it is something we have successfully eradicated for a while now.\"\n\n[Byline: Lauren Melink]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Deschutes County, with a population of 157 733 residents in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Bend (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deschutes_County,_Oregon). Luedtke: \"We are not the best vaccinated state and Lane County is not the best vaccinated of Oregon's 36 counties, so we are clearly at risk. So this is a preventive measure to say, it's out there, go get protected, and practice respiratory etiquette.\"\n\n[Byline: Rachael McDonald]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lane County, with a population of 351 715 residents in 2010, is located on the Pacific coast of the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Eugene (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_County,_Oregon). The health department says the victims in the outbreak are between the ages of 9 and 14 years old and they continue to see an increase of cases in school age children.\n\nState health officials say for the first 3 months of the year, there were 79 whooping cough cases statewide. Their figures showed Carteret County for 3 cases each in January and February [2018], while Craven County has 3 cases in February [2018].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Carteret County, with a population of 66 469 residents in 2010, is located on the Atlantic coast of the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is Beaufort (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carteret_County,_North_Carolina). A map of North Carolina counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New Mexico\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/pertussis-outbreak-reported-mckinley-county-new-mexico-79087/\n\n\nNew Mexico health officials are reporting a pertussis, or whooping cough outbreak in McKinley County in northwest New Mexico. As of [Wed 25 Apr 2018], there are 17 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough and an additional 43 probable cases.\n\nWhen the New Mexico Department of Health first announced this outbreak on [14 Mar 2018], there were 8 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough, with 15 probable cases. These cases continue to be primarily occurring in school-aged children and their close household contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[McKinley County, with a population of 71 492 residents, is located in the northwestern section of the U.S. state of New Mexico; its county seat is Gallup (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McKinley_County,_New_Mexico). A map of New Mexico showing the location of McKinley County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/McKinley+County,+NM. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Wisconsin\nDate: Fri 4 May 2018\nSource: Burnett County Sentinel [edited]\nhttp://www.burnettcountysentinel.com/news/siren-school-alerted-of-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-polk-county/article_67b3bd32-4e3a-11e8-9f50-33c94e316a11.html\n\n\nLast week Burnett County Health Department sent a letter to Siren School about a pertussis outbreak in Polk County. \"Polk County Health Department is actively investigating an outbreak of pertussis that started with the first reported case on [28 Mar 2018],\" said Anna Treague, nurse for Public Health in the letter. \"There are currently 12 lab-confirmed or epi-linked cases in this outbreak. All of the cases are high school students in the St. Croix Falls school district in Polk County. All have been fully immunized with pertussis containing vaccines.\"\n\nSiren School nurse Karen Vanek, said on [Tue 1 May 2018] that there were still no cases of pertussis in Siren School [Burnett County].\n\n\"Polk County is working closely with the school district in an effort to distribute information to parents and to assist in isolating symptomatic students who may need testing or who are awaiting test results,\" Treague said. \"Some close contacts may attend other schools in Polk County or neighboring counties. We will be notified if we have contacts or suspect cases in our county.\"\n\nThe best way to prevent whooping cough is to get vaccinated for it. Children need 5 doses of DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis) vaccine. The series of shots is given at ages 2, 4, 6 and 15 months with a booster between the ages of 4 and 6. Teenagers should get the Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) vaccine around age 11 or 12. Pregnant women are advised to get one Tdap dose during [each of their pregnancies] and other adults should also get the vaccine once in their life.\n\nThe Bureau of Communicable Diseases also suggests keeping babies and other high-risk people away from people who are sick.\n\nPeople with questions can contact Burnett County Public Health at 715-349-7600.\n\n[Byline: Jonathan Richie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Polk County, with a population of 44 205 in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Wisconsin; its county seat is Balsam Lake. Burnett County is an adjacent county north of Polk County and St. Croix County is an adjacent county to the south of Polk County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polk_County,_Wisconsin). Burnett County's seat is the city of Siren (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burnett_County,_Wisconsin). A map of Wisconsin showing its counties can be found at https://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] South Carolina\nDate: Tue 8 May 2008, 11:15 AM EDT\nSource: Fox Carolina [edited]\nhttp://www.foxcarolina.com/story/38139185/four-students-at-2-schools-sickened-with-whooping-cough-in-spartanburg-county\n\n\nA spokesperson for Spartanburg District Five Schools said a total of 4 students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, although the Department of Health and Environmental Control said only 3 cases had been confirmed.\n\nMelissa Robinette said the ill students attend Abner Creek Elementary and Beech Springs Intermediate School. Robinette said DHEC sent a letter to parents on [Mon 7 May 2018] warning them about signs of whooping cough and what to look for.\n\nStudents are required to have the vaccine, called the Tdap vaccine, before beginning school in South Carolina and must have a booster shot before entering the seventh grade, Robinette said. \"However, South Carolina is one of many states that allows exemptions to vaccinations for religious reasons,\" Robinette stated.\n\n[Byline: Dal Kalsi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The city of Spartanburg, with a population of 37 013 residents in 2010, is the most populous city in and the seat of Spartanburg County, South Carolina, United States,[3] and the 12th-largest city by population in the state (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spartanburg,_South_Carolina). A map showing the location of Spartanburg can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Spartanburg,+SC. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\nDate: Tue 8 May 2018, 9:51PM\nSource: The South Western Times [edited]\nhttps://thewest.com.au/news/south-western-times/big-spike-in-whooping-cough-brings-warning-ng-b88828007z\n\n\nBunbury parents are being urged to check their children for signs of whooping cough after a surge of reports of the disease in the city.\n\nWA Country Health Service South West acting director of population health Sharlene Abbott said a total of 75 cases of whooping cough had been reported to the South West Population Health Unit as of [1 May 2018], compared to 28 cases at the same time last year [2017].\n\n\"Cases have been reported predominantly in the Greater Bunbury area, but also from other South West towns,\" she said.\n\n\"Whooping cough is a cyclical disease, with epidemics occurring every 3 to 4 years, even in highly immunised populations. The last epidemic in the South West was in 2015 when there were over 400 reported cases.\"\n\n[Byline: Michael Philipps]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Western Australia (WA) is Australia's largest state, which occupies the entire western 3rd of Australia. The state has about 2.6 million residents - around 11 percent of the national total; 92 percent of residents live in the southwest corner, 73 percent of the population living in the area of the state capital, Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Australia).\n\nBunbury, with a population of 75 628 residents in 2015, is a coastal city in Western Australia, approximately 175 km (109 mi) south of Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bunbury,_Western_Australia). Greater Bunbury includes 4 local government areas (the City of Bunbury and the shires of Capel, Dardanup, and Harvey). - Mod.ML]\n\n[HeathMaps:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186]\nSee Also\nPertussis (05): USA, China 20180408.5732702\nPertussis (04): USA, Armenia, Australia, New Zealand "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6226635", "date": "2018-05-09 16:25:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (06): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\n[2] Oregon\n[3] North Carolina\n[4] New Mexico\n[5] Wisconsin\n[6] South Carolina\n\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018, 8:42 PM PDT\nSource: KTVZ [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvz.com/news/redmond-whooping-cough-cases-prompt-letters-to-parents/734169668\n\n\nFour Redmond School District (RSD) students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, also known as pertussis, prompting letters to parents from district schools, advising of possible exposure and symptoms to watch for.\n\nSchool district spokesman Rainier Butler said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that Deschutes County Public Health had advised of the cases and \"recommended with notify all RSD families about possible exposure, symptoms and prevention.\"\n\nFamily Choice Urgent Care physician Dr. Terri Mucha said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that for the most part, immunizations have gotten rid of the disease. \"Whooping cough is caused by the pertussis bacteria, so antibiotics do treat it. It can be serious in the young kids or the elderly,\" Mucha said. \"It is something that is part of our childhood immunization, so it is something we have successfully eradicated for a while now.\"\n\n[Byline: Lauren Melink]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Deschutes County, with a population of 157 733 residents in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Bend (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deschutes_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Deschutes County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Deschutes+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n\n******\n[2] Oregon\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: KLCC [edited]\nhttp://klcc.org/post/public-health-officials-warn-whooping-cough-outbreak-eugene\n\n\nLane County Public Health has confirmed 10 cases of whooping cough, or pertussis, at Sheldon High School in Eugene [Oregon].\n\nDr. Patrick Luedtke with Lane County Public Health says pertussis can spread quickly among those who are not vaccinated. Luedtke: \"We are not the best vaccinated state and Lane County is not the best vaccinated of Oregon's 36 counties, so we are clearly at risk. So this is a preventive measure to say, it's out there, go get protected, and practice respiratory etiquette.\"\n\n[Byline: Rachael McDonald]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lane County, with a population of 351 715 residents in 2010, is located on the Pacific coast of the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Eugene (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Lane County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Lane+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] North Carolina\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018, 10:54 AM\nSource: WITN [edited]\nhttp://www.witn.com/content/news/Ten-confirmed-cases-in-Carteret-County-whooping-cough-outbreak-480817891.html?ref=891\n\n\nHealth officials in one Eastern Carolina county are warning parents to be on the lookout for whooping cough.\n\nThe Carteret County Health Department says so far there have been 10 confirmed cases of the highly contagious respiratory disease. The health department says the victims in the outbreak are between the ages of 9 and 14 years old and they continue to see an increase of cases in school age children.\n\nState health officials say for the first 3 months of the year, there were 79 whooping cough cases statewide. Their figures showed Carteret County for 3 cases each in January and February [2018], while Craven County has 3 cases in February [2018].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Carteret County, with a population of 66 469 residents in 2010, is located on the Atlantic coast of the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is Beaufort (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carteret_County,_North_Carolina). An adjacent county, north of Carteret County, Craven County, with a population of 103 505 residents in 2010, is also located in the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is New Bern (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craven_County,_North_Carolina). A map of North Carolina counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New Mexico\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/pertussis-outbreak-reported-mckinley-county-new-mexico-79087/\n\n\nNew Mexico health officials are reporting a pertussis, or whooping cough outbreak in McKinley County in northwest New Mexico. As of [Wed 25 Apr 2018], there are 17 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough and an additional 43 probable cases.\n\nWhen the New Mexico Department of Health first announced this outbreak on [14 Mar 2018], there were 8 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough, with 15 probable cases. These cases continue to be primarily occurring in school-aged children and their close household contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[McKinley County, with a population of 71 492 residents, is located in the northwestern section of the U.S. state of New Mexico; its county seat is Gallup (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McKinley_County,_New_Mexico). A map of New Mexico showing the location of McKinley County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/McKinley+County,+NM. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Wisconsin\nDate: Fri 4 May 2018\nSource: Burnett County Sentinel [edited]\nhttp://www.burnettcountysentinel.com/news/siren-school-alerted-of-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-polk-county/article_67b3bd32-4e3a-11e8-9f50-33c94e316a11.html\n\n\nLast week Burnett County Health Department sent a letter to Siren School about a pertussis outbreak in Polk County. \"Polk County Health Department is actively investigating an outbreak of pertussis that started with the first reported case on [28 Mar 2018],\" said Anna Treague, nurse for Public Health in the letter. \"There are currently 12 lab-confirmed or epi-linked cases in this outbreak. All of the cases are high school students in the St. Croix Falls school district in Polk County. All have been fully immunized with pertussis containing vaccines.\"\n\nSiren School nurse Karen Vanek, said on [Tue 1 May 2018] that there were still no cases of pertussis in Siren School [Burnett County].\n\n\"Polk County is working closely with the school district in an effort to distribute information to parents and to assist in isolating symptomatic students who may need testing or who are awaiting test results,\" Treague said. \"Some close contacts may attend other schools in Polk County or neighboring counties. We will be notified if we have contacts or suspect cases in our county.\"\n\nThe best way to prevent whooping cough is to get vaccinated for it. Children need 5 doses of DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis) vaccine. The series of shots is given at ages 2, 4, 6 and 15 months with a booster between the ages of 4 and 6. Teenagers should get the Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) vaccine around age 11 or 12. Pregnant women are advised to get one Tdap dose during [each of their pregnancies] and other adults should also get the vaccine once in their life.\n\nThe Bureau of Communicable Diseases also suggests keeping babies and other high-risk people away from people who are sick.\n\nPeople with questions can contact Burnett County Public Health at 715-349-7600.\n\n[Byline: Jonathan Richie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Polk County, with a population of 44 205 in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Wisconsin; its county seat is Balsam Lake. Burnett County is an adjacent county north of Polk County and St. Croix County is an adjacent county to the south of Polk County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polk_County,_Wisconsin). Burnett County's seat is the city of Siren (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burnett_County,_Wisconsin). A map of Wisconsin showing its counties can be found at https://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] South Carolina\nDate: Tue 8 May 2008, 11:15 AM EDT\nSource: Fox Carolina [edited]\nhttp://www.foxcarolina.com/story/38139185/four-students-at-2-schools-sickened-with-whooping-cough-in-spartanburg-county\n\n\nA spokesperson for Spartanburg District Five Schools said a total of 4 students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, although the Department of Health and Environmental Control said only 3 cases had been confirmed.\n\nMelissa Robinette said the ill students attend Abner Creek Elementary and Beech Springs Intermediate School. Robinette said DHEC sent a letter to parents on [Mon 7 May 2018] warning them about signs of whooping cough and what to look for.\n\nStudents are required to have the vaccine, called the Tdap vaccine, before beginning school in South Carolina and must have a booster shot before entering the seventh grade, Robinette said. \"However, South Carolina is one of many states that allows exemptions to vaccinations for religious reasons,\" Robinette stated.\n\n[Byline: Dal Kalsi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The city of Spartanburg, with a population of 37 013 residents in 2010, is the most populous city in and the seat of Spartanburg County, South Carolina, United States,[3] and the 12th-largest city by population in the state (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spartanburg,_South_Carolina). A map showing the location of Spartanburg can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Spartanburg,+SC. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\nDate: Tue 8 May 2018, 9:51PM\nSource: The South Western Times [edited]\nhttps://thewest.com.au/news/south-western-times/big-spike-in-whooping-cough-brings-warning-ng-b88828007z\n\n\nBunbury parents are being urged to check their children for signs of whooping cough after a surge of reports of the disease in the city.\n\nWA Country Health Service South West acting director of population health Sharlene Abbott said a total of 75 cases of whooping cough had been reported to the South West Population Health Unit as of [1 May 2018], compared to 28 cases at the same time last year [2017].\n\n\"Cases have been reported predominantly in the Greater Bunbury area, but also from other South West towns,\" she said.\n\n\"Whooping cough is a cyclical disease, with epidemics occurring every 3 to 4 years, even in highly immunised populations. post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\n[2] Oregon\n[3] North Carolina\n[4] New Mexico\n[5] Wisconsin\n[6] South Carolina\n\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018, 8:42 PM PDT\nSource: KTVZ [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvz.com/news/redmond-whooping-cough-cases-prompt-letters-to-parents/734169668\n\n\nFour Redmond School District (RSD) students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, also known as pertussis, prompting letters to parents from district schools, advising of possible exposure and symptoms to watch for.\n\nSchool district spokesman Rainier Butler said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that Deschutes County Public Health had advised of the cases and \"recommended with notify all RSD families about possible exposure, symptoms and prevention.\"\n\nFamily Choice Urgent Care physician Dr. Terri Mucha said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that for the most part, immunizations have gotten rid of the disease. \"Whooping cough is caused by the pertussis bacteria, so antibiotics do treat it. It can be serious in the young kids or the elderly,\" Mucha said. \"It is something that is part of our childhood immunization, so it is something we have successfully eradicated for a while now.\"\n\n[Byline: Lauren Melink]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Deschutes County, with a population of 157 733 residents in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Bend (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deschutes_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Deschutes County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Deschutes+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n\n******\n[2] Oregon\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: KLCC [edited]\nhttp://klcc.org/post/public-health-officials-warn-whooping-cough-outbreak-eugene\n\n\nLane County Public Health has confirmed 10 cases of whooping cough, or pertussis, at Sheldon High School in Eugene [Oregon].\n\nDr. Patrick Luedtke with Lane County Public Health says pertussis can spread quickly among those who are not vaccinated. Luedtke: \"We are not the best vaccinated state and Lane County is not the best vaccinated of Oregon's 36 counties, so we are clearly at risk. So this is a preventive measure to say, it's out there, go get protected, and practice respiratory etiquette.\"\n\n[Byline: Rachael McDonald]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lane County, with a population of 351 715 residents in 2010, is located on the Pacific coast of the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Eugene (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Lane County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Lane+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] North Carolina\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018, 10:54 AM\nSource: WITN [edited]\nhttp://www.witn.com/content/news/Ten-confirmed-cases-in-Carteret-County-whooping-cough-outbreak-480817891.html?ref=891\n\n\nHealth officials in one Eastern Carolina county are warning parents to be on the lookout for whooping cough.\n\nThe Carteret County Health Department says so far there have been 10 confirmed cases of the highly contagious respiratory disease. The health department says the victims in the outbreak are between the ages of 9 and 14 years old and they continue to see an increase of cases in school age children.\n\nState health officials say for the first 3 months of the year, there were 79 whooping cough cases statewide. Their figures showed Carteret County for 3 cases each in January and February [2018], while Craven County has 3 cases in February [2018].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Carteret County, with a population of 66 469 residents in 2010, is located on the Atlantic coast of the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is Beaufort (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carteret_County,_North_Carolina). An adjacent county, north of Carteret County, Craven County, with a population of 103 505 residents in 2010, is also located in the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is New Bern (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craven_County,_North_Carolina). A map of North Carolina counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New Mexico\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/pertussis-outbreak-reported-mckinley-county-new-mexico-79087/\n\n\nNew Mexico health officials are reporting a pertussis, or whooping cough outbreak in McKinley County in northwest New Mexico. As of [Wed 25 Apr 2018], there are 17 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough and an additional 43 probable cases.\n\nWhen the New Mexico Department of Health first announced this outbreak on [14 Mar 2018], there were 8 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough, with 15 probable cases. These cases continue to be primarily occurring in school-aged children and their close household contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[McKinley County, with a population of 71 492 residents, is located in the northwestern section of the U.S. state of New Mexico; its county seat is Gallup (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McKinley_County,_New_Mexico). A map of New Mexico showing the location of McKinley County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/McKinley+County,+NM. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Wisconsin\nDate: Fri 4 May 2018\nSource: Burnett County Sentinel [edited]\nhttp://www.burnettcountysentinel.com/news/siren-school-alerted-of-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-polk-county/article_67b3bd32-4e3a-11e8-9f50-33c94e316a11.html\n\n\nLast week Burnett County Health Department sent a letter to Siren School about a pertussis outbreak in Polk County. \"Polk County Health Department is actively investigating an outbreak of pertussis that started with the first reported case on [28 Mar 2018],\" said Anna Treague, nurse for Public Health in the letter. \"There are currently 12 lab-confirmed or epi-linked cases in this outbreak. All of the cases are high school students in the St. Croix Falls school district in Polk County. All have been fully immunized with pertussis containing vaccines.\"\n\nSiren School nurse Karen Vanek, said on [Tue 1 May 2018] that there were still no cases of pertussis in Siren School [Burnett County].\n\n\"Polk County is working closely with the school district in an effort to distribute information to parents and to assist in isolating symptomatic students who may need testing or who are awaiting test results,\" Treague said. \"Some close contacts may attend other schools in Polk County or neighboring counties. We will be notified if we have contacts or suspect cases in our county.\"\n\nThe best way to prevent whooping cough is to get vaccinated for it. Children need 5 doses of DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis) vaccine. The series of shots is given at ages 2, 4, 6 and 15 months with a booster between the ages of 4 and 6. Teenagers should get the Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) vaccine around age 11 or 12. Pregnant women are advised to get one Tdap dose during [each of their pregnancies] and other adults should also get the vaccine once in their life.\n\nThe Bureau of Communicable Diseases also suggests keeping babies and other high-risk people away from people who are sick.\n\nPeople with questions can contact Burnett County Public Health at 715-349-7600.\n\n[Byline: Jonathan Richie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Polk County, with a population of 44 205 in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Wisconsin; its county seat is Balsam Lake. Burnett County is an adjacent county north of Polk County and St. Croix County is an adjacent county to the south of Polk County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polk_County,_Wisconsin). Burnett County's seat is the city of Siren (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burnett_County,_Wisconsin). A map of Wisconsin showing its counties can be found at https://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] South Carolina\nDate: Tue 8 May 2008, 11:15 AM EDT\nSource: Fox Carolina [edited]\nhttp://www.foxcarolina.com/story/38139185/four-students-at-2-schools-sickened-with-whooping-cough-in-spartanburg-county\n\n\nA spokesperson for Spartanburg District Five Schools said a total of 4 students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, although the Department of Health and Environmental Control said only 3 cases had been confirmed.\n\nMelissa Robinette said the ill students attend Abner Creek Elementary and Beech Springs Intermediate School. Robinette said DHEC sent a letter to parents on [Mon 7 May 2018] warning them about signs of whooping cough and what to look for.\n\nStudents are required to have the vaccine, called the Tdap vaccine, before beginning school in South Carolina and must have a booster shot before entering the seventh grade, Robinette said. \"However, South Carolina is one of many states that allows exemptions to vaccinations for religious reasons,\" Robinette stated.\n\n[Byline: Dal Kalsi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The city of Spartanburg, with a population of 37 013 residents in 2010, is the most populous city in and the seat of Spartanburg County, South Carolina, United States,[3] and the 12th-largest city by population in the state (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spartanburg,_South_Carolina). A map showing the location of Spartanburg can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Spartanburg,+SC. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\nDate: Tue 8 May 2018, 9:51PM\nSource: The South Western Times [edited]\nhttps://thewest.com.au/news/south-western-times/big-spike-in-whooping-cough-brings-warning-ng-b88828007z\n\n\nBunbury parents are being urged to check their children for signs of whooping cough after a surge of reports of the disease in the city.\n\nWA Country Health Service South West acting director of population health Sharlene Abbott said a total of 75 cases of whooping cough had been reported to the South West Population Health Unit as of [1 May 2018], compared to 28 cases at the same time last year [2017].\n\n\"Cases have been reported predominantly in the Greater Bunbury area, but also from other South West towns,\" she said.\n\n\"Whooping cough is a cyclical disease, with epidemics occurring every 3 to 4 years, even in highly immunised populations. The last epidemic in the South West was in 2015 when there were over 400 reported cases.\"\n\n[Byline: Michael Philipps]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Western Australia (WA) is Australia's largest state, which occupies the entire western 3rd of Australia. The state has about 2.6 million residents - around 11 percent of the national total; 92 percent of residents live in the southwest corner, 73 percent of the population living in the area of the state capital, Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Australia).\n\nBunbury, with a population of 75 628 residents in 2015, is a coastal city in Western Australia, approximately 175 km (109 mi) south of Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bunbury,_Western_Australia). Greater Bunbury includes 4 local government areas (the City of Bunbury and the shires of Capel, Dardanup, and Harvey). - Mod.ML]\n\n[HeathMaps:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186]\nSee Also\nPertussis (05): USA, China 20180408.5732702\nPertussis (04): USA, Armenia, Australia, New Zealand ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\n[2] Oregon\n[3] North Carolina\n[4] New Mexico\n[5] Wisconsin\n[6] South Carolina\n\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018, 8:42 PM PDT\nSource: KTVZ [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvz.com/news/redmond-whooping-cough-cases-prompt-letters-to-parents/734169668\n\n\nFour Redmond School District (RSD) students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, also known as pertussis, prompting letters to parents from district schools, advising of possible exposure and symptoms to watch for.\n\nSchool district spokesman Rainier Butler said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that Deschutes County Public Health had advised of the cases and \"recommended with notify all RSD families about possible exposure, symptoms and prevention.\"\n\nFamily Choice Urgent Care physician Dr. Terri Mucha said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that for the most part, immunizations have gotten rid of the disease. \"Whooping cough is caused by the pertussis bacteria, so antibiotics do treat it. It can be serious in the young kids or the elderly,\" Mucha said. \"It is something that is part of our childhood immunization, so it is something we have successfully eradicated for a while now.\"\n\n[Byline: Lauren Melink]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Deschutes County, with a population of 157 733 residents in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Bend (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deschutes_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Deschutes County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Deschutes+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n\n******\n[2] Oregon\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: KLCC [edited]\nhttp://klcc.org/post/public-health-officials-warn-whooping-cough-outbreak-eugene\n\n\nLane County Public Health has confirmed 10 cases of whooping cough, or pertussis, at Sheldon High School in Eugene [Oregon].\n\nDr. Patrick Luedtke with Lane County Public Health says pertussis can spread quickly among those who are not vaccinated. Luedtke: \"We are not the best vaccinated state and Lane County is not the best vaccinated of Oregon's 36 counties, so we are clearly at risk. So this is a preventive measure to say, it's out there, go get protected, and practice respiratory etiquette.\"\n\n[Byline: Rachael McDonald]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lane County, with a population of 351 715 residents in 2010, is located on the Pacific coast of the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Eugene (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Lane County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Lane+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] North Carolina\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018, 10:54 AM\nSource: WITN [edited]\nhttp://www.witn.com/content/news/Ten-confirmed-cases-in-Carteret-County-whooping-cough-outbreak-480817891.html?ref=891\n\n\nHealth officials in one Eastern Carolina county are warning parents to be on the lookout for whooping cough.\n\nThe Carteret County Health Department says so far there have been 10 confirmed cases of the highly contagious respiratory disease. The health department says the victims in the outbreak are between the ages of 9 and 14 years old and they continue to see an increase of cases in school age children.\n\nState health officials say for the first 3 months of the year, there were 79 whooping cough cases statewide. Their figures showed Carteret County for 3 cases each in January and February [2018], while Craven County has 3 cases in February [2018].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Carteret County, with a population of 66 469 residents in 2010, is located on the Atlantic coast of the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is Beaufort (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carteret_County,_North_Carolina). An adjacent county, north of Carteret County, Craven County, with a population of 103 505 residents in 2010, is also located in the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is New Bern (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craven_County,_North_Carolina). A map of North Carolina counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New Mexico\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/pertussis-outbreak-reported-mckinley-county-new-mexico-79087/\n\n\nNew Mexico health officials are reporting a pertussis, or whooping cough outbreak in McKinley County in northwest New Mexico. As of [Wed 25 Apr 2018], there are 17 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough and an additional 43 probable cases.\n\nWhen the New Mexico Department of Health first announced this outbreak on [14 Mar 2018], there were 8 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough, with 15 probable cases. These cases continue to be primarily occurring in school-aged children and their close household contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[McKinley County, with a population of 71 492 residents, is located in the northwestern section of the U.S. state of New Mexico; its county seat is Gallup (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McKinley_County,_New_Mexico). A map of New Mexico showing the location of McKinley County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/McKinley+County,+NM. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Wisconsin\nDate: Fri 4 May 2018\nSource: Burnett County Sentinel [edited]\nhttp://www.burnettcountysentinel.com/news/siren-school-alerted-of-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-polk-county/article_67b3bd32-4e3a-11e8-9f50-33c94e316a11.html\n\n\nLast week Burnett County Health Department sent a letter to Siren School about a pertussis outbreak in Polk County. \"Polk County Health Department is actively investigating an outbreak of pertussis that started with the first reported case on [28 Mar 2018],\" said Anna Treague, nurse for Public Health in the letter. \"There are currently 12 lab-confirmed or epi-linked cases in this outbreak. All of the cases are high school students in the St. Croix Falls school district in Polk County. All have been fully immunized with pertussis containing vaccines.\"\n\nSiren School nurse Karen Vanek, said on [Tue 1 May 2018] that there were still no cases of pertussis in Siren School [Burnett County].\n\n\"Polk County is working closely with the school district in an effort to distribute information to parents and to assist in isolating symptomatic students who may need testing or who are awaiting test results,\" Treague said. \"Some close contacts may attend other schools in Polk County or neighboring counties. We will be notified if we have contacts or suspect cases in our county.\"\n\nThe best way to prevent whooping cough is to get vaccinated for it. Children need 5 doses of DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis) vaccine. The series of shots is given at ages 2, 4, 6 and 15 months with a booster between the ages of 4 and 6. Teenagers should get the Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) vaccine around age 11 or 12. Pregnant women are advised to get one Tdap dose during [each of their pregnancies] and other adults should also get the vaccine once in their life.\n\nThe Bureau of Communicable Diseases also suggests keeping babies and other high-risk people away from people who are sick.\n\nPeople with questions can contact Burnett County Public Health at 715-349-7600.\n\n[Byline: Jonathan Richie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Polk County, with a population of 44 205 in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Wisconsin; its county seat is Balsam Lake. Burnett County is an adjacent county north of Polk County and St. Croix County is an adjacent county to the south of Polk County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polk_County,_Wisconsin). Burnett County's seat is the city of Siren (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burnett_County,_Wisconsin). A map of Wisconsin showing its counties can be found at https://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] South Carolina\nDate: Tue 8 May 2008, 11:15 AM EDT\nSource: Fox Carolina [edited]\nhttp://www.foxcarolina.com/story/38139185/four-students-at-2-schools-sickened-with-whooping-cough-in-spartanburg-county\n\n\nA spokesperson for Spartanburg District Five Schools said a total of 4 students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, although the Department of Health and Environmental Control said only 3 cases had been confirmed.\n\nMelissa Robinette said the ill students attend Abner Creek Elementary and Beech Springs Intermediate School. Robinette said DHEC sent a letter to parents on [Mon 7 May 2018] warning them about signs of whooping cough and what to look for.\n\nStudents are required to have the vaccine, called the Tdap vaccine, before beginning school in South Carolina and must have a booster shot before entering the seventh grade, Robinette said. \"However, South Carolina is one of many states that allows exemptions to vaccinations for religious reasons,\" Robinette stated.\n\n[Byline: Dal Kalsi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The city of Spartanburg, with a population of 37 013 residents in 2010, is the most populous city in and the seat of Spartanburg County, South Carolina, United States,[3] and the 12th-largest city by population in the state (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spartanburg,_South_Carolina). A map showing the location of Spartanburg can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Spartanburg,+SC. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\nDate: Tue 8 May 2018, 9:51PM\nSource: The South Western Times [edited]\nhttps://thewest.com.au/news/south-western-times/big-spike-in-whooping-cough-brings-warning-ng-b88828007z\n\n\nBunbury parents are being urged to check their children for signs of whooping cough after a surge of reports of the disease in the city.\n\nWA Country Health Service South West acting director of population health Sharlene Abbott said a total of 75 cases of whooping cough had been reported to the South West Population Health Unit as of [1 May 2018], compared to 28 cases at the same time last year [2017].\n\n\"Cases have been reported predominantly in the Greater Bunbury area, but also from other South West towns,\" she said.\n\n\"Whooping cough is a cyclical disease, with epidemics occurring every 3 to 4 years, even in highly immunised populations. The last epidemic in the South West was in 2015 when there were over 400 reported cases.\"\n\n[Byline: Michael Philipps]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Western Australia (WA) is Australia's largest state, which occupies the entire western 3rd of Australia. The state has about 2.6 million residents - around 11 percent of the national total; 92 percent of residents live in the southwest corner, 73 percent of the population living in the area of the state capital, Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Australia).\n\nBunbury, with a population of 75 628 residents in 2015, is a coastal city in Western Australia, approximately 175 km (109 mi) south of Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bunbury,_Western_Australia). Greater Bunbury includes 4 local government areas (the City of Bunbury and the shires of Capel, Dardanup, and Harvey). - Mod.ML]\n\n[HeathMaps:\nUnited States: Canada, Dominican Republic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5914353", "date": "2018-05-09 16:25:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (06): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\n[2] Oregon\n[3] North Carolina\n[4] New Mexico\n[5] Wisconsin\n[6] South Carolina\n\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018, 8:42 PM PDT\nSource: KTVZ [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvz.com/news/redmond-whooping-cough-cases-prompt-letters-to-parents/734169668\n\n\nFour Redmond School District (RSD) students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, also known as pertussis, prompting letters to parents from district schools, advising of possible exposure and symptoms to watch for.\n\nSchool district spokesman Rainier Butler said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that Deschutes County Public Health had advised of the cases and \"recommended with notify all RSD families about possible exposure, symptoms and prevention.\"\n\nFamily Choice Urgent Care physician Dr. Terri Mucha said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that for the most part, immunizations have gotten rid of the disease. \"Whooping cough is caused by the pertussis bacteria, so antibiotics do treat it. It can be serious in the young kids or the elderly,\" Mucha said. \"It is something that is part of our childhood immunization, so it is something we have successfully eradicated for a while now.\"\n\n[Byline: Lauren Melink]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Deschutes County, with a population of 157 733 residents in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Bend (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deschutes_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Deschutes County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Deschutes+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n\n******\n[2] Oregon\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: KLCC [edited]\nhttp://klcc.org/post/public-health-officials-warn-whooping-cough-outbreak-eugene\n\n\nLane County Public Health has confirmed 10 cases of whooping cough, or pertussis, at Sheldon High School in Eugene [Oregon].\n\nDr. Patrick Luedtke with Lane County Public Health says pertussis can spread quickly among those who are not vaccinated. Luedtke: \"We are not the best vaccinated state and Lane County is not the best vaccinated of Oregon's 36 counties, so we are clearly at risk. So this is a preventive measure to say, it's out there, go get protected, and practice respiratory etiquette.\"\n\n[Byline: Rachael McDonald]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lane County, with a population of 351 715 residents in 2010, is located on the Pacific coast of the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Eugene (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Lane County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Lane+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] North Carolina\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018, 10:54 AM\nSource: WITN [edited]\nhttp://www.witn.com/content/news/Ten-confirmed-cases-in-Carteret-County-whooping-cough-outbreak-480817891.html?ref=891\n\n\nHealth officials in one Eastern Carolina county are warning parents to be on the lookout for whooping cough.\n\nThe Carteret County Health Department says so far there have been 10 confirmed cases of the highly contagious respiratory disease. The health department says the victims in the outbreak are between the ages of 9 and 14 years old and they continue to see an increase of cases in school age children.\n\nState health officials say for the first 3 months of the year, there were 79 whooping cough cases statewide. Their figures showed Carteret County for 3 cases each in January and February [2018], while Craven County has 3 cases in February [2018].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Carteret County, with a population of 66 469 residents in 2010, is located on the Atlantic coast of the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is Beaufort (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carteret_County,_North_Carolina). An adjacent county, north of Carteret County, Craven County, with a population of 103 505 residents in 2010, is also located in the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is New Bern (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craven_County,_North_Carolina). A map of North Carolina counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New Mexico\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/pertussis-outbreak-reported-mckinley-county-new-mexico-79087/\n\n\nNew Mexico health officials are reporting a pertussis, or whooping cough outbreak in McKinley County in northwest New Mexico. As of [Wed 25 Apr 2018], there are 17 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough and an additional 43 probable cases.\n\nWhen the New Mexico Department of Health first announced this outbreak on [14 Mar 2018], there were 8 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough, with 15 probable cases. These cases continue to be primarily occurring in school-aged children and their close household contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[McKinley County, with a population of 71 492 residents, is located in the northwestern section of the U.S. state of New Mexico; its county seat is Gallup (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McKinley_County,_New_Mexico). A map of New Mexico showing the location of McKinley County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/McKinley+County,+NM. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Wisconsin\nDate: Fri 4 May 2018\nSource: Burnett County Sentinel [edited]\nhttp://www.burnettcountysentinel.com/news/siren-school-alerted-of-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-polk-county/article_67b3bd32-4e3a-11e8-9f50-33c94e316a11.html\n\n\nLast week Burnett County Health Department sent a letter to Siren School about a pertussis outbreak in Polk County. \"Polk County Health Department is actively investigating an outbreak of pertussis that started with the first reported case on [28 Mar 2018],\" said Anna Treague, nurse for Public Health in the letter. \"There are currently 12 lab-confirmed or epi-linked cases in this outbreak. All of the cases are high school students in the St. Croix Falls school district in Polk County. All have been fully immunized with pertussis containing vaccines.\"\n\nSiren School nurse Karen Vanek, said on [Tue 1 May 2018] that there were still no cases of pertussis in Siren School [Burnett County].\n\n\"Polk County is working closely with the school district in an effort to distribute information to parents and to assist in isolating symptomatic students who may need testing or who are awaiting test results,\" Treague said. \"Some close contacts may attend other schools in Polk County or neighboring counties. We will be notified if we have contacts or suspect cases in our county.\"\n\nThe best way to prevent whooping cough is to get vaccinated for it. Children need 5 doses of DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis) vaccine. The series of shots is given at ages 2, 4, 6 and 15 months with a booster between the ages of 4 and 6. Teenagers should get the Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) vaccine around age 11 or 12. Pregnant women are advised to get one Tdap dose during [each of their pregnancies] and other adults should also get the vaccine once in their life.\n\nThe Bureau of Communicable Diseases also suggests keeping babies and other high-risk people away from people who are sick.\n\nPeople with questions can contact Burnett County Public Health at 715-349-7600.\n\n[Byline: Jonathan Richie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Polk County, with a population of 44 205 in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Wisconsin; its county seat is Balsam Lake. Burnett County is an adjacent county north of Polk County and St. Croix County is an adjacent county to the south of Polk County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polk_County,_Wisconsin). Burnett County's seat is the city of Siren (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burnett_County,_Wisconsin). A map of Wisconsin showing its counties can be found at https://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] South Carolina\nDate: Tue 8 May 2008, 11:15 AM EDT\nSource: Fox Carolina [edited]\nhttp://www.foxcarolina.com/story/38139185/four-students-at-2-schools-sickened-with-whooping-cough-in-spartanburg-county\n\n\nA spokesperson for Spartanburg District Five Schools said a total of 4 students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, although the Department of Health and Environmental Control said only 3 cases had been confirmed.\n\nMelissa Robinette said the ill students attend Abner Creek Elementary and Beech Springs Intermediate School. Robinette said DHEC sent a letter to parents on [Mon 7 May 2018] warning them about signs of whooping cough and what to look for.\n\nStudents are required to have the vaccine, called the Tdap vaccine, before beginning school in South Carolina and must have a booster shot before entering the seventh grade, Robinette said. \"However, South Carolina is one of many states that allows exemptions to vaccinations for religious reasons,\" Robinette stated.\n\n[Byline: Dal Kalsi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The city of Spartanburg, with a population of 37 013 residents in 2010, is the most populous city in and the seat of Spartanburg County, South Carolina, United States,[3] and the 12th-largest city by population in the state (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spartanburg,_South_Carolina). A map showing the location of Spartanburg can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Spartanburg,+SC. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\nDate: Tue 8 May 2018, 9:51PM\nSource: The South Western Times [edited]\nhttps://thewest.com.au/news/south-western-times/big-spike-in-whooping-cough-brings-warning-ng-b88828007z\n\n\nBunbury parents are being urged to check their children for signs of whooping cough after a surge of reports of the disease in the city.\n\nWA Country Health Service South West acting director of population health Sharlene Abbott said a total of 75 cases of whooping cough had been reported to the South West Population Health Unit as of [1 May 2018], compared to 28 cases at the same time last year [2017].\n\n\"Cases have been reported predominantly in the Greater Bunbury area, but also from other South West towns,\" she said.\n\n\"Whooping cough is a cyclical disease, with epidemics occurring every 3 to 4 years, even in highly immunised populations. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5841308", "date": "2018-05-09 16:25:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (06): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\n[2] Oregon\n[3] North Carolina\n[4] New Mexico\n[5] Wisconsin\n[6] South Carolina\n\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\n\n******\nUSA\n---\n[1] Oregon\nDate: Tue 24 Apr 2018, 8:42 PM PDT\nSource: KTVZ [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvz.com/news/redmond-whooping-cough-cases-prompt-letters-to-parents/734169668\n\n\nFour Redmond School District (RSD) students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, also known as pertussis, prompting letters to parents from district schools, advising of possible exposure and symptoms to watch for.\n\nSchool district spokesman Rainier Butler said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that Deschutes County Public Health had advised of the cases and \"recommended with notify all RSD families about possible exposure, symptoms and prevention.\"\n\nFamily Choice Urgent Care physician Dr. Terri Mucha said [Wed 18 Apr 2018] that for the most part, immunizations have gotten rid of the disease. \"Whooping cough is caused by the pertussis bacteria, so antibiotics do treat it. It can be serious in the young kids or the elderly,\" Mucha said. \"It is something that is part of our childhood immunization, so it is something we have successfully eradicated for a while now.\"\n\n[Byline: Lauren Melink]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Deschutes County, with a population of 157 733 residents in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Bend (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deschutes_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Deschutes County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Deschutes+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n\n******\n[2] Oregon\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: KLCC [edited]\nhttp://klcc.org/post/public-health-officials-warn-whooping-cough-outbreak-eugene\n\n\nLane County Public Health has confirmed 10 cases of whooping cough, or pertussis, at Sheldon High School in Eugene [Oregon].\n\nDr. Patrick Luedtke with Lane County Public Health says pertussis can spread quickly among those who are not vaccinated. Luedtke: \"We are not the best vaccinated state and Lane County is not the best vaccinated of Oregon's 36 counties, so we are clearly at risk. So this is a preventive measure to say, it's out there, go get protected, and practice respiratory etiquette.\"\n\n[Byline: Rachael McDonald]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lane County, with a population of 351 715 residents in 2010, is located on the Pacific coast of the U.S. state of Oregon; its county seat is Eugene (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_County,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Lane County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Lane+County,+OR. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] North Carolina\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2018, 10:54 AM\nSource: WITN [edited]\nhttp://www.witn.com/content/news/Ten-confirmed-cases-in-Carteret-County-whooping-cough-outbreak-480817891.html?ref=891\n\n\nHealth officials in one Eastern Carolina county are warning parents to be on the lookout for whooping cough.\n\nThe Carteret County Health Department says so far there have been 10 confirmed cases of the highly contagious respiratory disease. The health department says the victims in the outbreak are between the ages of 9 and 14 years old and they continue to see an increase of cases in school age children.\n\nState health officials say for the first 3 months of the year, there were 79 whooping cough cases statewide. Their figures showed Carteret County for 3 cases each in January and February [2018], while Craven County has 3 cases in February [2018].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Carteret County, with a population of 66 469 residents in 2010, is located on the Atlantic coast of the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is Beaufort (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carteret_County,_North_Carolina). An adjacent county, north of Carteret County, Craven County, with a population of 103 505 residents in 2010, is also located in the U.S. state of North Carolina; its county seat is New Bern (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craven_County,_North_Carolina). A map of North Carolina counties can be found at https://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] New Mexico\nDate: Mon 30 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/pertussis-outbreak-reported-mckinley-county-new-mexico-79087/\n\n\nNew Mexico health officials are reporting a pertussis, or whooping cough outbreak in McKinley County in northwest New Mexico. As of [Wed 25 Apr 2018], there are 17 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough and an additional 43 probable cases.\n\nWhen the New Mexico Department of Health first announced this outbreak on [14 Mar 2018], there were 8 laboratory-confirmed cases of whooping cough, with 15 probable cases. These cases continue to be primarily occurring in school-aged children and their close household contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[McKinley County, with a population of 71 492 residents, is located in the northwestern section of the U.S. state of New Mexico; its county seat is Gallup (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McKinley_County,_New_Mexico). A map of New Mexico showing the location of McKinley County can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/McKinley+County,+NM. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Wisconsin\nDate: Fri 4 May 2018\nSource: Burnett County Sentinel [edited]\nhttp://www.burnettcountysentinel.com/news/siren-school-alerted-of-whooping-cough-outbreak-in-polk-county/article_67b3bd32-4e3a-11e8-9f50-33c94e316a11.html\n\n\nLast week Burnett County Health Department sent a letter to Siren School about a pertussis outbreak in Polk County. \"Polk County Health Department is actively investigating an outbreak of pertussis that started with the first reported case on [28 Mar 2018],\" said Anna Treague, nurse for Public Health in the letter. \"There are currently 12 lab-confirmed or epi-linked cases in this outbreak. All of the cases are high school students in the St. Croix Falls school district in Polk County. All have been fully immunized with pertussis containing vaccines.\"\n\nSiren School nurse Karen Vanek, said on [Tue 1 May 2018] that there were still no cases of pertussis in Siren School [Burnett County].\n\n\"Polk County is working closely with the school district in an effort to distribute information to parents and to assist in isolating symptomatic students who may need testing or who are awaiting test results,\" Treague said. \"Some close contacts may attend other schools in Polk County or neighboring counties. We will be notified if we have contacts or suspect cases in our county.\"\n\nThe best way to prevent whooping cough is to get vaccinated for it. Children need 5 doses of DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis) vaccine. The series of shots is given at ages 2, 4, 6 and 15 months with a booster between the ages of 4 and 6. Teenagers should get the Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) vaccine around age 11 or 12. Pregnant women are advised to get one Tdap dose during [each of their pregnancies] and other adults should also get the vaccine once in their life.\n\nThe Bureau of Communicable Diseases also suggests keeping babies and other high-risk people away from people who are sick.\n\nPeople with questions can contact Burnett County Public Health at 715-349-7600.\n\n[Byline: Jonathan Richie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Polk County, with a population of 44 205 in 2010, is located in the U.S. state of Wisconsin; its county seat is Balsam Lake. Burnett County is an adjacent county north of Polk County and St. Croix County is an adjacent county to the south of Polk County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polk_County,_Wisconsin). Burnett County's seat is the city of Siren (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burnett_County,_Wisconsin). A map of Wisconsin showing its counties can be found at https://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] South Carolina\nDate: Tue 8 May 2008, 11:15 AM EDT\nSource: Fox Carolina [edited]\nhttp://www.foxcarolina.com/story/38139185/four-students-at-2-schools-sickened-with-whooping-cough-in-spartanburg-county\n\n\nA spokesperson for Spartanburg District Five Schools said a total of 4 students have been diagnosed with whooping cough, although the Department of Health and Environmental Control said only 3 cases had been confirmed.\n\nMelissa Robinette said the ill students attend Abner Creek Elementary and Beech Springs Intermediate School. Robinette said DHEC sent a letter to parents on [Mon 7 May 2018] warning them about signs of whooping cough and what to look for.\n\nStudents are required to have the vaccine, called the Tdap vaccine, before beginning school in South Carolina and must have a booster shot before entering the seventh grade, Robinette said. \"However, South Carolina is one of many states that allows exemptions to vaccinations for religious reasons,\" Robinette stated.\n\n[Byline: Dal Kalsi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The city of Spartanburg, with a population of 37 013 residents in 2010, is the most populous city in and the seat of Spartanburg County, South Carolina, United States,[3] and the 12th-largest city by population in the state (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spartanburg,_South_Carolina). A map showing the location of Spartanburg can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Spartanburg,+SC. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\nAustralia\n---\n[7] Western Australia\nDate: Tue 8 May 2018, 9:51PM\nSource: The South Western Times [edited]\nhttps://thewest.com.au/news/south-western-times/big-spike-in-whooping-cough-brings-warning-ng-b88828007z\n\n\nBunbury parents are being urged to check their children for signs of whooping cough after a surge of reports of the disease in the city.\n\nWA Country Health Service South West acting director of population health Sharlene Abbott said a total of 75 cases of whooping cough had been reported to the South West Population Health Unit as of [1 May 2018], compared to 28 cases at the same time last year [2017].\n\n\"Cases have been reported predominantly in the Greater Bunbury area, but also from other South West towns,\" she said.\n\n\"Whooping cough is a cyclical disease, with epidemics occurring every 3 to 4 years, even in highly immunised populations. The last epidemic in the South West was in 2015 when there were over 400 reported cases.\"\n\n[Byline: Michael Philipps]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Western Australia (WA) is Australia's largest state, which occupies the entire western 3rd of Australia. The state has about 2.6 million residents - around 11 percent of the national total; 92 percent of residents live in the southwest corner, 73 percent of the population living in the area of the state capital, Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Australia).\n\nBunbury, with a population of 75 628 residents in 2015, is a coastal city in Western Australia, approximately 175 km (109 mi) south of Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bunbury,_Western_Australia). Greater Bunbury includes 4 local government areas (the City of Bunbury and the shires of Capel, Dardanup, and Harvey). - Mod.ML]\n\n[HeathMaps:\nUnited States:
