"PERTUSSIS (10): CANADA, USA, AUSTRALIA\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nCanada\n---\n[1] Alberta\n[2] Nunavut\n[3] Saskatchewan\nUSA\n---\n[4] Kentucky\n[5] Oregon\nAustralia\n---\n[6] South Australia\n\n******\n[1] Canada (Alberta)\nDate: Mon 2 Oct 2017 3:47:39 PM MDT\nSource: Whitecourt Star [edited]\nhttp://www.whitecourtstar.com/2017/10/02/whooping-cough-appearing-in-whitecourt-schools\n\n\nMultiple cases of whooping cough [pertussis] have been confirmed in Pat Hardy Elementary School, Hilltop High School, and Ecole St Joseph School [in Whitecourt, Alberta]. All 3 schools have notified parents through a letter.\n\n\"Of course, those students with pertussis are immediately refrained from attending school,\" said Lisa Bakos, communications officer with Northern Gateway Public Schools. She added that regular janitorial duties have been scaled up at Hilltop and Pat Hardy to prevent the spread of the infection. Bakos advised that parents read the letter carefully and that students continue to keep themselves clean. \"Hand washing, of course, is always so important in schools,\" she said.\n\nDr Kathryn Koliaska, a north zone medical officer with Alberta Health Services, said the levels of whooping cough in Alberta fluctuate year to year and that outbreaks in schools are not uncommon. \"There's obviously large groups of kids together in schools,\" Koliaska said.\n\nThe group most vulnerable to whooping cough is babies, especially during their 1st year of life. Koliaska encouraged parents to immunize their infants and for pregnant women or anyone who spends extended time around newborns to immunize themselves.\n\nWhooping cough symptoms include persistent coughing, gagging and vomiting following coughing and spasms of coughing followed by a \"whoop\" sound.\n\nHowever, Koliaska said going to the doctor is the surest way to diagnose whooping cough. \"It's very hard to tell the difference symptom-wise from a common cold,\" Koliaska said. \"Of course, the test takes a couple of days, so it will also be the conversation at your doctor's office.\"\n\nAs of [28 Sep 2017], the north zone has 83 confirmed cases with Alberta having 744 overall. For further information on whooping cough, call Health Link at 811.\n\n[Byline: Peter Shokeir]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at http://www.map-of-canada.org/canada-map-795.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12.\nWhitecourt, with a population of 10 204 residents in 2016, is a town in Woodlands County in the central portion of the Canadian province of Alberta, approximately 177 km (110 mi) northwest of Edmonton, the capital city of Alberta (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whitecourt). A map of Alberta, showing the location of Whitecourt can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Whitecourt,+AB,+Canada. Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Canada (Nunavut)\nDate: Mon 25 Sep 2017 1:10 PM EDT\nSource: Nunatsiaq Online [edited]\nhttp://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674nunavut_confirms_new_cases_of_whooping_cough/\n\n\nLess than 6 months after the Government of Nunavut [GN] declared that the territory's most recent outbreak of whooping cough is over, health officials say they've confirmed new cases of the respiratory infection in the Kivalliq community of Arviat, population about 3000. A spokesperson with Nunavut's Department of Health could not specify the number of cases, but said it was low. The infection is currently confined to Arviat only.\n\nHealth officials are asking Nunavummiut -- especially the parents of babies and young children -- to take note, given that the infection can spread easily.\n\nAdults or children with those symptoms should visit their local health centre right away, health officials said; early diagnosis and treatment of whooping cough are important to making a full recovery.\n\nIf you've ever considered getting vaccinated against pertussis, now's the time: the GN encourages all Nunavummiut to ask community health care staff about getting a free vaccination. Anyone showing signs of the infections should also stay home from school or the workplace, to prevent the spread of the illness.\n\nNunavut's latest outbreak began in May 2016 in Pond Inlet, when 4 cases of whooping cough were first confirmed. Gradually the infection spread to other community members and other communities in the Baffin region. By the fall of 2016, Nunavut's health department had tracked more than 100 cases of pertussis in 11 communities throughout the Baffin and Kivalliq regions.\n\nIt wasn't until April 2017 that the health department declared the outbreak over.\n\n[Byline: Sarah Rogers]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nunavut, with a population of almost 36 000 residents, is the northernmost territory of Canada and is Canada's largest in area and the second least populous of its provinces and territories (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nunavut). Its capital is Iqaluit on Baffin Island. Arviat, with a population of 2657 in 2006, is a predominantly Inuit hamlet located on the western shore of Hudson Bay in the Kivalliq Region of Nunavut (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arviat). A map of Canada showing the location of Arviat can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Arviat,+NU,+Canada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Canada (Saskatchewan)\nDate: Thu 21 Sep 2017\nSource: Toronto Metro, The Canadian Press report [edited]\nhttp://goo.gl/qV17Sr\n\n\nThe Five Hills Health Region [Saskatchewan] is confirming 67 lab-proven cases of pertussis, more commonly known as whooping cough due to the sound people who have it make while coughing. Medical health officer Dr Mark Vooght said he wasn't aware of any cases that resulted in hospitalization, but the illness can be quite serious for young children and those with compromised immune systems. Risks include obstruction of airwaves, sepsis, and serious infection.\n\nVooght said many people only get checked out when they're very sick -- even bed-bound -- and have had whooping cough for a while. In February [2017], the Five Hills Health Region confirmed an outbreak of whooping cough involving school-aged children. 5 people were affected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Five Hills Health Region is located in south-central portion of the Canadian province of Saskatchewan and serves a population of approximately 54 000 people in an area that extends from Lake Diefenbaker to the United States border (http://www.fhhr.ca/about.htm). A map of the Five Hills Health Region can be found at http://www.fhhr.ca/about.htm. The city of Moose Jaw, with a population of 33 274 residents in 2011, is located in the Five Hills Health Region and is 77 km (48 mi) west of Regina, the capital of Saskatchewan. A map of Canada showing the location of Moose jaw an be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Moose+Jaw,+SK+S6J,+Canada.- Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] USA (Kentucky}\nDate: Thu 28 Sep 2017 11:52 PM CEST\nSource: WDRB [edited]\nhttp://www.wdrb.com/story/36479199/whooping-cough-cases-in-infants-spike-in-jefferson-county\n\n\nJefferson County [Kentucky] health officials say they have seen a dramatic spike in whooping cough in children under age one [year of age].\n\nIn a release, the Department of Public Health and Wellness is stressing the importance of immunization schedules for children. 6 cases have been reported so far in September [2017] in infants.\n\nHealth officials say the best way to prevent whooping cough is through the DTaP vaccination for children. A Tdap booster is suggested for adolescents and adults to protect against whooping cough, tetanus and diphtheria. It is recommended that infants receive the DTap immunization at 2, 4 and 6 month. Boosters are recommended at ages 15-18 months and at 4-6 years. Health officials say children should get a single dose of Tdap at 11 to 12 years of age. And they say pregnant women should receive a single dose of Tdap during every pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks.\n\nHealth officials recommend parents, siblings, and caregivers of infants be immunized against whooping cough with the Tdap vaccine. Families are urged to check with their doctor to see if children are up to date with immunizations.\n\nFamilies without insurance are urged to contact the Department of Public Health and Wellness at 574-6520.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. Jefferson County, with a population of 741 096 residents in 2010, is located in the US state of Kentucky, includes the city of Louisville and is known as Louisville/Jefferson County Metro. A map of Louisville/Jefferson County Metro can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Jefferson+County,+KY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] USA (Oregon)\nDate: Sun 17 Sep 2017 7:07 PM PDT\nSource: Columbian [edited]\nhttp://www.columbian.com/news/2017/sep/17/officials-face-pertussis-in-ashland-schools/\n\n\nJackson County [Oregon] health officials are responding to an outbreak of whooping cough in Ashland schools. Jackson County Medical Director Dr Jim Shames told the Mail Tribune last week that there are 2 confirmed cases and 1 suspected case. All 3 had contact with one another.\n\nSchool and health officials have not said where the outbreak of the contagious respiratory illness, also known as pertussis, has occurred. A joint statement from the Ashland School District and Jackson County Health Department said employees and students may have had contact with a person with confirmed pertussis during the 1st 2 weeks of school. Health officials said Oregon law requires children who have been exposed to pertussis but are under vaccinated to be excluded from school for 21 days.\n\nWhooping cough is spread by coughing and sneezing. Young children, especially infants who have not had all their vaccinations, can be particularly susceptible.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jackson County, with a population of 203 206 in 2010, is located in the southwestern portion of the US state of Oregon, on the border with California (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson_County,_Oregon). She said that the outbreak had caused quite a disruption to the school. \"It is quite annoying because it has a disruption to the kids' learning programs,\" she said. \"I have certainly spent a lot of time (dealing with the outbreak) and I would rather be dealing with their NAPLAN [National Assessment Program - Literacy and Numeracy] results. \"I would rather be talking about that than whooping cough!\"\n\nNo staff at Riverton Primary have contracted the infection.\n\nThe virus [pertussis is caused by a bacterium, _Bordetella pertussis_, not a virus] however, has begun to travel into surrounding towns with confirmed cases of Riverton Primary students from Saddleworth and Marrabel contracting whooping cough.\n\nHealth Minister Jack Snelling urged South Australians to get vaccinated for the infection back in June [2017] as the number of reported cases was rising at an alarming rate. Australia\n\n******\n[1] Canada (Alberta)\nDate: Mon 2 Oct 2017 3:47:39 PM MDT\nSource: Whitecourt Star [edited]\nhttp://www.whitecourtstar.com/2017/10/02/whooping-cough-appearing-in-whitecourt-schools\n\n\nMultiple cases of whooping cough [pertussis] have been confirmed in Pat Hardy Elementary School, Hilltop High School, and Ecole St Joseph School [in Whitecourt, Alberta]. All 3 schools have notified parents through a letter.\n\n\"Of course, those students with pertussis are immediately refrained from attending school,\" said Lisa Bakos, communications officer with Northern Gateway Public Schools. She added that regular janitorial duties have been scaled up at Hilltop and Pat Hardy to prevent the spread of the infection. Bakos advised that parents read the letter carefully and that students continue to keep themselves clean. \"Hand washing, of course, is always so important in schools,\" she said.\n\nDr Kathryn Koliaska, a north zone medical officer with Alberta Health Services, said the levels of whooping cough in Alberta fluctuate year to year and that outbreaks in schools are not uncommon. \"There's obviously large groups of kids together in schools,\" Koliaska said.\n\nThe group most vulnerable to whooping cough is babies, especially during their 1st year of life. Koliaska encouraged parents to immunize their infants and for pregnant women or anyone who spends extended time around newborns to immunize themselves.\n\nWhooping cough symptoms include persistent coughing, gagging and vomiting following coughing and spasms of coughing followed by a \"whoop\" sound.\n\nHowever, Koliaska said going to the doctor is the surest way to diagnose whooping cough. \"It's very hard to tell the difference symptom-wise from a common cold,\" Koliaska said. \"Of course, the test takes a couple of days, so it will also be the conversation at your doctor's office.\"\n\nAs of [28 Sep 2017], the north zone has 83 confirmed cases with Alberta having 744 overall. For further information on whooping cough, call Health Link at 811.\n\n[Byline: Peter Shokeir]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at http://www.map-of-canada.org/canada-map-795.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12.\nWhitecourt, with a population of 10 204 residents in 2016, is a town in Woodlands County in the central portion of the Canadian province of Alberta, approximately 177 km (110 mi) northwest of Edmonton, the capital city of Alberta (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whitecourt). A map of Alberta, showing the location of Whitecourt can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Whitecourt,+AB,+Canada. Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Canada (Nunavut)\nDate: Mon 25 Sep 2017 1:10 PM EDT\nSource: Nunatsiaq Online [edited]\nhttp://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674nunavut_confirms_new_cases_of_whooping_cough/\n\n\nLess than 6 months after the Government of Nunavut [GN] declared that the territory's most recent outbreak of whooping cough is over, health officials say they've confirmed new cases of the respiratory infection in the Kivalliq community of Arviat, population about 3000. A spokesperson with Nunavut's Department of Health could not specify the number of cases, but said it was low. The infection is currently confined to Arviat only.\n\nHealth officials are asking Nunavummiut -- especially the parents of babies and young children -- to take note, given that the infection can spread easily.\n\nAdults or children with those symptoms should visit their local health centre right away, health officials said; early diagnosis and treatment of whooping cough are important to making a full recovery.\n\nIf you've ever considered getting vaccinated against pertussis, now's the time: the GN encourages all Nunavummiut to ask community health care staff about getting a free vaccination. Anyone showing signs of the infections should also stay home from school or the workplace, to prevent the spread of the illness.\n\nNunavut's latest outbreak began in May 2016 in Pond Inlet, when 4 cases of whooping cough were first confirmed. Gradually the infection spread to other community members and other communities in the Baffin region. By the fall of 2016, Nunavut's health department had tracked more than 100 cases of pertussis in 11 communities throughout the Baffin and Kivalliq regions.\n\nIt wasn't until April 2017 that the health department declared the outbreak over.\n\n[Byline: Sarah Rogers]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nunavut, with a population of almost 36 000 residents, is the northernmost territory of Canada and is Canada's largest in area and the second least populous of its provinces and territories (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nunavut). Its capital is Iqaluit on Baffin Island. Arviat, with a population of 2657 in 2006, is a predominantly Inuit hamlet located on the western shore of Hudson Bay in the Kivalliq Region of Nunavut (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arviat). A map of Canada showing the location of Arviat can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Arviat,+NU,+Canada. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Canada (Saskatchewan)\nDate: Thu 21 Sep 2017\nSource: Toronto Metro, The Canadian Press report [edited]\nhttp://goo.gl/qV17Sr\n\n\nThe Five Hills Health Region [Saskatchewan] is confirming 67 lab-proven cases of pertussis, more commonly known as whooping cough due to the sound people who have it make while coughing. Medical health officer Dr Mark Vooght said he wasn't aware of any cases that resulted in hospitalization, but the illness can be quite serious for young children and those with compromised immune systems. Risks include obstruction of airwaves, sepsis, and serious infection.\n\nVooght said many people only get checked out when they're very sick -- even bed-bound -- and have had whooping cough for a while. In February [2017], the Five Hills Health Region confirmed an outbreak of whooping cough involving school-aged children. 5 people were affected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Five Hills Health Region is located in south-central portion of the Canadian province of Saskatchewan and serves a population of approximately 54 000 people in an area that extends from Lake Diefenbaker to the United States border (http://www.fhhr.ca/about.htm). A map of the Five Hills Health Region can be found at http://www.fhhr.ca/about.htm. The city of Moose Jaw, with a population of 33 274 residents in 2011, is located in the Five Hills Health Region and is 77 km (48 mi) west of Regina, the capital of Saskatchewan. A map of Canada showing the location of Moose jaw an be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Moose+Jaw,+SK+S6J,+Canada.- Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] USA (Kentucky}\nDate: Thu 28 Sep 2017 11:52 PM CEST\nSource: WDRB [edited]\nhttp://www.wdrb.com/story/36479199/whooping-cough-cases-in-infants-spike-in-jefferson-county\n\n\nJefferson County [Kentucky] health officials say they have seen a dramatic spike in whooping cough in children under age one [year of age].\n\nIn a release, the Department of Public Health and Wellness is stressing the importance of immunization schedules for children. 6 cases have been reported so far in September [2017] in infants.\n\nHealth officials say the best way to prevent whooping cough is through the DTaP vaccination for children. A Tdap booster is suggested for adolescents and adults to protect against whooping cough, tetanus and diphtheria. It is recommended that infants receive the DTap immunization at 2, 4 and 6 month. Boosters are recommended at ages 15-18 months and at 4-6 years. Health officials say children should get a single dose of Tdap at 11 to 12 years of age. And they say pregnant women should receive a single dose of Tdap during every pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks.\n\nHealth officials recommend parents, siblings, and caregivers of infants be immunized against whooping cough with the Tdap vaccine. Families are urged to check with their doctor to see if children are up to date with immunizations.\n\nFamilies without insurance are urged to contact the Department of Public Health and Wellness at 574-6520.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. Jefferson County, with a population of 741 096 residents in 2010, is located in the US state of Kentucky, includes the city of Louisville and is known as Louisville/Jefferson County Metro. A map of Louisville/Jefferson County Metro can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Jefferson+County,+KY. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] USA (Oregon)\nDate: Sun 17 Sep 2017 7:07 PM PDT\nSource: Columbian [edited]\nhttp://www.columbian.com/news/2017/sep/17/officials-face-pertussis-in-ashland-schools/\n\n\nJackson County [Oregon] health officials are responding to an outbreak of whooping cough in Ashland schools. Jackson County Medical Director Dr Jim Shames told the Mail Tribune last week that there are 2 confirmed cases and 1 suspected case. All 3 had contact with one another.\n\nSchool and health officials have not said where the outbreak of the contagious respiratory illness, also known as pertussis, has occurred. A joint statement from the Ashland School District and Jackson County Health Department said employees and students may have had contact with a person with confirmed pertussis during the 1st 2 weeks of school. Health officials said Oregon law requires children who have been exposed to pertussis but are under vaccinated to be excluded from school for 21 days.\n\nWhooping cough is spread by coughing and sneezing. Young children, especially infants who have not had all their vaccinations, can be particularly susceptible.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jackson County, with a population of 203 206 in 2010, is located in the southwestern portion of the US state of Oregon, on the border with California (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson_County,_Oregon). Ashland, with a population of about 21 000, is a city in south-central Jackson County, about 16 miles (26 km) north of the California border (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashland,_Oregon). A map of Oregon showing the location of Ashland can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Ashland,+OR+97520. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[6] Australia (South Australia)\nDate: Tue 12 Sep 2017 3:31 PM ACDT\nSource: Northern Argus [edited]\nhttp://www.northernargus.com.au/story/4911825/whooping-cough-spreads/\n\n\nThe respiratory infection whooping cough is sweeping through Riverton [South Australia] with an outbreak of the disease over recent weeks.\n\nA total of 21 students from Riverton Primary School and 1 student at Riverton Kindergarten have been confirmed to have contracted the infection since the start of August [2017]. Riverton Primary principal Cheryl Glendie said she had been in almost daily contact with both the Health Department and the Education Department since the 1st reported case last month [August 2017].\n\n\"I report every single case to the Health Department every day so that we keep right on top of it,\" she said. Ms Glendie said she had reported the 1st case of whooping cough to SA [South Australia] Health on [7 Aug 2017] with the infection at its worst over a 2-week period.\n\nThe infection has been sweeping through the school for around a month, but Ms Glendie believed that it was now beginning to wind down. She said that the outbreak had caused quite a disruption to the school. \"It is quite annoying because it has a disruption to the kids' learning programs,\" she said. \"I have certainly spent a lot of time (dealing with the outbreak) and I would rather be dealing with their NAPLAN [National Assessment Program - Literacy and Numeracy] results. \"I would rather be talking about that than whooping cough!\"\n\nNo staff at Riverton Primary have contracted the infection.\n\nThe virus [pertussis is caused by a bacterium, _Bordetella pertussis_, not a virus] however, has begun to travel into surrounding towns with confirmed cases of Riverton Primary students from Saddleworth and Marrabel contracting whooping cough.\n\nHealth Minister Jack Snelling urged South Australians to get vaccinated for the infection back in June [2017] as the number of reported cases was rising at an alarming rate. At the time, the state had seen a 50 per cent increase in the number of reported cases compared to 12 months ago as 860 South Australians contracted the disease compared to 571 at the same time last year [2016]. Health experts were concerned that cases of whooping cough would reach a 5-year high.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63238. Riverton, with a population of 810 in 2013, is a small town in southeastern South Australia (SA) about 100 km (62 mi) north of Adelaide, the capital city of the state of SA (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riverton,_South_Australia). A map of south Australia showing the location of Riverton can be found at (http://www.australiaab.com/distance/29005348-29189024). - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nPertussis (09): USA, Canada "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (10): CANADA, USA, AUSTRALIA\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nCanada\n---\n[1] Alberta\n[2] Nunavut\n[3] Saskatchewan\nUSA\n---\n[4] Kentucky\n[5] Oregon\nAustralia\n---\n[6] South Australia\n\n******\n[1] Canada (Alberta)\nDate: Mon 2 Oct 2017 3:47:39 PM MDT\nSource: Whitecourt Star [edited]\nhttp://www.whitecourtstar.com/2017/10/02/whooping-cough-appearing-in-whitecourt-schools\n\n\nMultiple cases of whooping cough [pertussis] have been confirmed in Pat Hardy Elementary School, Hilltop High School, and Ecole St Joseph School [in Whitecourt, Alberta]. All 3 schools have notified parents through a letter.\n\n\"Of course, those students with pertussis are immediately refrained from attending school,\" said Lisa Bakos, communications officer with Northern Gateway Public Schools. She added that regular janitorial duties have been scaled up at Hilltop and Pat Hardy to prevent the spread of the infection. Bakos advised that parents read the letter carefully and that students continue to keep themselves clean. \"Hand washing, of course, is always so important in schools,\" she said.\n\nDr Kathryn Koliaska, a north zone medical officer with Alberta Health Services, said the levels of whooping cough in Alberta fluctuate year to year and that outbreaks in schools are not uncommon. \"There's obviously large groups of kids together in schools,\" Koliaska said.\n\nThe group most vulnerable to whooping cough is babies, especially during their 1st year of life. Koliaska encouraged parents to immunize their infants and for pregnant women or anyone who spends extended time around newborns to immunize themselves.\n\nWhooping cough symptoms include persistent coughing, gagging and vomiting following coughing and spasms of coughing followed by a \"whoop\" sound.\n\nHowever, Koliaska said going to the doctor is the surest way to diagnose whooping cough. \"It's very hard to tell the difference symptom-wise from a common cold,\" Koliaska said. \"Of course, the test takes a couple of days, so it will also be the conversation at your doctor's office.\"\n\nAs of [28 Sep 2017], the north zone has 83 confirmed cases with Alberta having 744 overall. For further information on whooping cough, call Health Link at 811.\n\n[Byline: Peter Shokeir]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at http://www.map-of-canada.org/canada-map-795.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12.\nWhitecourt, with a population of 10 204 residents in 2016, is a town in Woodlands County in the central portion of the Canadian province of Alberta, approximately 177 km (110 mi) northwest of Edmonton, the capital city of Alberta (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whitecourt). A map of Alberta, showing the location of Whitecourt can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Whitecourt,+AB,+Canada. A spokesperson with Nunavut's Department of Health could not specify the number of cases, but said it was low. The infection is currently confined to Arviat only.\n\nHealth officials are asking Nunavummiut -- especially the parents of babies and young children -- to take note, given that the infection can spread easily.\n\nAdults or children with those symptoms should visit their local health centre right away, health officials said; early diagnosis and treatment of whooping cough are important to making a full recovery.\n\nIf you've ever considered getting vaccinated against pertussis, now's the time: the GN encourages all Nunavummiut to ask community health care staff about getting a free vaccination. Anyone showing signs of the infections should also stay home from school or the workplace, to prevent the spread of the illness.\n\nNunavut's latest outbreak began in May 2016 in Pond Inlet, when 4 cases of whooping cough were first confirmed. Gradually the infection spread to other community members and other communities in the Baffin region. By the fall of 2016, Nunavut's health department had tracked more than 100 cases of pertussis in 11 communities throughout the Baffin and Kivalliq regions.\n\nIt wasn't until April 2017 that the health department declared the outbreak over.\n\n[Byline: Sarah Rogers]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nunavut, with a population of almost 36 000 residents, is the northernmost territory of Canada and is Canada's largest in area and the second least populous of its provinces and territories (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nunavut). A Tdap booster is suggested for adolescents and adults to protect against whooping cough, tetanus and diphtheria. It is recommended that infants receive the DTap immunization at 2, 4 and 6 month. Boosters are recommended at ages 15-18 months and at 4-6 years. Health officials say children should get a single dose of Tdap at 11 to 12 years of age. And they say pregnant women should receive a single dose of Tdap during every pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks.\n\nHealth officials recommend parents, siblings, and caregivers of infants be immunized against whooping cough with the Tdap vaccine. Jackson County Medical Director Dr Jim Shames told the Mail Tribune last week that there are 2 confirmed cases and 1 suspected case. All 3 had contact with one another.\n\nSchool and health officials have not said where the outbreak of the contagious respiratory illness, also known as pertussis, has occurred. A joint statement from the Ashland School District and Jackson County Health Department said employees and students may have had contact with a person with confirmed pertussis during the 1st 2 weeks of school. Health officials said Oregon law requires children who have been exposed to pertussis but are under vaccinated to be excluded from school for 21 days.\n\nWhooping cough is spread by coughing and sneezing. Riverton Primary principal Cheryl Glendie said she had been in almost daily contact with both the Health Department and the Education Department since the 1st reported case last month [August 2017].\n\n\"I report every single case to the Health Department every day so that we keep right on top of it,\" she said. She said that the outbreak had caused quite a disruption to the school. \"It is quite annoying because it has a disruption to the kids' learning programs,\" she said. \"I have certainly spent a lot of time (dealing with the outbreak) and I would rather be dealing with their NAPLAN [National Assessment Program - Literacy and Numeracy] results. \"I would rather be talking about that than whooping cough!\"\n\nNo staff at Riverton Primary have contracted the infection.\n\nThe virus [pertussis is caused by a bacterium, _Bordetella pertussis_, not a virus] however, has begun to travel into surrounding towns with confirmed cases of Riverton Primary students from Saddleworth and Marrabel contracting whooping cough.\n\nHealth Minister Jack Snelling urged South Australians to get vaccinated for the infection back in June [2017] as the number of reported cases was rising at an alarming rate. At the time, the state had seen a 50 per cent increase in the number of reported cases compared to 12 months ago as 860 South Australians contracted the disease compared to 571 at the same time last year [2016]. Health experts were concerned that cases of whooping cough would reach a 5-year high.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63238. Riverton, with a population of 810 in 2013, is a small town in southeastern South Australia (SA) about 100 km (62 mi) north of Adelaide, the capital city of the state of SA (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riverton,_South_Australia). A map of south Australia showing the location of Riverton can be found at (http://www.australiaab.com/distance/29005348-29189024). - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nPertussis (09): USA, Canada "PERTUSSIS (03): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Kansas, USA\nDate: Thu 27 Apr 2017 10:58 pm\nSource: Parsonssun.com [edited]\nhttp://www.parsonssun.com/news/article_015be532-2bc7-11e7-a026-dbbd7aa1e4fd.html\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases in Labette County has grown to 6, with 2 more suspected cases awaiting test results, so the Kansas Department of Health and Environment [KDHE] considers it an outbreak.\n\nAn outbreak is seeing more cases of a certain illness than health care professionals would on a normal day, so Public Health of Labette County administrator Debbi Baugher said one case of whooping cough, or pertussis, could be considered an outbreak. But with the potential for 8 cases in students, KDHE decided this week [week of Sun 22 Apr 2017] to declare an outbreak. Baugher said health department personnel are tracking the cases to find connections among patients and try to find the source.\n\nThe disease was 1st found in a high school student, but most of the recent victims are from middle-school age students at Meadow View Grade School. Baugher said a 4 month old infant [had been] admitted to Labette Health with pertussis. A family member who attends Labette County High School and had been exposed to the disease was in the presence of the infant. The infant was born with respiratory issues and was too young to be fully vaccinated.\n\nTesting continues for suspected cases, but results have been slow to come back. Baugher said her department worked with KDHE, where cultures are tested, and arranged to reduce that delay for those who get the pertussis test at the hospital's lab. Baugher said the tests had been returning in 5 to 6 days. \"If they take a 5-day treatment they're already done with the treatment before we know what caused it,\" Baugher said. Because of the outbreak, KDHE has agreed to test cultures immediately when the hospital lab calls ahead. \"As soon as they get it they test it, so we have a much shorter turn-around time. So we cut it about in half.\"\n\nBaugher said as soon as the health department is able to connect the cases, KDHE will quit testing. At that point, if a patient presents at a doctor's office with symptoms, he or she is given a 5-day dose of antibiotic. \"Right now they still want to test because we don't quite have the connections,\" Baugher said.\n\n[byline: Ray Nolting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Labette County, with a population of 21 607 residents, is located in the south eastern portion of the US state of Kansas; its most populous city is Parsons (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labette_County,_Kansas). A map of the US can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky, USA\nDate: Fri 28 Apr 2017 7:27 PM EDT\nSource: WLWT [edited]\nhttp://www.wlwt.com/article/19-whooping-cough-cases-reported-in-grant-county-schools/9577025\n\n\nFor a 3rd time in 7 years, whooping cough is showing up in greater numbers than usual in Northern Kentucky. The disease has moved through several schools in Grant County this week [week of Sun 22 Apr 2017]. As the number of cases grows, so does concern. Those in charge of running Grant County schools are putting the word out to parents Friday night [28 April 2017] about pertussis.\n\nAs of mid-afternoon Friday [28 Apr 2017, presumably. - Mod.SH], there were 25 cases in Grant County, according to the Northern Kentucky Health Department. \"The vast majority are in Grant County schools,\" said Emily Wherle, a spokeswoman for the health department. Most of the 19 cases in 4 of the 6 Grant County schools were concentrated in the high school.\n\nGrant County counted 5 cases of whooping cough during all of 2016. As of March 23 this year [2017], there were 5 times that number. There are 3800 students in the district.\n\nAs of [Fri 28 Apr 2017], the state health department had not labeled the increased instances of whooping cough an outbreak. The operative phrase was \"a spike in cases\". Howe said there is information on the school district's website. \"We'd like to see this wrapped up and out of our district and out of our community as soon as possible,\" said Howe.\n\nFree vaccines are available for those who meet certain criteria. To learn whether you quality, call the Northern Kentucky Health Department at 859-363-2071.\n\n[byline: John London]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County, with a population of 24 662 residents, is located in the north-central portion of the US state of Kentucky; Grant County is included in the Cincinnati (Ohio)-Middletown (Ohio) Metropolitan Statistical Area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grant_County,_Kentucky). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Wisconsin, USA\nDate: Wed 3 May 2017\nSource: Star Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.starjournalnow.com/2017/05/03/pertussis-in-the-northwoods-again/#_\n\n\nThe Oneida County Health Department (OCHD) has reported 4 lab-confirmed cases of pertussis at Three Lakes Elementary School. The OCHD is working with the Three Lakes School District, the Wisconsin Department of Health Services and community health care providers to prevent the spread of pertussis, also known as whooping cough.\n\nFor more information, call the OCHD at 715-369-6111.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oneida County, with a population of 35 998 residents, is located in the north-central portion of the US state of Wisconsin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oneida_County,_Wisconsin). Three Lakes Elementary School is located in the town of Three Lakes, Wisconsin, which has a population of 2339 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Lakes,_Wisconsin). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Alabama, USA\nDate: Thu 4 May 2017 3:12 pm EDT\nSource: WTVM [edited]\nhttp://www.wtvm.com/story/35345092/whooping-cough-outbreak-reported-at-chambers-county-schools\n\n\nThe Alabama Department of Public Health's Immunization Division is investigating an outbreak of 6 laboratory-confirmed cases of pertussis (whooping cough) at multiple schools in Chambers County.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Chambers County, with a population of 34 215 residents, is located in the east-central portion of the US state of Alabama (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chambers_County,_Alabama). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] New South Wales, Australia\nDate: Thu 4 May 2017 8:49 AM\nSource: Northern Star [edited]\nhttps://www.northernstar.com.au/news/vaccinate-now-37-cases-of-whooping-cough-in-a-week/3173820/\n\n\nA local public health spokesperson said the recent spike in whooping cough cases on the Northern Rivers was a continuation of a worrying trend. This year [2017] 79 cases of whooping cough were confirmed during the month of April in the Northern NSW Local Health District, according to statistics from the NSW Department of Health. In 2016 this number was 77, in 2015 it was 8, just 3 in 2014 and 4 cases in 2013.\n\nFrom the figures the current spike was no surprise to the North Coast Public Health Unit, which anticipated a threat of the infection, acting director of public health, Greg Bell, said: \"Months April-May hold a real threat but last year [2016] cases dropped off as quickly as they rose,\" Mr Bell said.\n\nThe North Coast Public Health Unit is asking parents to immunize their children against preventable diseases after a spike in cases of the potentially deadly whooping cough disease. Bell said there had been 37 whooping cough notifications on the North Coast in the past week [week of Sun 23 Apr 2017], more than double that in the previous week [week of Sun 16 Apr 2017].\n\nMr Bell said the North Coast experienced a similar spike in whooping cough cases leading into winter last year [2016]. He said persistent low vaccination levels in some parts of Northern NSW was worrying, given that free vaccination is available to all parents. Whooping cough vaccination is valuable in preventing severe infection in infants and toddlers, and if unvaccinated children are infected they are at high risk of severe disease. \"It must be remembered that prior to the NSW Government introducing free antenatal whooping cough vaccinations in 2015, 4 infants had died in the preceding 6 years,\" Mr Bell said. \"All pregnant women are urged to have the free whooping cough vaccine during their 3rd trimester, preferably at 28 weeks, to provide optimal protection to their infants.\"\n\nPositive health interventions, such as vaccination, in the 1st 5 years of a child's life are vitally important in laying the foundation for a healthy and fulfilling life.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Northern Rivers is one of 14 regions of the Australian state of New South Wales (NSW); it is located in the northern portion of NSW, on the border with the state of Queensland to the north and the Pacific Coast to the east; at its most northern point, Northern Rivers is 102 km (63 mi) south east of Brisbane, the Queensland capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Rivers). A map of Australia can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186. - Mod.ML\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551 and my colleague Mod.LL's comments in Pertussis - USA (06) 20160917.4495935. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186.]\nSee {"archive_id": "5186476", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (07): USA, France, Canada", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5186476", "date": "2017-05-06 12:15:07", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (03): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Kansas, USA\nDate: Thu 27 Apr 2017 10:58 pm\nSource: Parsonssun.com [edited]\nhttp://www.parsonssun.com/news/article_015be532-2bc7-11e7-a026-dbbd7aa1e4fd.html\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases in Labette County has grown to 6, with 2 more suspected cases awaiting test results, so the Kansas Department of Health and Environment [KDHE] considers it an outbreak.\n\nAn outbreak is seeing more cases of a certain illness than health care professionals would on a normal day, so Public Health of Labette County administrator Debbi Baugher said one case of whooping cough, or pertussis, could be considered an outbreak. But with the potential for 8 cases in students, KDHE decided this week [week of Sun 22 Apr 2017] to declare an outbreak. Baugher said health department personnel are tracking the cases to find connections among patients and try to find the source.\n\nThe disease was 1st found in a high school student, but most of the recent victims are from middle-school age students at Meadow View Grade School. Baugher said a 4 month old infant [had been] admitted to Labette Health with pertussis. A family member who attends Labette County High School and had been exposed to the disease was in the presence of the infant. The infant was born with respiratory issues and was too young to be fully vaccinated.\n\nTesting continues for suspected cases, but results have been slow to come back. Baugher said her department worked with KDHE, where cultures are tested, and arranged to reduce that delay for those who get the pertussis test at the hospital's lab. Baugher said the tests had been returning in 5 to 6 days. \"If they take a 5-day treatment they're already done with the treatment before we know what caused it,\" Baugher said. Because of the outbreak, KDHE has agreed to test cultures immediately when the hospital lab calls ahead. \"As soon as they get it they test it, so we have a much shorter turn-around time. So we cut it about in half.\"\n\nBaugher said as soon as the health department is able to connect the cases, KDHE will quit testing. At that point, if a patient presents at a doctor's office with symptoms, he or she is given a 5-day dose of antibiotic. \"Right now they still want to test because we don't quite have the connections,\" Baugher said.\n\n[byline: Ray Nolting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Labette County, with a population of 21 607 residents, is located in the south eastern portion of the US state of Kansas; its most populous city is Parsons (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labette_County,_Kansas). A map of the US can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky, USA\nDate: Fri 28 Apr 2017 7:27 PM EDT\nSource: WLWT [edited]\nhttp://www.wlwt.com/article/19-whooping-cough-cases-reported-in-grant-county-schools/9577025\n\n\nFor a 3rd time in 7 years, whooping cough is showing up in greater numbers than usual in Northern Kentucky. The disease has moved through several schools in Grant County this week [week of Sun 22 Apr 2017]. As the number of cases grows, so does concern. Those in charge of running Grant County schools are putting the word out to parents Friday night [28 April 2017] about pertussis.\n\nAs of mid-afternoon Friday [28 Apr 2017, presumably. - Mod.SH], there were 25 cases in Grant County, according to the Northern Kentucky Health Department. \"The vast majority are in Grant County schools,\" said Emily Wherle, a spokeswoman for the health department. Most of the 19 cases in 4 of the 6 Grant County schools were concentrated in the high school.\n\nGrant County counted 5 cases of whooping cough during all of 2016. As of March 23 this year [2017], there were 5 times that number. There are 3800 students in the district.\n\nAs of [Fri 28 Apr 2017], the state health department had not labeled the increased instances of whooping cough an outbreak. The operative phrase was \"a spike in cases\". Howe said there is information on the school district's website. \"We'd like to see this wrapped up and out of our district and out of our community as soon as possible,\" said Howe.\n\nFree vaccines are available for those who meet certain criteria. To learn whether you quality, call the Northern Kentucky Health Department at 859-363-2071.\n\n[byline: John London]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County, with a population of 24 662 residents, is located in the north-central portion of the US state of Kentucky; Grant County is included in the Cincinnati (Ohio)-Middletown (Ohio) Metropolitan Statistical Area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grant_County,_Kentucky). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Wisconsin, USA\nDate: Wed 3 May 2017\nSource: Star Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.starjournalnow.com/2017/05/03/pertussis-in-the-northwoods-again/#_\n\n\nThe Oneida County Health Department (OCHD) has reported 4 lab-confirmed cases of pertussis at Three Lakes Elementary School. The OCHD is working with the Three Lakes School District, the Wisconsin Department of Health Services and community health care providers to prevent the spread of pertussis, also known as whooping cough.\n\nFor more information, call the OCHD at 715-369-6111.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oneida County, with a population of 35 998 residents, is located in the north-central portion of the US state of Wisconsin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oneida_County,_Wisconsin). Three Lakes Elementary School is located in the town of Three Lakes, Wisconsin, which has a population of 2339 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Lakes,_Wisconsin). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Alabama, USA\nDate: Thu 4 May 2017 3:12 pm EDT\nSource: WTVM [edited]\nhttp://www.wtvm.com/story/35345092/whooping-cough-outbreak-reported-at-chambers-county-schools\n\n\nThe Alabama Department of Public Health's Immunization Division is investigating an outbreak of 6 laboratory-confirmed cases of pertussis (whooping cough) at multiple schools in Chambers County.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Chambers County, with a population of 34 215 residents, is located in the east-central portion of the US state of Alabama (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chambers_County,_Alabama). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] New South Wales, Australia\nDate: Thu 4 May 2017 8:49 AM\nSource: Northern Star [edited]\nhttps://www.northernstar.com.au/news/vaccinate-now-37-cases-of-whooping-cough-in-a-week/3173820/\n\n\nA local public health spokesperson said the recent spike in whooping cough cases on the Northern Rivers was a continuation of a worrying trend. This year [2017] 79 cases of whooping cough were confirmed during the month of April in the Northern NSW Local Health District, according to statistics from the NSW Department of Health. In 2016 this number was 77, in 2015 it was 8, just 3 in 2014 and 4 cases in 2013.\n\nFrom the figures the current spike was no surprise to the North Coast Public Health Unit, which anticipated a threat of the infection, acting director of public health, Greg Bell, said: \"Months April-May hold a real threat but last year [2016] cases dropped off as quickly as they rose,\" Mr Bell said.\n\nThe North Coast Public Health Unit is asking parents to immunize their children against preventable diseases after a spike in cases of the potentially deadly whooping cough disease. Bell said there had been 37 whooping cough notifications on the North Coast in the past week [week of Sun 23 Apr 2017], more than double that in the previous week [week of Sun 16 Apr 2017].\n\nMr Bell said the North Coast experienced a similar spike in whooping cough cases leading into winter last year [2016]. He said persistent low vaccination levels in some parts of Northern NSW was worrying, given that free vaccination is available to all parents. Whooping cough vaccination is valuable in preventing severe infection in infants and toddlers, and if unvaccinated children are infected they are at high risk of severe disease. \"It must be remembered that prior to the NSW Government introducing free antenatal whooping cough vaccinations in 2015, 4 infants had died in the preceding 6 years,\" Mr Bell said. \"All pregnant women are urged to have the free whooping cough vaccine during their 3rd trimester, preferably at 28 weeks, to provide optimal protection to their infants.\"\n\nPositive health interventions, such as vaccination, in the 1st 5 years of a child's life are vitally important in laying the foundation for a healthy and fulfilling life.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Northern Rivers is one of 14 regions of the Australian state of New South Wales (NSW); it is located in the northern portion of NSW, on the border with the state of Queensland to the north and the Pacific Coast to the east; at its most northern point, Northern Rivers is 102 km (63 mi) south east of Brisbane, the Queensland capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Rivers). A map of Australia can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186. - Mod.ML\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551 and my colleague Mod.LL's comments in Pertussis - USA (06) 20160917.4495935. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186.]\nSee {"archive_id": "5085227", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (05): New Zealand, USA, Australia, Spain", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5085227", "date": "2017-05-06 12:15:07", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (03): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Kansas, USA\nDate: Thu 27 Apr 2017 10:58 pm\nSource: Parsonssun.com [edited]\nhttp://www.parsonssun.com/news/article_015be532-2bc7-11e7-a026-dbbd7aa1e4fd.html\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases in Labette County has grown to 6, with 2 more suspected cases awaiting test results, so the Kansas Department of Health and Environment [KDHE] considers it an outbreak.\n\nAn outbreak is seeing more cases of a certain illness than health care professionals would on a normal day, so Public Health of Labette County administrator Debbi Baugher said one case of whooping cough, or pertussis, could be considered an outbreak. But with the potential for 8 cases in students, KDHE decided this week [week of Sun 22 Apr 2017] to declare an outbreak. Baugher said health department personnel are tracking the cases to find connections among patients and try to find the source.\n\nThe disease was 1st found in a high school student, but most of the recent victims are from middle-school age students at Meadow View Grade School. Baugher said a 4 month old infant [had been] admitted to Labette Health with pertussis. A family member who attends Labette County High School and had been exposed to the disease was in the presence of the infant. The infant was born with respiratory issues and was too young to be fully vaccinated.\n\nTesting continues for suspected cases, but results have been slow to come back. Baugher said her department worked with KDHE, where cultures are tested, and arranged to reduce that delay for those who get the pertussis test at the hospital's lab. Baugher said the tests had been returning in 5 to 6 days. \"If they take a 5-day treatment they're already done with the treatment before we know what caused it,\" Baugher said. Because of the outbreak, KDHE has agreed to test cultures immediately when the hospital lab calls ahead. \"As soon as they get it they test it, so we have a much shorter turn-around time. So we cut it about in half.\"\n\nBaugher said as soon as the health department is able to connect the cases, KDHE will quit testing. At that point, if a patient presents at a doctor's office with symptoms, he or she is given a 5-day dose of antibiotic. \"Right now they still want to test because we don't quite have the connections,\" Baugher said.\n\n[byline: Ray Nolting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Labette County, with a population of 21 607 residents, is located in the south eastern portion of the US state of Kansas; its most populous city is Parsons (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labette_County,_Kansas). A map of the US can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky, USA\nDate: Fri 28 Apr 2017 7:27 PM EDT\nSource: WLWT [edited]\nhttp://www.wlwt.com/article/19-whooping-cough-cases-reported-in-grant-county-schools/9577025\n\n\nFor a 3rd time in 7 years, whooping cough is showing up in greater numbers than usual in Northern Kentucky. The disease has moved through several schools in Grant County this week [week of Sun 22 Apr 2017]. As the number of cases grows, so does concern. Those in charge of running Grant County schools are putting the word out to parents Friday night [28 April 2017] about pertussis.\n\nAs of mid-afternoon Friday [28 Apr 2017, presumably. - Mod.SH], there were 25 cases in Grant County, according to the Northern Kentucky Health Department. \"The vast majority are in Grant County schools,\" said Emily Wherle, a spokeswoman for the health department. Most of the 19 cases in 4 of the 6 Grant County schools were concentrated in the high school.\n\nGrant County counted 5 cases of whooping cough during all of 2016. As of March 23 this year [2017], there were 5 times that number. There are 3800 students in the district.\n\nAs of [Fri 28 Apr 2017], the state health department had not labeled the increased instances of whooping cough an outbreak. The operative phrase was \"a spike in cases\". Howe said there is information on the school district's website. \"We'd like to see this wrapped up and out of our district and out of our community as soon as possible,\" said Howe.\n\nFree vaccines are available for those who meet certain criteria. To learn whether you quality, call the Northern Kentucky Health Department at 859-363-2071.\n\n[byline: John London]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County, with a population of 24 662 residents, is located in the north-central portion of the US state of Kentucky; Grant County is included in the Cincinnati (Ohio)-Middletown (Ohio) Metropolitan Statistical Area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grant_County,_Kentucky). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Wisconsin, USA\nDate: Wed 3 May 2017\nSource: Star Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.starjournalnow.com/2017/05/03/pertussis-in-the-northwoods-again/#_\n\n\nThe Oneida County Health Department (OCHD) has reported 4 lab-confirmed cases of pertussis at Three Lakes Elementary School. The OCHD is working with the Three Lakes School District, the Wisconsin Department of Health Services and community health care providers to prevent the spread of pertussis, also known as whooping cough.\n\nFor more information, call the OCHD at 715-369-6111.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oneida County, with a population of 35 998 residents, is located in the north-central portion of the US state of Wisconsin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oneida_County,_Wisconsin). Three Lakes Elementary School is located in the town of Three Lakes, Wisconsin, which has a population of 2339 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Lakes,_Wisconsin). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Alabama, USA\nDate: Thu 4 May 2017 3:12 pm EDT\nSource: WTVM [edited]\nhttp://www.wtvm.com/story/35345092/whooping-cough-outbreak-reported-at-chambers-county-schools\n\n\nThe Alabama Department of Public Health's Immunization Division is investigating an outbreak of 6 laboratory-confirmed cases of pertussis (whooping cough) at multiple schools in Chambers County.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Chambers County, with a population of 34 215 residents, is located in the east-central portion of the US state of Alabama (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chambers_County,_Alabama). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] New South Wales, Australia\nDate: Thu 4 May 2017 8:49 AM\nSource: Northern Star [edited]\nhttps://www.northernstar.com.au/news/vaccinate-now-37-cases-of-whooping-cough-in-a-week/3173820/\n\n\nA local public health spokesperson said the recent spike in whooping cough cases on the Northern Rivers was a continuation of a worrying trend. This year [2017] 79 cases of whooping cough were confirmed during the month of April in the Northern NSW Local Health District, according to statistics from the NSW Department of Health. In 2016 this number was 77, in 2015 it was 8, just 3 in 2014 and 4 cases in 2013.\n\nFrom the figures the current spike was no surprise to the North Coast Public Health Unit, which anticipated a threat of the infection, acting director of public health, Greg Bell, said: \"Months April-May hold a real threat but last year [2016] cases dropped off as quickly as they rose,\" Mr Bell said.\n\nThe North Coast Public Health Unit is asking parents to immunize their children against preventable diseases after a spike in cases of the potentially deadly whooping cough disease. Bell said there had been 37 whooping cough notifications on the North Coast in the past week [week of Sun 23 Apr 2017], more than double that in the previous week [week of Sun 16 Apr 2017].\n\nMr Bell said the North Coast experienced a similar spike in whooping cough cases leading into winter last year [2016]. He said persistent low vaccination levels in some parts of Northern NSW was worrying, given that free vaccination is available to all parents. Whooping cough vaccination is valuable in preventing severe infection in infants and toddlers, and if unvaccinated children are infected they are at high risk of severe disease. \"It must be remembered that prior to the NSW Government introducing free antenatal whooping cough vaccinations in 2015, 4 infants had died in the preceding 6 years,\" Mr Bell said. \"All pregnant women are urged to have the free whooping cough vaccine during their 3rd trimester, preferably at 28 weeks, to provide optimal protection to their infants.\"\n\nPositive health interventions, such as vaccination, in the 1st 5 years of a child's life are vitally important in laying the foundation for a healthy and fulfilling life.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Northern Rivers is one of 14 regions of the Australian state of New South Wales (NSW); it is located in the northern portion of NSW, on the border with the state of Queensland to the north and the Pacific Coast to the east; at its most northern point, Northern Rivers is 102 km (63 mi) south east of Brisbane, the Queensland capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Rivers). A map of Australia can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186. - Mod.ML\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551 and my colleague Mod.LL's comments in Pertussis - USA (06) 20160917.4495935. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186.]\nSee {"archive_id": "5048581", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (04): Canada, USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5048581", "date": "2017-05-06 12:15:07", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (03): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Kansas, USA\nDate: Thu 27 Apr 2017 10:58 pm\nSource: Parsonssun.com [edited]\nhttp://www.parsonssun.com/news/article_015be532-2bc7-11e7-a026-dbbd7aa1e4fd.html\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases in Labette County has grown to 6, with 2 more suspected cases awaiting test results, so the Kansas Department of Health and Environment [KDHE] considers it an outbreak.\n\nAn outbreak is seeing more cases of a certain illness than health care professionals would on a normal day, so Public Health of Labette County administrator Debbi Baugher said one case of whooping cough, or pertussis, could be considered an outbreak. But with the potential for 8 cases in students, KDHE decided this week [week of Sun 22 Apr 2017] to declare an outbreak. Baugher said health department personnel are tracking the cases to find connections among patients and try to find the source.\n\nThe disease was 1st found in a high school student, but most of the recent victims are from middle-school age students at Meadow View Grade School. Baugher said a 4 month old infant [had been] admitted to Labette Health with pertussis. A family member who attends Labette County High School and had been exposed to the disease was in the presence of the infant. The infant was born with respiratory issues and was too young to be fully vaccinated.\n\nTesting continues for suspected cases, but results have been slow to come back. Baugher said her department worked with KDHE, where cultures are tested, and arranged to reduce that delay for those who get the pertussis test at the hospital's lab. Baugher said the tests had been returning in 5 to 6 days. \"If they take a 5-day treatment they're already done with the treatment before we know what caused it,\" Baugher said. Because of the outbreak, KDHE has agreed to test cultures immediately when the hospital lab calls ahead. \"As soon as they get it they test it, so we have a much shorter turn-around time. So we cut it about in half.\"\n\nBaugher said as soon as the health department is able to connect the cases, KDHE will quit testing. At that point, if a patient presents at a doctor's office with symptoms, he or she is given a 5-day dose of antibiotic. \"Right now they still want to test because we don't quite have the connections,\" Baugher said.\n\n[byline: Ray Nolting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Labette County, with a population of 21 607 residents, is located in the south eastern portion of the US state of Kansas; its most populous city is Parsons (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labette_County,_Kansas). {"archive_id": "5017287", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (03): USA, Australia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5017287", "date": "2017-05-06 12:15:07", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (03): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Kansas, USA\nDate: Thu 27 Apr 2017 10:58 pm\nSource: Parsonssun.com [edited]\nhttp://www.parsonssun.com/news/article_015be532-2bc7-11e7-a026-dbbd7aa1e4fd.html\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases in Labette County has grown to 6, with 2 more suspected cases awaiting test results, so the Kansas Department of Health and Environment [KDHE] considers it an outbreak.\n\nAn outbreak is seeing more cases of a certain illness than health care professionals would on a normal day, so Public Health of Labette County administrator Debbi Baugher said one case of whooping cough, or pertussis, could be considered an outbreak. But with the potential for 8 cases in students, KDHE decided this week [week of Sun 22 Apr 2017] to declare an outbreak. Baugher said health department personnel are tracking the cases to find connections among patients and try to find the source.\n\nThe disease was 1st found in a high school student, but most of the recent victims are from middle-school age students at Meadow View Grade School. Baugher said a 4 month old infant [had been] admitted to Labette Health with pertussis. A family member who attends Labette County High School and had been exposed to the disease was in the presence of the infant. The infant was born with respiratory issues and was too young to be fully vaccinated.\n\nTesting continues for suspected cases, but results have been slow to come back. Baugher said her department worked with KDHE, where cultures are tested, and arranged to reduce that delay for those who get the pertussis test at the hospital's lab. Baugher said the tests had been returning in 5 to 6 days. \"If they take a 5-day treatment they're already done with the treatment before we know what caused it,\" Baugher said. Because of the outbreak, KDHE has agreed to test cultures immediately when the hospital lab calls ahead. \"As soon as they get it they test it, so we have a much shorter turn-around time. So we cut it about in half.\"\n\nBaugher said as soon as the health department is able to connect the cases, KDHE will quit testing. At that point, if a patient presents at a doctor's office with symptoms, he or she is given a 5-day dose of antibiotic. \"Right now they still want to test because we don't quite have the connections,\" Baugher said.\n\n[byline: Ray Nolting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Labette County, with a population of 21 607 residents, is located in the south eastern portion of the US state of Kansas; its most populous city is Parsons (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labette_County,_Kansas). A map of the US can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky, USA\nDate: Fri 28 Apr 2017 7:27 PM EDT\nSource: WLWT [edited]\nhttp://www.wlwt.com/article/19-whooping-cough-cases-reported-in-grant-county-schools/9577025\n\n\nFor a 3rd time in 7 years, whooping cough is showing up in greater numbers than usual in Northern Kentucky. The disease has moved through several schools in Grant County this week [week of Sun 22 Apr 2017]. As the number of cases grows, so does concern. Those in charge of running Grant County schools are putting the word out to parents Friday night [28 April 2017] about pertussis.\n\nAs of mid-afternoon Friday [28 Apr 2017, presumably. - Mod.SH], there were 25 cases in Grant County, according to the Northern Kentucky Health Department. \"The vast majority are in Grant County schools,\" said Emily Wherle, a spokeswoman for the health department. Most of the 19 cases in 4 of the 6 Grant County schools were concentrated in the high school.\n\nGrant County counted 5 cases of whooping cough during all of 2016. As of March 23 this year [2017], there were 5 times that number. There are 3800 students in the district.\n\nAs of [Fri 28 Apr 2017], the state health department had not labeled the increased instances of whooping cough an outbreak. The operative phrase was \"a spike in cases\". Howe said there is information on the school district's website. \"We'd like to see this wrapped up and out of our district and out of our community as soon as possible,\" said Howe.\n\nFree vaccines are available for those who meet certain criteria. To learn whether you quality, call the Northern Kentucky Health Department at 859-363-2071.\n\n[byline: John London]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County, with a population of 24 662 residents, is located in the north-central portion of the US state of Kentucky; Grant County is included in the Cincinnati (Ohio)-Middletown (Ohio) Metropolitan Statistical Area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grant_County,_Kentucky). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[3] Wisconsin, USA\nDate: Wed 3 May 2017\nSource: Star Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.starjournalnow.com/2017/05/03/pertussis-in-the-northwoods-again/#_\n\n\nThe Oneida County Health Department (OCHD) has reported 4 lab-confirmed cases of pertussis at Three Lakes Elementary School. The OCHD is working with the Three Lakes School District, the Wisconsin Department of Health Services and community health care providers to prevent the spread of pertussis, also known as whooping cough.\n\nFor more information, call the OCHD at 715-369-6111.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oneida County, with a population of 35 998 residents, is located in the north-central portion of the US state of Wisconsin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oneida_County,_Wisconsin). Three Lakes Elementary School is located in the town of Three Lakes, Wisconsin, which has a population of 2339 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Lakes,_Wisconsin). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[4] Alabama, USA\nDate: Thu 4 May 2017 3:12 pm EDT\nSource: WTVM [edited]\nhttp://www.wtvm.com/story/35345092/whooping-cough-outbreak-reported-at-chambers-county-schools\n\n\nThe Alabama Department of Public Health's Immunization Division is investigating an outbreak of 6 laboratory-confirmed cases of pertussis (whooping cough) at multiple schools in Chambers County.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Chambers County, with a population of 34 215 residents, is located in the east-central portion of the US state of Alabama (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chambers_County,_Alabama). - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[5] New South Wales, Australia\nDate: Thu 4 May 2017 8:49 AM\nSource: Northern Star [edited]\nhttps://www.northernstar.com.au/news/vaccinate-now-37-cases-of-whooping-cough-in-a-week/3173820/\n\n\nA local public health spokesperson said the recent spike in whooping cough cases on the Northern Rivers was a continuation of a worrying trend. This year [2017] 79 cases of whooping cough were confirmed during the month of April in the Northern NSW Local Health District, according to statistics from the NSW Department of Health. In 2016 this number was 77, in 2015 it was 8, just 3 in 2014 and 4 cases in 2013.\n\nFrom the figures the current spike was no surprise to the North Coast Public Health Unit, which anticipated a threat of the infection, acting director of public health, Greg Bell, said: \"Months April-May hold a real threat but last year [2016] cases dropped off as quickly as they rose,\" Mr Bell said.\n\nThe North Coast Public Health Unit is asking parents to immunize their children against preventable diseases after a spike in cases of the potentially deadly whooping cough disease. Bell said there had been 37 whooping cough notifications on the North Coast in the past week [week of Sun 23 Apr 2017], more than double that in the previous week [week of Sun 16 Apr 2017].\n\nMr Bell said the North Coast experienced a similar spike in whooping cough cases leading into winter last year [2016]. He said persistent low vaccination levels in some parts of Northern NSW was worrying, given that free vaccination is available to all parents. Whooping cough vaccination is valuable in preventing severe infection in infants and toddlers, and if unvaccinated children are infected they are at high risk of severe disease. \"It must be remembered that prior to the NSW Government introducing free antenatal whooping cough vaccinations in 2015, 4 infants had died in the preceding 6 years,\" Mr Bell said. \"All pregnant women are urged to have the free whooping cough vaccine during their 3rd trimester, preferably at 28 weeks, to provide optimal protection to their infants.\"\n\nPositive health interventions, such as vaccination, in the 1st 5 years of a child's life are vitally important in laying the foundation for a healthy and fulfilling life.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Northern Rivers is one of 14 regions of the Australian state of New South Wales (NSW); it is located in the northern portion of NSW, on the border with the state of Queensland to the north and the Pacific Coast to the east; at its most northern point, Northern Rivers is 102 km (63 mi) south east of Brisbane, the Queensland capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Rivers). A map of Australia can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186. - Mod.ML\n\n[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA: (CA) fatal {"archive_id": "4971327", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis (02): USA, maternal immunization", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4971327", "date": "2017-05-06 12:15:07", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS (03): USA, AUSTRALIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Kansas, USA\nDate: Thu 27 Apr 2017 10:58 pm\nSource: Parsonssun.com [edited]\nhttp://www.parsonssun.com/news/article_015be532-2bc7-11e7-a026-dbbd7aa1e4fd.html\n\n\nThe number of whooping cough cases in Labette County has grown to 6, with 2 more suspected cases awaiting test results, so the Kansas Department of Health and Environment [KDHE] considers it an outbreak.\n\nAn outbreak is seeing more cases of a certain illness than health care professionals would on a normal day, so Public Health of Labette County administrator Debbi Baugher said one case of whooping cough, or pertussis, could be considered an outbreak. But with the potential for 8 cases in students, KDHE decided this week [week of Sun 22 Apr 2017] to declare an outbreak. Baugher said health department personnel are tracking the cases to find connections among patients and try to find the source.\n\nThe disease was 1st found in a high school student, but most of the recent victims are from middle-school age students at Meadow View Grade School. Baugher said a 4 month old infant [had been] admitted to Labette Health with pertussis. A family member who attends Labette County High School and had been exposed to the disease was in the presence of the infant. The infant was born with respiratory issues and was too young to be fully vaccinated.\n\nTesting continues for suspected cases, but results have been slow to come back. Baugher said her department worked with KDHE, where cultures are tested, and arranged to reduce that delay for those who get the pertussis test at the hospital's lab. Baugher said the tests had been returning in 5 to 6 days. \"If they take a 5-day treatment they're already done with the treatment before we know what caused it,\" Baugher said. Because of the outbreak, KDHE has agreed to test cultures immediately when the hospital lab calls ahead. \"As soon as they get it they test it, so we have a much shorter turn-around time. So we cut it about in half.\"\n\nBaugher said as soon as the health department is able to connect the cases, KDHE will quit testing. At that point, if a patient presents at a doctor's office with symptoms, he or she is given a 5-day dose of antibiotic. \"Right now they still want to test because we don't quite have the connections,\" Baugher said.\n\n[byline: Ray Nolting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Labette County, with a population of 21 607 residents, is located in the south eastern portion of the US state of Kansas; its most populous city is Parsons (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labette_County,_Kansas). A map of the US can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.ML]\n\n******\n[2] Kentucky, USA\nDate: Fri 28 Apr 2017 7:27 PM EDT\nSource: WLWT [edited]\nhttp://www.wlwt.com/article/19-whooping-cough-cases-reported-in-grant-county-schools/9577025\n\n\nFor a 3rd time in 7 years, whooping cough is showing up in greater numbers than usual in Northern Kentucky.
