{"archive_id": "4902867", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis update (01): Viet Nam, New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4902867", "date": "2016-10-17 15:55:11", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SUDAN: (NORTH DARFUR)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[There is a correction of this report: Pertussis - Sudan: (ND) corr 20161019.4571016. The article below is from October 2015 and it was likely accidentally re-issued by AllAfrica.]\n\nDate: Mon 17 Oct 2016\nSource: allAfrica [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201610170205.html\n\n\nThe North Darfur Ministry of Health has reported that the outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] in El Sereif Beni Hussein locality started in early September [2016]. As of 7 Oct 2016, 323 suspected cases were reported in the locality. The Health Ministry and the WHO are coordinating the response with partners to ensure that daily reporting, proper case management, and effective community mobilisation campaigns take place. A 3-month action plan has been prepared to deal with this outbreak.\n\nThe UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its weekly bulletin that the Health Ministry -with WHO support- sent an investigation team to the locality mid-September. The team collected 13 samples that were sent to the National Public Health laboratory for analysis, 4 of which tested positive for [the pertussis bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_].\n\nDoctors Without Borders/M\u00e9decins Sans Fronti\u00e8res-Spain (MSF-E) initiated case management and a community awareness-raising exercise has been conducted. Preparations are underway to conduct a vaccination campaign for children under 5 in the locality.\n\nPertussis can be prevented by immunization and is part of Sudan's national immunization program.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED reported on pertussis outbreaks in the same area in 2013 and 2015.\n\nMost of the morbidity and mortality of pertussis is in infants, especially those under 6 months of age where most of the mortality occurs in the developed world. The percent of people in North Sudan who are adequately immunized against pertussis is unclear.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest) sometimes with hypoxia-induced (low oxygen) seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea, and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/27297.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (02): (ND) 20151109.3778426\nPertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20151027.3746994\nPertussis - Liberia: (MY) 20150301.3200714\n2013\n----\nPertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20131104.2036595\nPertussis - Afghanistan (02): background 20130103.1478809\nPertussis - Afghanistan: (BD), fatalities 20130101.1477768\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. (03) 20031008.2530\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. 20031003.2488\n.................................................sb/ll/ao/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-10-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equatoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4735420", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (01): (WI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4735420", "date": "2016-10-17 15:55:11", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SUDAN: (NORTH DARFUR)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[There is a correction of this report: Pertussis - Sudan: (ND) corr 20161019.4571016. The article below is from October 2015 and it was likely accidentally re-issued by AllAfrica.]\n\nDate: Mon 17 Oct 2016\nSource: allAfrica [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201610170205.html\n\n\nThe North Darfur Ministry of Health has reported that the outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] in El Sereif Beni Hussein locality started in early September [2016]. As of 7 Oct 2016, 323 suspected cases were reported in the locality. The Health Ministry and the WHO are coordinating the response with partners to ensure that daily reporting, proper case management, and effective community mobilisation campaigns take place. A 3-month action plan has been prepared to deal with this outbreak.\n\nThe UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its weekly bulletin that the Health Ministry -with WHO support- sent an investigation team to the locality mid-September. The team collected 13 samples that were sent to the National Public Health laboratory for analysis, 4 of which tested positive for [the pertussis bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_].\n\nDoctors Without Borders/M\u00e9decins Sans Fronti\u00e8res-Spain (MSF-E) initiated case management and a community awareness-raising exercise has been conducted. Preparations are underway to conduct a vaccination campaign for children under 5 in the locality.\n\nPertussis can be prevented by immunization and is part of Sudan's national immunization program.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED reported on pertussis outbreaks in the same area in 2013 and 2015.\n\nMost of the morbidity and mortality of pertussis is in infants, especially those under 6 months of age where most of the mortality occurs in the developed world. The percent of people in North Sudan who are adequately immunized against pertussis is unclear.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest) sometimes with hypoxia-induced (low oxygen) seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea, and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/27297.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (02): (ND) 20151109.3778426\nPertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20151027.3746994\nPertussis - Liberia: (MY) 20150301.3200714\n2013\n----\nPertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20131104.2036595\nPertussis - Afghanistan (02): background 20130103.1478809\nPertussis - Afghanistan: (BD), fatalities 20130101.1477768\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. The article below is from October 2015 and it was likely accidentally re-issued by AllAfrica.]\n\nDate: Mon 17 Oct 2016\nSource: allAfrica [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201610170205.html\n\n\nThe North Darfur Ministry of Health has reported that the outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] in El Sereif Beni Hussein locality started in early September [2016]. As of 7 Oct 2016, 323 suspected cases were reported in the locality. The Health Ministry and the WHO are coordinating the response with partners to ensure that daily reporting, proper case management, and effective community mobilisation campaigns take place. A 3-month action plan has been prepared to deal with this outbreak.\n\nThe UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its weekly bulletin that the Health Ministry -with WHO support- sent an investigation team to the locality mid-September. The team collected 13 samples that were sent to the National Public Health laboratory for analysis, 4 of which tested positive for [the pertussis bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_].\n\nDoctors Without Borders/M\u00e9decins Sans Fronti\u00e8res-Spain (MSF-E) initiated case management and a community awareness-raising exercise has been conducted. Preparations are underway to conduct a vaccination campaign for children under 5 in the locality.\n\nPertussis can be prevented by immunization and is part of Sudan's national immunization program.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED reported on pertussis outbreaks in the same area in 2013 and 2015.\n\nMost of the morbidity and mortality of pertussis is in infants, especially those under 6 months of age where most of the mortality occurs in the developed world. The percent of people in North Sudan who are adequately immunized against pertussis is unclear.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest) sometimes with hypoxia-induced (low oxygen) seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea, and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/27297.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (02): (ND) 20151109.3778426\nPertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20151027.3746994\nPertussis - Liberia: (MY) 20150301.3200714\n2013\n----\nPertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20131104.2036595\nPertussis - Afghanistan (02): background 20130103.1478809\nPertussis - Afghanistan: (BD), fatalities 20130101.1477768\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. As of 7 Oct 2016, 323 suspected cases were reported in the locality. The Health Ministry and the WHO are coordinating the response with partners to ensure that daily reporting, proper case management, and effective community mobilisation campaigns take place. A 3-month action plan has been prepared to deal with this outbreak.\n\nThe UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its weekly bulletin that the Health Ministry -with WHO support- sent an investigation team to the locality mid-September. The team collected 13 samples that were sent to the National Public Health laboratory for analysis, 4 of which tested positive for [the pertussis bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_].\n\nDoctors Without Borders/M\u00e9decins Sans Fronti\u00e8res-Spain (MSF-E) initiated case management and a community awareness-raising exercise has been conducted. The percent of people in North Sudan who are adequately immunized against pertussis is unclear.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest) sometimes with hypoxia-induced (low oxygen) seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea, and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/27297.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (02): (ND) 20151109.3778426\nPertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20151027.3746994\nPertussis - Liberia: (MY) 20150301.3200714\n2013\n----\nPertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20131104.2036595\nPertussis - Afghanistan (02): background 20130103.1478809\nPertussis - Afghanistan: (BD), fatalities 20130101.1477768\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. (03) 20031008.2530\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. 20031003.2488\n.................................................sb/ll/ao/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-10-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equatoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4495935", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4495935", "date": "2016-04-03 18:45:14", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (02): (NEW YORK)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 Apr 2016\nSource: WAMC [edited]\nhttp://wamc.org/post/winter-brought-high-number-pertussis-cases-dutchess#stream/0\n\n\nThe Dutchess County Department of Behavioral & Community Health in mid-February [20176] reported an increase in cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, particularly among adolescents, with more than 20 cases since [1 Jan 2016]. As Dutchess County's Director of Communicable Disease Control Linda Squires says, the number then continued to rise.\n\n\"From between [1 Jan 2016] through the current date, we've had a total of 47 confirmed cases of pertussis but, fortunately, we are seeing a decline in the past 2 weeks, with only 5 cases reported since [15 Mar 2016],\" says Squires. While the numbers of new cases have waned in the past few weeks, health experts say the recurrence of the disease, in general, is puzzling, and urge vaccination.\n\nAccording to the New York State Department of Health, pertussis is a serious lung infection caused by bacteria. It is also very contagious and causes coughing fits. \"Well, pertussis incidents sort of wax and wane over time and we do see clusters that are not really explainable,\" says Squires. \"In 2011 we had 100 cases reported, but between 2012 and 2014 we've probably stayed under 20-30 cases each of those years, so it's variable.\"\n\nDr Stuart Feinstein is an infectious disease specialist at Vassar Brothers Medical Center in Poughkeepsie and with Health Quest Medical Practice. \"It's just not something that seems to go away. It seems like every time they get it snuffed out, it's popping up somewhere,\" says Dr Feinstein. \"It's been unusual.\"\n\nSquires underscores the importance of vaccinating against pertussis. \"Vaccinations are extremely important in reducing the risk and the severity of pertussis,\" says Squires. \"The recommendations begin at 2 months of age. And now there's Tdap [tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis] vaccine, which is a booster for adolescents and adults, and is particularly recommended for those persons who are going to be around infants younger than 2 months, so that you could almost cocoon them against pertussis because they cannot be vaccinated themselves.\"\n\nDr Feinstein agrees and says the fluctuation in annual cases defies easy explanation. \"I think it's very hard to say why the fluctuation in cases occurs. I know there is certainly an effort, a successful effort, to vaccinate, re-vaccinate adults, to give the Tdap vaccine, and to keep the children on tabs,\" Dr Feinstein says. \"It's something that's never been totally wiped out. I think in the last 10 years, there's been waves of it back and forth.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Squires says her department a few weeks ago sent an advisory to area health care providers to be on alert for screening and treatment of pertussis. She says the cases in Dutchess County were reported as far south as Beacon and as far north as the Rhinebeck/Red Hook area. Other whooping cough cases since the new year [2016] were seen in Orange and Sullivan Counties.\n\n[Byline: Allison Dunne]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of pertussis, please see my colleague moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts below.\n\nThe state of New York can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1181. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-york-county-map.gif.\nDutchess, Orange, and Sullivan Counties are located in the mid-Hudson Region of the Hudson Valley and, with the Lower Hudson Region, is considered part of the Downstate New York region due to its geographical and cultural proximity to New York City (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hudson_Valley). - As Dutchess County's Director of Communicable Disease Control Linda Squires says, the number then continued to rise.\n\n\"From between [1 Jan 2016] through the current date, we've had a total of 47 confirmed cases of pertussis but, fortunately, we are seeing a decline in the past 2 weeks, with only 5 cases reported since [15 Mar 2016],\" says Squires. While the numbers of new cases have waned in the past few weeks, health experts say the recurrence of the disease, in general, is puzzling, and urge vaccination.\n\nAccording to the New York State Department of Health, pertussis is a serious lung infection caused by bacteria. It is also very contagious and causes coughing fits. \"Well, pertussis incidents sort of wax and wane over time and we do see clusters that are not really explainable,\" says Squires. \"In 2011 we had 100 cases reported, but between 2012 and 2014 we've probably stayed under 20-30 cases each of those years, so it's variable.\"\n\nDr Stuart Feinstein is an infectious disease specialist at Vassar Brothers Medical Center in Poughkeepsie and with Health Quest Medical Practice. \"It's just not something that seems to go away. It seems like every time they get it snuffed out, it's popping up somewhere,\" says Dr Feinstein. \"It's been unusual.\"\n\nSquires underscores the importance of vaccinating against pertussis. \"Vaccinations are extremely important in reducing the risk and the severity of pertussis,\" says Squires. \"The recommendations begin at 2 months of age. I know there is certainly an effort, a successful effort, to vaccinate, re-vaccinate adults, to give the Tdap vaccine, and to keep the children on tabs,\" Dr Feinstein says. \"It's something that's never been totally wiped out. I think in the last 10 years, there's been waves of it back and forth.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Squires says her department a few weeks ago sent an advisory to area health care providers to be on alert for screening and treatment of pertussis. She says the cases in Dutchess County were reported as far south as Beacon and as far north as the Rhinebeck/Red Hook area. USA (04): (CA) increasing incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4315517", "date": "2016-04-03 18:45:14", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (02): (NEW YORK)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 Apr 2016\nSource: WAMC [edited]\nhttp://wamc.org/post/winter-brought-high-number-pertussis-cases-dutchess#stream/0\n\n\nThe Dutchess County Department of Behavioral & Community Health in mid-February [20176] reported an increase in cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, particularly among adolescents, with more than 20 cases since [1 Jan 2016]. As Dutchess County's Director of Communicable Disease Control Linda Squires says, the number then continued to rise.\n\n\"From between [1 Jan 2016] through the current date, we've had a total of 47 confirmed cases of pertussis but, fortunately, we are seeing a decline in the past 2 weeks, with only 5 cases reported since [15 Mar 2016],\" says Squires. While the numbers of new cases have waned in the past few weeks, health experts say the recurrence of the disease, in general, is puzzling, and urge vaccination.\n\nAccording to the New York State Department of Health, pertussis is a serious lung infection caused by bacteria. It is also very contagious and causes coughing fits. \"Well, pertussis incidents sort of wax and wane over time and we do see clusters that are not really explainable,\" says Squires. \"In 2011 we had 100 cases reported, but between 2012 and 2014 we've probably stayed under 20-30 cases each of those years, so it's variable.\"\n\nDr Stuart Feinstein is an infectious disease specialist at Vassar Brothers Medical Center in Poughkeepsie and with Health Quest Medical Practice. \"It's just not something that seems to go away. It seems like every time they get it snuffed out, it's popping up somewhere,\" says Dr Feinstein. \"It's been unusual.\"\n\nSquires underscores the importance of vaccinating against pertussis. \"Vaccinations are extremely important in reducing the risk and the severity of pertussis,\" says Squires. \"The recommendations begin at 2 months of age. And now there's Tdap [tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis] vaccine, which is a booster for adolescents and adults, and is particularly recommended for those persons who are going to be around infants younger than 2 months, so that you could almost cocoon them against pertussis because they cannot be vaccinated themselves.\"\n\nDr Feinstein agrees and says the fluctuation in annual cases defies easy explanation. \"I think it's very hard to say why the fluctuation in cases occurs. I know there is certainly an effort, a successful effort, to vaccinate, re-vaccinate adults, to give the Tdap vaccine, and to keep the children on tabs,\" Dr Feinstein says. \"It's something that's never been totally wiped out. I think in the last 10 years, there's been waves of it back and forth.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Squires says her department a few weeks ago sent an advisory to area health care providers to be on alert for screening and treatment of pertussis. She says the cases in Dutchess County were reported as far south as Beacon and as far north as the Rhinebeck/Red Hook area. Other whooping cough cases since the new year [2016] were seen in Orange and Sullivan Counties.\n\n[Byline: Allison Dunne]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of pertussis, please see my colleague moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts below.\n\nThe state of New York can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1181. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-york-county-map.gif.\nDutchess, Orange, and Sullivan Counties are located in the mid-Hudson Region of the Hudson Valley and, with the Lower Hudson Region, is considered part of the Downstate New York region due to its geographical and cultural proximity to New York City (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hudson_Valley). - USA (02) 20150116.3094367\nPertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-01-01 00:00:00", "2016-01-01 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poughkeepsie", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dutchess County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4101954", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Measles, pertussis - Nigeria: (JI) fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4101954", "date": "2015-12-17 11:01:34", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2015\nSource: Health Quality and Safety Commission New Zealand [edited]\nhttp://www.nzdoctor.co.nz/un-doctored/2015/december-2015/16/Immunisation-against-whooping-cough-crucial-in-pregnancy-new-report.aspx\n\n\nA new report discusses how rates of whooping cough can be reduced by immunizing women during pregnancy and improving education about the illness. The report Mortality and morbidity of pertussis in children and young people in New Zealand: Special Report 2002-2014, was released today by the Child and Youth Mortality Review Committee (CYMRC). It shows rates of whooping cough (also known as pertussis) in New Zealand using data from 2002-2014, for children and young people under the age of 25.\n\nPertussis is a contagious disease, characterised by long coughing episodes. It can be very serious and in some cases fatal. Nearly 13 000 cases of whooping cough were recorded, an average of 992 cases per year, including 8 deaths. 7 deaths were in infants under 3 months old. There were 1515 hospital admissions and more than 75 percent were for infants under 6 months old.\n\nDr Felicity Dumble, CYMRC chair, says that among the easiest and safest ways to prevent or reduce the severity of the illness is to immunize mothers during pregnancy. \"All pregnant women should receive a booster shot in their 3rd trimester and should be given information by their GP or lead maternity carer about where and how to get one. Many women don't know a booster shot is required,\" says Dr Dumble.\n\nImmunization during pregnancy is safe for mothers and babies and is now funded during the 3rd trimester.\n\n\"GPs and midwives play an important part in education about whooping cough, so it is crucial they take the lead in informing pregnant women about the need for immunization.\"\n\nThe Committee endorses the work the Ministry of Health is doing in this area, including the release of new 'let's talk about immunisation' resources and a focus on whooping cough and influenza immunisation during 2016's National Immunisation Week.\n\nThe report also makes a number of other recommendations to reduce the rates and impact of whooping cough.\n\nRecommendations include:\n- giving pregnant women whooping cough booster shots should be a quality improvement measure or target for DHBs [district health boards]\n- booster shots given to pregnant women should be captured in the National Immunization Register and recorded as part of a baby's immunization record\n- the Ministry of Health should develop education resources for pregnant women, lead maternity carers and other health care providers on the benefits of immunization against whooping cough during pregnancy (work on this is already underway)\n- DHB-funded community antenatal education classes should include information about the need for a whooping cough booster shot in the 3rd trimester\n- when confirming a woman is pregnant, their GP or other provider should put in place a plan to ensure they are recalled for a pertussis booster shot in their 3rd trimester\n- a national system should be developed that enables general practices, lead maternity carers and other immunization providers to communicate with each other on whooping cough booster shots given to pregnant women\n- lead maternity carers and other health care providers should ensure pregnant women are aware that they need a whooping cough booster in their 3rd trimester and they know where to go to get it\n- pregnant women should be offered whooping cough booster shots in a wide range of settings, including general practice, secondary care and outreach community settings, to reduce access barriers for hard-to-reach groups.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The full commission report can be found at http://www.hqsc.govt.nz/assets/CYMRC/Publications/pertussis-special-report-Dec-2015.pdf.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest), with seizures induced by hypoxia (low oxygen) usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis -- particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 -- and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and accounted for most of the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Australia (Canberra) New Zealand (South Island) 20150827.3606181\n2012\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand (03): update 20120706.1190855\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\n2011\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\n.................................................sb/ll/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1515-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canberra", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4097729", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (03): (NS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4097729", "date": "2015-12-17 11:01:34", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2015\nSource: Health Quality and Safety Commission New Zealand [edited]\nhttp://www.nzdoctor.co.nz/un-doctored/2015/december-2015/16/Immunisation-against-whooping-cough-crucial-in-pregnancy-new-report.aspx\n\n\nA new report discusses how rates of whooping cough can be reduced by immunizing women during pregnancy and improving education about the illness. The report Mortality and morbidity of pertussis in children and young people in New Zealand: Special Report 2002-2014, was released today by the Child and Youth Mortality Review Committee (CYMRC). It shows rates of whooping cough (also known as pertussis) in New Zealand using data from 2002-2014, for children and young people under the age of 25.\n\nPertussis is a contagious disease, characterised by long coughing episodes. It can be very serious and in some cases fatal. Nearly 13 000 cases of whooping cough were recorded, an average of 992 cases per year, including 8 deaths. 7 deaths were in infants under 3 months old. There were 1515 hospital admissions and more than 75 percent were for infants under 6 months old.\n\nDr Felicity Dumble, CYMRC chair, says that among the easiest and safest ways to prevent or reduce the severity of the illness is to immunize mothers during pregnancy. \"All pregnant women should receive a booster shot in their 3rd trimester and should be given information by their GP or lead maternity carer about where and how to get one. Many women don't know a booster shot is required,\" says Dr Dumble.\n\nImmunization during pregnancy is safe for mothers and babies and is now funded during the 3rd trimester.\n\n\"GPs and midwives play an important part in education about whooping cough, so it is crucial they take the lead in informing pregnant women about the need for immunization.\"\n\nThe Committee endorses the work the Ministry of Health is doing in this area, including the release of new 'let's talk about immunisation' resources and a focus on whooping cough and influenza immunisation during 2016's National Immunisation Week.\n\nThe report also makes a number of other recommendations to reduce the rates and impact of whooping cough.\n\nRecommendations include:\n- giving pregnant women whooping cough booster shots should be a quality improvement measure or target for DHBs [district health boards]\n- booster shots given to pregnant women should be captured in the National Immunization Register and recorded as part of a baby's immunization record\n- the Ministry of Health should develop education resources for pregnant women, lead maternity carers and other health care providers on the benefits of immunization against whooping cough during pregnancy (work on this is already underway)\n- DHB-funded community antenatal education classes should include information about the need for a whooping cough booster shot in the 3rd trimester\n- when confirming a woman is pregnant, their GP or other provider should put in place a plan to ensure they are recalled for a pertussis booster shot in their 3rd trimester\n- a national system should be developed that enables general practices, lead maternity carers and other immunization providers to communicate with each other on whooping cough booster shots given to pregnant women\n- lead maternity carers and other health care providers should ensure pregnant women are aware that they need a whooping cough booster in their 3rd trimester and they know where to go to get it\n- pregnant women should be offered whooping cough booster shots in a wide range of settings, including general practice, secondary care and outreach community settings, to reduce access barriers for hard-to-reach groups.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The full commission report can be found at http://www.hqsc.govt.nz/assets/CYMRC/Publications/pertussis-special-report-Dec-2015.pdf.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest), with seizures induced by hypoxia (low oxygen) usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis -- particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 -- and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and accounted for most of the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Australia (Canberra) New Zealand (South Island) 20150827.3606181\n2012\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand (03): update 20120706.1190855\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\n2011\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\n.................................................sb/ll/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1515-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canberra", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4068067", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (02): (NS) vaccine shortage", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4068067", "date": "2015-12-17 11:01:34", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2015\nSource: Health Quality and Safety Commission New Zealand [edited]\nhttp://www.nzdoctor.co.nz/un-doctored/2015/december-2015/16/Immunisation-against-whooping-cough-crucial-in-pregnancy-new-report.aspx\n\n\nA new report discusses how rates of whooping cough can be reduced by immunizing women during pregnancy and improving education about the illness. The report Mortality and morbidity of pertussis in children and young people in New Zealand: Special Report 2002-2014, was released today by the Child and Youth Mortality Review Committee (CYMRC). It shows rates of whooping cough (also known as pertussis) in New Zealand using data from 2002-2014, for children and young people under the age of 25.\n\nPertussis is a contagious disease, characterised by long coughing episodes. It can be very serious and in some cases fatal. Nearly 13 000 cases of whooping cough were recorded, an average of 992 cases per year, including 8 deaths. 7 deaths were in infants under 3 months old. There were 1515 hospital admissions and more than 75 percent were for infants under 6 months old.\n\nDr Felicity Dumble, CYMRC chair, says that among the easiest and safest ways to prevent or reduce the severity of the illness is to immunize mothers during pregnancy. \"All pregnant women should receive a booster shot in their 3rd trimester and should be given information by their GP or lead maternity carer about where and how to get one. Many women don't know a booster shot is required,\" says Dr Dumble.\n\nImmunization during pregnancy is safe for mothers and babies and is now funded during the 3rd trimester.\n\n\"GPs and midwives play an important part in education about whooping cough, so it is crucial they take the lead in informing pregnant women about the need for immunization.\"\n\nThe Committee endorses the work the Ministry of Health is doing in this area, including the release of new 'let's talk about immunisation' resources and a focus on whooping cough and influenza immunisation during 2016's National Immunisation Week.\n\nThe report also makes a number of other recommendations to reduce the rates and impact of whooping cough.\n\nRecommendations include:\n- giving pregnant women whooping cough booster shots should be a quality improvement measure or target for DHBs [district health boards]\n- booster shots given to pregnant women should be captured in the National Immunization Register and recorded as part of a baby's immunization record\n- the Ministry of Health should develop education resources for pregnant women, lead maternity carers and other health care providers on the benefits of immunization against whooping cough during pregnancy (work on this is already underway)\n- DHB-funded community antenatal education classes should include information about the need for a whooping cough booster shot in the 3rd trimester\n- when confirming a woman is pregnant, their GP or other provider should put in place a plan to ensure they are recalled for a pertussis booster shot in their 3rd trimester\n- a national system should be developed that enables general practices, lead maternity carers and other immunization providers to communicate with each other on whooping cough booster shots given to pregnant women\n- lead maternity carers and other health care providers should ensure pregnant women are aware that they need a whooping cough booster in their 3rd trimester and they know where to go to get it\n- pregnant women should be offered whooping cough booster shots in a wide range of settings, including general practice, secondary care and outreach community settings, to reduce access barriers for hard-to-reach groups.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The full commission report can be found at http://www.hqsc.govt.nz/assets/CYMRC/Publications/pertussis-special-report-Dec-2015.pdf.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest), with seizures induced by hypoxia (low oxygen) usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis -- particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 -- and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and accounted for most of the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Australia (Canberra) New Zealand (South Island) 20150827.3606181\n2012\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand (03): update 20120706.1190855\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\n2011\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\n.................................................sb/ll/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1515-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canberra", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4018889", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Spain: (CM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4018889", "date": "2015-12-17 11:01:34", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2015\nSource: Health Quality and Safety Commission New Zealand [edited]\nhttp://www.nzdoctor.co.nz/un-doctored/2015/december-2015/16/Immunisation-against-whooping-cough-crucial-in-pregnancy-new-report.aspx\n\n\nA new report discusses how rates of whooping cough can be reduced by immunizing women during pregnancy and improving education about the illness. The report Mortality and morbidity of pertussis in children and young people in New Zealand: Special Report 2002-2014, was released today by the Child and Youth Mortality Review Committee (CYMRC). It shows rates of whooping cough (also known as pertussis) in New Zealand using data from 2002-2014, for children and young people under the age of 25.\n\nPertussis is a contagious disease, characterised by long coughing episodes. It can be very serious and in some cases fatal. Nearly 13 000 cases of whooping cough were recorded, an average of 992 cases per year, including 8 deaths. 7 deaths were in infants under 3 months old. There were 1515 hospital admissions and more than 75 percent were for infants under 6 months old.\n\nDr Felicity Dumble, CYMRC chair, says that among the easiest and safest ways to prevent or reduce the severity of the illness is to immunize mothers during pregnancy. \"All pregnant women should receive a booster shot in their 3rd trimester and should be given information by their GP or lead maternity carer about where and how to get one. Many women don't know a booster shot is required,\" says Dr Dumble.\n\nImmunization during pregnancy is safe for mothers and babies and is now funded during the 3rd trimester.\n\n\"GPs and midwives play an important part in education about whooping cough, so it is crucial they take the lead in informing pregnant women about the need for immunization.\"\n\nThe Committee endorses the work the Ministry of Health is doing in this area, including the release of new 'let's talk about immunisation' resources and a focus on whooping cough and influenza immunisation during 2016's National Immunisation Week.\n\nThe report also makes a number of other recommendations to reduce the rates and impact of whooping cough.\n\nRecommendations include:\n- giving pregnant women whooping cough booster shots should be a quality improvement measure or target for DHBs [district health boards]\n- booster shots given to pregnant women should be captured in the National Immunization Register and recorded as part of a baby's immunization record\n- the Ministry of Health should develop education resources for pregnant women, lead maternity carers and other health care providers on the benefits of immunization against whooping cough during pregnancy (work on this is already underway)\n- DHB-funded community antenatal education classes should include information about the need for a whooping cough booster shot in the 3rd trimester\n- when confirming a woman is pregnant, their GP or other provider should put in place a plan to ensure they are recalled for a pertussis booster shot in their 3rd trimester\n- a national system should be developed that enables general practices, lead maternity carers and other immunization providers to communicate with each other on whooping cough booster shots given to pregnant women\n- lead maternity carers and other health care providers should ensure pregnant women are aware that they need a whooping cough booster in their 3rd trimester and they know where to go to get it\n- pregnant women should be offered whooping cough booster shots in a wide range of settings, including general practice, secondary care and outreach community settings, to reduce access barriers for hard-to-reach groups.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The full commission report can be found at http://www.hqsc.govt.nz/assets/CYMRC/Publications/pertussis-special-report-Dec-2015.pdf.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest), with seizures induced by hypoxia (low oxygen) usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis -- particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 -- and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and accounted for most of the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. The report Mortality and morbidity of pertussis in children and young people in New Zealand: Special Report 2002-2014, was released today by the Child and Youth Mortality Review Committee (CYMRC). It shows rates of whooping cough (also known as pertussis) in New Zealand using data from 2002-2014, for children and young people under the age of 25.\n\nPertussis is a contagious disease, characterised by long coughing episodes. It can be very serious and in some cases fatal. Nearly 13 000 cases of whooping cough were recorded, an average of 992 cases per year, including 8 deaths. 7 deaths were in infants under 3 months old. There were 1515 hospital admissions and more than 75 percent were for infants under 6 months old.\n\nDr Felicity Dumble, CYMRC chair, says that among the easiest and safest ways to prevent or reduce the severity of the illness is to immunize mothers during pregnancy. \"All pregnant women should receive a booster shot in their 3rd trimester and should be given information by their GP or lead maternity carer about where and how to get one. Many women don't know a booster shot is required,\" says Dr Dumble.\n\nImmunization during pregnancy is safe for mothers and babies and is now funded during the 3rd trimester.\n\n\"GPs and midwives play an important part in education about whooping cough, so it is crucial they take the lead in informing pregnant women about the need for immunization.\"\n\nThe Committee endorses the work the Ministry of Health is doing in this area, including the release of new 'let's talk about immunisation' resources and a focus on whooping cough and influenza immunisation during 2016's National Immunisation Week.\n\nThe report also makes a number of other recommendations to reduce the rates and impact of whooping cough.\n\nRecommendations include:\n- giving pregnant women whooping cough booster shots should be a quality improvement measure or target for DHBs [district health boards]\n- booster shots given to pregnant women should be captured in the National Immunization Register and recorded as part of a baby's immunization record\n- the Ministry of Health should develop education resources for pregnant women, lead maternity carers and other health care providers on the benefits of immunization against whooping cough during pregnancy (work on this is already underway)\n- DHB-funded community antenatal education classes should include information about the need for a whooping cough booster shot in the 3rd trimester\n- when confirming a woman is pregnant, their GP or other provider should put in place a plan to ensure they are recalled for a pertussis booster shot in their 3rd trimester\n- a national system should be developed that enables general practices, lead maternity carers and other immunization providers to communicate with each other on whooping cough booster shots given to pregnant women\n- lead maternity carers and other health care providers should ensure pregnant women are aware that they need a whooping cough booster in their 3rd trimester and they know where to go to get it\n- pregnant women should be offered whooping cough booster shots in a wide range of settings, including general practice, secondary care and outreach community settings, to reduce access barriers for hard-to-reach groups.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The full commission report can be found at http://www.hqsc.govt.nz/assets/CYMRC/Publications/pertussis-special-report-Dec-2015.pdf.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest), with seizures induced by hypoxia (low oxygen) usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis -- particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 -- and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality. The report Mortality and morbidity of pertussis in children and young people in New Zealand: Special Report 2002-2014, was released today by the Child and Youth Mortality Review Committee (CYMRC). It shows rates of whooping cough (also known as pertussis) in New Zealand using data from 2002-2014, for children and young people under the age of 25.\n\nPertussis is a contagious disease, characterised by long coughing episodes. It can be very serious and in some cases fatal. Nearly 13 000 cases of whooping cough were recorded, an average of 992 cases per year, including 8 deaths. 7 deaths were in infants under 3 months old. There were 1515 hospital admissions and more than 75 percent were for infants under 6 months old.\n\nDr Felicity Dumble, CYMRC chair, says that among the easiest and safest ways to prevent or reduce the severity of the illness is to immunize mothers during pregnancy. \"All pregnant women should receive a booster shot in their 3rd trimester and should be given information by their GP or lead maternity carer about where and how to get one. Many women don't know a booster shot is required,\" says Dr Dumble.\n\nImmunization during pregnancy is safe for mothers and babies and is now funded during the 3rd trimester.\n\n\"GPs and midwives play an important part in education about whooping cough, so it is crucial they take the lead in informing pregnant women about the need for immunization.\"\n\nThe Committee endorses the work the Ministry of Health is doing in this area, including the release of new 'let's talk about immunisation' resources and a focus on whooping cough and influenza immunisation during 2016's National Immunisation Week.\n\nThe report also makes a number of other recommendations to reduce the rates and impact of whooping cough.\n\nRecommendations include:\n- giving pregnant women whooping cough booster shots should be a quality improvement measure or target for DHBs [district health boards]\n- booster shots given to pregnant women should be captured in the National Immunization Register and recorded as part of a baby's immunization record\n- the Ministry of Health should develop education resources for pregnant women, lead maternity carers and other health care providers on the benefits of immunization against whooping cough during pregnancy (work on this is already underway)\n- DHB-funded community antenatal education classes should include information about the need for a whooping cough booster shot in the 3rd trimester\n- when confirming a woman is pregnant, their GP or other provider should put in place a plan to ensure they are recalled for a pertussis booster shot in their 3rd trimester\n- a national system should be developed that enables general practices, lead maternity carers and other immunization providers to communicate with each other on whooping cough booster shots given to pregnant women\n- lead maternity carers and other health care providers should ensure pregnant women are aware that they need a whooping cough booster in their 3rd trimester and they know where to go to get it\n- pregnant women should be offered whooping cough booster shots in a wide range of settings, including general practice, secondary care and outreach community settings, to reduce access barriers for hard-to-reach groups.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The full commission report can be found at http://www.hqsc.govt.nz/assets/CYMRC/Publications/pertussis-special-report-Dec-2015.pdf.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest), with seizures induced by hypoxia (low oxygen) usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis -- particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 -- and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and accounted for most of the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Australia (Canberra) New Zealand (South Island) 20150827.3606181\n2012\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand (03): update 20120706.1190855\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\n2011\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\n.................................................sb/ll/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1515-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canberra", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3926728", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia: (WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3926728", "date": "2015-12-17 11:01:34", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2015\nSource: Health Quality and Safety Commission New Zealand [edited]\nhttp://www.nzdoctor.co.nz/un-doctored/2015/december-2015/16/Immunisation-against-whooping-cough-crucial-in-pregnancy-new-report.aspx\n\n\nA new report discusses how rates of whooping cough can be reduced by immunizing women during pregnancy and improving education about the illness. The report Mortality and morbidity of pertussis in children and young people in New Zealand: Special Report 2002-2014, was released today by the Child and Youth Mortality Review Committee (CYMRC). It shows rates of whooping cough (also known as pertussis) in New Zealand using data from 2002-2014, for children and young people under the age of 25.\n\nPertussis is a contagious disease, characterised by long coughing episodes. It can be very serious and in some cases fatal. Nearly 13 000 cases of whooping cough were recorded, an average of 992 cases per year, including 8 deaths. 7 deaths were in infants under 3 months old. There were 1515 hospital admissions and more than 75 percent were for infants under 6 months old.\n\nDr Felicity Dumble, CYMRC chair, says that among the easiest and safest ways to prevent or reduce the severity of the illness is to immunize mothers during pregnancy. \"All pregnant women should receive a booster shot in their 3rd trimester and should be given information by their GP or lead maternity carer about where and how to get one. Many women don't know a booster shot is required,\" says Dr Dumble.\n\nImmunization during pregnancy is safe for mothers and babies and is now funded during the 3rd trimester.\n\n\"GPs and midwives play an important part in education about whooping cough, so it is crucial they take the lead in informing pregnant women about the need for immunization.\"\n\nThe Committee endorses the work the Ministry of Health is doing in this area, including the release of new 'let's talk about immunisation' resources and a focus on whooping cough and influenza immunisation during 2016's National Immunisation Week.\n\nThe report also makes a number of other recommendations to reduce the rates and impact of whooping cough.\n\nRecommendations include:\n- giving pregnant women whooping cough booster shots should be a quality improvement measure or target for DHBs [district health boards]\n- booster shots given to pregnant women should be captured in the National Immunization Register and recorded as part of a baby's immunization record\n- the Ministry of Health should develop education resources for pregnant women, lead maternity carers and other health care providers on the benefits of immunization against whooping cough during pregnancy (work on this is already underway)\n- DHB-funded community antenatal education classes should include information about the need for a whooping cough booster shot in the 3rd trimester\n- when confirming a woman is pregnant, their GP or other provider should put in place a plan to ensure they are recalled for a pertussis booster shot in their 3rd trimester\n- a national system should be developed that enables general practices, lead maternity carers and other immunization providers to communicate with each other on whooping cough booster shots given to pregnant women\n- lead maternity carers and other health care providers should ensure pregnant women are aware that they need a whooping cough booster in their 3rd trimester and they know where to go to get it\n- pregnant women should be offered whooping cough booster shots in a wide range of settings, including general practice, secondary care and outreach community settings, to reduce access barriers for hard-to-reach groups.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The full commission report can be found at http://www.hqsc.govt.nz/assets/CYMRC/Publications/pertussis-special-report-Dec-2015.pdf.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest), with seizures induced by hypoxia (low oxygen) usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis -- particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 -- and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and accounted for most of the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Australia (Canberra) New Zealand (South Island) 20150827.3606181\n2012\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand (03): update 20120706.1190855\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\n2011\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\n.................................................sb/ll/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1515-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canberra", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3869310", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3869310", "date": "2015-12-17 11:01:34", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2015\nSource: Health Quality and Safety Commission New Zealand [edited]\nhttp://www.nzdoctor.co.nz/un-doctored/2015/december-2015/16/Immunisation-against-whooping-cough-crucial-in-pregnancy-new-report.aspx\n\n\nA new report discusses how rates of whooping cough can be reduced by immunizing women during pregnancy and improving education about the illness. The report Mortality and morbidity of pertussis in children and young people in New Zealand: Special Report 2002-2014, was released today by the Child and Youth Mortality Review Committee (CYMRC). It shows rates of whooping cough (also known as pertussis) in New Zealand using data from 2002-2014, for children and young people under the age of 25.\n\nPertussis is a contagious disease, characterised by long coughing episodes. It can be very serious and in some cases fatal. Nearly 13 000 cases of whooping cough were recorded, an average of 992 cases per year, including 8 deaths. 7 deaths were in infants under 3 months old. There were 1515 hospital admissions and more than 75 percent were for infants under 6 months old.\n\nDr Felicity Dumble, CYMRC chair, says that among the easiest and safest ways to prevent or reduce the severity of the illness is to immunize mothers during pregnancy. \"All pregnant women should receive a booster shot in their 3rd trimester and should be given information by their GP or lead maternity carer about where and how to get one. Many women don't know a booster shot is required,\" says Dr Dumble.\n\nImmunization during pregnancy is safe for mothers and babies and is now funded during the 3rd trimester.\n\n\"GPs and midwives play an important part in education about whooping cough, so it is crucial they take the lead in informing pregnant women about the need for immunization.\"\n\nThe Committee endorses the work the Ministry of Health is doing in this area, including the release of new 'let's talk about immunisation' resources and a focus on whooping cough and influenza immunisation during 2016's National Immunisation Week.\n\nThe report also makes a number of other recommendations to reduce the rates and impact of whooping cough.\n\nRecommendations include:\n- giving pregnant women whooping cough booster shots should be a quality improvement measure or target for DHBs [district health boards]\n- booster shots given to pregnant women should be captured in the National Immunization Register and recorded as part of a baby's immunization record\n- the Ministry of Health should develop education resources for pregnant women, lead maternity carers and other health care providers on the benefits of immunization against whooping cough during pregnancy (work on this is already underway)\n- DHB-funded community antenatal education classes should include information about the need for a whooping cough booster shot in the 3rd trimester\n- when confirming a woman is pregnant, their GP or other provider should put in place a plan to ensure they are recalled for a pertussis booster shot in their 3rd trimester\n- a national system should be developed that enables general practices, lead maternity carers and other immunization providers to communicate with each other on whooping cough booster shots given to pregnant women\n- lead maternity carers and other health care providers should ensure pregnant women are aware that they need a whooping cough booster in their 3rd trimester and they know where to go to get it\n- pregnant women should be offered whooping cough booster shots in a wide range of settings, including general practice, secondary care and outreach community settings, to reduce access barriers for hard-to-reach groups.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The full commission report can be found at http://www.hqsc.govt.nz/assets/CYMRC/Publications/pertussis-special-report-Dec-2015.pdf.\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe, with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea (breathing arrest), with seizures induced by hypoxia (low oxygen) usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis -- particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 -- and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs of mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital, and accounted for most of the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care.\n\nA 2014 publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904 (http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Australia (Canberra) New Zealand (South Island) 20150827.3606181\n2012\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand (03): update 20120706.1190855\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\n2011\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\n.................................................sb/ll/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1515-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canberra", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3846064", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Spain (03): (MD) infant fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3846064", "date": "2015-11-09 15:23:06", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SUDAN (02): (NORTH DARFUR)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2015\nSource: Dabanga Sudan [edited]\nhttps://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/whooping-cough-outbreak-in-north-darfur-s-el-sereif\n\n\nAs of 28 Oct 2015, 410 cases of whooping cough have been reported in El Sereif Beni Hussein locality, according to the Sudanese Ministry of Health (SMoH). The outbreak started in early September 2015 and has affected all age groups including infants, children and adults. No deaths have been reported so far, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its latest weekly bulletin.\n\nOut of the 14 samples collected, 4 tested positive for whooping cough (pertussis). About half (193) of all cases have been reported in the El Hariga village where the outbreak started. The remaining cases are from 8 neighboring villages. The majority of cases are of people under 15 years of age.\n\nIn response, the SMoH, WHO, and health partners on the ground are implementing a 3-month action plan in the locality. MoH and WHO teams have been deployed to the locality to assist in the response activities. Medecins Sans Frontieres Spain (MSF-Spain) has initiated case management and community awareness-raising activities.\n\nBetween 17-22 Oct 2015, the MoH vaccinated more than 16 600 children under 5 years. The rate of transmission seems to be decreasing, according to WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A whooping cough outbreak was reported in El Sareif Beni Hussein in November 2013. At least 2 people died from the disease then. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/27297.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20151027.3746994\nPertussis - Liberia: (MY) 20150301.3200714\n2013\n----\nPertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20131104.2036595\nPertussis - Afghanistan (02): background 20130103.1478809\nPertussis - Afghanistan: (BD), fatalities 20130101.1477768\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. The outbreak started in early September 2015 and has affected all age groups including infants, children and adults. No deaths have been reported so far, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its latest weekly bulletin.\n\nOut of the 14 samples collected, 4 tested positive for whooping cough (pertussis). About half (193) of all cases have been reported in the El Hariga village where the outbreak started. The remaining cases are from 8 neighboring villages. The majority of cases are of people under 15 years of age.\n\nIn response, the SMoH, WHO, and health partners on the ground are implementing a 3-month action plan in the locality. MoH and WHO teams have been deployed to the locality to assist in the response activities. Medecins Sans Frontieres Spain (MSF-Spain) has initiated case management and community awareness-raising activities.\n\nBetween 17-22 Oct 2015, the MoH vaccinated more than 16 600 children under 5 years. The rate of transmission seems to be decreasing, according to WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A whooping cough outbreak was reported in El Sareif Beni Hussein in November 2013. (03) 20031008.2530\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. 20031003.2488\n.................................................sb/ll/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Equatoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SMoH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3809154", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Spain (02): (AN) infant fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3809154", "date": "2015-11-09 15:23:06", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - SUDAN (02): (NORTH DARFUR)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2015\nSource: Dabanga Sudan [edited]\nhttps://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/whooping-cough-outbreak-in-north-darfur-s-el-sereif\n\n\nAs of 28 Oct 2015, 410 cases of whooping cough have been reported in El Sereif Beni Hussein locality, according to the Sudanese Ministry of Health (SMoH). The outbreak started in early September 2015 and has affected all age groups including infants, children and adults. No deaths have been reported so far, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its latest weekly bulletin.\n\nOut of the 14 samples collected, 4 tested positive for whooping cough (pertussis). About half (193) of all cases have been reported in the El Hariga village where the outbreak started. The remaining cases are from 8 neighboring villages. The majority of cases are of people under 15 years of age.\n\nIn response, the SMoH, WHO, and health partners on the ground are implementing a 3-month action plan in the locality. MoH and WHO teams have been deployed to the locality to assist in the response activities. Medecins Sans Frontieres Spain (MSF-Spain) has initiated case management and community awareness-raising activities.\n\nBetween 17-22 Oct 2015, the MoH vaccinated more than 16 600 children under 5 years. The rate of transmission seems to be decreasing, according to WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A whooping cough outbreak was reported in El Sareif Beni Hussein in November 2013.
