The outbreak started in early September 2015 and has affected all age groups including infants, children and adults. No deaths have been reported so far, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its latest weekly bulletin.\n\nOut of the 14 samples collected, 4 tested positive for whooping cough (pertussis). About half (193) of all cases have been reported in the El Hariga village where the outbreak started. The remaining cases are from 8 neighboring villages. The majority of cases are of people under 15 years of age.\n\nIn response, the SMoH, WHO, and health partners on the ground are implementing a 3-month action plan in the locality. MoH and WHO teams have been deployed to the locality to assist in the response activities. Medecins Sans Frontieres Spain (MSF-Spain) has initiated case management and community awareness-raising activities.\n\nBetween 17-22 Oct 2015, the MoH vaccinated more than 16 600 children under 5 years. The rate of transmission seems to be decreasing, according to WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A whooping cough outbreak was reported in El Sareif Beni Hussein in November 2013. The outbreak started in early September 2015 and has affected all age groups including infants, children and adults. No deaths have been reported so far, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its latest weekly bulletin.\n\nOut of the 14 samples collected, 4 tested positive for whooping cough (pertussis). About half (193) of all cases have been reported in the El Hariga village where the outbreak started. The remaining cases are from 8 neighboring villages. The majority of cases are of people under 15 years of age.\n\nIn response, the SMoH, WHO, and health partners on the ground are implementing a 3-month action plan in the locality. MoH and WHO teams have been deployed to the locality to assist in the response activities. Medecins Sans Frontieres Spain (MSF-Spain) has initiated case management and community awareness-raising activities.\n\nBetween 17-22 Oct 2015, the MoH vaccinated more than 16 600 children under 5 years. The rate of transmission seems to be decreasing, according to WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A whooping cough outbreak was reported in El Sareif Beni Hussein in November 2013. MoH and WHO teams have been deployed to the locality to assist in the response activities. The outbreak started in early September 2015 and has affected all age groups including infants, children and adults. No deaths have been reported so far, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its latest weekly bulletin.\n\nOut of the 14 samples collected, 4 tested positive for whooping cough (pertussis). About half (193) of all cases have been reported in the El Hariga village where the outbreak started. The remaining cases are from 8 neighboring villages. The majority of cases are of people under 15 years of age.\n\nIn response, the SMoH, WHO, and health partners on the ground are implementing a 3-month action plan in the locality. MoH and WHO teams have been deployed to the locality to assist in the response activities. Medecins Sans Frontieres Spain (MSF-Spain) has initiated case management and community awareness-raising activities.\n\nBetween 17-22 Oct 2015, the MoH vaccinated more than 16 600 children under 5 years. The rate of transmission seems to be decreasing, according to WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A whooping cough outbreak was reported in El Sareif Beni Hussein in November 2013. At least 2 people died from the disease then. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/27297.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20151027.3746994\nPertussis - Liberia: (MY) 20150301.3200714\n2013\n----\nPertussis - Sudan: (ND) 20131104.2036595\nPertussis - Afghanistan (02): background 20130103.1478809\nPertussis - Afghanistan: (BD), fatalities 20130101.1477768\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. (03) 20031008.2530\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. 20031003.2488\n.................................................sb/ll/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Equatoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SMoH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3746994", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Sudan: (ND)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3746994", "date": "2015-07-26 20:07:30", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (11): (KANSAS), UPDATE\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 25 Jul 2015\nSource: The Hutchinson News [edited]\nhttp://www.hutchnews.com/news/local_state_news/whooping-cough-outbreak-won-t-give-up/article_be45552e-7d31-5647-b2e0-1f76fa58365f.html\n\n\nReno County's whooping cough outbreak continues, local health officials said, with the number of suspected pertussis cases now topping 70.\n\nThe persistent nature of the outbreak has health officials concerned that it won't be contained before school starts back up, creating fear of a potential \"micro-outbreak,\" said Health Department Director Nick Baldetti. The last new case the agency began investigating was Friday [24 Jul 2015], Baldetti said. An outbreak is not considered contained until 2 full cycles of the disease -- a cycle is 21 days -- pass without a new case. At this point, that would be 4 Sep [2015].\n\n\"I'm not confident to say we won't get any more,\" Baldetti said. \"It seems we get one to 3 new cases a day. It just seems like it builds up. We don't have any for several days, and then we get 3 or 4.\"\n\nWhooping cough is a contagious respiratory disease caused by _Bordetella pertussis_ bacteria. Initial symptoms include runny nose, sneezing and a mild cough, which may seem like a typical cold, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Usually, the cough slowly becomes more severe, and eventually the patient may experience bouts of rapid, violent coughing followed by the \"whooping\" sound that gives the disease its common name when trying to take a breath. The disease can cause serious and sometimes life-threatening complications, permanent disability, and even death, especially in infants and young children.\n\nAs of Friday [24 Jul 2015], the Kansas Department of Health and Environment listed Reno County with 41 confirmed or probable cases of pertussis, accounting for 20 percent of all cases in the state. That was up from 18 on Jun 29 [2015]. The state figures showed additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno -- Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick -- as well as in 2 other counties in the region.\n\nThe Reno County Health Department is actively working with area school districts to be prepared, \"but we can't put the onus on schools to get out in front of it. We hope to have (vaccination) clinics for Buhler, Haven and Nickerson [3 of the 7 Reno County school districts],\" Baldetti said. \"(USD) 308 [Unified School District 308, also called Hutchinson] has committed to not allow anyone to enroll without the vaccination or an acceptance form.\"\n\nWhile the pertussis vaccine offers \"90 percent protection\" from the disease, new research shows antibodies decline in 2-5 years. That has health officials advising anyone who has regular contact with children, particularly infants, or immune compromised adults, to get a Tdap (tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis) booster. The health department has at least 450 doses of vaccine and is offering the shots free.\n\n\"It's really important for people to be proactive and be on guard for symptoms,\" Baldetti said. \"Anyone suspected of being sick needs [to be] checked immediately. We cannot let cold symptoms be unchecked. It's too widespread now; it's better to be safe than sorry.\" They are particularly focusing on families with school age children, school staff who work with children, and daycare providers.\n\n\"There's serious concern for a potential exponential spread through our schools,\" Baldetti said. \"When they get back to school, it will be concentrated, so we want to focus on that group.\" Active cases, however, range from infants to high school to adults \"and everywhere in between,\" he said. \"We're not isolating our effort to elementary, middle or high school, but all levels of education, daycare providers, churches and businesses. This is truly a widespread outbreak. And it is truly on us, as a community, to ensure we are protecting those in our community that cannot protect themselves. If your children have been vaccinated, but it has been more years than you can count on one hand, I encourage you to see your local provider and ask for a Tdap booster,\" he said. \"It's not a bad idea for parents or even grandparents to check and see if they're outside that window.\"\n\n[Byline: John Green]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kansas, with a population of 2 904 021 in 2014, is a state located in the Midwestern United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Kansas). A map of Kansas counties is available at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/kansas.shtml.\n\nThe news article above reports increasing numbers of cases of pertussis in Reno County, with a population of 64 511 in 2011, which is located in the south-central part of Kansas, and also reports additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno (Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick Counties) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reno_County,_Kansas#Education). Last month [June 2015], ProMED-mail also reported cases of pertussis this year (2015) in nearby Barton County, Kansas (Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509).\n\nThe following is extracted from the moderator comments in ProMED post Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509:\n\nIn the U.S., DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nPertussis is nationally notifiable to the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/trends.html). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. During the 1980s the incidence of pertussis began increasing gradually, and peaked in 2012 at 48 277 cases of pertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph.jpg). This was the most reported cases since 1955. Pertussis again declined during 2013 and by 2014, more than 28 000 cases were reported nationwide.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509\nPertussis - USA (04) 20150205.3141284\nPertussis - USA (03): (MD) health care worker presenteeism, 2014 20150123.3111598\nPertussis - USA (02) 20150116.3094367\nPertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551\n2014\n----\nPertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140720.2623332\nPertussis - USA (13) 20140713.2603059\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2070-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-06-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1955-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Midwestern United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=kansa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nickerson", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3653562", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (04): (AB,SK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3653562", "date": "2015-07-26 20:07:30", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (11): (KANSAS), UPDATE\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 25 Jul 2015\nSource: The Hutchinson News [edited]\nhttp://www.hutchnews.com/news/local_state_news/whooping-cough-outbreak-won-t-give-up/article_be45552e-7d31-5647-b2e0-1f76fa58365f.html\n\n\nReno County's whooping cough outbreak continues, local health officials said, with the number of suspected pertussis cases now topping 70.\n\nThe persistent nature of the outbreak has health officials concerned that it won't be contained before school starts back up, creating fear of a potential \"micro-outbreak,\" said Health Department Director Nick Baldetti. The last new case the agency began investigating was Friday [24 Jul 2015], Baldetti said. An outbreak is not considered contained until 2 full cycles of the disease -- a cycle is 21 days -- pass without a new case. At this point, that would be 4 Sep [2015].\n\n\"I'm not confident to say we won't get any more,\" Baldetti said. \"It seems we get one to 3 new cases a day. It just seems like it builds up. We don't have any for several days, and then we get 3 or 4.\"\n\nWhooping cough is a contagious respiratory disease caused by _Bordetella pertussis_ bacteria. Initial symptoms include runny nose, sneezing and a mild cough, which may seem like a typical cold, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Usually, the cough slowly becomes more severe, and eventually the patient may experience bouts of rapid, violent coughing followed by the \"whooping\" sound that gives the disease its common name when trying to take a breath. The disease can cause serious and sometimes life-threatening complications, permanent disability, and even death, especially in infants and young children.\n\nAs of Friday [24 Jul 2015], the Kansas Department of Health and Environment listed Reno County with 41 confirmed or probable cases of pertussis, accounting for 20 percent of all cases in the state. That was up from 18 on Jun 29 [2015]. The state figures showed additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno -- Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick -- as well as in 2 other counties in the region.\n\nThe Reno County Health Department is actively working with area school districts to be prepared, \"but we can't put the onus on schools to get out in front of it. We hope to have (vaccination) clinics for Buhler, Haven and Nickerson [3 of the 7 Reno County school districts],\" Baldetti said. \"(USD) 308 [Unified School District 308, also called Hutchinson] has committed to not allow anyone to enroll without the vaccination or an acceptance form.\"\n\nWhile the pertussis vaccine offers \"90 percent protection\" from the disease, new research shows antibodies decline in 2-5 years. That has health officials advising anyone who has regular contact with children, particularly infants, or immune compromised adults, to get a Tdap (tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis) booster. The health department has at least 450 doses of vaccine and is offering the shots free.\n\n\"It's really important for people to be proactive and be on guard for symptoms,\" Baldetti said. \"Anyone suspected of being sick needs [to be] checked immediately. We cannot let cold symptoms be unchecked. It's too widespread now; it's better to be safe than sorry.\" They are particularly focusing on families with school age children, school staff who work with children, and daycare providers.\n\n\"There's serious concern for a potential exponential spread through our schools,\" Baldetti said. \"When they get back to school, it will be concentrated, so we want to focus on that group.\" Active cases, however, range from infants to high school to adults \"and everywhere in between,\" he said. \"We're not isolating our effort to elementary, middle or high school, but all levels of education, daycare providers, churches and businesses. This is truly a widespread outbreak. And it is truly on us, as a community, to ensure we are protecting those in our community that cannot protect themselves. If your children have been vaccinated, but it has been more years than you can count on one hand, I encourage you to see your local provider and ask for a Tdap booster,\" he said. \"It's not a bad idea for parents or even grandparents to check and see if they're outside that window.\"\n\n[Byline: John Green]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kansas, with a population of 2 904 021 in 2014, is a state located in the Midwestern United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Kansas). A map of Kansas counties is available at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/kansas.shtml.\n\nThe news article above reports increasing numbers of cases of pertussis in Reno County, with a population of 64 511 in 2011, which is located in the south-central part of Kansas, and also reports additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno (Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick Counties) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reno_County,_Kansas#Education). Last month [June 2015], ProMED-mail also reported cases of pertussis this year (2015) in nearby Barton County, Kansas (Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509).\n\nThe following is extracted from the moderator comments in ProMED post Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509:\n\nIn the U.S., DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nPertussis is nationally notifiable to the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/trends.html). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. During the 1980s the incidence of pertussis began increasing gradually, and peaked in 2012 at 48 277 cases of pertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph.jpg). This was the most reported cases since 1955. Pertussis again declined during 2013 and by 2014, more than 28 000 cases were reported nationwide.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509\nPertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140720.2623332\nPertussis - USA (13) 20140713.2603059\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2070-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-06-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1955-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Midwestern United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=kansa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nickerson", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3637867", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (13): (OH,KY,IN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3637867", "date": "2015-07-26 20:07:30", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (11): (KANSAS), UPDATE\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 25 Jul 2015\nSource: The Hutchinson News [edited]\nhttp://www.hutchnews.com/news/local_state_news/whooping-cough-outbreak-won-t-give-up/article_be45552e-7d31-5647-b2e0-1f76fa58365f.html\n\n\nReno County's whooping cough outbreak continues, local health officials said, with the number of suspected pertussis cases now topping 70.\n\nThe persistent nature of the outbreak has health officials concerned that it won't be contained before school starts back up, creating fear of a potential \"micro-outbreak,\" said Health Department Director Nick Baldetti. The last new case the agency began investigating was Friday [24 Jul 2015], Baldetti said. An outbreak is not considered contained until 2 full cycles of the disease -- a cycle is 21 days -- pass without a new case. At this point, that would be 4 Sep [2015].\n\n\"I'm not confident to say we won't get any more,\" Baldetti said. \"It seems we get one to 3 new cases a day. It just seems like it builds up. We don't have any for several days, and then we get 3 or 4.\"\n\nWhooping cough is a contagious respiratory disease caused by _Bordetella pertussis_ bacteria. Initial symptoms include runny nose, sneezing and a mild cough, which may seem like a typical cold, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Usually, the cough slowly becomes more severe, and eventually the patient may experience bouts of rapid, violent coughing followed by the \"whooping\" sound that gives the disease its common name when trying to take a breath. The disease can cause serious and sometimes life-threatening complications, permanent disability, and even death, especially in infants and young children.\n\nAs of Friday [24 Jul 2015], the Kansas Department of Health and Environment listed Reno County with 41 confirmed or probable cases of pertussis, accounting for 20 percent of all cases in the state. That was up from 18 on Jun 29 [2015]. The state figures showed additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno -- Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick -- as well as in 2 other counties in the region.\n\nThe Reno County Health Department is actively working with area school districts to be prepared, \"but we can't put the onus on schools to get out in front of it. We hope to have (vaccination) clinics for Buhler, Haven and Nickerson [3 of the 7 Reno County school districts],\" Baldetti said. \"(USD) 308 [Unified School District 308, also called Hutchinson] has committed to not allow anyone to enroll without the vaccination or an acceptance form.\"\n\nWhile the pertussis vaccine offers \"90 percent protection\" from the disease, new research shows antibodies decline in 2-5 years. That has health officials advising anyone who has regular contact with children, particularly infants, or immune compromised adults, to get a Tdap (tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis) booster. The health department has at least 450 doses of vaccine and is offering the shots free.\n\n\"It's really important for people to be proactive and be on guard for symptoms,\" Baldetti said. \"Anyone suspected of being sick needs [to be] checked immediately. We cannot let cold symptoms be unchecked. It's too widespread now; it's better to be safe than sorry.\" They are particularly focusing on families with school age children, school staff who work with children, and daycare providers.\n\n\"There's serious concern for a potential exponential spread through our schools,\" Baldetti said. \"When they get back to school, it will be concentrated, so we want to focus on that group.\" Active cases, however, range from infants to high school to adults \"and everywhere in between,\" he said. \"We're not isolating our effort to elementary, middle or high school, but all levels of education, daycare providers, churches and businesses. This is truly a widespread outbreak. And it is truly on us, as a community, to ensure we are protecting those in our community that cannot protect themselves. If your children have been vaccinated, but it has been more years than you can count on one hand, I encourage you to see your local provider and ask for a Tdap booster,\" he said. \"It's not a bad idea for parents or even grandparents to check and see if they're outside that window.\"\n\n[Byline: John Green]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kansas, with a population of 2 904 021 in 2014, is a state located in the Midwestern United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Kansas). A map of Kansas counties is available at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/kansas.shtml.\n\nThe news article above reports increasing numbers of cases of pertussis in Reno County, with a population of 64 511 in 2011, which is located in the south-central part of Kansas, and also reports additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno (Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick Counties) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reno_County,_Kansas#Education). Last month [June 2015], ProMED-mail also reported cases of pertussis this year (2015) in nearby Barton County, Kansas (Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509).\n\nThe following is extracted from the moderator comments in ProMED post Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509:\n\nIn the U.S., DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nPertussis is nationally notifiable to the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/trends.html). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. During the 1980s the incidence of pertussis began increasing gradually, and peaked in 2012 at 48 277 cases of pertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph.jpg). This was the most reported cases since 1955. Pertussis again declined during 2013 and by 2014, more than 28 000 cases were reported nationwide.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509\nPertussis - This is truly a widespread outbreak. And it is truly on us, as a community, to ensure we are protecting those in our community that cannot protect themselves. If your children have been vaccinated, but it has been more years than you can count on one hand, I encourage you to see your local provider and ask for a Tdap booster,\" he said. \"It's not a bad idea for parents or even grandparents to check and see if they're outside that window.\"\n\n[Byline: John Green]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kansas, with a population of 2 904 021 in 2014, is a state located in the Midwestern United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Kansas). A map of Kansas counties is available at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/kansas.shtml.\n\nThe news article above reports increasing numbers of cases of pertussis in Reno County, with a population of 64 511 in 2011, which is located in the south-central part of Kansas, and also reports additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno (Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick Counties) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reno_County,_Kansas#Education). Last month [June 2015], ProMED-mail also reported cases of pertussis this year (2015) in nearby Barton County, Kansas (Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509).\n\nThe following is extracted from the moderator comments in ProMED post Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509:\n\nIn the U.S., DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nPertussis is nationally notifiable to the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/trends.html). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. During the 1980s the incidence of pertussis began increasing gradually, and peaked in 2012 at 48 277 cases of pertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph.jpg). This was the most reported cases since 1955. Pertussis again declined during 2013 and by 2014, more than 28 000 cases were reported nationwide.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509\nPertussis - USA (09) 20150425.3320344\nPertussis - USA (08): (NC) 20150418.3305675\nPertussis - USA (07) 20150412.3292930\nPertussis - USA (06): (CA) infant fatality 20150314.3230176\nPertussis - USA (05): (OR) 20150314.3229781\nPertussis - USA (04) 20150205.3141284\nPertussis - USA (03): (MD) health care worker presenteeism, 2014 20150123.3111598\nPertussis - USA (02) 20150116.3094367\nPertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551\n2014\n----\nPertussis - USA (30) 20141228.3058832\nPertussis - USA (29) 20141222.3044440\nPertussis - USA (27): (MI) undervaccination 20141211.3027769\nPertussis - USA (26) 20141211.3024716\nPertussis - USA (25): (CA) 20141205.3012191\nPertussis - USA (24) 20141121.2979932\nPertussis - USA (23) 20141116.2947034\nPertussis - USA (22) 20141105.2922903\nPertussis - USA (21): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20141015.2864604\nPertussis - USA (20): (CO) increasing incidence 20141005.2833302\nPertussis - USA (19): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20140921.2792202\nPertussis - USA (18): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20140815.2692228\nPertussis - USA (16): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140809.2675224\nPertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140720.2623332\nPertussis - USA (13) 20140713.2603059\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2070-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-06-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1955-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Midwestern United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=kansa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nickerson", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3628904", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - French Polynesia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3628904", "date": "2015-07-26 20:07:30", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (11): (KANSAS), UPDATE\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 25 Jul 2015\nSource: The Hutchinson News [edited]\nhttp://www.hutchnews.com/news/local_state_news/whooping-cough-outbreak-won-t-give-up/article_be45552e-7d31-5647-b2e0-1f76fa58365f.html\n\n\nReno County's whooping cough outbreak continues, local health officials said, with the number of suspected pertussis cases now topping 70.\n\nThe persistent nature of the outbreak has health officials concerned that it won't be contained before school starts back up, creating fear of a potential \"micro-outbreak,\" said Health Department Director Nick Baldetti. The last new case the agency began investigating was Friday [24 Jul 2015], Baldetti said. An outbreak is not considered contained until 2 full cycles of the disease -- a cycle is 21 days -- pass without a new case. At this point, that would be 4 Sep [2015].\n\n\"I'm not confident to say we won't get any more,\" Baldetti said. \"It seems we get one to 3 new cases a day. It just seems like it builds up. We don't have any for several days, and then we get 3 or 4.\"\n\nWhooping cough is a contagious respiratory disease caused by _Bordetella pertussis_ bacteria. Initial symptoms include runny nose, sneezing and a mild cough, which may seem like a typical cold, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Usually, the cough slowly becomes more severe, and eventually the patient may experience bouts of rapid, violent coughing followed by the \"whooping\" sound that gives the disease its common name when trying to take a breath. The disease can cause serious and sometimes life-threatening complications, permanent disability, and even death, especially in infants and young children.\n\nAs of Friday [24 Jul 2015], the Kansas Department of Health and Environment listed Reno County with 41 confirmed or probable cases of pertussis, accounting for 20 percent of all cases in the state. That was up from 18 on Jun 29 [2015]. The state figures showed additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno -- Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick -- as well as in 2 other counties in the region.\n\nThe Reno County Health Department is actively working with area school districts to be prepared, \"but we can't put the onus on schools to get out in front of it. We hope to have (vaccination) clinics for Buhler, Haven and Nickerson [3 of the 7 Reno County school districts],\" Baldetti said. \"(USD) 308 [Unified School District 308, also called Hutchinson] has committed to not allow anyone to enroll without the vaccination or an acceptance form.\"\n\nWhile the pertussis vaccine offers \"90 percent protection\" from the disease, new research shows antibodies decline in 2-5 years. That has health officials advising anyone who has regular contact with children, particularly infants, or immune compromised adults, to get a Tdap (tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis) booster. The health department has at least 450 doses of vaccine and is offering the shots free.\n\n\"It's really important for people to be proactive and be on guard for symptoms,\" Baldetti said. \"Anyone suspected of being sick needs [to be] checked immediately. We cannot let cold symptoms be unchecked. It's too widespread now; it's better to be safe than sorry.\" They are particularly focusing on families with school age children, school staff who work with children, and daycare providers.\n\n\"There's serious concern for a potential exponential spread through our schools,\" Baldetti said. \"When they get back to school, it will be concentrated, so we want to focus on that group.\" Active cases, however, range from infants to high school to adults \"and everywhere in between,\" he said. \"We're not isolating our effort to elementary, middle or high school, but all levels of education, daycare providers, churches and businesses. This is truly a widespread outbreak. And it is truly on us, as a community, to ensure we are protecting those in our community that cannot protect themselves. If your children have been vaccinated, but it has been more years than you can count on one hand, I encourage you to see your local provider and ask for a Tdap booster,\" he said. \"It's not a bad idea for parents or even grandparents to check and see if they're outside that window.\"\n\n[Byline: John Green]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kansas, with a population of 2 904 021 in 2014, is a state located in the Midwestern United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Kansas). A map of Kansas counties is available at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/kansas.shtml.\n\nThe news article above reports increasing numbers of cases of pertussis in Reno County, with a population of 64 511 in 2011, which is located in the south-central part of Kansas, and also reports additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno (Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick Counties) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reno_County,_Kansas#Education). Last month [June 2015], ProMED-mail also reported cases of pertussis this year (2015) in nearby Barton County, Kansas (Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509).\n\nThe following is extracted from the moderator comments in ProMED post Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509:\n\nIn the U.S., DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nPertussis is nationally notifiable to the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/trends.html). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. During the 1980s the incidence of pertussis began increasing gradually, and peaked in 2012 at 48 277 cases of pertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph.jpg). This was the most reported cases since 1955. Pertussis again declined during 2013 and by 2014, more than 28 000 cases were reported nationwide.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509\nPertussis - USA (04) 20150205.3141284\nPertussis - USA (03): (MD) health care worker presenteeism, 2014 20150123.3111598\nPertussis - USA (02) 20150116.3094367\nPertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551\n2014\n----\nPertussis - Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nPertussis is nationally notifiable to the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/trends.html). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. During the 1980s the incidence of pertussis began increasing gradually, and peaked in 2012 at 48 277 cases of pertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph.jpg). This was the most reported cases since 1955. Pertussis again declined during 2013 and by 2014, more than 28 000 cases were reported nationwide.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. USA (19): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20140921.2792202\nPertussis - USA (18): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20140815.2692228\nPertussis - USA (16): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140809.2675224\nPertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140720.2623332\nPertussis - USA (13) 20140713.2603059\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2070-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-06-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1955-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Midwestern United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=kansa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nickerson", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3606181", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia (Canberra) New Zealand (South Island)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3606181", "date": "2015-07-26 20:07:30", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (11): (KANSAS), UPDATE\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 25 Jul 2015\nSource: The Hutchinson News [edited]\nhttp://www.hutchnews.com/news/local_state_news/whooping-cough-outbreak-won-t-give-up/article_be45552e-7d31-5647-b2e0-1f76fa58365f.html\n\n\nReno County's whooping cough outbreak continues, local health officials said, with the number of suspected pertussis cases now topping 70.\n\nThe persistent nature of the outbreak has health officials concerned that it won't be contained before school starts back up, creating fear of a potential \"micro-outbreak,\" said Health Department Director Nick Baldetti. The last new case the agency began investigating was Friday [24 Jul 2015], Baldetti said. An outbreak is not considered contained until 2 full cycles of the disease -- a cycle is 21 days -- pass without a new case. At this point, that would be 4 Sep [2015].\n\n\"I'm not confident to say we won't get any more,\" Baldetti said. \"It seems we get one to 3 new cases a day. It just seems like it builds up. We don't have any for several days, and then we get 3 or 4.\"\n\nWhooping cough is a contagious respiratory disease caused by _Bordetella pertussis_ bacteria. Initial symptoms include runny nose, sneezing and a mild cough, which may seem like a typical cold, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Usually, the cough slowly becomes more severe, and eventually the patient may experience bouts of rapid, violent coughing followed by the \"whooping\" sound that gives the disease its common name when trying to take a breath. The disease can cause serious and sometimes life-threatening complications, permanent disability, and even death, especially in infants and young children.\n\nAs of Friday [24 Jul 2015], the Kansas Department of Health and Environment listed Reno County with 41 confirmed or probable cases of pertussis, accounting for 20 percent of all cases in the state. That was up from 18 on Jun 29 [2015]. The state figures showed additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno -- Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick -- as well as in 2 other counties in the region.\n\nThe Reno County Health Department is actively working with area school districts to be prepared, \"but we can't put the onus on schools to get out in front of it. We hope to have (vaccination) clinics for Buhler, Haven and Nickerson [3 of the 7 Reno County school districts],\" Baldetti said. \"(USD) 308 [Unified School District 308, also called Hutchinson] has committed to not allow anyone to enroll without the vaccination or an acceptance form.\"\n\nWhile the pertussis vaccine offers \"90 percent protection\" from the disease, new research shows antibodies decline in 2-5 years. That has health officials advising anyone who has regular contact with children, particularly infants, or immune compromised adults, to get a Tdap (tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis) booster. The health department has at least 450 doses of vaccine and is offering the shots free.\n\n\"It's really important for people to be proactive and be on guard for symptoms,\" Baldetti said. \"Anyone suspected of being sick needs [to be] checked immediately. We cannot let cold symptoms be unchecked. It's too widespread now; it's better to be safe than sorry.\" They are particularly focusing on families with school age children, school staff who work with children, and daycare providers.\n\n\"There's serious concern for a potential exponential spread through our schools,\" Baldetti said. \"When they get back to school, it will be concentrated, so we want to focus on that group.\" Active cases, however, range from infants to high school to adults \"and everywhere in between,\" he said. \"We're not isolating our effort to elementary, middle or high school, but all levels of education, daycare providers, churches and businesses. This is truly a widespread outbreak. And it is truly on us, as a community, to ensure we are protecting those in our community that cannot protect themselves. If your children have been vaccinated, but it has been more years than you can count on one hand, I encourage you to see your local provider and ask for a Tdap booster,\" he said. \"It's not a bad idea for parents or even grandparents to check and see if they're outside that window.\"\n\n[Byline: John Green]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kansas, with a population of 2 904 021 in 2014, is a state located in the Midwestern United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Kansas). A map of Kansas counties is available at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/kansas.shtml.\n\nThe news article above reports increasing numbers of cases of pertussis in Reno County, with a population of 64 511 in 2011, which is located in the south-central part of Kansas, and also reports additional new cases in 4 counties that abut Reno (Kingman, Harvey, McPherson and Sedgwick Counties) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reno_County,_Kansas#Education). Last month [June 2015], ProMED-mail also reported cases of pertussis this year (2015) in nearby Barton County, Kansas (Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509).\n\nThe following is extracted from the moderator comments in ProMED post Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509:\n\nIn the U.S., DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nPertussis is nationally notifiable to the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/trends.html). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. During the 1980s the incidence of pertussis began increasing gradually, and peaked in 2012 at 48 277 cases of pertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph.jpg). This was the most reported cases since 1955. Pertussis again declined during 2013 and by 2014, more than 28 000 cases were reported nationwide.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509\nPertussis - That has health officials advising anyone who has regular contact with children, particularly infants, or immune compromised adults, to get a Tdap (tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis) booster. The health department has at least 450 doses of vaccine and is offering the shots free.\n\n\"It's really important for people to be proactive and be on guard for symptoms,\" Baldetti said. \"Anyone suspected of being sick needs [to be] checked immediately. We cannot let cold symptoms be unchecked. It's too widespread now; it's better to be safe than sorry.\" They are particularly focusing on families with school age children, school staff who work with children, and daycare providers.\n\n\"There's serious concern for a potential exponential spread through our schools,\" Baldetti said. \"When they get back to school, it will be concentrated, so we want to focus on that group.\" Active cases, however, range from infants to high school to adults \"and everywhere in between,\" he said. \"We're not isolating our effort to elementary, middle or high school, but all levels of education, daycare providers, churches and businesses. This is truly a widespread outbreak. And it is truly on us, as a community, to ensure we are protecting those in our community that cannot protect themselves. If your children have been vaccinated, but it has been more years than you can count on one hand, I encourage you to see your local provider and ask for a Tdap booster,\" he said. \"It's not a bad idea for parents or even grandparents to check and see if they're outside that window.\"\n\n[Byline: John Green]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kansas, with a population of 2 904 021 in 2014, is a state located in the Midwestern United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Kansas). Last month [June 2015], ProMED-mail also reported cases of pertussis this year (2015) in nearby Barton County, Kansas (Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509).\n\nThe following is extracted from the moderator comments in ProMED post Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509:\n\nIn the U.S., DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nPertussis is nationally notifiable to the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/outbreaks/trends.html). Following the introduction of pertussis vaccines in the 1940s when case counts frequently exceeded 100 000 cases per year, case counts declined dramatically to fewer than 10 000 by 1965. During the 1980s the incidence of pertussis began increasing gradually, and peaked in 2012 at 48 277 cases of pertussis (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/images/incidence-graph.jpg). This was the most reported cases since 1955. Pertussis again declined during 2013 and by 2014, more than 28 000 cases were reported nationwide.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. In 2014, over 10 percent of cases occurred in children under 6 months of age and the incidence rate of pertussis among infants in this age group (about 150 cases per 100 000) exceeded that of all other age groups (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/downloads/pertuss-surv-report-2014.pdf). Most deaths from pertussis occur in infants less than 3 months old. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update 20150618.3446509\nPertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140720.2623332\nPertussis - USA (13) 20140713.2603059\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2070-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-06-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1955-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Midwestern United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=kansa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nickerson", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3537081", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (03): (ON) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3537081", "date": "2015-04-18 09:59:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (08): (NORTH CAROLINA)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2015\nSource: The Transylvania Times [edited]\nhttp://www.transylvaniatimes.com/story/2015/04/16/news/pertussis-cases-back-in-transylvania-county-transylvania-county-nc/22380.html\n\n\nPublic health officials are investigating several cases of pertussis (whooping cough) that have occurred in Transylvania County [North Carolina] in recent months. 5 cases have been confirmed since January [2015].\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious bacterial infection of the mouth, nose, and throat. Symptoms usually begin with cold- or flu-like symptoms such as a runny nose, mild cough, watery eyes, sneezing, and a low-grade fever. The cough becomes worse and often includes rapid coughs followed by a high-pitched whoop; the cough can be severe enough to break a person's rib or cause vomiting.\n\nTransylvania County Department of Public Health is working to find any links between the cases and identify people who have had contact with the sick individuals in order to control the spread of the disease. In late 2014, the county had 31 confirmed cases of pertussis and followed up with more than 450 individuals who had possibly been exposed to the disease.\n\nAll of the cases in 2015 have been in infants 7 months of age and younger, and 2 of these children have been hospitalized. Infants and young children have a higher risk for serious whooping cough, and are more likely to experience serious illness and complications, such as pneumonia, encephalitis and seizures.\n\nOne of the children diagnosed with pertussis was a 4-week-old [girl]. After she developed a cough, she was tested for both RSV [respiratory syncytial virus] and pertussis at her pediatrician's office. \"She didn't really have a 'whoop' like you hear about,\" [her mother] said, \"But you don't always have that at such a young age.\" The RSV test was positive, so she was taken to Mission Children's Hospital in Asheville [North Carolina] to begin treatment. Then, the pertussis test results also came back positive. \"It was scary,\" [her mother] said. \"She's 4 weeks old. She's little. There's not much you can do.\"\n\nSuction helped to clear the mucus from [girl's] airways. She and the rest of her family were put on a course of antibiotics, which are used to control the symptoms and help prevent infected people from spreading the disease.\n\nBecause pertussis is so contagious, it is very important for infected people to stay away from others and take the entire course of antibiotics as prescribed. \"It's miserable and awful, but when they say quarantine, you have to stay home,\" [her mother] said.\n\nThe best way to prevent pertussis is through immunization: the CDC recommends 5 doses of \"DTaP\" [diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus] for young children beginning at 2 months of age. However, the vaccine's protection only lasts 5-10 years, so additional doses of \"Tdap\" should be given at age 11 or 12 and as an adult. Pregnant women should receive a dose during each pregnancy to fully protect their newborns.\n\n\"It's so important to 'cocoon' very young babies by ensuring that all the people around the baby are up-to-date on their pertussis shots,\" said Elaine Russell, health director for Transylvania County. \"This applies not only to mom and dad, but to anyone who spends any significant time with the baby, like grandparents, siblings, and caregivers.\"\n\n\"These immunizations are almost always covered by health insurance, and people who are uninsured can receive the vaccine for no charge here at the health department,\" Russell said.\n\nOlder children and adults who have been fully immunized can still contract and spread pertussis to others, and because they usually have much milder symptoms, they may not even know they are infected. Good hygiene practices -- like hand washing, covering coughs and sneezes, and staying home when sick -- will also help prevent the spread of the disease.\n\n[The 4-month-old girl] still has a slight cough, which is to be expected: pertussis is often called the '100-day cough' because that cough can linger for several months.\n\nWhen it comes to pertussis, [the baby's mother] says that other parents should \"take it very seriously. Heed the warnings, the cautions, and keep them protected,\" she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the US, DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. The news report above fails to tell us if the 4-month-old child's mother received Tdap during her pregnancy, if those in close contact with the infant were also vaccinated, or who was the suspected source of the infant's infection.\n\nThe state of North Carolina can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1159. Transylvania County, with a population of about 33 000 in 2010, is located in the southwestern region of state, on its southern border with the state of South Carolina (http://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina-county-map.gif). -
