USA (23) 20141116.2947034\nPertussis - USA (22) 20141105.2922903\nPertussis - USA (21): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20141015.2864604\nPertussis - USA (20): (CO) increasing incidence 20141005.2833302\nPertussis - USA (19): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20140921.2792202\nPertussis - USA (18): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20140815.2692228\nPertussis - USA (16): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140809.2675224\nPertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140720.2623332\nPertussis - USA (13) 20140713.2603059\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NORTH CAROLINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Asheville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Transylvania County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3446509", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (10): (KS) fatal, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3446509", "date": "2015-04-18 09:59:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (08): (NORTH CAROLINA)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2015\nSource: The Transylvania Times [edited]\nhttp://www.transylvaniatimes.com/story/2015/04/16/news/pertussis-cases-back-in-transylvania-county-transylvania-county-nc/22380.html\n\n\nPublic health officials are investigating several cases of pertussis (whooping cough) that have occurred in Transylvania County [North Carolina] in recent months. 5 cases have been confirmed since January [2015].\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious bacterial infection of the mouth, nose, and throat. Symptoms usually begin with cold- or flu-like symptoms such as a runny nose, mild cough, watery eyes, sneezing, and a low-grade fever. The cough becomes worse and often includes rapid coughs followed by a high-pitched whoop; the cough can be severe enough to break a person's rib or cause vomiting.\n\nTransylvania County Department of Public Health is working to find any links between the cases and identify people who have had contact with the sick individuals in order to control the spread of the disease. In late 2014, the county had 31 confirmed cases of pertussis and followed up with more than 450 individuals who had possibly been exposed to the disease.\n\nAll of the cases in 2015 have been in infants 7 months of age and younger, and 2 of these children have been hospitalized. Infants and young children have a higher risk for serious whooping cough, and are more likely to experience serious illness and complications, such as pneumonia, encephalitis and seizures.\n\nOne of the children diagnosed with pertussis was a 4-week-old [girl]. After she developed a cough, she was tested for both RSV [respiratory syncytial virus] and pertussis at her pediatrician's office. \"She didn't really have a 'whoop' like you hear about,\" [her mother] said, \"But you don't always have that at such a young age.\" The RSV test was positive, so she was taken to Mission Children's Hospital in Asheville [North Carolina] to begin treatment. Then, the pertussis test results also came back positive. \"It was scary,\" [her mother] said. \"She's 4 weeks old. She's little. There's not much you can do.\"\n\nSuction helped to clear the mucus from [girl's] airways. She and the rest of her family were put on a course of antibiotics, which are used to control the symptoms and help prevent infected people from spreading the disease.\n\nBecause pertussis is so contagious, it is very important for infected people to stay away from others and take the entire course of antibiotics as prescribed. \"It's miserable and awful, but when they say quarantine, you have to stay home,\" [her mother] said.\n\nThe best way to prevent pertussis is through immunization: the CDC recommends 5 doses of \"DTaP\" [diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus] for young children beginning at 2 months of age. However, the vaccine's protection only lasts 5-10 years, so additional doses of \"Tdap\" should be given at age 11 or 12 and as an adult. Pregnant women should receive a dose during each pregnancy to fully protect their newborns.\n\n\"It's so important to 'cocoon' very young babies by ensuring that all the people around the baby are up-to-date on their pertussis shots,\" said Elaine Russell, health director for Transylvania County. \"This applies not only to mom and dad, but to anyone who spends any significant time with the baby, like grandparents, siblings, and caregivers.\"\n\n\"These immunizations are almost always covered by health insurance, and people who are uninsured can receive the vaccine for no charge here at the health department,\" Russell said.\n\nOlder children and adults who have been fully immunized can still contract and spread pertussis to others, and because they usually have much milder symptoms, they may not even know they are infected. Good hygiene practices -- like hand washing, covering coughs and sneezes, and staying home when sick -- will also help prevent the spread of the disease.\n\n[The 4-month-old girl] still has a slight cough, which is to be expected: pertussis is often called the '100-day cough' because that cough can linger for several months.\n\nWhen it comes to pertussis, [the baby's mother] says that other parents should \"take it very seriously. Heed the warnings, the cautions, and keep them protected,\" she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the US, DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. The news report above fails to tell us if the 4-month-old child's mother received Tdap during her pregnancy, if those in close contact with the infant were also vaccinated, or who was the suspected source of the infant's infection.\n\nThe state of North Carolina can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1159. Transylvania County, with a population of about 33 000 in 2010, is located in the southwestern region of state, on its southern border with the state of South Carolina (http://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina-county-map.gif). - Symptoms usually begin with cold- or flu-like symptoms such as a runny nose, mild cough, watery eyes, sneezing, and a low-grade fever. The cough becomes worse and often includes rapid coughs followed by a high-pitched whoop; the cough can be severe enough to break a person's rib or cause vomiting.\n\nTransylvania County Department of Public Health is working to find any links between the cases and identify people who have had contact with the sick individuals in order to control the spread of the disease. Infants and young children have a higher risk for serious whooping cough, and are more likely to experience serious illness and complications, such as pneumonia, encephalitis and seizures.\n\nOne of the children diagnosed with pertussis was a 4-week-old [girl]. However, the vaccine's protection only lasts 5-10 years, so additional doses of \"Tdap\" should be given at age 11 or 12 and as an adult. Pregnant women should receive a dose during each pregnancy to fully protect their newborns.\n\n\"It's so important to 'cocoon' very young babies by ensuring that all the people around the baby are up-to-date on their pertussis shots,\" said Elaine Russell, health director for Transylvania County. \"This applies not only to mom and dad, but to anyone who spends any significant time with the baby, like grandparents, siblings, and caregivers.\"\n\n\"These immunizations are almost always covered by health insurance, and people who are uninsured can receive the vaccine for no charge here at the health department,\" Russell said.\n\nOlder children and adults who have been fully immunized can still contract and spread pertussis to others, and because they usually have much milder symptoms, they may not even know they are infected. Australia (04): waning immunity, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3344844", "date": "2015-04-18 09:59:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (08): (NORTH CAROLINA)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2015\nSource: The Transylvania Times [edited]\nhttp://www.transylvaniatimes.com/story/2015/04/16/news/pertussis-cases-back-in-transylvania-county-transylvania-county-nc/22380.html\n\n\nPublic health officials are investigating several cases of pertussis (whooping cough) that have occurred in Transylvania County [North Carolina] in recent months. 5 cases have been confirmed since January [2015].\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious bacterial infection of the mouth, nose, and throat. Symptoms usually begin with cold- or flu-like symptoms such as a runny nose, mild cough, watery eyes, sneezing, and a low-grade fever. The cough becomes worse and often includes rapid coughs followed by a high-pitched whoop; the cough can be severe enough to break a person's rib or cause vomiting.\n\nTransylvania County Department of Public Health is working to find any links between the cases and identify people who have had contact with the sick individuals in order to control the spread of the disease. In late 2014, the county had 31 confirmed cases of pertussis and followed up with more than 450 individuals who had possibly been exposed to the disease.\n\nAll of the cases in 2015 have been in infants 7 months of age and younger, and 2 of these children have been hospitalized. Infants and young children have a higher risk for serious whooping cough, and are more likely to experience serious illness and complications, such as pneumonia, encephalitis and seizures.\n\nOne of the children diagnosed with pertussis was a 4-week-old [girl]. After she developed a cough, she was tested for both RSV [respiratory syncytial virus] and pertussis at her pediatrician's office. \"She didn't really have a 'whoop' like you hear about,\" [her mother] said, \"But you don't always have that at such a young age.\" The RSV test was positive, so she was taken to Mission Children's Hospital in Asheville [North Carolina] to begin treatment. Then, the pertussis test results also came back positive. \"It was scary,\" [her mother] said. \"She's 4 weeks old. She's little. There's not much you can do.\"\n\nSuction helped to clear the mucus from [girl's] airways. She and the rest of her family were put on a course of antibiotics, which are used to control the symptoms and help prevent infected people from spreading the disease.\n\nBecause pertussis is so contagious, it is very important for infected people to stay away from others and take the entire course of antibiotics as prescribed. \"It's miserable and awful, but when they say quarantine, you have to stay home,\" [her mother] said.\n\nThe best way to prevent pertussis is through immunization: the CDC recommends 5 doses of \"DTaP\" [diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus] for young children beginning at 2 months of age. However, the vaccine's protection only lasts 5-10 years, so additional doses of \"Tdap\" should be given at age 11 or 12 and as an adult. Pregnant women should receive a dose during each pregnancy to fully protect their newborns.\n\n\"It's so important to 'cocoon' very young babies by ensuring that all the people around the baby are up-to-date on their pertussis shots,\" said Elaine Russell, health director for Transylvania County. \"This applies not only to mom and dad, but to anyone who spends any significant time with the baby, like grandparents, siblings, and caregivers.\"\n\n\"These immunizations are almost always covered by health insurance, and people who are uninsured can receive the vaccine for no charge here at the health department,\" Russell said.\n\nOlder children and adults who have been fully immunized can still contract and spread pertussis to others, and because they usually have much milder symptoms, they may not even know they are infected. Good hygiene practices -- like hand washing, covering coughs and sneezes, and staying home when sick -- will also help prevent the spread of the disease.\n\n[The 4-month-old girl] still has a slight cough, which is to be expected: pertussis is often called the '100-day cough' because that cough can linger for several months.\n\nWhen it comes to pertussis, [the baby's mother] says that other parents should \"take it very seriously. Heed the warnings, the cautions, and keep them protected,\" she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the US, DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. The news report above fails to tell us if the 4-month-old child's mother received Tdap during her pregnancy, if those in close contact with the infant were also vaccinated, or who was the suspected source of the infant's infection.\n\nThe state of North Carolina can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1159. Transylvania County, with a population of about 33 000 in 2010, is located in the southwestern region of state, on its southern border with the state of South Carolina (http://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina-county-map.gif). - UK: (England) increasing incidence, 2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3344092", "date": "2015-04-18 09:59:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (08): (NORTH CAROLINA)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2015\nSource: The Transylvania Times [edited]\nhttp://www.transylvaniatimes.com/story/2015/04/16/news/pertussis-cases-back-in-transylvania-county-transylvania-county-nc/22380.html\n\n\nPublic health officials are investigating several cases of pertussis (whooping cough) that have occurred in Transylvania County [North Carolina] in recent months. 5 cases have been confirmed since January [2015].\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious bacterial infection of the mouth, nose, and throat. Symptoms usually begin with cold- or flu-like symptoms such as a runny nose, mild cough, watery eyes, sneezing, and a low-grade fever. The cough becomes worse and often includes rapid coughs followed by a high-pitched whoop; the cough can be severe enough to break a person's rib or cause vomiting.\n\nTransylvania County Department of Public Health is working to find any links between the cases and identify people who have had contact with the sick individuals in order to control the spread of the disease. In late 2014, the county had 31 confirmed cases of pertussis and followed up with more than 450 individuals who had possibly been exposed to the disease.\n\nAll of the cases in 2015 have been in infants 7 months of age and younger, and 2 of these children have been hospitalized. Infants and young children have a higher risk for serious whooping cough, and are more likely to experience serious illness and complications, such as pneumonia, encephalitis and seizures.\n\nOne of the children diagnosed with pertussis was a 4-week-old [girl]. After she developed a cough, she was tested for both RSV [respiratory syncytial virus] and pertussis at her pediatrician's office. \"She didn't really have a 'whoop' like you hear about,\" [her mother] said, \"But you don't always have that at such a young age.\" The RSV test was positive, so she was taken to Mission Children's Hospital in Asheville [North Carolina] to begin treatment. Then, the pertussis test results also came back positive. \"It was scary,\" [her mother] said. \"She's 4 weeks old. She's little. There's not much you can do.\"\n\nSuction helped to clear the mucus from [girl's] airways. She and the rest of her family were put on a course of antibiotics, which are used to control the symptoms and help prevent infected people from spreading the disease.\n\nBecause pertussis is so contagious, it is very important for infected people to stay away from others and take the entire course of antibiotics as prescribed. \"It's miserable and awful, but when they say quarantine, you have to stay home,\" [her mother] said.\n\nThe best way to prevent pertussis is through immunization: the CDC recommends 5 doses of \"DTaP\" [diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus] for young children beginning at 2 months of age. However, the vaccine's protection only lasts 5-10 years, so additional doses of \"Tdap\" should be given at age 11 or 12 and as an adult. Pregnant women should receive a dose during each pregnancy to fully protect their newborns.\n\n\"It's so important to 'cocoon' very young babies by ensuring that all the people around the baby are up-to-date on their pertussis shots,\" said Elaine Russell, health director for Transylvania County. \"This applies not only to mom and dad, but to anyone who spends any significant time with the baby, like grandparents, siblings, and caregivers.\"\n\n\"These immunizations are almost always covered by health insurance, and people who are uninsured can receive the vaccine for no charge here at the health department,\" Russell said.\n\nOlder children and adults who have been fully immunized can still contract and spread pertussis to others, and because they usually have much milder symptoms, they may not even know they are infected. Good hygiene practices -- like hand washing, covering coughs and sneezes, and staying home when sick -- will also help prevent the spread of the disease.\n\n[The 4-month-old girl] still has a slight cough, which is to be expected: pertussis is often called the '100-day cough' because that cough can linger for several months.\n\nWhen it comes to pertussis, [the baby's mother] says that other parents should \"take it very seriously. Heed the warnings, the cautions, and keep them protected,\" she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the US, DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. The news report above fails to tell us if the 4-month-old child's mother received Tdap during her pregnancy, if those in close contact with the infant were also vaccinated, or who was the suspected source of the infant's infection.\n\nThe state of North Carolina can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1159. Symptoms usually begin with cold- or flu-like symptoms such as a runny nose, mild cough, watery eyes, sneezing, and a low-grade fever. The cough becomes worse and often includes rapid coughs followed by a high-pitched whoop; the cough can be severe enough to break a person's rib or cause vomiting.\n\nTransylvania County Department of Public Health is working to find any links between the cases and identify people who have had contact with the sick individuals in order to control the spread of the disease. Infants and young children have a higher risk for serious whooping cough, and are more likely to experience serious illness and complications, such as pneumonia, encephalitis and seizures.\n\nOne of the children diagnosed with pertussis was a 4-week-old [girl]. However, the vaccine's protection only lasts 5-10 years, so additional doses of \"Tdap\" should be given at age 11 or 12 and as an adult. Pregnant women should receive a dose during each pregnancy to fully protect their newborns.\n\n\"It's so important to 'cocoon' very young babies by ensuring that all the people around the baby are up-to-date on their pertussis shots,\" said Elaine Russell, health director for Transylvania County. \"This applies not only to mom and dad, but to anyone who spends any significant time with the baby, like grandparents, siblings, and caregivers.\"\n\n\"These immunizations are almost always covered by health insurance, and people who are uninsured can receive the vaccine for no charge here at the health department,\" Russell said.\n\nOlder children and adults who have been fully immunized can still contract and spread pertussis to others, and because they usually have much milder symptoms, they may not even know they are infected. Good hygiene practices -- like hand washing, covering coughs and sneezes, and staying home when sick -- will also help prevent the spread of the disease.\n\n[The 4-month-old girl] still has a slight cough, which is to be expected: pertussis is often called the '100-day cough' because that cough can linger for several months.\n\nWhen it comes to pertussis, [the baby's mother] says that other parents should \"take it very seriously. USA (09)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3320344", "date": "2015-04-18 09:59:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (08): (NORTH CAROLINA)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2015\nSource: The Transylvania Times [edited]\nhttp://www.transylvaniatimes.com/story/2015/04/16/news/pertussis-cases-back-in-transylvania-county-transylvania-county-nc/22380.html\n\n\nPublic health officials are investigating several cases of pertussis (whooping cough) that have occurred in Transylvania County [North Carolina] in recent months. 5 cases have been confirmed since January [2015].\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious bacterial infection of the mouth, nose, and throat. Symptoms usually begin with cold- or flu-like symptoms such as a runny nose, mild cough, watery eyes, sneezing, and a low-grade fever. The cough becomes worse and often includes rapid coughs followed by a high-pitched whoop; the cough can be severe enough to break a person's rib or cause vomiting.\n\nTransylvania County Department of Public Health is working to find any links between the cases and identify people who have had contact with the sick individuals in order to control the spread of the disease. In late 2014, the county had 31 confirmed cases of pertussis and followed up with more than 450 individuals who had possibly been exposed to the disease.\n\nAll of the cases in 2015 have been in infants 7 months of age and younger, and 2 of these children have been hospitalized. Infants and young children have a higher risk for serious whooping cough, and are more likely to experience serious illness and complications, such as pneumonia, encephalitis and seizures.\n\nOne of the children diagnosed with pertussis was a 4-week-old [girl]. After she developed a cough, she was tested for both RSV [respiratory syncytial virus] and pertussis at her pediatrician's office. \"She didn't really have a 'whoop' like you hear about,\" [her mother] said, \"But you don't always have that at such a young age.\" The RSV test was positive, so she was taken to Mission Children's Hospital in Asheville [North Carolina] to begin treatment. Then, the pertussis test results also came back positive. \"It was scary,\" [her mother] said. \"She's 4 weeks old. She's little. There's not much you can do.\"\n\nSuction helped to clear the mucus from [girl's] airways. She and the rest of her family were put on a course of antibiotics, which are used to control the symptoms and help prevent infected people from spreading the disease.\n\nBecause pertussis is so contagious, it is very important for infected people to stay away from others and take the entire course of antibiotics as prescribed. \"It's miserable and awful, but when they say quarantine, you have to stay home,\" [her mother] said.\n\nThe best way to prevent pertussis is through immunization: the CDC recommends 5 doses of \"DTaP\" [diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus] for young children beginning at 2 months of age. However, the vaccine's protection only lasts 5-10 years, so additional doses of \"Tdap\" should be given at age 11 or 12 and as an adult. Pregnant women should receive a dose during each pregnancy to fully protect their newborns.\n\n\"It's so important to 'cocoon' very young babies by ensuring that all the people around the baby are up-to-date on their pertussis shots,\" said Elaine Russell, health director for Transylvania County. \"This applies not only to mom and dad, but to anyone who spends any significant time with the baby, like grandparents, siblings, and caregivers.\"\n\n\"These immunizations are almost always covered by health insurance, and people who are uninsured can receive the vaccine for no charge here at the health department,\" Russell said.\n\nOlder children and adults who have been fully immunized can still contract and spread pertussis to others, and because they usually have much milder symptoms, they may not even know they are infected. Good hygiene practices -- like hand washing, covering coughs and sneezes, and staying home when sick -- will also help prevent the spread of the disease.\n\n[The 4-month-old girl] still has a slight cough, which is to be expected: pertussis is often called the '100-day cough' because that cough can linger for several months.\n\nWhen it comes to pertussis, [the baby's mother] says that other parents should \"take it very seriously. Heed the warnings, the cautions, and keep them protected,\" she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the US, DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. The news report above fails to tell us if the 4-month-old child's mother received Tdap during her pregnancy, if those in close contact with the infant were also vaccinated, or who was the suspected source of the infant's infection.\n\nThe state of North Carolina can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1159. Transylvania County, with a population of about 33 000 in 2010, is located in the southwestern region of state, on its southern border with the state of South Carolina (http://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina-county-map.gif). - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (07) 20150412.3292930\nPertussis - USA (06): (CA) infant fatality 20150314.3230176\nPertussis - USA (05): (OR) 20150314.3229781\nPertussis - USA (04) 20150205.3141284\nPertussis - USA (03): (MD) health care worker presenteeism, 2014 20150123.3111598\nPertussis - USA (02) 20150116.3094367\nPertussis - USA: (CA) fatal 20150115.3093551\n2014\n----\nPertussis - USA (30) 20141228.3058832\nPertussis - USA (23) 20141116.2947034\nPertussis - USA (22) 20141105.2922903\nPertussis - USA (21): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20141015.2864604\nPertussis - USA (20): (CO) increasing incidence 20141005.2833302\nPertussis - USA (19): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20140921.2792202\nPertussis - USA (18): (CA) increasing incidence, update 20140815.2692228\nPertussis - USA (16): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140809.2675224\nPertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140720.2623332\nPertussis - USA (13) 20140713.2603059\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NORTH CAROLINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Asheville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Transylvania County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3305675", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (08): (NC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3305675", "date": "2015-04-18 09:59:47", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (08): (NORTH CAROLINA)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2015\nSource: The Transylvania Times [edited]\nhttp://www.transylvaniatimes.com/story/2015/04/16/news/pertussis-cases-back-in-transylvania-county-transylvania-county-nc/22380.html\n\n\nPublic health officials are investigating several cases of pertussis (whooping cough) that have occurred in Transylvania County [North Carolina] in recent months. 5 cases have been confirmed since January [2015].\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious bacterial infection of the mouth, nose, and throat. Symptoms usually begin with cold- or flu-like symptoms such as a runny nose, mild cough, watery eyes, sneezing, and a low-grade fever. The cough becomes worse and often includes rapid coughs followed by a high-pitched whoop; the cough can be severe enough to break a person's rib or cause vomiting.\n\nTransylvania County Department of Public Health is working to find any links between the cases and identify people who have had contact with the sick individuals in order to control the spread of the disease. In late 2014, the county had 31 confirmed cases of pertussis and followed up with more than 450 individuals who had possibly been exposed to the disease.\n\nAll of the cases in 2015 have been in infants 7 months of age and younger, and 2 of these children have been hospitalized. Infants and young children have a higher risk for serious whooping cough, and are more likely to experience serious illness and complications, such as pneumonia, encephalitis and seizures.\n\nOne of the children diagnosed with pertussis was a 4-week-old [girl]. After she developed a cough, she was tested for both RSV [respiratory syncytial virus] and pertussis at her pediatrician's office. \"She didn't really have a 'whoop' like you hear about,\" [her mother] said, \"But you don't always have that at such a young age.\" The RSV test was positive, so she was taken to Mission Children's Hospital in Asheville [North Carolina] to begin treatment. Then, the pertussis test results also came back positive. \"It was scary,\" [her mother] said. \"She's 4 weeks old. She's little. There's not much you can do.\"\n\nSuction helped to clear the mucus from [girl's] airways. She and the rest of her family were put on a course of antibiotics, which are used to control the symptoms and help prevent infected people from spreading the disease.\n\nBecause pertussis is so contagious, it is very important for infected people to stay away from others and take the entire course of antibiotics as prescribed. \"It's miserable and awful, but when they say quarantine, you have to stay home,\" [her mother] said.\n\nThe best way to prevent pertussis is through immunization: the CDC recommends 5 doses of \"DTaP\" [diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus] for young children beginning at 2 months of age. However, the vaccine's protection only lasts 5-10 years, so additional doses of \"Tdap\" should be given at age 11 or 12 and as an adult. Pregnant women should receive a dose during each pregnancy to fully protect their newborns.\n\n\"It's so important to 'cocoon' very young babies by ensuring that all the people around the baby are up-to-date on their pertussis shots,\" said Elaine Russell, health director for Transylvania County. \"This applies not only to mom and dad, but to anyone who spends any significant time with the baby, like grandparents, siblings, and caregivers.\"\n\n\"These immunizations are almost always covered by health insurance, and people who are uninsured can receive the vaccine for no charge here at the health department,\" Russell said.\n\nOlder children and adults who have been fully immunized can still contract and spread pertussis to others, and because they usually have much milder symptoms, they may not even know they are infected. Good hygiene practices -- like hand washing, covering coughs and sneezes, and staying home when sick -- will also help prevent the spread of the disease.\n\n[The 4-month-old girl] still has a slight cough, which is to be expected: pertussis is often called the '100-day cough' because that cough can linger for several months.\n\nWhen it comes to pertussis, [the baby's mother] says that other parents should \"take it very seriously. Heed the warnings, the cautions, and keep them protected,\" she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the US, DTaP and Tdap vaccines are used for pertussis immunization (http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm#vacc). Upper-case letters in these abbreviations denote full-strength doses of diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) toxoids, and pertussis (P) vaccine. Lower-case \"d\" and \"p\" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. The \"a\" in DTaP and Tdap stands for \"acellular,\" meaning that the pertussis component contains only a part of the pertussis organism.\n\nDTaP is given to children younger than 7 years of age, and Tdap is given to older children and adults. Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years of age. Adolescents 11 through 18 years of age (preferably at age 11-12 years) should receive a single dose of Tdap. One dose of Tdap is also recommended for adults 19 years of age and older who did not get Tdap as an adolescent. Expectant mothers should receive Tdap during each pregnancy, preferably at 27 through 36 weeks, because maternal antibodies are acquired by the fetus following maternal vaccination during this time. Tdap should also be given to 7-10 year olds who are not fully immunized against pertussis.\n\nBecause infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated are the most vulnerable to severe, sometimes fatal, cases of pertussis, it is important for all those in close contact with newborns and infants (such as, parents, grandparents, siblings, and other care givers) to have up-to-date vaccination. The news report above fails to tell us if the 4-month-old child's mother received Tdap during her pregnancy, if those in close contact with the infant were also vaccinated, or who was the suspected source of the infant's infection.\n\nThe state of North Carolina can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1159. Transylvania County, with a population of about 33 000 in 2010, is located in the southwestern region of state, on its southern border with the state of South Carolina (http://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina-county-map.gif). - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140720.2623332\nPertussis - USA (13) 20140713.2603059\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NORTH CAROLINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Asheville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Transylvania County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3292931", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (02): (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3292931", "date": "2015-01-28 21:03:03", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - BRAZIL: (ACRE) INDIGENOUS PEOPLE, INFANT MORTALITY\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Jan 2015\nSource: A Gazeta do Acre [in Portuguese, machine trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://agazetadoacre.com/noticias/epidemia-de-coqueluche-matou-11-criancas-indigenas-em-2014-no-acre/\n\n\nFrom June to September 2014, 11 children of indigenous people of the Rio Breu area in Acre State, died with suspected pertussis. 9 of the children were from the Kaxinawa Indigenous Land called HuniKui, and 2 were of the Ashaninka people. One of the victims was 7 years of age, however, the majority were between 1 and 3 months of age.\n\nFor the communities to receive medical care, it is necessary to go by a motor canoe to the municipality of Marechal Thaumaturgo is necessary. The closest village, San Jose, can be 8 to 12 hours of additional travel when the level of the river is high, and the hard trip to the farthest town, Jacobina, takes 2 days. When the river is dry, the journey can take up to 4 days with some stretches traveled on foot, carrying the canoe. 2 children did not survive the long journey over the past year.\n\nAlthough the diagnosis of pertussis has not been confirmed, the symptoms are similar to those of the disease. The disease in older children and in adults was not so severe as it was in the young infants.\n\n[Byline: Isabela Gadelha]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. In such remote areas, the degree, if any, of medical care and the availability of antimicrobials and vaccines are likely to be quite problematic.\n\nA recent publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904; http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817).\n\nMaps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10553. Acre (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acre_(state)) is located in the westernmost part of the Brazil, with a 2-hour time difference from Brasilia. It is bordered clockwise by Amazonas to the north and northeast, Rondonia to the east, the Bolivian department of Pando to the southeast, and the Peruvian regions of Madre de Dios, Ucayali, and Loreto to the south and west. It occupies an area of 152 581.4 sq km, being slightly smaller than Tunisia. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nPertussis - Brazil (04): (PI) 20141222.3048988\nPertussis - Brazil (03): (PE) 20140719.2620446\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\n.................................................rna/ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-01-27 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Kaxinawa Indigenous Land", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Loreto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Jose", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jacobina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rondonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tunisia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Acre State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brasilia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3292930", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (07)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3292930", "date": "2015-01-28 21:03:03", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - BRAZIL: (ACRE) INDIGENOUS PEOPLE, INFANT MORTALITY\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Jan 2015\nSource: A Gazeta do Acre [in Portuguese, machine trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://agazetadoacre.com/noticias/epidemia-de-coqueluche-matou-11-criancas-indigenas-em-2014-no-acre/\n\n\nFrom June to September 2014, 11 children of indigenous people of the Rio Breu area in Acre State, died with suspected pertussis. 9 of the children were from the Kaxinawa Indigenous Land called HuniKui, and 2 were of the Ashaninka people. One of the victims was 7 years of age, however, the majority were between 1 and 3 months of age.\n\nFor the communities to receive medical care, it is necessary to go by a motor canoe to the municipality of Marechal Thaumaturgo is necessary. The closest village, San Jose, can be 8 to 12 hours of additional travel when the level of the river is high, and the hard trip to the farthest town, Jacobina, takes 2 days. When the river is dry, the journey can take up to 4 days with some stretches traveled on foot, carrying the canoe. 2 children did not survive the long journey over the past year.\n\nAlthough the diagnosis of pertussis has not been confirmed, the symptoms are similar to those of the disease. The disease in older children and in adults was not so severe as it was in the young infants.\n\n[Byline: Isabela Gadelha]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. Acre (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acre_(state)) is located in the westernmost part of the Brazil, with a 2-hour time difference from Brasilia. It is bordered clockwise by Amazonas to the north and northeast, Rondonia to the east, the Bolivian department of Pando to the southeast, and the Peruvian regions of Madre de Dios, Ucayali, and Loreto to the south and west. New Zealand (03): update 20120706.1190855\nPertussis - Argentina (03): (MZ) 20120703.1188519\nPertussis - UK (02): background 20120608.1161130\nPertussis - UK 20120607.1159983\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\n.................................................rna/ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-01-27 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Kaxinawa Indigenous Land", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Loreto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Jose", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jacobina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rondonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tunisia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Acre State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brasilia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3230176", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (06): (CA) infant fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3230176", "date": "2015-01-28 21:03:03", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - BRAZIL: (ACRE) INDIGENOUS PEOPLE, INFANT MORTALITY\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Jan 2015\nSource: A Gazeta do Acre [in Portuguese, machine trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://agazetadoacre.com/noticias/epidemia-de-coqueluche-matou-11-criancas-indigenas-em-2014-no-acre/\n\n\nFrom June to September 2014, 11 children of indigenous people of the Rio Breu area in Acre State, died with suspected pertussis. 9 of the children were from the Kaxinawa Indigenous Land called HuniKui, and 2 were of the Ashaninka people. One of the victims was 7 years of age, however, the majority were between 1 and 3 months of age.\n\nFor the communities to receive medical care, it is necessary to go by a motor canoe to the municipality of Marechal Thaumaturgo is necessary. The closest village, San Jose, can be 8 to 12 hours of additional travel when the level of the river is high, and the hard trip to the farthest town, Jacobina, takes 2 days. When the river is dry, the journey can take up to 4 days with some stretches traveled on foot, carrying the canoe. 2 children did not survive the long journey over the past year.\n\nAlthough the diagnosis of pertussis has not been confirmed, the symptoms are similar to those of the disease. The disease in older children and in adults was not so severe as it was in the young infants.\n\n[Byline: Isabela Gadelha]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. In such remote areas, the degree, if any, of medical care and the availability of antimicrobials and vaccines are likely to be quite problematic.\n\nA recent publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904; http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817).\n\nMaps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10553. Acre (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acre_(state)) is located in the westernmost part of the Brazil, with a 2-hour time difference from Brasilia. It is bordered clockwise by Amazonas to the north and northeast, Rondonia to the east, the Bolivian department of Pando to the southeast, and the Peruvian regions of Madre de Dios, Ucayali, and Loreto to the south and west. It occupies an area of 152 581.4 sq km, being slightly smaller than Tunisia. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nPertussis - Brazil (04): (PI) 20141222.3048988\nPertussis - Brazil (03): (PE) 20140719.2620446\nPertussis - Brazil (02): (BA) 20140630.2577639\nPertussis - Brazil: (SP) fatalities 20140608.2526398\n2012\n----\nPertussis - Colombia (02): fatal 20121119.1415845\nPertussis - UK (03) 20120710.1196457\nPertussis - New Zealand (03): update 20120706.1190855\nPertussis - Argentina (03): (MZ) 20120703.1188519\nPertussis - UK (02): background 20120608.1161130\nPertussis - UK 20120607.1159983\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\n.................................................rna/ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-01-27 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Kaxinawa Indigenous Land", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Loreto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Jose", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jacobina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rondonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tunisia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Acre State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brasilia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3229781", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - One of the victims was 7 years of age, however, the majority were between 1 and 3 months of age.\n\nFor the communities to receive medical care, it is necessary to go by a motor canoe to the municipality of Marechal Thaumaturgo is necessary. The closest village, San Jose, can be 8 to 12 hours of additional travel when the level of the river is high, and the hard trip to the farthest town, Jacobina, takes 2 days. When the river is dry, the journey can take up to 4 days with some stretches traveled on foot, carrying the canoe. 2 children did not survive the long journey over the past year.\n\nAlthough the diagnosis of pertussis has not been confirmed, the symptoms are similar to those of the disease. The disease in older children and in adults was not so severe as it was in the young infants.\n\n[Byline: Isabela Gadelha]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. In such remote areas, the degree, if any, of medical care and the availability of antimicrobials and vaccines are likely to be quite problematic.\n\nA recent publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904; http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817).\n\nMaps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10553. Acre (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acre_(state)) is located in the westernmost part of the Brazil, with a 2-hour time difference from Brasilia. It is bordered clockwise by Amazonas to the north and northeast, Rondonia to the east, the Bolivian department of Pando to the southeast, and the Peruvian regions of Madre de Dios, Ucayali, and Loreto to the south and west. It occupies an area of 152 581.4 sq km, being slightly smaller than Tunisia. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nPertussis - Brazil (04): (PI) 20141222.3048988\nPertussis - Brazil (03): (PE) 20140719.2620446\nPertussis - Brazil (02): (BA) 20140630.2577639\nPertussis - Brazil: (SP) fatalities 20140608.2526398\n2012\n----\nPertussis - Colombia (02): fatal 20121119.1415845\nPertussis - UK (03) 20120710.1196457\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\n.................................................rna/ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-01-27 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Kaxinawa Indigenous Land", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Loreto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Jose", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jacobina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rondonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tunisia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Acre State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brasilia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3126014", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Brazil: (AC) indigenous people, infant mortality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3126014", "date": "2015-01-28 21:03:03", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - BRAZIL: (ACRE) INDIGENOUS PEOPLE, INFANT MORTALITY\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Jan 2015\nSource: A Gazeta do Acre [in Portuguese, machine trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://agazetadoacre.com/noticias/epidemia-de-coqueluche-matou-11-criancas-indigenas-em-2014-no-acre/\n\n\nFrom June to September 2014, 11 children of indigenous people of the Rio Breu area in Acre State, died with suspected pertussis. 9 of the children were from the Kaxinawa Indigenous Land called HuniKui, and 2 were of the Ashaninka people. One of the victims was 7 years of age, however, the majority were between 1 and 3 months of age.\n\nFor the communities to receive medical care, it is necessary to go by a motor canoe to the municipality of Marechal Thaumaturgo is necessary. The closest village, San Jose, can be 8 to 12 hours of additional travel when the level of the river is high, and the hard trip to the farthest town, Jacobina, takes 2 days. When the river is dry, the journey can take up to 4 days with some stretches traveled on foot, carrying the canoe. 2 children did not survive the long journey over the past year.\n\nAlthough the diagnosis of pertussis has not been confirmed, the symptoms are similar to those of the disease. The disease in older children and in adults was not so severe as it was in the young infants.\n\n[Byline: Isabela Gadelha]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Neonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental oxygen in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. In such remote areas, the degree, if any, of medical care and the availability of antimicrobials and vaccines are likely to be quite problematic.\n\nA recent publication confirms the safety of maternal pertussis immunization: Kharbanda EO, Vazquez-Benitez G, Lipkind HS, et al: Evaluation of the association of maternal pertussis vaccination with obstetric events and birth outcomes. JAMA. 2014; 312(18): 1897-904; http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1930817).\n\nMaps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10553. Acre (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acre_(state)) is located in the westernmost part of the Brazil, with a 2-hour time difference from Brasilia. It is bordered clockwise by Amazonas to the north and northeast, Rondonia to the east, the Bolivian department of Pando to the southeast, and the Peruvian regions of Madre de Dios, Ucayali, and Loreto to the south and west. USA (03): (MD) health care worker presenteeism, 2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3111598", "date": "2014-12-22 16:29:28", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (29)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\n[2] Montana (Gallatin County)\n[3] Nebraska (Dodge, Saunders and Washington counties)\n[4] California\n[5] Ohio (Holmes County)\n[6] Texas\n[7] New Mexico (Valencia County)\n\n******\n[1] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: MLive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/12/whooping_cough_outbreak_in_gra.html\n\n\nThe pertussis outbreak in Grand Traverse County [Michigan] has reached 70 confirmed cases, plus 14 cases of a similar disease, called parapertussis, according to the health department. Students at 19 schools in the county have been affected by the disease, also known as whooping cough. The county health department has received 3750 calls to the hotline set up to field questions from parents of children who may have been exposed to the illness.\n\nAs they announced the update on the outbreak on Thu 18 Dec 2014, health officials urged residents to get vaccinated in advance of holiday travel and get-togethers. \"Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority,\" said Wendy Trute, the Grand Traverse health officer. \"We urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated. We also urge parents to vaccinate infants as soon as possible.\"\n\nA pertussis outbreak was reported in November 2014 at Grand Traverse Academy, a charter school. The number of confirmed cases linked to the school remains at 12, said Mike Lahey. He did not have numbers on the cases in the Traverse City Area Public School District.\n\n[byline: Sue Thoms]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It appears that a significant minority of students at Grand Traverse Academy were unvaccinated related to \"philosophical\" objections of the parents. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Montana (Gallatin County)\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Belgrade News [edited]\nhttp://www.belgrade-news.com/news/article_ac6e21ac-871d-11e4-9f73-ef7df241ce97.html\n\n\nAs of Thu 18 Dec 2014, 9 students in Three Forks Schools [Gallatin County, Montana] are confirmed to have whooping cough. 4 children in grades kindergarten through 5th have the respiratory illness and 5 in the middle and high school contracted it. A press release issued on the school's website on states, \"The school is a safe place for all stakeholders and unless your son or daughter has been diagnosed with pertussis, there is not any reason that they should not be in school.\"\n\nWhooping cough is spread in much the same way as a regular cold virus, by coughing or sneezing while in close contact with others who then breath in the bacteria. There is a pertussis vaccination, which the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] says is the most effective tool in preventing the disease. But the vaccine is not 100 per cent effective.\n\nThree Forks School officials say the Gallatin City-County Health Department is working closely with the school staff to interview every person with a confirmed case of pertussis to identify close contacts. According to Gallatin City-County health officer Matt Kelley, there have been no other confirmed pertussis cases at other schools in the Gallatin Valley.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The vaccination status of the affected students is not stated. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[3] Nebraska (Dodge, Saunders and Washington counties)\nDate: Tue 16 Dec 2014\nSource: The Republic, Associated Press report [edited]\nhttp://www.therepublic.com/view/story/9a0752fa5c6841d5b249fa8064de1f5c/NE--Eastern-Nebraska-Illnesses\n\n\nAn eastern Nebraska health department is reporting several cases of whooping cough. The Fremont Tribune reports that Three Rivers Health Department in Fremont says at least 2 cases of whooping cough have been confirmed in the district, which includes Dodge, Saunders and Washington counties.\n\nWhooping cough, or pertussis, is spread when infected people cough or sneeze. It starts like the common cold and can progress into violent coughing spells.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] California\nDate: Mon 15 Dec 2014\nSource: Oregon Live, Associated Press report [edited]\nhttp://www.oregonlive.com/health/index.ssf/2014/12/whooping_cough_epidemic_hits_c.html\n\n\nCalifornia officials are battling the worst whooping cough epidemic to hit the state in 7 decades as a recent rebound in cases raises questions about the effectiveness of the pertussis vaccine. Doctors emphasize that the inoculation has led to fewer deaths than in the past and in instances where people do get sick, their illnesses aren't as severe. But California officials say the limited protection of the vaccine introduced in the 1990s has led to the rise in cases. Research has shown it doesn't last as long as the one it replaced, and a new study suggests the vaccine may not prevent the spread of the disease. Whooping cough peaks every 3 to 5 years, and California's last epidemic was in 2010. But despite an aggressive public health campaign in response, the current outbreak is worse.\n\nA total of 9935 cases were reported to the California Department of Public Health from 1 Jan 2014 to 26 Nov 2014, the highest number in 70 years. The cases included an infant who died. Elementary, middle and high school outbreaks have occurred across the state. San Diego County is among the hardest hit areas with 1819 cases reported so far in 2014.\n\n\"We'd have to go way back to the 1940s to find more cases,\" said Dr Eric McDonald, medical director of the epidemiology and immunization branch for public health services in San Diego County. That's when whooping cough was common, causing hundreds of thousands of illnesses annually and thousands of deaths. But after a vaccine was introduced in the 1940s, cases dropped to fewer than 5000 a year. That vaccine was replaced in the 1990s because of side effects, which included pain and swelling from the shot and fever. The newer vaccine is part of routine childhood vaccinations as well as adult booster shots. [the older killed whole cell vaccine was thought to be too reactogenic in adults. - Mod.LL]\n\n2013 was the nation's worst year for whooping cough in 6 decades; health officials received reports of more than 48 000 cases, including 18 deaths. In 2014, the number of reported cases nationwide dropped to about 20 000.\n\nDr Gil Chavez, epidemiologist with the California Department of Public Health, does not believe low inoculation rates are the primary cause of the current epidemic: Of this year's [2014] pediatric cases that had information on the child's vaccination history, only 10 per cent of those infected in 2014 had not been vaccinated against pertussis. Chavez says the new vaccine's limitations and better tests have led to the increase in cases.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Ohio (Holmes County)\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: Fox 8 Cleveland [edited]\nhttp://fox8.com/2014/12/18/whooping-cough-concerns-force-78-holmes-county-students-to-stay-home-from-school/\n\n\nThe East Holmes School District [Holmes County, Ohio] is telling 78 students from 2 elementary schools to stay at home after they might have been exposed to whooping cough, and have either not been vaccinated or their vaccinations are not complete. Holmes County Health Department director Dr DJ McFadden said 3 cases of whooping cough, also known as pertussis, have been confirmed in the county.\n\n\"It does happen, but it doesn't happen as regularly as it is happening now. I mean, we are back to higher, as high of rates as we had before vaccinations in some parts of the country,\" McFadden said.\n\nMcFadden made the recommendation to the school district to keep the kids home to try and limit the spread of the disease. \"They are well at this time and I certainly hope they are excluded for no good reason. There's about a week-long process to display symptoms so these children could be ill and we just don't know it yet so they are excluded as that precaution because if they are sick those symptoms will show up soon and they could be exposing other people at the same time,\" said East Holmes superintendent Joe Edinger.\n\nEdinger said parents make decisions regarding the immunizations based on a number of good reasons. \"Maybe history with other children having reactions to the immunizations or for religious and cultural reasons and with that decision they accept the fact that when an outbreak occurs they will be asked to stay home,\" Edinger said. Although the county has a large Amish population, Edinger said most of the kids who are being told to stay home are not Amish.\n\nThe timing means students will miss only about a week of classes before Christmas break. They will also miss their school's Christmas activities, but the school and the health district are not stopping them from attending family functions or other community events.\n\n[byline: Dave Nethers]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[6] Texas\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: KTRE [edited]\nhttp://www.ktre.com/story/27669239/whooping-cough-moves-through-etx\n\n\nIt's a startling sound, especially if you're the parent of a small child. A deep cough with a \"whoop\" sound is the sign of pertussis, also called whooping cough. It starts like a cold with a low fever and even a runny nose, but if left untreated, a lingering cough with the recognizable sound could lead to some serious health problems.\n\nThe number of pertussis cases is rising around the country, and has claimed 2 lives in Texas this year [2014]. More than 25 per cent of pertussis cases in children result in a hospital stay, according to health reports. Pediatrician Melanie Wick said adults or teenagers can be the culprits when it comes to spreading pertussis. \"We can get a cough that lasts for several weeks and we are the ones that expose those little children to pertussis,\" wick said.\n\nWick said it's common to see more respiratory illnesses during the winter months when more people are indoors for longer times of the day. Some of the more serious complications of pertussis include pneumonia and apnea -- where one stops breathing for brief periods.\n\nWhile pertussis has been elevated to an epidemic status by health agencies in California, Wick said the number of patients she has seen with the illness here in East Texas in 2014 is about average. NetHealth, which surveyed 6 counties, said 94 cases of pertussis have been reported: Smith County accounted for 74 of those cases.\n\nIn Texas, just under 2200 cases have occurred in 2014 including 2 deaths. Nearly 50 percent of cases have been in children under the age of 7.\n\n[byline: Alex Osiadacz]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[7] New Mexico (Valencia County)\nDate: Wed 17 Dec 2014\nSource: KRQE [edited]\nhttp://krqe.com/2014/12/17/school-district-warns-parents-of-whopping-cough/\n\n\nA New Mexico school district is warning parents about whooping cough. Los Lunas schools [Valencia County] sent emails to parents and even called them saying there have been several cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, in the area.\n\nHealth officials say whooping cough tends to hit in waves. In New Mexico in 2012, there were nearly 900 cases. In 2013 there were more than 600; so far in 2014 there were about 300.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in the number of cases of pertussis in the past few years in the USA is likely multifactorial, although in part due to the wave-like nature of the disease over years it is clear that the acellular vaccine, which is much better tolerated in children and can be given to adults, does not protect against _Bordetella pertussis_ as long. There is also some evidence that recent clonal strains have toxins that are less antigenic similar to the vaccine strain. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis -
