USA (29)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3044440", "date": "2014-12-22 16:29:28", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (29)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\n[2] Montana (Gallatin County)\n[3] Nebraska (Dodge, Saunders and Washington counties)\n[4] California\n[5] Ohio (Holmes County)\n[6] Texas\n[7] New Mexico (Valencia County)\n\n******\n[1] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: MLive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/12/whooping_cough_outbreak_in_gra.html\n\n\nThe pertussis outbreak in Grand Traverse County [Michigan] has reached 70 confirmed cases, plus 14 cases of a similar disease, called parapertussis, according to the health department. Students at 19 schools in the county have been affected by the disease, also known as whooping cough. The county health department has received 3750 calls to the hotline set up to field questions from parents of children who may have been exposed to the illness.\n\nAs they announced the update on the outbreak on Thu 18 Dec 2014, health officials urged residents to get vaccinated in advance of holiday travel and get-togethers. \"Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority,\" said Wendy Trute, the Grand Traverse health officer. \"We urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated. We also urge parents to vaccinate infants as soon as possible.\"\n\nA pertussis outbreak was reported in November 2014 at Grand Traverse Academy, a charter school. The number of confirmed cases linked to the school remains at 12, said Mike Lahey. He did not have numbers on the cases in the Traverse City Area Public School District.\n\n[byline: Sue Thoms]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It appears that a significant minority of students at Grand Traverse Academy were unvaccinated related to \"philosophical\" objections of the parents. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Montana (Gallatin County)\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Belgrade News [edited]\nhttp://www.belgrade-news.com/news/article_ac6e21ac-871d-11e4-9f73-ef7df241ce97.html\n\n\nAs of Thu 18 Dec 2014, 9 students in Three Forks Schools [Gallatin County, Montana] are confirmed to have whooping cough. 4 children in grades kindergarten through 5th have the respiratory illness and 5 in the middle and high school contracted it. A press release issued on the school's website on states, \"The school is a safe place for all stakeholders and unless your son or daughter has been diagnosed with pertussis, there is not any reason that they should not be in school.\"\n\nWhooping cough is spread in much the same way as a regular cold virus, by coughing or sneezing while in close contact with others who then breath in the bacteria. There is a pertussis vaccination, which the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] says is the most effective tool in preventing the disease. But the vaccine is not 100 per cent effective.\n\nThree Forks School officials say the Gallatin City-County Health Department is working closely with the school staff to interview every person with a confirmed case of pertussis to identify close contacts. According to Gallatin City-County health officer Matt Kelley, there have been no other confirmed pertussis cases at other schools in the Gallatin Valley.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The vaccination status of the affected students is not stated. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[3] Nebraska (Dodge, Saunders and Washington counties)\nDate: Tue 16 Dec 2014\nSource: The Republic, Associated Press report [edited]\nhttp://www.therepublic.com/view/story/9a0752fa5c6841d5b249fa8064de1f5c/NE--Eastern-Nebraska-Illnesses\n\n\nAn eastern Nebraska health department is reporting several cases of whooping cough. The Fremont Tribune reports that Three Rivers Health Department in Fremont says at least 2 cases of whooping cough have been confirmed in the district, which includes Dodge, Saunders and Washington counties.\n\nWhooping cough, or pertussis, is spread when infected people cough or sneeze. It starts like the common cold and can progress into violent coughing spells.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] California\nDate: Mon 15 Dec 2014\nSource: Oregon Live, Associated Press report [edited]\nhttp://www.oregonlive.com/health/index.ssf/2014/12/whooping_cough_epidemic_hits_c.html\n\n\nCalifornia officials are battling the worst whooping cough epidemic to hit the state in 7 decades as a recent rebound in cases raises questions about the effectiveness of the pertussis vaccine. Doctors emphasize that the inoculation has led to fewer deaths than in the past and in instances where people do get sick, their illnesses aren't as severe. But California officials say the limited protection of the vaccine introduced in the 1990s has led to the rise in cases. Research has shown it doesn't last as long as the one it replaced, and a new study suggests the vaccine may not prevent the spread of the disease. Whooping cough peaks every 3 to 5 years, and California's last epidemic was in 2010. But despite an aggressive public health campaign in response, the current outbreak is worse.\n\nA total of 9935 cases were reported to the California Department of Public Health from 1 Jan 2014 to 26 Nov 2014, the highest number in 70 years. The cases included an infant who died. Elementary, middle and high school outbreaks have occurred across the state. San Diego County is among the hardest hit areas with 1819 cases reported so far in 2014.\n\n\"We'd have to go way back to the 1940s to find more cases,\" said Dr Eric McDonald, medical director of the epidemiology and immunization branch for public health services in San Diego County. That's when whooping cough was common, causing hundreds of thousands of illnesses annually and thousands of deaths. But after a vaccine was introduced in the 1940s, cases dropped to fewer than 5000 a year. That vaccine was replaced in the 1990s because of side effects, which included pain and swelling from the shot and fever. The newer vaccine is part of routine childhood vaccinations as well as adult booster shots. [the older killed whole cell vaccine was thought to be too reactogenic in adults. - Mod.LL]\n\n2013 was the nation's worst year for whooping cough in 6 decades; health officials received reports of more than 48 000 cases, including 18 deaths. In 2014, the number of reported cases nationwide dropped to about 20 000.\n\nDr Gil Chavez, epidemiologist with the California Department of Public Health, does not believe low inoculation rates are the primary cause of the current epidemic: Of this year's [2014] pediatric cases that had information on the child's vaccination history, only 10 per cent of those infected in 2014 had not been vaccinated against pertussis. Chavez says the new vaccine's limitations and better tests have led to the increase in cases.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5] Ohio (Holmes County)\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: Fox 8 Cleveland [edited]\nhttp://fox8.com/2014/12/18/whooping-cough-concerns-force-78-holmes-county-students-to-stay-home-from-school/\n\n\nThe East Holmes School District [Holmes County, Ohio] is telling 78 students from 2 elementary schools to stay at home after they might have been exposed to whooping cough, and have either not been vaccinated or their vaccinations are not complete. Holmes County Health Department director Dr DJ McFadden said 3 cases of whooping cough, also known as pertussis, have been confirmed in the county.\n\n\"It does happen, but it doesn't happen as regularly as it is happening now. I mean, we are back to higher, as high of rates as we had before vaccinations in some parts of the country,\" McFadden said.\n\nMcFadden made the recommendation to the school district to keep the kids home to try and limit the spread of the disease. \"They are well at this time and I certainly hope they are excluded for no good reason. There's about a week-long process to display symptoms so these children could be ill and we just don't know it yet so they are excluded as that precaution because if they are sick those symptoms will show up soon and they could be exposing other people at the same time,\" said East Holmes superintendent Joe Edinger.\n\nEdinger said parents make decisions regarding the immunizations based on a number of good reasons. \"Maybe history with other children having reactions to the immunizations or for religious and cultural reasons and with that decision they accept the fact that when an outbreak occurs they will be asked to stay home,\" Edinger said. Although the county has a large Amish population, Edinger said most of the kids who are being told to stay home are not Amish.\n\nThe timing means students will miss only about a week of classes before Christmas break. They will also miss their school's Christmas activities, but the school and the health district are not stopping them from attending family functions or other community events.\n\n[byline: Dave Nethers]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[6] Texas\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: KTRE [edited]\nhttp://www.ktre.com/story/27669239/whooping-cough-moves-through-etx\n\n\nIt's a startling sound, especially if you're the parent of a small child. A deep cough with a \"whoop\" sound is the sign of pertussis, also called whooping cough. It starts like a cold with a low fever and even a runny nose, but if left untreated, a lingering cough with the recognizable sound could lead to some serious health problems.\n\nThe number of pertussis cases is rising around the country, and has claimed 2 lives in Texas this year [2014]. More than 25 per cent of pertussis cases in children result in a hospital stay, according to health reports. Pediatrician Melanie Wick said adults or teenagers can be the culprits when it comes to spreading pertussis. \"We can get a cough that lasts for several weeks and we are the ones that expose those little children to pertussis,\" wick said.\n\nWick said it's common to see more respiratory illnesses during the winter months when more people are indoors for longer times of the day. Some of the more serious complications of pertussis include pneumonia and apnea -- where one stops breathing for brief periods.\n\nWhile pertussis has been elevated to an epidemic status by health agencies in California, Wick said the number of patients she has seen with the illness here in East Texas in 2014 is about average. NetHealth, which surveyed 6 counties, said 94 cases of pertussis have been reported: Smith County accounted for 74 of those cases.\n\nIn Texas, just under 2200 cases have occurred in 2014 including 2 deaths. Nearly 50 percent of cases have been in children under the age of 7.\n\n[byline: Alex Osiadacz]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[7] New Mexico (Valencia County)\nDate: Wed 17 Dec 2014\nSource: KRQE [edited]\nhttp://krqe.com/2014/12/17/school-district-warns-parents-of-whopping-cough/\n\n\nA New Mexico school district is warning parents about whooping cough. In 2013 there were more than 600; so far in 2014 there were about 300.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in the number of cases of pertussis in the past few years in the USA is likely multifactorial, although in part due to the wave-like nature of the disease over years it is clear that the acellular vaccine, which is much better tolerated in children and can be given to adults, does not protect against _Bordetella pertussis_ as long. EU: 2012 increase", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3039729", "date": "2014-11-21 15:26:01", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (24)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\n[3] Massachusetts (Barnstable County)\n[4] Idaho\n\n******\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: KTTC [edited]\nhttp://www.kttc.com/story/27422372/2014/11/18/zumbrota-mazeppa-schools-dealing-with-whooping-cough-outbreak\n\n\nAn outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] has affected the Zumbrota-Mazeppa Public Schools. At least 11 children in Zumbrota-Mazeppa Middle School and Zumbrota-Mazeppa High School [in Zumbrota, Goodhue County, Minnesota] are confirmed to have the infection. Additionally, 80 children stayed home sick from Zumbrota-Mazeppa schools on Tuesday, 18 Nov 2014, although not all of the cases are related to the outbreak. Doctors and health professionals in the Zumbrota area were still tracking the apparent outbreak of pertussis on Wednesday, 19 Nov 2014. State, county, and local officials compared notes on the outbreak in a conference call.\n\nMayo Clinic Dr. Elizabeth Cozine said she has been treating confirmed cases in her clinic in Zumbrota. She wants people to know that if you know for sure you have been exposed to pertussis, you should call your doctor. She said you might not need to come to the clinic to be treated.\n\nKTTC talked with the mother of an 8-year-old girl who is one of the 11 confirmed cases of pertussis. \"What I did learn about my daughter's pertussis is it acts like the common cold,\" she said. \"You have no idea that it's anything more severe.\"\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health has taken interest in the outbreak as well. A conference call between the Department of Health and the health departments of Goodhue and Wabasha counties is planned for Wednesday morning, 19 Nov 2014.\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health advises kids to get vaccinated so they can avoid whooping cough and for those suspected of having whooping cough to stay home from school.\n\n[Byline: Taj Simmons]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail From HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\nDate: Thu 20 Nov 2014\nSource: MLive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/11/confirming_cases_of_whooping_c.html\n\n\nThe Grand Traverse County [Michigan] Health Department has confirmed 34 cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, including 12 new cases this week. 27 of the confirmed cases are tied to 2 schools, Grand Traverse Academy, a K-12 charter school, and Traverse City Area Public Schools (TCAPS). Health department officials say they are working closely with affected schools.\n\n\"We continue to actively monitor this situation and make adjustments to make sure we have adequate staff,\" said Mike Lahey, the emergency preparedness coordinator for the health department.\n\n12 of the confirmed cases are associated with Grand Traverse Academy outbreak, up from 11 on Monday, 17 Nov 2014. The school of 1200 students reopened on Monday, 17 Nov 2014, after shutting down on 11 Nov 2014 because spread of the illness.\n\nThe health department says there are 166 probable cases linked to the charter school outbreak. Many more are being tested according to physician offices reports. This week Superintendent Susan Dameron, superintendent of Grand Traverse Academy, said all of the students at risk have taken the preventative antibiotic.\n\nThere are currently 15 confirmed cases at Traverse City Area Public Schools, up from 7 on Monday, 17 Nov 2014, according to Christine Guitar, director of marketing and communications for TCAPS. \"We continue to work in close collaboration with the Grand Traverse County Health Department to identify possible cases and provide information about pertussis to families,\" said Guitar, who said there are also confirmed cases in other school districts and in neighboring counties.\n\n\"It is important that both children and adults are up-to-date on their immunization,\" the health department reiterated in Thursday's [20 Nov 2014] update. \"Booster shots for pertussis are critical because, unlike some other vaccine-preventable diseases, neither the pertussis disease nor vaccine confers lifelong immunity.\"\n\n[Byline: Monica Scott]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Massachusetts (Barnstable County)\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: CapeCod.com [edited]\nhttp://www.capecod.com/newscenter/falmouth-students-whooping-cough/\n\n\nParents of students who attend Falmouth [Barnstable County, Massachusetts] schools have received written notification about a rash of cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough. Falmouth Schools Assistant Superintendent Nancy Taylor said that 17 students are currently out of school recuperating from the disease. Taylor said school administrators are in touch almost daily with state officials about the status of the situation at the schools.\n\nIn Massachusetts, pertussis is most common among people over 10 years old who have lost the protection they get from childhood vaccines, according to state health officials. All but one of the students who have pertussis were immunized, Taylor said. The treatment is to stay home on antimicrobials for 5 days before returning to school, she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Idaho\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: KPVI [edited]\nhttp://www.kpvi.com/content/news/local/story/Idaho-Attributes-Increase-in-Pertussis-to-Low/M2FEtvj900SynGy_dNF1Tw.cspx\n\n\nHealth officials in Idaho are attributing the increase in pertussis due to the low vaccination rates in the state. The number of cases in Idaho doubled from January to August 2014 from the same periods in 2012 and 2013.\n\nAccording to the Idaho Department of Health and Welfare, of the 287 cases diagnosed through August 2014, one infant died.\n\nThere have been 31 cases of pertussis in the Pocatello and Idaho Falls area, with the highest number of cases being in Boise, Caldwell and Twin Falls.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The risk for acquiring pertussis is certainly higher in the unimmunized. Overall, however, waning immunity in those previously vaccinated with the acellular pertussis vaccine seems to be, in most states, the explanation for a rise of cases. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Australia (02): cruise ship, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3032695", "date": "2014-11-21 15:26:01", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (24)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\n[3] Massachusetts (Barnstable County)\n[4] Idaho\n\n******\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: KTTC [edited]\nhttp://www.kttc.com/story/27422372/2014/11/18/zumbrota-mazeppa-schools-dealing-with-whooping-cough-outbreak\n\n\nAn outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] has affected the Zumbrota-Mazeppa Public Schools. At least 11 children in Zumbrota-Mazeppa Middle School and Zumbrota-Mazeppa High School [in Zumbrota, Goodhue County, Minnesota] are confirmed to have the infection. Additionally, 80 children stayed home sick from Zumbrota-Mazeppa schools on Tuesday, 18 Nov 2014, although not all of the cases are related to the outbreak. Doctors and health professionals in the Zumbrota area were still tracking the apparent outbreak of pertussis on Wednesday, 19 Nov 2014. State, county, and local officials compared notes on the outbreak in a conference call.\n\nMayo Clinic Dr. Elizabeth Cozine said she has been treating confirmed cases in her clinic in Zumbrota. She wants people to know that if you know for sure you have been exposed to pertussis, you should call your doctor. She said you might not need to come to the clinic to be treated.\n\nKTTC talked with the mother of an 8-year-old girl who is one of the 11 confirmed cases of pertussis. \"What I did learn about my daughter's pertussis is it acts like the common cold,\" she said. \"You have no idea that it's anything more severe.\"\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health has taken interest in the outbreak as well. A conference call between the Department of Health and the health departments of Goodhue and Wabasha counties is planned for Wednesday morning, 19 Nov 2014.\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health advises kids to get vaccinated so they can avoid whooping cough and for those suspected of having whooping cough to stay home from school.\n\n[Byline: Taj Simmons]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail From HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\nDate: Thu 20 Nov 2014\nSource: MLive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/11/confirming_cases_of_whooping_c.html\n\n\nThe Grand Traverse County [Michigan] Health Department has confirmed 34 cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, including 12 new cases this week. 27 of the confirmed cases are tied to 2 schools, Grand Traverse Academy, a K-12 charter school, and Traverse City Area Public Schools (TCAPS). Health department officials say they are working closely with affected schools.\n\n\"We continue to actively monitor this situation and make adjustments to make sure we have adequate staff,\" said Mike Lahey, the emergency preparedness coordinator for the health department.\n\n12 of the confirmed cases are associated with Grand Traverse Academy outbreak, up from 11 on Monday, 17 Nov 2014. The school of 1200 students reopened on Monday, 17 Nov 2014, after shutting down on 11 Nov 2014 because spread of the illness.\n\nThe health department says there are 166 probable cases linked to the charter school outbreak. Many more are being tested according to physician offices reports. USA (03) 20140331.2368032\nPertussis - USA 20140301.2301877\n.................................................sb/ll/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Traverse City Area Public Schools", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zumbrota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boise", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Goodhue County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barnstable County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3027769", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (27): (MI) undervaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3027769", "date": "2014-11-21 15:26:01", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (24)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\n[3] Massachusetts (Barnstable County)\n[4] Idaho\n\n******\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: KTTC [edited]\nhttp://www.kttc.com/story/27422372/2014/11/18/zumbrota-mazeppa-schools-dealing-with-whooping-cough-outbreak\n\n\nAn outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] has affected the Zumbrota-Mazeppa Public Schools. At least 11 children in Zumbrota-Mazeppa Middle School and Zumbrota-Mazeppa High School [in Zumbrota, Goodhue County, Minnesota] are confirmed to have the infection. Additionally, 80 children stayed home sick from Zumbrota-Mazeppa schools on Tuesday, 18 Nov 2014, although not all of the cases are related to the outbreak. Doctors and health professionals in the Zumbrota area were still tracking the apparent outbreak of pertussis on Wednesday, 19 Nov 2014. State, county, and local officials compared notes on the outbreak in a conference call.\n\nMayo Clinic Dr. Elizabeth Cozine said she has been treating confirmed cases in her clinic in Zumbrota. She wants people to know that if you know for sure you have been exposed to pertussis, you should call your doctor. She said you might not need to come to the clinic to be treated.\n\nKTTC talked with the mother of an 8-year-old girl who is one of the 11 confirmed cases of pertussis. \"What I did learn about my daughter's pertussis is it acts like the common cold,\" she said. \"You have no idea that it's anything more severe.\"\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health has taken interest in the outbreak as well. A conference call between the Department of Health and the health departments of Goodhue and Wabasha counties is planned for Wednesday morning, 19 Nov 2014.\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health advises kids to get vaccinated so they can avoid whooping cough and for those suspected of having whooping cough to stay home from school.\n\n[Byline: Taj Simmons]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail From HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\nDate: Thu 20 Nov 2014\nSource: MLive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/11/confirming_cases_of_whooping_c.html\n\n\nThe Grand Traverse County [Michigan] Health Department has confirmed 34 cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, including 12 new cases this week. 27 of the confirmed cases are tied to 2 schools, Grand Traverse Academy, a K-12 charter school, and Traverse City Area Public Schools (TCAPS). Health department officials say they are working closely with affected schools.\n\n\"We continue to actively monitor this situation and make adjustments to make sure we have adequate staff,\" said Mike Lahey, the emergency preparedness coordinator for the health department.\n\n12 of the confirmed cases are associated with Grand Traverse Academy outbreak, up from 11 on Monday, 17 Nov 2014. The school of 1200 students reopened on Monday, 17 Nov 2014, after shutting down on 11 Nov 2014 because spread of the illness.\n\nThe health department says there are 166 probable cases linked to the charter school outbreak. Many more are being tested according to physician offices reports. This week Superintendent Susan Dameron, superintendent of Grand Traverse Academy, said all of the students at risk have taken the preventative antibiotic.\n\nThere are currently 15 confirmed cases at Traverse City Area Public Schools, up from 7 on Monday, 17 Nov 2014, according to Christine Guitar, director of marketing and communications for TCAPS. \"We continue to work in close collaboration with the Grand Traverse County Health Department to identify possible cases and provide information about pertussis to families,\" said Guitar, who said there are also confirmed cases in other school districts and in neighboring counties.\n\n\"It is important that both children and adults are up-to-date on their immunization,\" the health department reiterated in Thursday's [20 Nov 2014] update. \"Booster shots for pertussis are critical because, unlike some other vaccine-preventable diseases, neither the pertussis disease nor vaccine confers lifelong immunity.\"\n\n[Byline: Monica Scott]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Massachusetts (Barnstable County)\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: CapeCod.com [edited]\nhttp://www.capecod.com/newscenter/falmouth-students-whooping-cough/\n\n\nParents of students who attend Falmouth [Barnstable County, Massachusetts] schools have received written notification about a rash of cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough. Falmouth Schools Assistant Superintendent Nancy Taylor said that 17 students are currently out of school recuperating from the disease. Taylor said school administrators are in touch almost daily with state officials about the status of the situation at the schools.\n\nIn Massachusetts, pertussis is most common among people over 10 years old who have lost the protection they get from childhood vaccines, according to state health officials. All but one of the students who have pertussis were immunized, Taylor said. The treatment is to stay home on antimicrobials for 5 days before returning to school, she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Idaho\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: KPVI [edited]\nhttp://www.kpvi.com/content/news/local/story/Idaho-Attributes-Increase-in-Pertussis-to-Low/M2FEtvj900SynGy_dNF1Tw.cspx\n\n\nHealth officials in Idaho are attributing the increase in pertussis due to the low vaccination rates in the state. The number of cases in Idaho doubled from January to August 2014 from the same periods in 2012 and 2013.\n\nAccording to the Idaho Department of Health and Welfare, of the 287 cases diagnosed through August 2014, one infant died.\n\nThere have been 31 cases of pertussis in the Pocatello and Idaho Falls area, with the highest number of cases being in Boise, Caldwell and Twin Falls.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The risk for acquiring pertussis is certainly higher in the unimmunized. Overall, however, waning immunity in those previously vaccinated with the acellular pertussis vaccine seems to be, in most states, the explanation for a rise of cases. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - At least 11 children in Zumbrota-Mazeppa Middle School and Zumbrota-Mazeppa High School [in Zumbrota, Goodhue County, Minnesota] are confirmed to have the infection. Additionally, 80 children stayed home sick from Zumbrota-Mazeppa schools on Tuesday, 18 Nov 2014, although not all of the cases are related to the outbreak. Doctors and health professionals in the Zumbrota area were still tracking the apparent outbreak of pertussis on Wednesday, 19 Nov 2014. State, county, and local officials compared notes on the outbreak in a conference call.\n\nMayo Clinic Dr. Elizabeth Cozine said she has been treating confirmed cases in her clinic in Zumbrota. She wants people to know that if you know for sure you have been exposed to pertussis, you should call your doctor. She said you might not need to come to the clinic to be treated.\n\nKTTC talked with the mother of an 8-year-old girl who is one of the 11 confirmed cases of pertussis. \"What I did learn about my daughter's pertussis is it acts like the common cold,\" she said. \"You have no idea that it's anything more severe.\"\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health has taken interest in the outbreak as well. A conference call between the Department of Health and the health departments of Goodhue and Wabasha counties is planned for Wednesday morning, 19 Nov 2014.\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health advises kids to get vaccinated so they can avoid whooping cough and for those suspected of having whooping cough to stay home from school.\n\n[Byline: Taj Simmons]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail From HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\nDate: Thu 20 Nov 2014\nSource: MLive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/11/confirming_cases_of_whooping_c.html\n\n\nThe Grand Traverse County [Michigan] Health Department has confirmed 34 cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, including 12 new cases this week. 27 of the confirmed cases are tied to 2 schools, Grand Traverse Academy, a K-12 charter school, and Traverse City Area Public Schools (TCAPS). Health department officials say they are working closely with affected schools.\n\n\"We continue to actively monitor this situation and make adjustments to make sure we have adequate staff,\" said Mike Lahey, the emergency preparedness coordinator for the health department.\n\n12 of the confirmed cases are associated with Grand Traverse Academy outbreak, up from 11 on Monday, 17 Nov 2014. USA (25): (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3012191", "date": "2014-11-21 15:26:01", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (24)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\n[3] Massachusetts (Barnstable County)\n[4] Idaho\n\n******\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: KTTC [edited]\nhttp://www.kttc.com/story/27422372/2014/11/18/zumbrota-mazeppa-schools-dealing-with-whooping-cough-outbreak\n\n\nAn outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] has affected the Zumbrota-Mazeppa Public Schools. At least 11 children in Zumbrota-Mazeppa Middle School and Zumbrota-Mazeppa High School [in Zumbrota, Goodhue County, Minnesota] are confirmed to have the infection. Additionally, 80 children stayed home sick from Zumbrota-Mazeppa schools on Tuesday, 18 Nov 2014, although not all of the cases are related to the outbreak. Doctors and health professionals in the Zumbrota area were still tracking the apparent outbreak of pertussis on Wednesday, 19 Nov 2014. State, county, and local officials compared notes on the outbreak in a conference call.\n\nMayo Clinic Dr. Elizabeth Cozine said she has been treating confirmed cases in her clinic in Zumbrota. She wants people to know that if you know for sure you have been exposed to pertussis, you should call your doctor. She said you might not need to come to the clinic to be treated.\n\nKTTC talked with the mother of an 8-year-old girl who is one of the 11 confirmed cases of pertussis. \"What I did learn about my daughter's pertussis is it acts like the common cold,\" she said. \"You have no idea that it's anything more severe.\"\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health has taken interest in the outbreak as well. A conference call between the Department of Health and the health departments of Goodhue and Wabasha counties is planned for Wednesday morning, 19 Nov 2014.\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health advises kids to get vaccinated so they can avoid whooping cough and for those suspected of having whooping cough to stay home from school.\n\n[Byline: Taj Simmons]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail From HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\nDate: Thu 20 Nov 2014\nSource: MLive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/11/confirming_cases_of_whooping_c.html\n\n\nThe Grand Traverse County [Michigan] Health Department has confirmed 34 cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, including 12 new cases this week. 27 of the confirmed cases are tied to 2 schools, Grand Traverse Academy, a K-12 charter school, and Traverse City Area Public Schools (TCAPS). Health department officials say they are working closely with affected schools.\n\n\"We continue to actively monitor this situation and make adjustments to make sure we have adequate staff,\" said Mike Lahey, the emergency preparedness coordinator for the health department.\n\n12 of the confirmed cases are associated with Grand Traverse Academy outbreak, up from 11 on Monday, 17 Nov 2014. USA (03) 20140331.2368032\nPertussis - USA 20140301.2301877\n.................................................sb/ll/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Traverse City Area Public Schools", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zumbrota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boise", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Goodhue County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barnstable County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2979932", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (24)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2979932", "date": "2014-11-21 15:26:01", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (24)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\n[3] Massachusetts (Barnstable County)\n[4] Idaho\n\n******\n[1] Minnesota (Goodhue and Wabasha counties)\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: KTTC [edited]\nhttp://www.kttc.com/story/27422372/2014/11/18/zumbrota-mazeppa-schools-dealing-with-whooping-cough-outbreak\n\n\nAn outbreak of whooping cough [pertussis] has affected the Zumbrota-Mazeppa Public Schools. At least 11 children in Zumbrota-Mazeppa Middle School and Zumbrota-Mazeppa High School [in Zumbrota, Goodhue County, Minnesota] are confirmed to have the infection. Additionally, 80 children stayed home sick from Zumbrota-Mazeppa schools on Tuesday, 18 Nov 2014, although not all of the cases are related to the outbreak. Doctors and health professionals in the Zumbrota area were still tracking the apparent outbreak of pertussis on Wednesday, 19 Nov 2014. State, county, and local officials compared notes on the outbreak in a conference call.\n\nMayo Clinic Dr. Elizabeth Cozine said she has been treating confirmed cases in her clinic in Zumbrota. She wants people to know that if you know for sure you have been exposed to pertussis, you should call your doctor. She said you might not need to come to the clinic to be treated.\n\nKTTC talked with the mother of an 8-year-old girl who is one of the 11 confirmed cases of pertussis. \"What I did learn about my daughter's pertussis is it acts like the common cold,\" she said. \"You have no idea that it's anything more severe.\"\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health has taken interest in the outbreak as well. A conference call between the Department of Health and the health departments of Goodhue and Wabasha counties is planned for Wednesday morning, 19 Nov 2014.\n\nThe Minnesota Department of Health advises kids to get vaccinated so they can avoid whooping cough and for those suspected of having whooping cough to stay home from school.\n\n[Byline: Taj Simmons]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail From HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Michigan (Grand Traverse County)\nDate: Thu 20 Nov 2014\nSource: MLive [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2014/11/confirming_cases_of_whooping_c.html\n\n\nThe Grand Traverse County [Michigan] Health Department has confirmed 34 cases of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, including 12 new cases this week. 27 of the confirmed cases are tied to 2 schools, Grand Traverse Academy, a K-12 charter school, and Traverse City Area Public Schools (TCAPS). Health department officials say they are working closely with affected schools.\n\n\"We continue to actively monitor this situation and make adjustments to make sure we have adequate staff,\" said Mike Lahey, the emergency preparedness coordinator for the health department.\n\n12 of the confirmed cases are associated with Grand Traverse Academy outbreak, up from 11 on Monday, 17 Nov 2014. The school of 1200 students reopened on Monday, 17 Nov 2014, after shutting down on 11 Nov 2014 because spread of the illness.\n\nThe health department says there are 166 probable cases linked to the charter school outbreak. Many more are being tested according to physician offices reports. This week Superintendent Susan Dameron, superintendent of Grand Traverse Academy, said all of the students at risk have taken the preventative antibiotic.\n\nThere are currently 15 confirmed cases at Traverse City Area Public Schools, up from 7 on Monday, 17 Nov 2014, according to Christine Guitar, director of marketing and communications for TCAPS. \"We continue to work in close collaboration with the Grand Traverse County Health Department to identify possible cases and provide information about pertussis to families,\" said Guitar, who said there are also confirmed cases in other school districts and in neighboring counties.\n\n\"It is important that both children and adults are up-to-date on their immunization,\" the health department reiterated in Thursday's [20 Nov 2014] update. \"Booster shots for pertussis are critical because, unlike some other vaccine-preventable diseases, neither the pertussis disease nor vaccine confers lifelong immunity.\"\n\n[Byline: Monica Scott]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Massachusetts (Barnstable County)\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: CapeCod.com [edited]\nhttp://www.capecod.com/newscenter/falmouth-students-whooping-cough/\n\n\nParents of students who attend Falmouth [Barnstable County, Massachusetts] schools have received written notification about a rash of cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough. Falmouth Schools Assistant Superintendent Nancy Taylor said that 17 students are currently out of school recuperating from the disease. Taylor said school administrators are in touch almost daily with state officials about the status of the situation at the schools.\n\nIn Massachusetts, pertussis is most common among people over 10 years old who have lost the protection they get from childhood vaccines, according to state health officials. All but one of the students who have pertussis were immunized, Taylor said. The treatment is to stay home on antimicrobials for 5 days before returning to school, she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Idaho\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: KPVI [edited]\nhttp://www.kpvi.com/content/news/local/story/Idaho-Attributes-Increase-in-Pertussis-to-Low/M2FEtvj900SynGy_dNF1Tw.cspx\n\n\nHealth officials in Idaho are attributing the increase in pertussis due to the low vaccination rates in the state. The number of cases in Idaho doubled from January to August 2014 from the same periods in 2012 and 2013.\n\nAccording to the Idaho Department of Health and Welfare, of the 287 cases diagnosed through August 2014, one infant died.\n\nThere have been 31 cases of pertussis in the Pocatello and Idaho Falls area, with the highest number of cases being in Boise, Caldwell and Twin Falls.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The risk for acquiring pertussis is certainly higher in the unimmunized. Overall, however, waning immunity in those previously vaccinated with the acellular pertussis vaccine seems to be, in most states, the explanation for a rise of cases. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (03) 20140331.2368032\nPertussis - USA 20140301.2301877\n.................................................sb/ll/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Traverse City Area Public Schools", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zumbrota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boise", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Goodhue County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Barnstable County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2922903", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (22)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2922903", "date": "2014-08-13 18:38:46", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (17): (IDAHO), INCREASED INCIDENCE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Aug 2014\nSource: The Spokesman-Review [edited]\nhttp://www.spokesman.com/stories/2014/aug/13/in-brief-whooping-cough-nearly-doubles-in-idaho/\n\n\nNearly twice as many cases of whooping cough have been reported in Idaho so far this year [2014]. One infant has died from the highly contagious bacterial disease, also known as pertussis, the Idaho Department of Health and Welfare reported on Tuesday [12 Aug 2014].\n\nThrough July 2014, 241 cases were reported to public health officials, compared with 122 cases in the 1st 7 months of 2013. In the 5 North Idaho counties, 25 cases were reported through July 2014, compared to 24 last year [2013].\n\n\"The best way to protect children and infants from pertussis is to get vaccinated so you are protected, and then you drastically reduce the risk of passing it on to extremely vulnerable infants,\" said Mitch Scoggins, program manager for the Idaho Immunization Program.\n\nPertussis vaccines are available in many physicians' offices, local public health district offices and pharmacies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence, archive number: 20140424.2426383.\n\nIdaho is a state in the northwestern region of the United States (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idaho). A map of the US on which Idaho can be located is available at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idaho#mediaviewer/File:Idaho_in_United_States.svg. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/215.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (16): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140809.2675224\nPertussis - USA (15): (MI) increased incidence 20140808.2670068\nPertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update 20140720.2623332\nPertussis - USA (21): (CA) increasing incidence, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2864604", "date": "2014-08-13 18:38:46", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (17): (IDAHO), INCREASED INCIDENCE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Aug 2014\nSource: The Spokesman-Review [edited]\nhttp://www.spokesman.com/stories/2014/aug/13/in-brief-whooping-cough-nearly-doubles-in-idaho/\n\n\nNearly twice as many cases of whooping cough have been reported in Idaho so far this year [2014]. One infant has died from the highly contagious bacterial disease, also known as pertussis, the Idaho Department of Health and Welfare reported on Tuesday [12 Aug 2014].\n\nThrough July 2014, 241 cases were reported to public health officials, compared with 122 cases in the 1st 7 months of 2013. In the 5 North Idaho counties, 25 cases were reported through July 2014, compared to 24 last year [2013].\n\n\"The best way to protect children and infants from pertussis is to get vaccinated so you are protected, and then you drastically reduce the risk of passing it on to extremely vulnerable infants,\" said Mitch Scoggins, program manager for the Idaho Immunization Program.\n\nPertussis vaccines are available in many physicians' offices, local public health district offices and pharmacies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. One infant has died from the highly contagious bacterial disease, also known as pertussis, the Idaho Department of Health and Welfare reported on Tuesday [12 Aug 2014].\n\nThrough July 2014, 241 cases were reported to public health officials, compared with 122 cases in the 1st 7 months of 2013. In the 5 North Idaho counties, 25 cases were reported through July 2014, compared to 24 last year [2013].\n\n\"The best way to protect children and infants from pertussis is to get vaccinated so you are protected, and then you drastically reduce the risk of passing it on to extremely vulnerable infants,\" said Mitch Scoggins, program manager for the Idaho Immunization Program.\n\nPertussis vaccines are available in many physicians' offices, local public health district offices and pharmacies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. A map of the US on which Idaho can be located is available at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idaho#mediaviewer/File:Idaho_in_United_States.svg. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/215.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (17): (ID) increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2687562", "date": "2014-08-13 18:38:46", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (17): (IDAHO), INCREASED INCIDENCE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Aug 2014\nSource: The Spokesman-Review [edited]\nhttp://www.spokesman.com/stories/2014/aug/13/in-brief-whooping-cough-nearly-doubles-in-idaho/\n\n\nNearly twice as many cases of whooping cough have been reported in Idaho so far this year [2014]. One infant has died from the highly contagious bacterial disease, also known as pertussis, the Idaho Department of Health and Welfare reported on Tuesday [12 Aug 2014].\n\nThrough July 2014, 241 cases were reported to public health officials, compared with 122 cases in the 1st 7 months of 2013. In the 5 North Idaho counties, 25 cases were reported through July 2014, compared to 24 last year [2013].\n\n\"The best way to protect children and infants from pertussis is to get vaccinated so you are protected, and then you drastically reduce the risk of passing it on to extremely vulnerable infants,\" said Mitch Scoggins, program manager for the Idaho Immunization Program.\n\nPertussis vaccines are available in many physicians' offices, local public health district offices and pharmacies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pertussis has been on the increase throughout most of the world. This has been attributed in part to increased virulence and other genetic changes in the circulating clones of _Bordetella pertussis_, as well as waning or an ineffective immune response after vaccination. For a discussion of these problems, see moderator LL's comments in prior ProMED-mail posts on pertussis and moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence, archive number: 20140424.2426383.\n\nIdaho is a state in the northwestern region of the United States (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idaho). A map of the US on which Idaho can be located is available at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idaho#mediaviewer/File:Idaho_in_United_States.svg. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/215.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (13) 20140713.2603059\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\nPertussis - USA (11) 20140625.2559418\nPertussis - USA (10) 20140617.2544391\nPertussis - USA (09): (CA) 20140604.2513925\nPertussis - USA (08): (SD,CA) 20140527.2499851\nPertussis - USA (07) 20140514.2469830\nPertussis - USA (06) 20140503.2445291\nPertussis - USA (05): (CA) increased incidence 20140426.2431379\nPertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383\nPertussis - North America: USA (GA, CA) Canada (AB) 20140411.2395621\nPertussis - USA (03) 20140331.2368032\nPertussis - USA (02) 20140306.2315829\nPertussis - USA 20140301.2301877\n2013\n----\nPertussis - USA (04) 20131229.2140560\nPertussis - USA (03) 20131225.2135158\nPertussis - USA (02) 20130905.1923593\nPertussis - USA: waning immunity 20130316.1590032\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-07-16 00:00:00", "2014-07-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2675224", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (16): (CA) increased incidence, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2675224", "date": "2014-07-13 16:52:13", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (13)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\n[3] California (Riverside County)\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\n[5] South Dakota\n\n******\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: KAPP-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kapptv.com/article/2014/jul/08/pertussis-outbreak-among-migrant-farm-workers-near/\n\n\nGrant County Health District (GCHD) staff are investigating 3 laboratory confirmed cases and 210 people that came in contact with ill individuals with whooping cough (pertussis) in Mattawa and Quincy, WA. No one has been hospitalized.\n\n\"We are responding to a cluster of whooping cough cases among migrant farm workers near Mattawa and Quincy. Because of a large number of exposed and ill individuals in a very well-defined area, we are considering this a local outbreak,\" states Dr. Alexander Brzezny, Grant County Health Officer. He adds, \"Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority. We urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated and urge parents to vaccinate infants and children if they are not up to date.\" More cases related to this location are likely.\n\nIn an effort to control the spread of the disease, the Grant County Health Officer has recommended antibiotics for a defined number of individuals who have come into close contact, been housed with, or transported together with the ill individuals. Antibiotics are not recommended to the general public. The highest priority is given to those who come in contact with children under 12 months of age, to pregnant women and those with certain lung conditions. A pertussis (Tdap) shot is recommended for all who are not up to date, especially those who work, live, or have recently visited Mattawa or Quincy.\n\nBetween 3 and 7 Jul 2014, 210 patients received antibiotics. Also, a pertussis (Tdap) shot will be offered to all the workers. The vaccine reduces a chance that a person will become sick with pertussis.\n\nIn Grant County, there were 56 cases of pertussis in 2013 and 11 cases so far in 2014.\n\n[Byline: Dan Thesman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Washington state showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-pertussis-reports-0709-20140708,0,6545519.story\n\n\nOfficials with Virginia's Peninsula Health District received no reports of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, during the 1st 4 months this year [2014], but received 5 reports of the illness in the last 2 months, a state health official said Tue 8 Jul 2014.\n\nAccording to Dr. Nzinga Teule-Hekima, health director for the Virginia Department of Health's Peninsula Health District, those 5 cases are still under investigation and have not been categorized as confirmed. The Peninsula Health District includes James City, York, Poquoson, Williamsburg and Newport News. Hampton has its own health department. \"These are provisional reports that have to go through all these different check marks to be confirmed,\" Teule-Hekima explained.\n\nThe VDH reported that Virginia saw 418 cases of pertussis reported in 2013, 55 of which were located in the Peninsula Health District. In 2012, 625 cases were reported in Virginia, including 30 in the Peninsula Health District. Nationally, according to the CDC, about 24 231 cases of pertussis were reported provisionally in the USA in 2013 and 48 277 in 2012.\n\nWhile a case is being investigated, Teule-Hekima said the VDH district offices will circulate letters within their specific jurisdictions, through places like schools and churches, to let people know it may be present without identifying the specific source due to privacy concerns.\n\n\"Our whole point is to protect public health and make sure that people have the information they need,\" she said.\n\n[Byline: Christine Sampson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Peninsula Health District serves Newport News, Poquoson, Williamsburg, James City County and York County in Virginia (http://www.vdh.state.va.us/lhd/peninsula/). For a map of Virginia showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/virginia.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[3] California (Riverside County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: Desert Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.desertsun.com/story/news/health/2014/07/09/whooping-cough-cases-riverside-county/12437001/\u20ac\n\n\nOne person has died, and nearly 10 times as many people have been diagnosed with whooping cough in Riverside County in 2014 compared to 2013. The number has spiked to 148 county residents infected with the contagious bacterial disease as of late June 2014. Five of those cases have been in the Coachella Valley. Only 15 Riverside County residents had been diagnosed with pertussis, or \"whooping cough,\" at this time last year [2013], county health officials said.\n\n\"We need people in the general public to be aware it is circulating in their communities and to contact their health care provider if they're feeling sick and think it's pertussis or know they've had exposure to someone with pertussis,\" said Barbara Cole, director of disease control for the Riverside County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe numbers reflect a statewide epidemic putting infants, the elderly and others with compromised immune systems at risk. The state Pertussis Report for June 2014 shows there have been reported outbreaks at elementary, middle and high schools at counties throughout California, according to the California Department of Public Health. The number of cases throughout California is roughly 4558 in 2014, more than the 2532 that were reported in all of 2013. A total of 142 patients have been hospitalized, and 20 percent required intensive care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of California showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: My Champlain Valley [edited]\nhttp://www.mychamplainvalley.com/story/d/story/windham-county-experiencing-rise-in-whooping-cough/11424/4ddXik-cjUOQs1KQrr0nrw\n\n\nThe Vermont Health Department says Windham County is experiencing a rise in whooping cough (pertussis) cases. There was a total of 11 confirmed cases of whooping cough during the month of June 2014. Ten of the cases were among children ages 3 to 17, and one was an adult. In July 2014, 5 more suspected cases were discovered. The Health Department says all but one of the confirmed and suspected cases are from Brattleboro.\n\n\"Anyone who has a persistent cough should be evaluated by his or her health care provider,\" said Susan Schoenfeld, deputy state epidemiologist for infectious disease. \"People with suspected or confirmed pertussis should stay away from others until 5 days of antimicrobial therapy have been completed. We ask anyone with coughing illness to stay away from infants, and we recommend that pregnant women get vaccinated to pass some protection on to their newborn.\"\n\nThe Health Department says cases occurred as schools were closing or had closed for the summer.\n\n[Byline: Joe Gullo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Vermont showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/vermont.shtml.- Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[5] South Dakota\nDate: Fri 4 Jul 2014\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/lawrence-county-leads-state-with-pertussis-cases/article_74ac0968-4283-530a-9441-a8cd4149d274.html\n\n\nThe South Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 51 pertussis cases statewide in 2014. The majority are in Lawrence County, which has 17 confirmed cases. Ziebach County has 4 confirmed cases. Pennington, Custer, Butte, and Shannon counties have 3 or fewer cases.\n\n3/4ths of confirmed cases are children under 15, 1/4th of whom were not vaccinated, according to State Epidemiologist Lon Kightlinger.\n\nThe Department of Health is urging those who still need to be vaccinated to contact local health providers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of South Dakota showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/south-dakota.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting the susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013. 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.long.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013; 56(9): 1248-54; available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/9/1248.long. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\nPertussis - USA (11) 20140625.2559418\nPertussis - USA (10) 20140617.2544391\nPertussis - USA (09): (CA) 20140604.2513925\nPertussis - USA (08): (SD,CA) 20140527.2499851\nPertussis - USA (07) 20140514.2469830\nPertussis - USA (06) 20140503.2445291\nPertussis - USA (05): (CA) increased incidence and 210 people that came in contact with ill individuals with whooping cough (pertussis) in Mattawa and Quincy, WA. No one has been hospitalized.\n\n\"We are responding to a cluster of whooping cough cases among migrant farm workers near Mattawa and Quincy. Because of a large number of exposed and ill individuals in a very well-defined area, we are considering this a local outbreak,\" states Dr. Alexander Brzezny, Grant County Health Officer. He adds, \"Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority. We urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated and urge parents to vaccinate infants and children if they are not up to date.\" More cases related to this location are likely.\n\nIn an effort to control the spread of the disease, the Grant County Health Officer has recommended antibiotics for a defined number of individuals who have come into close contact, been housed with, or transported together with the ill individuals. Antibiotics are not recommended to the general public. The highest priority is given to those who come in contact with children under 12 months of age, to pregnant women and those with certain lung conditions. A pertussis (Tdap) shot is recommended for all who are not up to date, especially those who work, live, or have recently visited Mattawa or Quincy.\n\nBetween 3 and 7 Jul 2014, 210 patients received antibiotics. Also, a pertussis (Tdap) shot will be offered to all the workers. The vaccine reduces a chance that a person will become sick with pertussis.\n\nIn Grant County, there were 56 cases of pertussis in 2013 and 11 cases so far in 2014.\n\n[Byline: Dan Thesman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Washington state showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-pertussis-reports-0709-20140708,0,6545519.story\n\n\nOfficials with Virginia's Peninsula Health District received no reports of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, during the 1st 4 months this year [2014], but received 5 reports of the illness in the last 2 months, a state health official said Tue 8 Jul 2014.\n\nAccording to Dr. Nzinga Teule-Hekima, health director for the Virginia Department of Health's Peninsula Health District, those 5 cases are still under investigation and have not been categorized as confirmed. The Peninsula Health District includes James City, York, Poquoson, Williamsburg and Newport News. Hampton has its own health department. \"These are provisional reports that have to go through all these different check marks to be confirmed,\" Teule-Hekima explained.\n\nThe VDH reported that Virginia saw 418 cases of pertussis reported in 2013, 55 of which were located in the Peninsula Health District. In 2012, 625 cases were reported in Virginia, including 30 in the Peninsula Health District. For a map of Virginia showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/virginia.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[3] California (Riverside County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: Desert Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.desertsun.com/story/news/health/2014/07/09/whooping-cough-cases-riverside-county/12437001/\u20ac\n\n\nOne person has died, and nearly 10 times as many people have been diagnosed with whooping cough in Riverside County in 2014 compared to 2013. The number has spiked to 148 county residents infected with the contagious bacterial disease as of late June 2014. Five of those cases have been in the Coachella Valley. Only 15 Riverside County residents had been diagnosed with pertussis, or \"whooping cough,\" at this time last year [2013], county health officials said.\n\n\"We need people in the general public to be aware it is circulating in their communities and to contact their health care provider if they're feeling sick and think it's pertussis or know they've had exposure to someone with pertussis,\" said Barbara Cole, director of disease control for the Riverside County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe numbers reflect a statewide epidemic putting infants, the elderly and others with compromised immune systems at risk. The state Pertussis Report for June 2014 shows there have been reported outbreaks at elementary, middle and high schools at counties throughout California, according to the California Department of Public Health. The number of cases throughout California is roughly 4558 in 2014, more than the 2532 that were reported in all of 2013. A total of 142 patients have been hospitalized, and 20 percent required intensive care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of California showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: My Champlain Valley [edited]\nhttp://www.mychamplainvalley.com/story/d/story/windham-county-experiencing-rise-in-whooping-cough/11424/4ddXik-cjUOQs1KQrr0nrw\n\n\nThe Vermont Health Department says Windham County is experiencing a rise in whooping cough (pertussis) cases. There was a total of 11 confirmed cases of whooping cough during the month of June 2014. Ten of the cases were among children ages 3 to 17, and one was an adult. In July 2014, 5 more suspected cases were discovered. The Health Department says all but one of the confirmed and suspected cases are from Brattleboro.\n\n\"Anyone who has a persistent cough should be evaluated by his or her health care provider,\" said Susan Schoenfeld, deputy state epidemiologist for infectious disease. \"People with suspected or confirmed pertussis should stay away from others until 5 days of antimicrobial therapy have been completed. We ask anyone with coughing illness to stay away from infants, and we recommend that pregnant women get vaccinated to pass some protection on to their newborn.\"\n\nThe Health Department says cases occurred as schools were closing or had closed for the summer.\n\n[Byline: Joe Gullo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Vermont showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/vermont.shtml.- Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[5] South Dakota\nDate: Fri 4 Jul 2014\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/lawrence-county-leads-state-with-pertussis-cases/article_74ac0968-4283-530a-9441-a8cd4149d274.html\n\n\nThe South Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 51 pertussis cases statewide in 2014. The majority are in Lawrence County, which has 17 confirmed cases. Ziebach County has 4 confirmed cases. Pennington, Custer, Butte, and Shannon counties have 3 or fewer cases.\n\n3/4ths of confirmed cases are children under 15, 1/4th of whom were not vaccinated, according to State Epidemiologist Lon Kightlinger.\n\nThe Department of Health is urging those who still need to be vaccinated to contact local health providers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of South Dakota showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/south-dakota.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting the susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013. 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.long.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013; 56(9): 1248-54; available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/9/1248.long. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\nPertussis - USA (11) 20140625.2559418\nPertussis - USA (10) 20140617.2544391\nPertussis - USA (09): (CA) 20140604.2513925\nPertussis - USA (08): (SD,CA) 20140527.2499851\nPertussis - USA (07) 20140514.2469830\nPertussis - USA (06) 20140503.2445291\nPertussis - USA (05): (CA) increased incidence 20140426.2431379\nPertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383\nPertussis - North America: USA (GA, CA) Canada (AB) 20140411.2395621\nPertussis - USA (03) (02) 20130905.1923593\nPertussis - USA: waning immunity 20130316.1590032\n.................................................sb/ll/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-06-16 00:00:00", "4558-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-07-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brattleboro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "James City County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mattawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country":
