{"location": "Lawrence County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2623332", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (14): (CA) increased incidence, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2623332", "date": "2014-07-13 16:52:13", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (13)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\n[3] California (Riverside County)\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\n[5] South Dakota\n\n******\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: KAPP-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kapptv.com/article/2014/jul/08/pertussis-outbreak-among-migrant-farm-workers-near/\n\n\nGrant County Health District (GCHD) staff are investigating 3 laboratory confirmed cases and 210 people that came in contact with ill individuals with whooping cough (pertussis) in Mattawa and Quincy, WA. No one has been hospitalized.\n\n\"We are responding to a cluster of whooping cough cases among migrant farm workers near Mattawa and Quincy. Because of a large number of exposed and ill individuals in a very well-defined area, we are considering this a local outbreak,\" states Dr. Alexander Brzezny, Grant County Health Officer. He adds, \"Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority. We urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated and urge parents to vaccinate infants and children if they are not up to date.\" More cases related to this location are likely.\n\nIn an effort to control the spread of the disease, the Grant County Health Officer has recommended antibiotics for a defined number of individuals who have come into close contact, been housed with, or transported together with the ill individuals. Antibiotics are not recommended to the general public. The highest priority is given to those who come in contact with children under 12 months of age, to pregnant women and those with certain lung conditions. A pertussis (Tdap) shot is recommended for all who are not up to date, especially those who work, live, or have recently visited Mattawa or Quincy.\n\nBetween 3 and 7 Jul 2014, 210 patients received antibiotics. Also, a pertussis (Tdap) shot will be offered to all the workers. The vaccine reduces a chance that a person will become sick with pertussis.\n\nIn Grant County, there were 56 cases of pertussis in 2013 and 11 cases so far in 2014.\n\n[Byline: Dan Thesman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Washington state showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-pertussis-reports-0709-20140708,0,6545519.story\n\n\nOfficials with Virginia's Peninsula Health District received no reports of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, during the 1st 4 months this year [2014], but received 5 reports of the illness in the last 2 months, a state health official said Tue 8 Jul 2014.\n\nAccording to Dr. Nzinga Teule-Hekima, health director for the Virginia Department of Health's Peninsula Health District, those 5 cases are still under investigation and have not been categorized as confirmed. The Peninsula Health District includes James City, York, Poquoson, Williamsburg and Newport News. Hampton has its own health department. \"These are provisional reports that have to go through all these different check marks to be confirmed,\" Teule-Hekima explained.\n\nThe VDH reported that Virginia saw 418 cases of pertussis reported in 2013, 55 of which were located in the Peninsula Health District. In 2012, 625 cases were reported in Virginia, including 30 in the Peninsula Health District. Nationally, according to the CDC, about 24 231 cases of pertussis were reported provisionally in the USA in 2013 and 48 277 in 2012.\n\nWhile a case is being investigated, Teule-Hekima said the VDH district offices will circulate letters within their specific jurisdictions, through places like schools and churches, to let people know it may be present without identifying the specific source due to privacy concerns.\n\n\"Our whole point is to protect public health and make sure that people have the information they need,\" she said.\n\n[Byline: Christine Sampson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Peninsula Health District serves Newport News, Poquoson, Williamsburg, James City County and York County in Virginia (http://www.vdh.state.va.us/lhd/peninsula/). For a map of Virginia showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/virginia.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[3] California (Riverside County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: Desert Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.desertsun.com/story/news/health/2014/07/09/whooping-cough-cases-riverside-county/12437001/\u20ac\n\n\nOne person has died, and nearly 10 times as many people have been diagnosed with whooping cough in Riverside County in 2014 compared to 2013. The number has spiked to 148 county residents infected with the contagious bacterial disease as of late June 2014. Five of those cases have been in the Coachella Valley. Only 15 Riverside County residents had been diagnosed with pertussis, or \"whooping cough,\" at this time last year [2013], county health officials said.\n\n\"We need people in the general public to be aware it is circulating in their communities and to contact their health care provider if they're feeling sick and think it's pertussis or know they've had exposure to someone with pertussis,\" said Barbara Cole, director of disease control for the Riverside County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe numbers reflect a statewide epidemic putting infants, the elderly and others with compromised immune systems at risk. The state Pertussis Report for June 2014 shows there have been reported outbreaks at elementary, middle and high schools at counties throughout California, according to the California Department of Public Health. The number of cases throughout California is roughly 4558 in 2014, more than the 2532 that were reported in all of 2013. A total of 142 patients have been hospitalized, and 20 percent required intensive care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of California showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: My Champlain Valley [edited]\nhttp://www.mychamplainvalley.com/story/d/story/windham-county-experiencing-rise-in-whooping-cough/11424/4ddXik-cjUOQs1KQrr0nrw\n\n\nThe Vermont Health Department says Windham County is experiencing a rise in whooping cough (pertussis) cases. Pennington, Custer, Butte, and Shannon counties have 3 or fewer cases.\n\n3/4ths of confirmed cases are children under 15, 1/4th of whom were not vaccinated, according to State Epidemiologist Lon Kightlinger.\n\nThe Department of Health is urging those who still need to be vaccinated to contact local health providers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of South Dakota showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/south-dakota.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting the susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\n1. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2620446", "date": "2014-07-13 16:52:13", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (13)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is (Riverside County)\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\n[5] South Dakota\n\n******\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: KAPP-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kapptv.com/article/2014/jul/08/pertussis-outbreak-among-migrant-farm-workers-near/\n\n\nGrant County Health District (GCHD) staff are investigating 3 laboratory confirmed cases and 210 people that came in contact with ill individuals with whooping cough (pertussis) in Mattawa and Quincy, WA. No one has been hospitalized.\n\n\"We are responding to a cluster of whooping cough cases among migrant farm workers near Mattawa and Quincy. Because of a large number of exposed and ill individuals in a very well-defined area, we are considering this a local outbreak,\" states Dr. Alexander Brzezny, Grant County Health Officer. He adds, \"Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority. We urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated and urge parents to vaccinate infants and children if they are not up to date.\" More cases related to this location are likely.\n\nIn an effort to control the spread of the disease, the Grant County Health Officer has recommended antibiotics for a defined number of individuals who have come into close contact, been housed with, or transported together with the ill individuals. Antibiotics are not recommended to the general public. The highest priority is given to those who come in contact with children under 12 months of age, to pregnant women and those with certain lung conditions. A pertussis (Tdap) shot is recommended for all who are not up to date, especially those who work, live, or have recently visited Mattawa or Quincy.\n\nBetween 3 and 7 Jul 2014, 210 patients received antibiotics. Also, a pertussis (Tdap) shot will be offered to all the workers. The vaccine reduces a chance that a person will become sick with pertussis.\n\nIn Grant County, there were 56 cases of pertussis in 2013 and 11 cases so far in 2014.\n\n[Byline: Dan Thesman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Washington state showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-pertussis-reports-0709-20140708,0,6545519.story\n\n\nOfficials with Virginia's Peninsula Health District received no reports of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, during the 1st 4 months this year [2014], but received 5 reports of the illness in the last 2 months, a state health official said Tue 8 Jul 2014.\n\nAccording to Dr. Nzinga Teule-Hekima, health director for the Virginia Department of Health's Peninsula Health District, those 5 cases are still under investigation and have not been categorized as confirmed. The Peninsula Health District includes James City, York, Poquoson, Williamsburg and Newport News. Hampton has its own health department. \"These are provisional reports that have to go through all these different check marks to be confirmed,\" Teule-Hekima explained.\n\nThe VDH reported that Virginia saw 418 cases of pertussis reported in 2013, 55 of which were located in the Peninsula Health District. In 2012, 625 cases were reported in Virginia, including 30 in the Peninsula Health District. Nationally, according to the CDC, about 24 231 cases of pertussis were reported provisionally in the USA in 2013 and 48 277 in 2012.\n\nWhile a case is being investigated, Teule-Hekima said the VDH district offices will circulate letters within their specific jurisdictions, through places like schools and churches, to let people know it may be present without identifying the specific source due to privacy concerns.\n\n\"Our whole point is to protect public health and make sure that people have the information they need,\" she said.\n\n[Byline: Christine Sampson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Peninsula Health District serves Newport News, Poquoson, Williamsburg, James City County and York County in Virginia (http://www.vdh.state.va.us/lhd/peninsula/). For a map of Virginia showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/virginia.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[3] California (Riverside County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: Desert Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.desertsun.com/story/news/health/2014/07/09/whooping-cough-cases-riverside-county/12437001/\u20ac\n\n\nOne person has died, and nearly 10 times as many people have been diagnosed with whooping cough in Riverside County in 2014 compared to 2013. The number has spiked to 148 county residents infected with the contagious bacterial disease as of late June 2014. Five of those cases have been in the Coachella Valley. Only 15 Riverside County residents had been diagnosed with pertussis, or \"whooping cough,\" at this time last year [2013], county health officials said.\n\n\"We need people in the general public to be aware it is circulating in their communities and to contact their health care provider if they're feeling sick and think it's pertussis or know they've had exposure to someone with pertussis,\" said Barbara Cole, director of disease control for the Riverside County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe numbers reflect a statewide epidemic putting infants, the elderly and others with compromised immune systems at risk. The state Pertussis Report for June 2014 shows there have been reported outbreaks at elementary, middle and high schools at counties throughout California, according to the California Department of Public Health. The number of cases throughout California is roughly 4558 in 2014, more than the 2532 that were reported in all of 2013. A total of 142 patients have been hospitalized, and 20 percent required intensive care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of California showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: My Champlain Valley [edited]\nhttp://www.mychamplainvalley.com/story/d/story/windham-county-experiencing-rise-in-whooping-cough/11424/4ddXik-cjUOQs1KQrr0nrw\n\n\nThe Vermont Health Department says Windham County is experiencing a rise in whooping cough (pertussis) cases. There was a total of 11 confirmed cases of whooping cough during the month of June 2014. Ten of the cases were among children ages 3 to 17, and one was an adult. In July 2014, 5 more suspected cases were discovered. The Health Department says all but one of the confirmed and suspected cases are from Brattleboro.\n\n\"Anyone who has a persistent cough should be evaluated by his or her health care provider,\" said Susan Schoenfeld, deputy state epidemiologist for infectious disease. \"People with suspected or confirmed pertussis should stay away from others until 5 days of antimicrobial therapy have been completed. We ask anyone with coughing illness to stay away from infants, and we recommend that pregnant women get vaccinated to pass some protection on to their newborn.\"\n\nThe Health Department says cases occurred as schools were closing or had closed for the summer.\n\n[Byline: Joe Gullo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Vermont showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/vermont.shtml.- Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[5] South Dakota\nDate: Fri 4 Jul 2014\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/lawrence-county-leads-state-with-pertussis-cases/article_74ac0968-4283-530a-9441-a8cd4149d274.html\n\n\nThe South Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 51 pertussis cases statewide in 2014. The majority are in Lawrence County, which has 17 confirmed cases. Ziebach County has 4 confirmed cases. Pennington, Custer, Butte, and Shannon counties have 3 or fewer cases.\n\n3/4ths of confirmed cases are children under 15, 1/4th of whom were not vaccinated, according to State Epidemiologist Lon Kightlinger.\n\nThe Department of Health is urging those who still need to be vaccinated to contact local health providers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of South Dakota showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/south-dakota.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting the susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013. 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.long.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013; 56(9): 1248-54; available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/9/1248.long. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\nPertussis - USA (11) 20140625.2559418\nPertussis - USA (10) 20140617.2544391\nPertussis - USA (09): (CA) 20140604.2513925\nPertussis - USA (08): (SD,CA) 20140527.2499851\nPertussis - USA (07) 20140514.2469830\nPertussis - USA (06) 20140503.2445291\nPertussis - USA (05): (CA) increased incidence 20140426.2431379\nPertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383\nPertussis - North America: USA (GA, CA) Canada (AB) 20140411.2395621\nPertussis - USA (03) [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brattleboro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "James City County", "country": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2603059", "date": "2014-07-13 16:52:13", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (13)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\n[3] California (Riverside County)\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\n[5] South Dakota\n\n******\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: KAPP-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kapptv.com/article/2014/jul/08/pertussis-outbreak-among-migrant-farm-workers-near/\n\n\nGrant County Health District (GCHD) staff are investigating 3 laboratory confirmed cases and 210 people that came in contact with ill individuals with whooping cough (pertussis) in Mattawa and Quincy, WA. No one has been hospitalized.\n\n\"We are responding to a cluster of whooping cough cases among migrant farm workers near Mattawa and Quincy. Because of a large number of exposed and ill individuals in a very well-defined area, we are considering this a local outbreak,\" states Dr. Alexander Brzezny, Grant County Health Officer. He adds, \"Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority. We urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated and urge parents to vaccinate infants and children if they are not up to date.\" More cases related to this location are likely.\n\nIn an effort to control the spread of the disease, the Grant County Health Officer has recommended antibiotics for a defined number of individuals who have come into close contact, been housed with, or transported together with the ill individuals. Antibiotics are not recommended to the general public. The highest priority is given to those who come in contact with children under 12 months of age, to pregnant women and those with certain lung conditions. A pertussis (Tdap) shot is recommended for all who are not up to date, especially those who work, live, or have recently visited Mattawa or Quincy.\n\nBetween 3 and 7 Jul 2014, 210 patients received antibiotics. Also, a pertussis (Tdap) shot will be offered to all the workers. The vaccine reduces a chance that a person will become sick with pertussis.\n\nIn Grant County, there were 56 cases of pertussis in 2013 and 11 cases so far in 2014.\n\n[Byline: Dan Thesman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Washington state showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-pertussis-reports-0709-20140708,0,6545519.story\n\n\nOfficials with Virginia's Peninsula Health District received no reports of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, during the 1st 4 months this year [2014], but received 5 reports of the illness in the last 2 months, a state health official said Tue 8 Jul 2014.\n\nAccording to Dr. Nzinga Teule-Hekima, health director for the Virginia Department of Health's Peninsula Health District, those 5 cases are still under investigation and have not been categorized as confirmed. The Peninsula Health District includes James City, York, Poquoson, Williamsburg and Newport News. Hampton has its own health department. \"These are provisional reports that have to go through all these different check marks to be confirmed,\" Teule-Hekima explained.\n\nThe VDH reported that Virginia saw 418 cases of pertussis reported in 2013, 55 of which were located in the Peninsula Health District. In 2012, 625 cases were reported in Virginia, including 30 in the Peninsula Health District. Nationally, according to the CDC, about 24 231 cases of pertussis were reported provisionally in the USA in 2013 and 48 277 in 2012.\n\nWhile a case is being investigated, Teule-Hekima said the VDH district offices will circulate letters within their specific jurisdictions, through places like schools and churches, to let people know it may be present without identifying the specific source due to privacy concerns.\n\n\"Our whole point is to protect public health and make sure that people have the information they need,\" she said.\n\n[Byline: Christine Sampson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Peninsula Health District serves Newport News, Poquoson, Williamsburg, James City County and York County in Virginia (http://www.vdh.state.va.us/lhd/peninsula/). For a map of Virginia showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/virginia.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[3] California (Riverside County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: Desert Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.desertsun.com/story/news/health/2014/07/09/whooping-cough-cases-riverside-county/12437001/\u20ac\n\n\nOne person has died, and nearly 10 times as many people have been diagnosed with whooping cough in Riverside County in 2014 compared to 2013. The number has spiked to 148 county residents infected with the contagious bacterial disease as of late June 2014. Five of those cases have been in the Coachella Valley. Only 15 Riverside County residents had been diagnosed with pertussis, or \"whooping cough,\" at this time last year [2013], county health officials said.\n\n\"We need people in the general public to be aware it is circulating in their communities and to contact their health care provider if they're feeling sick and think it's pertussis or know they've had exposure to someone with pertussis,\" said Barbara Cole, director of disease control for the Riverside County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe numbers reflect a statewide epidemic putting infants, the elderly and others with compromised immune systems at risk. The state Pertussis Report for June 2014 shows there have been reported outbreaks at elementary, middle and high schools at counties throughout California, according to the California Department of Public Health. A total of 142 patients have been hospitalized, and 20 percent required intensive care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of California showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: My Champlain Valley [edited]\nhttp://www.mychamplainvalley.com/story/d/story/windham-county-experiencing-rise-in-whooping-cough/11424/4ddXik-cjUOQs1KQrr0nrw\n\n\nThe Vermont Health Department says Windham County is experiencing a rise in whooping cough (pertussis) cases. We ask anyone with coughing illness to stay away from infants, and we recommend that pregnant women get vaccinated to pass some protection on to their newborn.\"\n\nThe Health Department says cases occurred as schools were closing or had closed for the summer.\n\n[Byline: Joe Gullo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Vermont showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/vermont.shtml.- Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[5] South Dakota\nDate: Fri 4 Jul 2014\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/lawrence-county-leads-state-with-pertussis-cases/article_74ac0968-4283-530a-9441-a8cd4149d274.html\n\n\nThe South Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 51 pertussis cases statewide in 2014. The majority are in Lawrence County, which has 17 confirmed cases. Ziebach County has 4 confirmed cases. Pennington, Custer, Butte, and Shannon counties have 3 or fewer cases.\n\n3/4ths of confirmed cases are children under 15, 1/4th of whom were not vaccinated, according to State Epidemiologist Lon Kightlinger.\n\nThe Department of Health is urging those who still need to be vaccinated to contact local health providers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of South Dakota showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/south-dakota.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting the susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. {"location": "Lawrence County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2577639", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Brazil (02): (BA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2577639", "date": "2014-07-13 16:52:13", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (13)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\n[3] California (Riverside County)\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\n[5] South Dakota\n\n******\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: KAPP-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kapptv.com/article/2014/jul/08/pertussis-outbreak-among-migrant-farm-workers-near/\n\n\nGrant County Health District (GCHD) staff are investigating 3 laboratory confirmed cases and 210 people that came in contact with ill individuals with whooping cough (pertussis) in Mattawa and Quincy, WA. No one has been hospitalized.\n\n\"We are responding to a cluster of whooping cough cases among migrant farm workers near Mattawa and Quincy. Because of a large number of exposed and ill individuals in a very well-defined area, we are considering this a local outbreak,\" states Dr. Alexander Brzezny, Grant County Health Officer. He adds, \"Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority. We urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated and urge parents to vaccinate infants and children if they are not up to date.\" More cases related to this location are likely.\n\nIn an effort to control the spread of the disease, the Grant County Health Officer has recommended antibiotics for a defined number of individuals who have come into close contact, been housed with, or transported together with the ill individuals. Antibiotics are not recommended to the general public. The highest priority is given to those who come in contact with children under 12 months of age, to pregnant women and those with certain lung conditions. A pertussis (Tdap) shot is recommended for all who are not up to date, especially those who work, live, or have recently visited Mattawa or Quincy.\n\nBetween 3 and 7 Jul 2014, 210 patients received antibiotics. Also, a pertussis (Tdap) shot will be offered to all the workers. The vaccine reduces a chance that a person will become sick with pertussis.\n\nIn Grant County, there were 56 cases of pertussis in 2013 and 11 cases so far in 2014.\n\n[Byline: Dan Thesman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Washington state showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-pertussis-reports-0709-20140708,0,6545519.story\n\n\nOfficials with Virginia's Peninsula Health District received no reports of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, during the 1st 4 months this year [2014], but received 5 reports of the illness in the last 2 months, a state health official said Tue 8 Jul 2014.\n\nAccording to Dr. Nzinga Teule-Hekima, health director for the Virginia Department of Health's Peninsula Health District, those 5 cases are still under investigation and have not been categorized as confirmed. The Peninsula Health District includes James City, York, Poquoson, Williamsburg and Newport News. Hampton has its own health department. \"These are provisional reports that have to go through all these different check marks to be confirmed,\" Teule-Hekima explained.\n\nThe VDH reported that Virginia saw 418 cases of pertussis reported in 2013, 55 of which were located in the Peninsula Health District. In 2012, 625 cases were reported in Virginia, including 30 in the Peninsula Health District. Nationally, according to the CDC, about 24 231 cases of pertussis were reported provisionally in the USA in 2013 and 48 277 in 2012.\n\nWhile a case is being investigated, Teule-Hekima said the VDH district offices will circulate letters within their specific jurisdictions, through places like schools and churches, to let people know it may be present without identifying the specific source due to privacy concerns.\n\n\"Our whole point is to protect public health and make sure that people have the information they need,\" she said.\n\n[Byline: Christine Sampson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Peninsula Health District serves Newport News, Poquoson, Williamsburg, James City County and York County in Virginia (http://www.vdh.state.va.us/lhd/peninsula/). For a map of Virginia showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/virginia.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[3] California (Riverside County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: Desert Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.desertsun.com/story/news/health/2014/07/09/whooping-cough-cases-riverside-county/12437001/\u20ac\n\n\nOne person has died, and nearly 10 times as many people have been diagnosed with whooping cough in Riverside County in 2014 compared to 2013. The number has spiked to 148 county residents infected with the contagious bacterial disease as of late June 2014. Five of those cases have been in the Coachella Valley. Only 15 Riverside County residents had been diagnosed with pertussis, or \"whooping cough,\" at this time last year [2013], county health officials said.\n\n\"We need people in the general public to be aware it is circulating in their communities and to contact their health care provider if they're feeling sick and think it's pertussis or know they've had exposure to someone with pertussis,\" said Barbara Cole, director of disease control for the Riverside County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe numbers reflect a statewide epidemic putting infants, the elderly and others with compromised immune systems at risk. The state Pertussis Report for June 2014 shows there have been reported outbreaks at elementary, middle and high schools at counties throughout California, according to the California Department of Public Health. The number of cases throughout California is roughly 4558 in 2014, more than the 2532 that were reported in all of 2013. A total of 142 patients have been hospitalized, and 20 percent required intensive care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of California showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: My Champlain Valley [edited]\nhttp://www.mychamplainvalley.com/story/d/story/windham-county-experiencing-rise-in-whooping-cough/11424/4ddXik-cjUOQs1KQrr0nrw\n\n\nThe Vermont Health Department says Windham County is experiencing a rise in whooping cough (pertussis) cases. There was a total of 11 confirmed cases of whooping cough during the month of June 2014. Ten of the cases were among children ages 3 to 17, and one was an adult. In July 2014, 5 more suspected cases were discovered. The Health Department says all but one of the confirmed and suspected cases are from Brattleboro.\n\n\"Anyone who has a persistent cough should be evaluated by his or her health care provider,\" said Susan Schoenfeld, deputy state epidemiologist for infectious disease. \"People with suspected or confirmed pertussis should stay away from others until 5 days of antimicrobial therapy have been completed. We ask anyone with coughing illness to stay away from infants, and we recommend that pregnant women get vaccinated to pass some protection on to their newborn.\"\n\nThe Health Department says cases occurred as schools were closing or had closed for the summer.\n\n[Byline: Joe Gullo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Vermont showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/vermont.shtml.- Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[5] South Dakota\nDate: Fri 4 Jul 2014\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/lawrence-county-leads-state-with-pertussis-cases/article_74ac0968-4283-530a-9441-a8cd4149d274.html\n\n\nThe South Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 51 pertussis cases statewide in 2014. The majority are in Lawrence County, which has 17 confirmed cases. Ziebach County has 4 confirmed cases. Pennington, Custer, Butte, and Shannon counties have 3 or fewer cases.\n\n3/4ths of confirmed cases are children under 15, 1/4th of whom were not vaccinated, according to State Epidemiologist Lon Kightlinger.\n\nThe Department of Health is urging those who still need to be vaccinated to contact local health providers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of South Dakota showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/south-dakota.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting the susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013. 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.long.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013; 56(9): 1248-54; available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/9/1248.long. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\nPertussis - USA (11) 20140625.2559418\nPertussis - USA (10) 20140617.2544391\nPertussis - USA (09): (CA) 20140604.2513925\nPertussis - USA (08): (SD,CA) 20140527.2499851\nPertussis - USA (07) 20140514.2469830\nPertussis - USA (06) 20140503.2445291\nPertussis - USA (05): (CA) increased incidence 20140426.2431379\nPertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383\nPertussis - North America: USA (GA, CA) Canada (AB) 20140411.2395621\nPertussis - USA (03) (02) 20130905.1923593\nPertussis - USA: waning immunity 20130316.1590032\n.................................................sb/ll/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": and 210 people that came in contact with ill individuals with whooping cough (pertussis) in Mattawa and Quincy, WA. No one has been hospitalized.\n\n\"We are responding to a cluster of whooping cough cases among migrant farm workers near Mattawa and Quincy. Because of a large number of exposed and ill individuals in a very well-defined area, we are considering this a local outbreak,\" states Dr. Alexander Brzezny, Grant County Health Officer. He adds, \"Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority. We urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated and urge parents to vaccinate infants and children if they are not up to date.\" More cases related to this location are likely.\n\nIn an effort to control the spread of the disease, the Grant County Health Officer has recommended antibiotics for a defined number of individuals who have come into close contact, been housed with, or transported together with the ill individuals. Antibiotics are not recommended to the general public. The highest priority is given to those who come in contact with children under 12 months of age, to pregnant women and those with certain lung conditions. A pertussis (Tdap) shot is recommended for all who are not up to date, especially those who work, live, or have recently visited Mattawa or Quincy.\n\nBetween 3 and 7 Jul 2014, 210 patients received antibiotics. Also, a pertussis (Tdap) shot will be offered to all the workers. The vaccine reduces a chance that a person will become sick with pertussis.\n\nIn Grant County, there were 56 cases of pertussis in 2013 and 11 cases so far in 2014.\n\n[Byline: Dan Thesman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Washington state showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-pertussis-reports-0709-20140708,0,6545519.story\n\n\nOfficials with Virginia's Peninsula Health District received no reports of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, during the 1st 4 months this year [2014], but received 5 reports of the illness in the last 2 months, a state health official said Tue 8 Jul 2014.\n\nAccording to Dr. Nzinga Teule-Hekima, health director for the Virginia Department of Health's Peninsula Health District, those 5 cases are still under investigation and have not been categorized as confirmed. The Peninsula Health District includes James City, York, Poquoson, Williamsburg and Newport News. Hampton has its own health department. \"These are provisional reports that have to go through all these different check marks to be confirmed,\" Teule-Hekima explained.\n\nThe VDH reported that Virginia saw 418 cases of pertussis reported in 2013, 55 of which were located in the Peninsula Health District. In 2012, 625 cases were reported in Virginia, including 30 in the Peninsula Health District. For a map of Virginia showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/virginia.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[3] California (Riverside County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: Desert Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.desertsun.com/story/news/health/2014/07/09/whooping-cough-cases-riverside-county/12437001/\u20ac\n\n\nOne person has died, and nearly 10 times as many people have been diagnosed with whooping cough in Riverside County in 2014 compared to 2013. The number has spiked to 148 county residents infected with the contagious bacterial disease as of late June 2014. Five of those cases have been in the Coachella Valley. Only 15 Riverside County residents had been diagnosed with pertussis, or \"whooping cough,\" at this time last year [2013], county health officials said.\n\n\"We need people in the general public to be aware it is circulating in their communities and to contact their health care provider if they're feeling sick and think it's pertussis or know they've had exposure to someone with pertussis,\" said Barbara Cole, director of disease control for the Riverside County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe numbers reflect a statewide epidemic putting infants, the elderly and others with compromised immune systems at risk. The state Pertussis Report for June 2014 shows there have been reported outbreaks at elementary, middle and high schools at counties throughout California, according to the California Department of Public Health. The number of cases throughout California is roughly 4558 in 2014, more than the 2532 that were reported in all of 2013. A total of 142 patients have been hospitalized, and 20 percent required intensive care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of California showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: My Champlain Valley [edited]\nhttp://www.mychamplainvalley.com/story/d/story/windham-county-experiencing-rise-in-whooping-cough/11424/4ddXik-cjUOQs1KQrr0nrw\n\n\nThe Vermont Health Department says Windham County is experiencing a rise in whooping cough (pertussis) cases. There was a total of 11 confirmed cases of whooping cough during the month of June 2014. Ten of the cases were among children ages 3 to 17, and one was an adult. In July 2014, 5 more suspected cases were discovered. The Health Department says all but one of the confirmed and suspected cases are from Brattleboro.\n\n\"Anyone who has a persistent cough should be evaluated by his or her health care provider,\" said Susan Schoenfeld, deputy state epidemiologist for infectious disease. \"People with suspected or confirmed pertussis should stay away from others until 5 days of antimicrobial therapy have been completed. We ask anyone with coughing illness to stay away from infants, and we recommend that pregnant women get vaccinated to pass some protection on to their newborn.\"\n\nThe Health Department says cases occurred as schools were closing or had closed for the summer.\n\n[Byline: Joe Gullo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Vermont showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/vermont.shtml.- Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[5] South Dakota\nDate: Fri 4 Jul 2014\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/lawrence-county-leads-state-with-pertussis-cases/article_74ac0968-4283-530a-9441-a8cd4149d274.html\n\n\nThe South Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 51 pertussis cases statewide in 2014. The majority are in Lawrence County, which has 17 confirmed cases. Ziebach County has 4 confirmed cases. Pennington, Custer, Butte, and Shannon counties have 3 or fewer cases.\n\n3/4ths of confirmed cases are children under 15, 1/4th of whom were not vaccinated, according to State Epidemiologist Lon Kightlinger.\n\nThe Department of Health is urging those who still need to be vaccinated to contact local health providers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of South Dakota showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/south-dakota.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting the susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\n1. [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 {"location": "Lawrence County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2559418", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (11)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2559418", "date": "2014-07-13 16:52:13", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (13)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\n[3] California (Riverside County)\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\n[5] South Dakota\n\n******\n[1] Washington (Grant County)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: KAPP-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kapptv.com/article/2014/jul/08/pertussis-outbreak-among-migrant-farm-workers-near/\n\n\nGrant County Health District (GCHD) staff are investigating 3 laboratory confirmed cases and 210 people that came in contact with ill individuals with whooping cough (pertussis) in Mattawa and Quincy, WA. No one has been hospitalized.\n\n\"We are responding to a cluster of whooping cough cases among migrant farm workers near Mattawa and Quincy. Because of a large number of exposed and ill individuals in a very well-defined area, we are considering this a local outbreak,\" states Dr. Alexander Brzezny, Grant County Health Officer. He adds, \"Preventing severe disease and death in infants is our highest priority. We urge all pregnant women to get vaccinated and urge parents to vaccinate infants and children if they are not up to date.\" More cases related to this location are likely.\n\nIn an effort to control the spread of the disease, the Grant County Health Officer has recommended antibiotics for a defined number of individuals who have come into close contact, been housed with, or transported together with the ill individuals. Antibiotics are not recommended to the general public. The highest priority is given to those who come in contact with children under 12 months of age, to pregnant women and those with certain lung conditions. A pertussis (Tdap) shot is recommended for all who are not up to date, especially those who work, live, or have recently visited Mattawa or Quincy.\n\nBetween 3 and 7 Jul 2014, 210 patients received antibiotics. Also, a pertussis (Tdap) shot will be offered to all the workers. The vaccine reduces a chance that a person will become sick with pertussis.\n\nIn Grant County, there were 56 cases of pertussis in 2013 and 11 cases so far in 2014.\n\n[Byline: Dan Thesman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Washington state showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[2] Virginia (Peninsula Health District)\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: The Virginia Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.vagazette.com/news/va-vg-pertussis-reports-0709-20140708,0,6545519.story\n\n\nOfficials with Virginia's Peninsula Health District received no reports of pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, during the 1st 4 months this year [2014], but received 5 reports of the illness in the last 2 months, a state health official said Tue 8 Jul 2014.\n\nAccording to Dr. Nzinga Teule-Hekima, health director for the Virginia Department of Health's Peninsula Health District, those 5 cases are still under investigation and have not been categorized as confirmed. The Peninsula Health District includes James City, York, Poquoson, Williamsburg and Newport News. Hampton has its own health department. \"These are provisional reports that have to go through all these different check marks to be confirmed,\" Teule-Hekima explained.\n\nThe VDH reported that Virginia saw 418 cases of pertussis reported in 2013, 55 of which were located in the Peninsula Health District. In 2012, 625 cases were reported in Virginia, including 30 in the Peninsula Health District. Nationally, according to the CDC, about 24 231 cases of pertussis were reported provisionally in the USA in 2013 and 48 277 in 2012.\n\nWhile a case is being investigated, Teule-Hekima said the VDH district offices will circulate letters within their specific jurisdictions, through places like schools and churches, to let people know it may be present without identifying the specific source due to privacy concerns.\n\n\"Our whole point is to protect public health and make sure that people have the information they need,\" she said.\n\n[Byline: Christine Sampson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Peninsula Health District serves Newport News, Poquoson, Williamsburg, James City County and York County in Virginia (http://www.vdh.state.va.us/lhd/peninsula/). For a map of Virginia showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/virginia.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[3] California (Riverside County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: Desert Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.desertsun.com/story/news/health/2014/07/09/whooping-cough-cases-riverside-county/12437001/\u20ac\n\n\nOne person has died, and nearly 10 times as many people have been diagnosed with whooping cough in Riverside County in 2014 compared to 2013. The number has spiked to 148 county residents infected with the contagious bacterial disease as of late June 2014. Five of those cases have been in the Coachella Valley. Only 15 Riverside County residents had been diagnosed with pertussis, or \"whooping cough,\" at this time last year [2013], county health officials said.\n\n\"We need people in the general public to be aware it is circulating in their communities and to contact their health care provider if they're feeling sick and think it's pertussis or know they've had exposure to someone with pertussis,\" said Barbara Cole, director of disease control for the Riverside County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe numbers reflect a statewide epidemic putting infants, the elderly and others with compromised immune systems at risk. The state Pertussis Report for June 2014 shows there have been reported outbreaks at elementary, middle and high schools at counties throughout California, according to the California Department of Public Health. The number of cases throughout California is roughly 4558 in 2014, more than the 2532 that were reported in all of 2013. A total of 142 patients have been hospitalized, and 20 percent required intensive care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of California showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[4] Vermont (Windham County)\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: My Champlain Valley [edited]\nhttp://www.mychamplainvalley.com/story/d/story/windham-county-experiencing-rise-in-whooping-cough/11424/4ddXik-cjUOQs1KQrr0nrw\n\n\nThe Vermont Health Department says Windham County is experiencing a rise in whooping cough (pertussis) cases. There was a total of 11 confirmed cases of whooping cough during the month of June 2014. Ten of the cases were among children ages 3 to 17, and one was an adult. In July 2014, 5 more suspected cases were discovered. The Health Department says all but one of the confirmed and suspected cases are from Brattleboro.\n\n\"Anyone who has a persistent cough should be evaluated by his or her health care provider,\" said Susan Schoenfeld, deputy state epidemiologist for infectious disease. \"People with suspected or confirmed pertussis should stay away from others until 5 days of antimicrobial therapy have been completed. We ask anyone with coughing illness to stay away from infants, and we recommend that pregnant women get vaccinated to pass some protection on to their newborn.\"\n\nThe Health Department says cases occurred as schools were closing or had closed for the summer.\n\n[Byline: Joe Gullo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of Vermont showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/vermont.shtml.- Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[5] South Dakota\nDate: Fri 4 Jul 2014\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/lawrence-county-leads-state-with-pertussis-cases/article_74ac0968-4283-530a-9441-a8cd4149d274.html\n\n\nThe South Dakota Department of Health has confirmed 51 pertussis cases statewide in 2014. The majority are in Lawrence County, which has 17 confirmed cases. Ziebach County has 4 confirmed cases. Pennington, Custer, Butte, and Shannon counties have 3 or fewer cases.\n\n3/4ths of confirmed cases are children under 15, 1/4th of whom were not vaccinated, according to State Epidemiologist Lon Kightlinger.\n\nThe Department of Health is urging those who still need to be vaccinated to contact local health providers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a map of South Dakota showing counties, see http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/south-dakota.shtml. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[It certainly appears that the current DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccine) vaccination protocol (1) results in waning pertussis immunity, which creates a reservoir for _Bordetella pertussis_ that can infect infants less than one year of age, and particularly less than 6 months old, that are particularly at risk for morbidity and mortality. Vaccination of the pregnant woman should assist in protecting the susceptible cohort.\n\nA recent paper in Pediatrics (2) included 224 378 children from Minnesota and 179 011 children from Oregon. Both Minnesota and Oregon had very high numbers of pertussis cases in 2010 and 2012. The researchers reviewed 458 of the children in the Minnesota group and 89 of the children in the Oregon group for the full time period studied. Over that time, the number of pertussis cases that occurred rose each year.\n\nDuring the 1st year of follow-up of the study, a rate of 15.6 out of 100 000 children contracted pertussis in Minnesota. By the 6th year of the study, that rate had risen to 138.4 out of 100 000 children. In Oregon, the rate of pertussis in the 1st year was 6.2 out of 100 000 children, which rose to 24.4 out of 100 000 children by the 6th year of the study.\n\nIn Minnesota, a child was twice as likely in the 2nd year of the study as in the 1st year to contract pertussis. By the 6th year, a child was 9 times more likely to catch whooping cough than they were in the 1st year of the study. In Oregon, a child was 30 percent more likely to catch pertussis in the 2nd year of the study than in the 1st year. By the 6th year, children were 4 times more likely to catch pertussis than they were in the 1st year.\n\nAn additional recent publication, in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilized a large cohort of young people receiving all of their health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and reported that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurred associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/other/su6201.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis M, Kenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013. 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.long.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis 2013; 56(9): 1248-54; available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/9/1248.long. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (12): (CA) 20140629.2572898\nPertussis - USA (11) 20140625.2559418\nPertussis - USA (10) 20140617.2544391\nPertussis - USA (09): (CA) "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2544391", "date": "2014-05-03 17:44:46", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (06)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] California (San Diego County)\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\n[4] Maine (York County)\n\n******\n[1] California (San Diego County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: KUSI News [edited]\nhttp://www.kusi.com/story/25389578/county-pertussis-cases-up-nearly-600-percent-over-last-year\n\n\nThere have been 298 pertussis cases reported in San Diego County [California] in 2014, nearly 6 times the 53 reported this time in 2013, the county Health and Human Services Agency reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. There were 18 cases of the illness, also known as whooping cough, reported last week [week of 21 Apr 2014], according to the agency. Infants not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk for complications.\n\n\"Pertussis has shown no signs of slowing down and this high level of activity should be a concern for parents and caregivers,\" said Dr. Wilma Wooten, the county public health officer. \"The vaccine's effectiveness lessens over time so it's very important that adults get their booster shots and that they make sure their children have the necessary doses of the vaccine at the recommended ages.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2014\nSource: Signal Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.signaltribunenewspaper.com/?p=23440\n\n\nPertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, is on the rise in Long Beach [Los Angeles County, California], and city health officials are encouraging residents to immunize themselves and their families against the preventable disease. \"A recent rise in pertussis in the city of Long Beach serves as a reminder that all age groups need to be properly immunized against this highly contagious disease,\" said Dr. Mitchell Kushner, health officer for the Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services.\n\nSo far in 2014, 42 confirmed cases of pertussis have been reported in Long Beach, but there have been no deaths. The majority of the cases are school-age children. Among the vaccine-preventable diseases, pertussis is the most common, according to health department.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious disease that is spread by the coughing of an infected person. Unimmunized or incompletely immunized young infants are particularly vulnerable and at increased risk for severe complications. In these cases, parents, older siblings and others in the household are often the source of their infection. A typical case of pertussis in a child or adult starts with a cough and runny nose lasting up to 2 weeks, followed by weeks to months of rapid coughing fits. Infants, not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk of complications.\n\nTo ensure all family members are protected from pertussis, everyone in the home should be vaccinated. Young children need 5 doses by kindergarten (ages 4 to 6). All students entering, advancing or transferring into 7th grade need proof of an adolescent whooping cough booster immunization (called \"Tdap\"). Pregnant women are recommended to receive a Tdap booster during their 3rd trimester of each pregnancy, even if they got it before pregnancy. Adults should receive Tdap in place of their routine 10-year tetanus (Td) booster, especially if they are in contact with infants or are healthcare workers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\nDate: Fri 2 May 2014\nSource: KXLH [edited]\nhttp://www.kxlh.com/news/nurses-warn-about-whooping-cough-outbreak-among-helena-students/\n\n\nLast week the Lewis and Clark County City-County Health Department was alerting the public to a rash of pertussis, or whooping cough, cases reported in the area. Now they're reporting 25 cases since the start of April 2014, and most of those cases are from students at Capital High School.\n\nThe school has been working in connection with the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department to identify those infected and figure out who may have come into contact. In most cases, students have been vaccinated already, according to Capital High nurse, Kathy Boutilier, RN. \"This is a vaccine that has a waning effectiveness. So, a number of variables that come into play as to why someone would get pertussis and why someone sitting next to them does not,\" said Boutilier.\n\nMike Henderson, a public health nurse at the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department, said that despite that, now is a perfect time for everyone to check their immunization status. Henderson said infants are the most vulnerable to pertussis, because the condition can be serious and even fatal, and they haven't been fully immunized for it yet [see vaccination schedules in the comment below]. In addition to high school-age kids, there is a pre-school-age child, and several adults who have been diagnosed with pertussis [in this outbreak].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Maine (York County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: WMTW [edited]\nhttp://m.wmtw.com/health/whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise/25740834\n\n\nWhooping cough cases are on the rise in Kennebunk [York County, Maine] and parents are on alert. A total of 6 cases have been reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. The superintendent sent an email to parents letting them know what's being done to keep kids at school, but it also talks about how prevention starts at home. \"We don't want to raise concern about issues that aren't significant. We don't want to create hysteria, but it is important to share when there are situations where there is a contagious disease that we want folks to be aware of,\" said Superintendent Andrew Dolloff.\n\nThis week, a student at the Middle School of the Kennebunks contracted the disease, making it the 6th case district-wide and the 4th at the school. Each confirmed case means a mandatory 5 days away from the school to help stop the spread.\n\n[Byline: Lindsay Liepman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[CDC has the following recommendation: \"Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years.\" http://www.cdc.gov/Vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm. in the UK, \"Children are vaccinated against whooping cough at 2, 3 and 4 months of age, and again with the 4-in-1 pre-school booster before starting school at the age of about three years.\" http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Whooping-cough/Pages/Introduction.aspx. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Vaccination of the pregnant mother towards the end of gestation is probably the best individual way of protecting an, as yet, not fully vaccinated infant against the morbidity and mortality of pertussis.\n\nClearly, much of the severe morbidity and almost all of the mortality from _Bordetella pertussis_ infection occur in those younger than 6 months. As many as 63 per cent of infants younger than 6 months of age with pertussis require hospitalization. In this CDC report from infants with pertussis in 1997-2000, there were 11.8 per cent with pneumonia, 1.4 per cent with seizures, 0.2 per cent with encephalopathy, and 0.8 per cent died [56/7203]. This compared with parallel numbers of 28 per cent, 8.6 per cent, 0.7 per cent, 0.1 per cent, and less than 0.1 per cent in infants 6-11 months of age (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm).\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental O2 in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (05): USA (CA) increased incidence 20140426.2431379\nPertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383\nPertussis -
