USA (04) 20120325.1080223\nPertussis - USA (03) 20120322.1076102\nPertussis - USA (02) 20120310.1066817\nPertussis - USA 20120229.1055492\n.................................................sb/ll/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Clark County City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henderson", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "York County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kennebunk [ York County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2526398", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Brazil: (SP) fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2526398", "date": "2014-05-03 17:44:46", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (06)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] California (San Diego County)\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\n[4] Maine (York County)\n\n******\n[1] California (San Diego County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: KUSI News [edited]\nhttp://www.kusi.com/story/25389578/county-pertussis-cases-up-nearly-600-percent-over-last-year\n\n\nThere have been 298 pertussis cases reported in San Diego County [California] in 2014, nearly 6 times the 53 reported this time in 2013, the county Health and Human Services Agency reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. There were 18 cases of the illness, also known as whooping cough, reported last week [week of 21 Apr 2014], according to the agency. Infants not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk for complications.\n\n\"Pertussis has shown no signs of slowing down and this high level of activity should be a concern for parents and caregivers,\" said Dr. Wilma Wooten, the county public health officer. \"The vaccine's effectiveness lessens over time so it's very important that adults get their booster shots and that they make sure their children have the necessary doses of the vaccine at the recommended ages.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2014\nSource: Signal Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.signaltribunenewspaper.com/?p=23440\n\n\nPertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, is on the rise in Long Beach [Los Angeles County, California], and city health officials are encouraging residents to immunize themselves and their families against the preventable disease. \"A recent rise in pertussis in the city of Long Beach serves as a reminder that all age groups need to be properly immunized against this highly contagious disease,\" said Dr. Mitchell Kushner, health officer for the Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services.\n\nSo far in 2014, 42 confirmed cases of pertussis have been reported in Long Beach, but there have been no deaths. The majority of the cases are school-age children. Among the vaccine-preventable diseases, pertussis is the most common, according to health department.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious disease that is spread by the coughing of an infected person. Unimmunized or incompletely immunized young infants are particularly vulnerable and at increased risk for severe complications. In these cases, parents, older siblings and others in the household are often the source of their infection. A typical case of pertussis in a child or adult starts with a cough and runny nose lasting up to 2 weeks, followed by weeks to months of rapid coughing fits. Infants, not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk of complications.\n\nTo ensure all family members are protected from pertussis, everyone in the home should be vaccinated. Young children need 5 doses by kindergarten (ages 4 to 6). All students entering, advancing or transferring into 7th grade need proof of an adolescent whooping cough booster immunization (called \"Tdap\"). Pregnant women are recommended to receive a Tdap booster during their 3rd trimester of each pregnancy, even if they got it before pregnancy. Adults should receive Tdap in place of their routine 10-year tetanus (Td) booster, especially if they are in contact with infants or are healthcare workers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\nDate: Fri 2 May 2014\nSource: KXLH [edited]\nhttp://www.kxlh.com/news/nurses-warn-about-whooping-cough-outbreak-among-helena-students/\n\n\nLast week the Lewis and Clark County City-County Health Department was alerting the public to a rash of pertussis, or whooping cough, cases reported in the area. Now they're reporting 25 cases since the start of April 2014, and most of those cases are from students at Capital High School.\n\nThe school has been working in connection with the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department to identify those infected and figure out who may have come into contact. In most cases, students have been vaccinated already, according to Capital High nurse, Kathy Boutilier, RN. \"This is a vaccine that has a waning effectiveness. So, a number of variables that come into play as to why someone would get pertussis and why someone sitting next to them does not,\" said Boutilier.\n\nMike Henderson, a public health nurse at the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department, said that despite that, now is a perfect time for everyone to check their immunization status. Henderson said infants are the most vulnerable to pertussis, because the condition can be serious and even fatal, and they haven't been fully immunized for it yet [see vaccination schedules in the comment below]. In addition to high school-age kids, there is a pre-school-age child, and several adults who have been diagnosed with pertussis [in this outbreak].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Maine (York County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: WMTW [edited]\nhttp://m.wmtw.com/health/whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise/25740834\n\n\nWhooping cough cases are on the rise in Kennebunk [York County, Maine] and parents are on alert. A total of 6 cases have been reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. The superintendent sent an email to parents letting them know what's being done to keep kids at school, but it also talks about how prevention starts at home. \"We don't want to raise concern about issues that aren't significant. We don't want to create hysteria, but it is important to share when there are situations where there is a contagious disease that we want folks to be aware of,\" said Superintendent Andrew Dolloff.\n\nThis week, a student at the Middle School of the Kennebunks contracted the disease, making it the 6th case district-wide and the 4th at the school. Each confirmed case means a mandatory 5 days away from the school to help stop the spread.\n\n[Byline: Lindsay Liepman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[CDC has the following recommendation: \"Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years.\" http://www.cdc.gov/Vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm. in the UK, \"Children are vaccinated against whooping cough at 2, 3 and 4 months of age, and again with the 4-in-1 pre-school booster before starting school at the age of about three years.\" http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Whooping-cough/Pages/Introduction.aspx. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Vaccination of the pregnant mother towards the end of gestation is probably the best individual way of protecting an, as yet, not fully vaccinated infant against the morbidity and mortality of pertussis.\n\nClearly, much of the severe morbidity and almost all of the mortality from _Bordetella pertussis_ infection occur in those younger than 6 months. As many as 63 per cent of infants younger than 6 months of age with pertussis require hospitalization. In this CDC report from infants with pertussis in 1997-2000, there were 11.8 per cent with pneumonia, 1.4 per cent with seizures, 0.2 per cent with encephalopathy, and 0.8 per cent died [56/7203]. This compared with parallel numbers of 28 per cent, 8.6 per cent, 0.7 per cent, 0.1 per cent, and less than 0.1 per cent in infants 6-11 months of age (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm).\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental O2 in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (05): USA (CA) increased incidence 20140426.2431379\nPertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383\nPertussis - USA (04) 20120325.1080223\nPertussis - USA (03) 20120322.1076102\nPertussis - USA (02) 20120310.1066817\nPertussis - USA 20120229.1055492\n.................................................sb/ll/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Clark County City - There were 18 cases of the illness, also known as whooping cough, reported last week [week of 21 Apr 2014], according to the agency. Infants not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk for complications.\n\n\"Pertussis has shown no signs of slowing down and this high level of activity should be a concern for parents and caregivers,\" said Dr. Wilma Wooten, the county public health officer. \"The vaccine's effectiveness lessens over time so it's very important that adults get their booster shots and that they make sure their children have the necessary doses of the vaccine at the recommended ages.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2014\nSource: Signal Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.signaltribunenewspaper.com/?p=23440\n\n\nPertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, is on the rise in Long Beach [Los Angeles County, California], and city health officials are encouraging residents to immunize themselves and their families against the preventable disease. \"A recent rise in pertussis in the city of Long Beach serves as a reminder that all age groups need to be properly immunized against this highly contagious disease,\" said Dr. Mitchell Kushner, health officer for the Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services.\n\nSo far in 2014, 42 confirmed cases of pertussis have been reported in Long Beach, but there have been no deaths. The majority of the cases are school-age children. Among the vaccine-preventable diseases, pertussis is the most common, according to health department.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious disease that is spread by the coughing of an infected person. Unimmunized or incompletely immunized young infants are particularly vulnerable and at increased risk for severe complications. In these cases, parents, older siblings and others in the household are often the source of their infection. A typical case of pertussis in a child or adult starts with a cough and runny nose lasting up to 2 weeks, followed by weeks to months of rapid coughing fits. Infants, not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk of complications.\n\nTo ensure all family members are protected from pertussis, everyone in the home should be vaccinated. Young children need 5 doses by kindergarten (ages 4 to 6). All students entering, advancing or transferring into 7th grade need proof of an adolescent whooping cough booster immunization (called \"Tdap\"). Pregnant women are recommended to receive a Tdap booster during their 3rd trimester of each pregnancy, even if they got it before pregnancy. Adults should receive Tdap in place of their routine 10-year tetanus (Td) booster, especially if they are in contact with infants or are healthcare workers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\nDate: Fri 2 May 2014\nSource: KXLH [edited]\nhttp://www.kxlh.com/news/nurses-warn-about-whooping-cough-outbreak-among-helena-students/\n\n\nLast week the Lewis and Clark County City-County Health Department was alerting the public to a rash of pertussis, or whooping cough, cases reported in the area. Henderson said infants are the most vulnerable to pertussis, because the condition can be serious and even fatal, and they haven't been fully immunized for it yet [see vaccination schedules in the comment below]. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. USA (08): (SD,CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2499851", "date": "2014-05-03 17:44:46", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (06)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] California (San Diego County)\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\n[4] Maine (York County)\n\n******\n[1] California (San Diego County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: KUSI News [edited]\nhttp://www.kusi.com/story/25389578/county-pertussis-cases-up-nearly-600-percent-over-last-year\n\n\nThere have been 298 pertussis cases reported in San Diego County [California] in 2014, nearly 6 times the 53 reported this time in 2013, the county Health and Human Services Agency reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. There were 18 cases of the illness, also known as whooping cough, reported last week [week of 21 Apr 2014], according to the agency. Infants not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk for complications.\n\n\"Pertussis has shown no signs of slowing down and this high level of activity should be a concern for parents and caregivers,\" said Dr. Wilma Wooten, the county public health officer. \"The vaccine's effectiveness lessens over time so it's very important that adults get their booster shots and that they make sure their children have the necessary doses of the vaccine at the recommended ages.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2014\nSource: Signal Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.signaltribunenewspaper.com/?p=23440\n\n\nPertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, is on the rise in Long Beach [Los Angeles County, California], and city health officials are encouraging residents to immunize themselves and their families against the preventable disease. \"A recent rise in pertussis in the city of Long Beach serves as a reminder that all age groups need to be properly immunized against this highly contagious disease,\" said Dr. Mitchell Kushner, health officer for the Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services.\n\nSo far in 2014, 42 confirmed cases of pertussis have been reported in Long Beach, but there have been no deaths. The majority of the cases are school-age children. Among the vaccine-preventable diseases, pertussis is the most common, according to health department.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious disease that is spread by the coughing of an infected person. Unimmunized or incompletely immunized young infants are particularly vulnerable and at increased risk for severe complications. In these cases, parents, older siblings and others in the household are often the source of their infection. A typical case of pertussis in a child or adult starts with a cough and runny nose lasting up to 2 weeks, followed by weeks to months of rapid coughing fits. Infants, not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk of complications.\n\nTo ensure all family members are protected from pertussis, everyone in the home should be vaccinated. Young children need 5 doses by kindergarten (ages 4 to 6). All students entering, advancing or transferring into 7th grade need proof of an adolescent whooping cough booster immunization (called \"Tdap\"). Pregnant women are recommended to receive a Tdap booster during their 3rd trimester of each pregnancy, even if they got it before pregnancy. Adults should receive Tdap in place of their routine 10-year tetanus (Td) booster, especially if they are in contact with infants or are healthcare workers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\nDate: Fri 2 May 2014\nSource: KXLH [edited]\nhttp://www.kxlh.com/news/nurses-warn-about-whooping-cough-outbreak-among-helena-students/\n\n\nLast week the Lewis and Clark County City-County Health Department was alerting the public to a rash of pertussis, or whooping cough, cases reported in the area. Now they're reporting 25 cases since the start of April 2014, and most of those cases are from students at Capital High School.\n\nThe school has been working in connection with the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department to identify those infected and figure out who may have come into contact. In most cases, students have been vaccinated already, according to Capital High nurse, Kathy Boutilier, RN. \"This is a vaccine that has a waning effectiveness. So, a number of variables that come into play as to why someone would get pertussis and why someone sitting next to them does not,\" said Boutilier.\n\nMike Henderson, a public health nurse at the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department, said that despite that, now is a perfect time for everyone to check their immunization status. Henderson said infants are the most vulnerable to pertussis, because the condition can be serious and even fatal, and they haven't been fully immunized for it yet [see vaccination schedules in the comment below]. In addition to high school-age kids, there is a pre-school-age child, and several adults who have been diagnosed with pertussis [in this outbreak].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Maine (York County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: WMTW [edited]\nhttp://m.wmtw.com/health/whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise/25740834\n\n\nWhooping cough cases are on the rise in Kennebunk [York County, Maine] and parents are on alert. A total of 6 cases have been reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. The superintendent sent an email to parents letting them know what's being done to keep kids at school, but it also talks about how prevention starts at home. \"We don't want to raise concern about issues that aren't significant. We don't want to create hysteria, but it is important to share when there are situations where there is a contagious disease that we want folks to be aware of,\" said Superintendent Andrew Dolloff.\n\nThis week, a student at the Middle School of the Kennebunks contracted the disease, making it the 6th case district-wide and the 4th at the school. Each confirmed case means a mandatory 5 days away from the school to help stop the spread.\n\n[Byline: Lindsay Liepman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[CDC has the following recommendation: \"Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years.\" http://www.cdc.gov/Vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm. in the UK, \"Children are vaccinated against whooping cough at 2, 3 and 4 months of age, and again with the 4-in-1 pre-school booster before starting school at the age of about three years.\" http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Whooping-cough/Pages/Introduction.aspx. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Vaccination of the pregnant mother towards the end of gestation is probably the best individual way of protecting an, as yet, not fully vaccinated infant against the morbidity and mortality of pertussis.\n\nClearly, much of the severe morbidity and almost all of the mortality from _Bordetella pertussis_ infection occur in those younger than 6 months. As many as 63 per cent of infants younger than 6 months of age with pertussis require hospitalization. In this CDC report from infants with pertussis in 1997-2000, there were 11.8 per cent with pneumonia, 1.4 per cent with seizures, 0.2 per cent with encephalopathy, and 0.8 per cent died [56/7203]. This compared with parallel numbers of 28 per cent, 8.6 per cent, 0.7 per cent, 0.1 per cent, and less than 0.1 per cent in infants 6-11 months of age (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm).\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental O2 in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (05): USA (CA) increased incidence 20140426.2431379\nPertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383\nPertussis - North America: USA (GA, CA) Canada (AB) 20140411.2395621\nPertussis - USA (03) 20140331.2368032\nPertussis - USA (02) 20140306.2315829\nPertussis - USA 20140301.2301877\n2013\n----\nPertussis - USA (04) 20131229.2140560\nPertussis - USA (03) 20131225.2135158\nPertussis - USA (02) 20130905.1923593\nPertussis - USA: waning immunity 20130316.1590032\n2012\n----\nPertussis - USA (12) 20120718.1204697\nPertussis - USA (11): (WA) hospital exposure 20120706.1190876\nPertussis - USA (10) 20120611.1161299\nPertussis - USA (09) 20120522.1137174\nPertussis - USA (08) 20120513.1122809\nPertussis - USA (07) 20120423.1111130\nPertussis - USA (06) 20120418.1105680\nPertussis - USA (05) 20120410.1096152\nPertussis - USA (04) 20120325.1080223\nPertussis - USA (03) 20120322.1076102\nPertussis - USA (02) 20120310.1066817\nPertussis - USA 20120229.1055492\n.................................................sb/ll/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Clark County City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henderson", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "York County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kennebunk [ York County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2493415", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada: (PE,BC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2493415", "date": "2014-05-03 17:44:46", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (06)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] California (San Diego County)\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\n[4] Maine (York County)\n\n******\n[1] California (San Diego County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: KUSI News [edited]\nhttp://www.kusi.com/story/25389578/county-pertussis-cases-up-nearly-600-percent-over-last-year\n\n\nThere have been 298 pertussis cases reported in San Diego County [California] in 2014, nearly 6 times the 53 reported this time in 2013, the county Health and Human Services Agency reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. There were 18 cases of the illness, also known as whooping cough, reported last week [week of 21 Apr 2014], according to the agency. Infants not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk for complications.\n\n\"Pertussis has shown no signs of slowing down and this high level of activity should be a concern for parents and caregivers,\" said Dr. Wilma Wooten, the county public health officer. \"The vaccine's effectiveness lessens over time so it's very important that adults get their booster shots and that they make sure their children have the necessary doses of the vaccine at the recommended ages.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2014\nSource: Signal Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.signaltribunenewspaper.com/?p=23440\n\n\nPertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, is on the rise in Long Beach [Los Angeles County, California], and city health officials are encouraging residents to immunize themselves and their families against the preventable disease. \"A recent rise in pertussis in the city of Long Beach serves as a reminder that all age groups need to be properly immunized against this highly contagious disease,\" said Dr. Mitchell Kushner, health officer for the Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services.\n\nSo far in 2014, 42 confirmed cases of pertussis have been reported in Long Beach, but there have been no deaths. The majority of the cases are school-age children. Among the vaccine-preventable diseases, pertussis is the most common, according to health department.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious disease that is spread by the coughing of an infected person. Unimmunized or incompletely immunized young infants are particularly vulnerable and at increased risk for severe complications. In these cases, parents, older siblings and others in the household are often the source of their infection. A typical case of pertussis in a child or adult starts with a cough and runny nose lasting up to 2 weeks, followed by weeks to months of rapid coughing fits. Infants, not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk of complications.\n\nTo ensure all family members are protected from pertussis, everyone in the home should be vaccinated. Young children need 5 doses by kindergarten (ages 4 to 6). All students entering, advancing or transferring into 7th grade need proof of an adolescent whooping cough booster immunization (called \"Tdap\"). Pregnant women are recommended to receive a Tdap booster during their 3rd trimester of each pregnancy, even if they got it before pregnancy. Adults should receive Tdap in place of their routine 10-year tetanus (Td) booster, especially if they are in contact with infants or are healthcare workers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\nDate: Fri 2 May 2014\nSource: KXLH [edited]\nhttp://www.kxlh.com/news/nurses-warn-about-whooping-cough-outbreak-among-helena-students/\n\n\nLast week the Lewis and Clark County City-County Health Department was alerting the public to a rash of pertussis, or whooping cough, cases reported in the area. Now they're reporting 25 cases since the start of April 2014, and most of those cases are from students at Capital High School.\n\nThe school has been working in connection with the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department to identify those infected and figure out who may have come into contact. In most cases, students have been vaccinated already, according to Capital High nurse, Kathy Boutilier, RN. \"This is a vaccine that has a waning effectiveness. So, a number of variables that come into play as to why someone would get pertussis and why someone sitting next to them does not,\" said Boutilier.\n\nMike Henderson, a public health nurse at the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department, said that despite that, now is a perfect time for everyone to check their immunization status. Henderson said infants are the most vulnerable to pertussis, because the condition can be serious and even fatal, and they haven't been fully immunized for it yet [see vaccination schedules in the comment below]. In addition to high school-age kids, there is a pre-school-age child, and several adults who have been diagnosed with pertussis [in this outbreak].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Maine (York County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: WMTW [edited]\nhttp://m.wmtw.com/health/whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise/25740834\n\n\nWhooping cough cases are on the rise in Kennebunk [York County, Maine] and parents are on alert. A total of 6 cases have been reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. The superintendent sent an email to parents letting them know what's being done to keep kids at school, but it also talks about how prevention starts at home. \"We don't want to raise concern about issues that aren't significant. We don't want to create hysteria, but it is important to share when there are situations where there is a contagious disease that we want folks to be aware of,\" said Superintendent Andrew Dolloff.\n\nThis week, a student at the Middle School of the Kennebunks contracted the disease, making it the 6th case district-wide and the 4th at the school. Each confirmed case means a mandatory 5 days away from the school to help stop the spread.\n\n[Byline: Lindsay Liepman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[CDC has the following recommendation: \"Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years.\" http://www.cdc.gov/Vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm. in the UK, \"Children are vaccinated against whooping cough at 2, 3 and 4 months of age, and again with the 4-in-1 pre-school booster before starting school at the age of about three years.\" http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Whooping-cough/Pages/Introduction.aspx. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Vaccination of the pregnant mother towards the end of gestation is probably the best individual way of protecting an, as yet, not fully vaccinated infant against the morbidity and mortality of pertussis.\n\nClearly, much of the severe morbidity and almost all of the mortality from _Bordetella pertussis_ infection occur in those younger than 6 months. As many as 63 per cent of infants younger than 6 months of age with pertussis require hospitalization. In this CDC report from infants with pertussis in 1997-2000, there were 11.8 per cent with pneumonia, 1.4 per cent with seizures, 0.2 per cent with encephalopathy, and 0.8 per cent died [56/7203]. This compared with parallel numbers of 28 per cent, 8.6 per cent, 0.7 per cent, 0.1 per cent, and less than 0.1 per cent in infants 6-11 months of age (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm).\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental O2 in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (05): USA (CA) increased incidence 20140426.2431379\nPertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383\nPertussis - USA (04) 20120325.1080223\nPertussis - USA (03) 20120322.1076102\nPertussis - USA (02) 20120310.1066817\nPertussis - USA 20120229.1055492\n.................................................sb/ll/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Clark County City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henderson", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "York County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kennebunk [ York County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2445291", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2445291", "date": "2014-05-03 17:44:46", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (06)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] California (San Diego County)\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\n[4] Maine (York County)\n\n******\n[1] California (San Diego County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: KUSI News [edited]\nhttp://www.kusi.com/story/25389578/county-pertussis-cases-up-nearly-600-percent-over-last-year\n\n\nThere have been 298 pertussis cases reported in San Diego County [California] in 2014, nearly 6 times the 53 reported this time in 2013, the county Health and Human Services Agency reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. There were 18 cases of the illness, also known as whooping cough, reported last week [week of 21 Apr 2014], according to the agency. Infants not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk for complications.\n\n\"Pertussis has shown no signs of slowing down and this high level of activity should be a concern for parents and caregivers,\" said Dr. Wilma Wooten, the county public health officer. \"The vaccine's effectiveness lessens over time so it's very important that adults get their booster shots and that they make sure their children have the necessary doses of the vaccine at the recommended ages.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2014\nSource: Signal Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.signaltribunenewspaper.com/?p=23440\n\n\nPertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, is on the rise in Long Beach [Los Angeles County, California], and city health officials are encouraging residents to immunize themselves and their families against the preventable disease. \"A recent rise in pertussis in the city of Long Beach serves as a reminder that all age groups need to be properly immunized against this highly contagious disease,\" said Dr. Mitchell Kushner, health officer for the Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services.\n\nSo far in 2014, 42 confirmed cases of pertussis have been reported in Long Beach, but there have been no deaths. The majority of the cases are school-age children. Among the vaccine-preventable diseases, pertussis is the most common, according to health department.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious disease that is spread by the coughing of an infected person. Unimmunized or incompletely immunized young infants are particularly vulnerable and at increased risk for severe complications. In these cases, parents, older siblings and others in the household are often the source of their infection. A typical case of pertussis in a child or adult starts with a cough and runny nose lasting up to 2 weeks, followed by weeks to months of rapid coughing fits. Infants, not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk of complications.\n\nTo ensure all family members are protected from pertussis, everyone in the home should be vaccinated. Young children need 5 doses by kindergarten (ages 4 to 6). All students entering, advancing or transferring into 7th grade need proof of an adolescent whooping cough booster immunization (called \"Tdap\"). Pregnant women are recommended to receive a Tdap booster during their 3rd trimester of each pregnancy, even if they got it before pregnancy. Adults should receive Tdap in place of their routine 10-year tetanus (Td) booster, especially if they are in contact with infants or are healthcare workers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\nDate: Fri 2 May 2014\nSource: KXLH [edited]\nhttp://www.kxlh.com/news/nurses-warn-about-whooping-cough-outbreak-among-helena-students/\n\n\nLast week the Lewis and Clark County City-County Health Department was alerting the public to a rash of pertussis, or whooping cough, cases reported in the area. Now they're reporting 25 cases since the start of April 2014, and most of those cases are from students at Capital High School.\n\nThe school has been working in connection with the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department to identify those infected and figure out who may have come into contact. In most cases, students have been vaccinated already, according to Capital High nurse, Kathy Boutilier, RN. \"This is a vaccine that has a waning effectiveness. So, a number of variables that come into play as to why someone would get pertussis and why someone sitting next to them does not,\" said Boutilier.\n\nMike Henderson, a public health nurse at the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department, said that despite that, now is a perfect time for everyone to check their immunization status. Henderson said infants are the most vulnerable to pertussis, because the condition can be serious and even fatal, and they haven't been fully immunized for it yet [see vaccination schedules in the comment below]. In addition to high school-age kids, there is a pre-school-age child, and several adults who have been diagnosed with pertussis [in this outbreak].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Maine (York County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: WMTW [edited]\nhttp://m.wmtw.com/health/whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise/25740834\n\n\nWhooping cough cases are on the rise in Kennebunk [York County, Maine] and parents are on alert. A total of 6 cases have been reported this week [week of 28 Apr 2014]. The superintendent sent an email to parents letting them know what's being done to keep kids at school, but it also talks about how prevention starts at home. \"We don't want to raise concern about issues that aren't significant. We don't want to create hysteria, but it is important to share when there are situations where there is a contagious disease that we want folks to be aware of,\" said Superintendent Andrew Dolloff.\n\nThis week, a student at the Middle School of the Kennebunks contracted the disease, making it the 6th case district-wide and the 4th at the school. Each confirmed case means a mandatory 5 days away from the school to help stop the spread.\n\n[Byline: Lindsay Liepman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[CDC has the following recommendation: \"Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years.\" http://www.cdc.gov/Vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm. in the UK, \"Children are vaccinated against whooping cough at 2, 3 and 4 months of age, and again with the 4-in-1 pre-school booster before starting school at the age of about three years.\" http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Whooping-cough/Pages/Introduction.aspx. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Vaccination of the pregnant mother towards the end of gestation is probably the best individual way of protecting an, as yet, not fully vaccinated infant against the morbidity and mortality of pertussis.\n\nClearly, much of the severe morbidity and almost all of the mortality from _Bordetella pertussis_ infection occur in those younger than 6 months. As many as 63 per cent of infants younger than 6 months of age with pertussis require hospitalization. In this CDC report from infants with pertussis in 1997-2000, there were 11.8 per cent with pneumonia, 1.4 per cent with seizures, 0.2 per cent with encephalopathy, and 0.8 per cent died [56/7203]. This compared with parallel numbers of 28 per cent, 8.6 per cent, 0.7 per cent, 0.1 per cent, and less than 0.1 per cent in infants 6-11 months of age (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm).\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental O2 in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (05): USA (CA) increased incidence 20140426.2431379\nPertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence 20140424.2426383\nPertussis - There were 18 cases of the illness, also known as whooping cough, reported last week [week of 21 Apr 2014], according to the agency. Infants not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk for complications.\n\n\"Pertussis has shown no signs of slowing down and this high level of activity should be a concern for parents and caregivers,\" said Dr. Wilma Wooten, the county public health officer. \"The vaccine's effectiveness lessens over time so it's very important that adults get their booster shots and that they make sure their children have the necessary doses of the vaccine at the recommended ages.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] California (Los Angeles County)\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2014\nSource: Signal Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.signaltribunenewspaper.com/?p=23440\n\n\nPertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, is on the rise in Long Beach [Los Angeles County, California], and city health officials are encouraging residents to immunize themselves and their families against the preventable disease. \"A recent rise in pertussis in the city of Long Beach serves as a reminder that all age groups need to be properly immunized against this highly contagious disease,\" said Dr. Mitchell Kushner, health officer for the Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services.\n\nSo far in 2014, 42 confirmed cases of pertussis have been reported in Long Beach, but there have been no deaths. The majority of the cases are school-age children. Among the vaccine-preventable diseases, pertussis is the most common, according to health department.\n\nPertussis is a highly contagious disease that is spread by the coughing of an infected person. Unimmunized or incompletely immunized young infants are particularly vulnerable and at increased risk for severe complications. In these cases, parents, older siblings and others in the household are often the source of their infection. A typical case of pertussis in a child or adult starts with a cough and runny nose lasting up to 2 weeks, followed by weeks to months of rapid coughing fits. Infants, not yet fully vaccinated are at highest risk of complications.\n\nTo ensure all family members are protected from pertussis, everyone in the home should be vaccinated. Young children need 5 doses by kindergarten (ages 4 to 6). All students entering, advancing or transferring into 7th grade need proof of an adolescent whooping cough booster immunization (called \"Tdap\"). Pregnant women are recommended to receive a Tdap booster during their 3rd trimester of each pregnancy, even if they got it before pregnancy. Adults should receive Tdap in place of their routine 10-year tetanus (Td) booster, especially if they are in contact with infants or are healthcare workers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3] Montana (Lewis and Clark County)\nDate: Fri 2 May 2014\nSource: KXLH [edited]\nhttp://www.kxlh.com/news/nurses-warn-about-whooping-cough-outbreak-among-helena-students/\n\n\nLast week the Lewis and Clark County City-County Health Department was alerting the public to a rash of pertussis, or whooping cough, cases reported in the area. In most cases, students have been vaccinated already, according to Capital High nurse, Kathy Boutilier, RN. \"This is a vaccine that has a waning effectiveness. So, a number of variables that come into play as to why someone would get pertussis and why someone sitting next to them does not,\" said Boutilier.\n\nMike Henderson, a public health nurse at the Lewis and Clark City-County Health Department, said that despite that, now is a perfect time for everyone to check their immunization status. Henderson said infants are the most vulnerable to pertussis, because the condition can be serious and even fatal, and they haven't been fully immunized for it yet [see vaccination schedules in the comment below]. In addition to high school-age kids, there is a pre-school-age child, and several adults who have been diagnosed with pertussis [in this outbreak].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Maine (York County)\nDate: Wed 30 Apr 2014\nSource: WMTW [edited]\nhttp://m.wmtw.com/health/whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise/25740834\n\n\nWhooping cough cases are on the rise in Kennebunk [York County, Maine] and parents are on alert. Each confirmed case means a mandatory 5 days away from the school to help stop the spread.\n\n[Byline: Lindsay Liepman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[CDC has the following recommendation: \"Children should get 5 doses of DTaP, one dose at each of the following ages: 2, 4, 6, and 15 through 18 months and 4 through 6 years.\" http://www.cdc.gov/Vaccines/vpd-vac/pertussis/default.htm. in the UK, \"Children are vaccinated against whooping cough at 2, 3 and 4 months of age, and again with the 4-in-1 pre-school booster before starting school at the age of about three years.\" http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Whooping-cough/Pages/Introduction.aspx. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Vaccination of the pregnant mother towards the end of gestation is probably the best individual way of protecting an, as yet, not fully vaccinated infant against the morbidity and mortality of pertussis.\n\nClearly, much of the severe morbidity and almost all of the mortality from _Bordetella pertussis_ infection occur in those younger than 6 months. As many as 63 per cent of infants younger than 6 months of age with pertussis require hospitalization. In this CDC report from infants with pertussis in 1997-2000, there were 11.8 per cent with pneumonia, 1.4 per cent with seizures, 0.2 per cent with encephalopathy, and 0.8 per cent died [56/7203]. This compared with parallel numbers of 28 per cent, 8.6 per cent, 0.7 per cent, 0.1 per cent, and less than 0.1 per cent in infants 6-11 months of age (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5104a1.htm).\n\nNeonatal pertussis is observed to be especially severe with as much as a 3 percent risk of death. Symptoms can be substantially different with periods of apnea [breathing arrest] sometimes with hypoxia-induced [low oxygen] seizures usually the most common manifestation of infection. The cough is present, but so weak that it may be unrecognized. In these children with so-called malignant pertussis, leukocytosis, particularly with white blood cell (WBC) counts of 30 000 to 100 000 and severe pulmonary hypertension are ominous signs for mortality. In a study comparing neonatal pertussis to other neonatal respiratory infections, pertussis-positive neonates had longer hospital stays, less fever, more apnea and cyanosis spells, and required more days of supplemental O2 in the hospital and represented all the infants discharged on respiratory supportive care. - North America: USA (GA, CA) Canada (AB) 20140411.2395621\nPertussis - USA (03) 20140331.2368032\nPertussis - USA (02) 20140306.2315829\nPertussis - USA 20140301.2301877\n2013\n----\nPertussis - USA (04) 20131229.2140560\nPertussis - USA (03) 20131225.2135158\nPertussis - USA (02) 20130905.1923593\nPertussis - USA: waning immunity 20130316.1590032\n2012\n----\nPertussis - USA (12) 20120718.1204697\nPertussis - USA (11): (WA) hospital exposure 20120706.1190876\nPertussis - USA (10) 20120611.1161299\nPertussis - USA (09) 20120522.1137174\nPertussis - USA (08) 20120513.1122809\nPertussis - USA (07) 20120423.1111130\nPertussis - USA (06) 20120418.1105680\nPertussis - USA (05) 20120410.1096152\nPertussis - USA (04) 20120325.1080223\nPertussis - USA (03) 20120322.1076102\nPertussis - USA (02) 20120310.1066817\nPertussis - USA 20120229.1055492\n.................................................sb/ll/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Clark County City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henderson", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "York County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kennebunk [ York County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2426383", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (04): (MT, CA) increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2426383", "date": "2013-12-25 19:21:29", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (03)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Texas (Nueces County): fatality\n[2] Texas (statewide)\n[3] Wisconsin (Wood County)\n[4] Ohio (Clark County)\n[5] Colorado (Phillips County)\n[6] Pathogen evolution\n\n******\n[1] Texas (Nueces County): fatality\nDate: Thu 19 Dec 2013\nSource: Alice (TX) Echo-News Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.alicetx.com/recordstar/news/article_2cc1463c-a15f-5b73-b353-b5d9ffed96a6.html\n\n\nThe 1st death from pertussis in Nueces County [Texas] was reported by authorities on Wed 18 Dec 2013, just after a press conference held by the Corpus Christi-Nueces County Health District focused on the increase of pertussis cases in the Coastal Bend, and the urgent need of vaccination to prevent the illness. A Corpus Christi baby of 6 months succumbed to the illness after a lengthy battle, having been hospitalized since 28 Aug 2013. Looking back on their records, the Health District states that the baby's death was the 1st in Corpus Christi for 2013, and may have been the 1st area death in over a decade from pertussis, otherwise known as whooping cough.\n\nA report from the Corpus Christi-Nueces County Public Health District states that the level of pertussis cases in Nueces County has been on a recent rise, with 16 cases reported in the area in 2013; 11 of those cases requiring hospitalization. With all of that being said, the fact remains, pertussis is preventable. \"Pertussis is preventable through vaccine and it is of vital importance that anyone who is around a pregnant female receives their pertussis vaccine,\" said Annette Rodriguez, MPH, Director of Public Health.\n\nDr Jaime Fergie, Pediatric Infectious Diseases, Driscoll Children's Hospital, further stressed this point, stating that the most important thing to prevent pertussis is for pregnant females to receive the vaccination in their 3rd trimester, and for all other relatives who will come into close proximity with the newborn to receive the vaccination [at least] 2 weeks before the baby is due.\n\nAccording to the Corpus Christi-Nueces County Public Health District, pertussis is an extremely serious respiratory infection, with the pertussis bacteria attacking the lungs and breathing tubes. It causes uncontrollable coughing.\n\nDr Fergie states that the whooping cough infects adults, and can cause many problems, but when a child under 2 (such as an infant who has not built up a tolerance or acquired the antibodies to fight against the infection) contracts the illness, it can be extremely harmful, or even deadly.\n\nThe death reported on Wed 18 Dec 2013 may be the 1st in 2013, but once again, there is a rising trend in cases. Remember to vaccinate early, in order to prevent more severe cases of pertussis.\n\n[Byline: Jimmy Willden]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2Jna. Nueces County and Corpus Christi in southern Texas can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/texas.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Texas (statewide)\nDate: Fri 20 Dec 2013\nSource: Brownwood News, Brownwood/Brown County Health Department (BBCHD) report [edited]\nhttp://www.brownwoodnews.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=14057\n\n\nPertussis, also known as whooping cough, is on a historic rise according to health officials. As of 16 Dec 2013, Texas has reported 3482 pertussis cases to the CDC for 2013 and has reported 3 deaths due to pertussis. Texas has not seen case numbers this high since 1959. Over the previous 3 weeks, there have been 3 cases of pertussis reported to the Brownwood/Brown County Health Department. The Brownwood/Brown County Health Department encourages the citizens of Brownwood and Brown County to check vaccination records and get vaccinated for this disease.\n\nPertussis is most harmful to young babies and can be deadly. It is very important that pregnant women and caregivers of babies maintain their Tdap [combined tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis] vaccination.\n\n[Byline: Cliff Karnes]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Wisconsin (Wood County)\nDate: Fri 20 Dec 2013\nSource: WSAU [edited]\nhttp://wsau.com/news/articles/2013/dec/20/health-officials-seeing-more-pertussis-cases-in-central-wisconsin/\n\n\nLocal health officials are continuing to see a number of cases of pertussis, or whooping cough. The Wood County Health Department is still seeing infections. Public health nurse Diane Rodd says they've had 31 cases of pertussis so far in 2013. \"Approximately 24 out of those 31 have occurred since 1 Nov 2013. So we are seeing an increase.\"\n\nRodd says many of the people being infected are students who are nearly out of date with their shots. \"Because of that, the protection they got in kindergarten is starting to wane, and so they're a little more susceptible.\" The early symptoms are much like catching a cold, but the mild cough progressively worsens to severe coughing spells. These coughing spells can include whooping and vomiting. Health officials say the illness can last nearly 6 weeks, and is contagious if left untreated. A course of antibiotics is available to help lessen the length of the disease, and Rodd says they need to do their job. \"We want to make sure people go through the entire cycle of antibiotics before going out into the public.\"\n\n[Byline: Raymond Neupert]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Wisconsin can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/9BMx. Wood County in central Wisconsin can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/wisconsin.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] Ohio (Clark County)\nDate: Sun 8 Dec 2013\nSource: Springfield (OH) News Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.springfieldnewssun.com/news/news/local/clark-pertussis-cases-still-rising/ncDhn/\n\n\nThe outbreak of pertussis cases in Clark County follows a national trend that shows that whooping cough rates reached a 50-year high in 2012. Clark County has had a record 117 confirmed and suspected cases of pertussis since 1 Oct 2013, up from 98 before the Thanksgiving holiday [28 Nov 2013], Clark County Combined Health District Director Charles Patterson said. Patterson expressed frustration Friday [6 Dec 2013] after announcing the pertussis outbreak continued to climb in the area. \"There is some frustration because, if one family with the disease has extended family of 10 people, and each of them spread it to 5 or 10 people, it makes it difficult to stop,\" Patterson said.\n\nIn 2013, Ohio has seen a 20 percent increase in reported pertussis cases, compared to 2012. As of 2 Nov 2013, there had been 901 cases reported in 2013, compared with 742 on the same date in 2012. Clark, Madison, Pickaway, Licking, Delaware, and Richland counties have the highest rates of the disease statewide, according to the Ohio Department of Health.\n\n[Byline: Tiffany Y Latta]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Ohio can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/9BMy. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/ohio.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] Colorado (Phillips County)\nDate: Fri 6 Dec 2013\nSource: Fort Morgan (CO) Times [edited]\nhttp://www.fortmorgantimes.com/fort-morgan-local-news/ci_24669544/pertussis-infections-rise-northeast-colorado\n\n\nOver the past month the Northeast Colorado Health Department [NCHD] has received notification of 14 positive cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, in Phillips County, according to a recent press release.\n\nThe majority of the positive cases are in school-aged children and even though the cases are concentrated in Phillips County at this time, case rates are high across the state. Health officials are urging individuals that have a cough, or have a family member that has a cough, that has lasted more than 14 days to see their healthcare provider, and to make sure family member vaccinations are up to date.\n\n\"Pertussis has been circulating at epidemic levels in Colorado for the past couple of years so it's not surprising we're seeing increased cases in our area,\" said Dr Tony Cappello, NCHD's public health director, in the release. \"While this infection can just be a nagging cough for some people, it can be very severe and even deadly for infants and others with compromised immune systems. This is not an illness you want to pass on to an infant that doesn't have the immunity to fight it off; whether it be your own grandchild, a neighbor's new baby, or your own newborn.\n\n\"It can also be very hard to get rid of once it gets in a community,\" continued Dr Cappello. \"Over the course of our case investigations in Phillips County we've had to touch base with several other school districts alerting them to probable exposures at school events. The best thing that people can do if they think they have pertussis is to visit their healthcare provider, stay home if they're ill, cover their cough, stay away from infants, wash their hands, and make sure they're up to date on vaccinations.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/9BMz. Phillips County in northeastern Colorado can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[6] Pathogen evolution\nDate: Mon 23 Dec 2013\nSource: Popular Science [edited]\nhttp://www.popsci.com/article/science/whooping-cough-has-evolved-response-its-vaccine\n\n\nThis is not your parents' pertussis. Over the last few years, this once-common childhood illness, also known as whooping cough, has evolved in response to its own vaccine, according to a new study from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nThe mutated pertussis is not more dangerous than the original, and vaccines against the illness are still effective. So the findings don't change researchers' and doctors' understanding of whooping cough as a public health problem. Instead, they're a glimpse into a fascinating natural phenomenon, and one that's happening as we speak. (Though this isn't the 1st time this has happened. Populations of pneumococcal illnesses changed after the introduction of its vaccine, prompting changes to the vaccine to deal with newly popular strains.) The whooping cough findings have kicked off research to determine whether this is related to the recent increase in whooping cough cases in the US.\n\nPaul Offit, chief of the division of infectious diseases at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, was not involved in the CDC study, but took part in a conference call about the study in which CDC researchers presented their results. He talked with Popular Science over the phone immediately after the call.\n\n\"We discussed the data and what the data allow us to say and what they don't allow us to say,\" he says. \"The data don't support the notion that the mutants are more virulent.\" Babies who fall ill from un-mutated pertussis have the same symptoms as babies who fall ill from mutated pertussis, he says.\n\nThere's also no evidence yet that pertussis vaccines are less effective against the new strains, say all of the researchers Popular Science talked with, both in and outside of the CDC. Everyone recommended Americans continue to get vaccinated right on schedule. \"Currently, we know it's the best form of protection we have,\" says Lucia Pawloski, the CDC scientist who led the new research. Kids who don't get vaccinated against pertussis are still 8 times as likely as vaccinated kids to get the disease, she adds.\n\nNevertheless, it's plausible whooping cough's changes do affect the vaccine's ability to protect. \"Yes, theoretically, there could be an issue, but we don't have any data to say that yet,\" Pawloski says. The CDC is interested in answering this question and hopefully will have data to do so in 6 or 8 months, Offit says.\n\nSo what exactly is different about pertussis nowadays? Since 2010, Pawloski and her colleagues have recorded a sharp rise in the US in strains of the illness that don't make a protein called pertactin. Before 2010, researchers saw only one US pertussis infection, from 1994, in which the bacteria didn't make pertactin. By 2012, the majority of pertussis infections researchers studied were caused by non-pertactin-making pertussis. Pawloski and her team examined 1300 samples taken from whooping cough outbreaks between 1935 and 2012.\n\nPertussis bacteria make thousands of proteins, but pertactin happens to be one of the few included in many forms of the vaccine used in developed countries, including the US. \"We've created this selective pressure,\" Offit says, by widely using vaccines with pertactin in them.\n\nWhen the proteins and other molecules in a vaccine enter your body through a shot, your immune system finds them, learns to recognize them, and develops defenses against them. Now, if you ever truly encounter that illness, your body will respond quickly to quash it. If the vaccine contains pertactin and the actual illness doesn't, that means your body is learning to recognize something that's useless to it when it encounters whooping cough.\n\nAll pertussis vaccines used in developed countries have one, 2, or 3 other pertussis molecules besides pertactin, so there's still stuff in there for your body to train on, even if pertactin is now useless. How much of a blow -- if any at all -- losing pertactin deals to vaccines that have other active molecules is still unclear. \"I think at this point it's hard to say exactly what it means for the vaccines' effectiveness,\" says Nicola Klein, co-director of the Kaiser Permanente Vaccine Study Center in California. Klein was not involved in the CDC study.\n\nMeanwhile, pertussis vaccines often used in developing countries contain entire killed _Bordetella pertussis_ bacteria, so they actually contain perhaps thousands of things the body is able to use to learn to recognize whooping cough. Those vaccines, which are cheaper to make, were discontinued in developed countries because they cause severe, if non-permanent, side effects, such as seizures in babies.\n\nCDC researchers now are looking into whether losing pertactin is related to another phenomenon associated with the increasing popularity of the newer whooping cough vaccines. Recent studies have found that even those kids who get all their recommended pertussis shots -- in the US administered as the DTaP [diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis] shot -- are vulnerable again to whooping cough at about age 8 or 10. Researchers think the new vaccine is why the US saw more cases of whooping cough in 2012 than it has in any year since 1955. The older shot, with the killed bacteria, protected people for longer. Scientists are unsure what exactly made the tougher stuff longer-lasting, however.\n\nIs pertussis' evolution the answer? That's not certain yet. \"We couldn't say yes or no at this point whether pertactin had a role in the waning of immunity,\" Pawloski says.\n\n[Byline: Francie Diep]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Palowski's paper, \"Prevalence and molecular characterization of pertactin-deficient _Bordetella pertussis_ in the US. Clin Vaccine Immunol. 2013 Nov 20. [Epub ahead of print] can be found at http://www.asm.org/images/Communications/tips/2013/1213pertussis.pdf.\n\nThe number of cases of pertussis over time tends to have upswing cycles every 3-5 years but the case increases have been greater and more prolonged in the past several years. Utah is just one of a number of USA states including Washington and Wisconsin that have had substantial increase in the disease with, in addition, infant deaths related to cases transmitted by family members. Most up-to-date ACIP (Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices) recommendations continue to increase vaccination recommendations to order to \"cocoon\" the susceptible infant cohort. The most recent recommendations include re-vaccination for pregnant women in the 2nd or 3rd trimester for each pregnancy (1).\n\nIn addition to the Tartlof paper (2), an additional recent publication, currently in press in Clinical Infectious Disease (3), utilizes a large cohort of young people receiving all of the health care at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in San Rafael, California, USA, and clearly shows that a markedly increased risk of pertussis occurs associated with those who received only acellular pertussis vaccine. As compared to those who received at least one dose of the killed, whole cell pertussis vaccine (prior to the switch to all acellular dosing), the relative risk of acquiring pertussis was 8.57 in those receiving 5 doses of the acellular vaccine, but fell to a relative risk of 3.55 in those receiving 6 doses of the acellular vaccine.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC: Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommended immunization schedule. MMWR 2013; 62 (Suppl): 1-19; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/wk/mm62e0128.pdf.\n2. Tartof SY, Lewis MKenyon C, et al: Waning immunity to pertussis following 5 doses of DTaP. Pediatrics 2013; 131(4): e1047-52. doi: 10.1542/peds.2012-1928; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/4/e1047.full.pdf+html.\n3. Witt MA, Arias L, Katz PH, et al: Reduced risk of pertussis among persons ever vaccinated with whole cell pertussis vaccine compared to recipients of acellular pertussis vaccines in a large US cohort. Clin Infect Dis. 2013 May; 56(9): 1248-54. doi: 10.1093/cid/cit046; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23487373.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (02) 20130905.1923593\nPertussis - USA: waning immunity 20130316.1590032\n2012\n----\nPertussis - USA (12) 20120718.1204697\nPertussis - USA (11): (WA) hospital exposure 20120706.1190876\nPertussis - USA (10) 20120611.1161299\nPertussis - USA (09) 20120522.1137174\nPertussis - USA (08) 20120513.1122809\nPertussis - USA (07) 20120423.1111130\nPertussis - USA (06) 20120418.1105680\nPertussis - USA (05) 20120410.1096152\nPertussis - USA (04) 20120325.1080223\nPertussis -
