Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.aporrea.org/internacionales/n217707.html\n\n\nWhooping cough [pertussis], a highly contagious infectious disease that can be prevented with vaccination in children, resurfaced in Bogota and this year [2012] has already caused the deaths of 23 children younger than 5 years. The District Department of Health [SDS by its Spanish initials] confirmed that this number almost doubles the 14 fatal cases recorded in 2011. Most of the victims were younger than one year, according to SDS epidemiologist Patricia Arce.\n\nThe National Institute of Health [INS by its Spanish initials] in turn reported that between January and September 2012, 589 cases of pertussis were confirmed in Bogota, 21 percent of all cases diagnosed in the country. Bogota is 2nd to Antioquia, with the most confirmed cases, mostly in children under 5 years.\n\nThe concern of health authorities is that pertussis is easily transmitted by saliva droplets when you cough or sneeze.\n\nIn Bogota, most sick children were infected by their parents. \"Newborns are most susceptible to infection because their immune system still does not have enough defenses against disease,\" explained Arce.\n\nSome health experts questioned the reemergence of pertussis, since a vaccine has been available for 50 years, and there are teams in the city which supposedly visit households to identify children requiring completion of their vaccination schedule. [But many were in children who were too young to be vaccinated. - Mod.JW].\n\nPertussis is caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_. It is transmitted by the respiratory route, has an incubation period of 6 to 20 days, and can last an average of 7 weeks or more. It begins with a catarrhal phase, and its characteristic symptom is persistent cough or wheezing with noise, which makes breathing difficult. In children, it can lead to breathing difficulties that last [for several] seconds, making them turn blue or purple and requiring urgent care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[2012 has been a dramatic year for pertussis throughout most of the world. Although there is some evidence for genetic changes in the strains, it is clear that the less reactogenic acellular pertussis vaccine has a shorter length of protection than the older whole cell, killed vaccine.\n\nAs is reported in this posting, much of the morbidity and mortality with this infection is in infants less than one year of age, especially less than 6 months, when they are not yet protected by active immunization. To protect this susceptible cohort, all care givers should have been given a TDap booster, and the pregnant mother should also be immunized in the 2nd or 3rd trimester to transplacentally provide maternal antibody. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1l0z.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - UK (03) 20120710.1196457\nPertussis - New Zealand (03): update 20120706.1190855\nPertussis - Argentina (03): (MZ) 20120703.1188519\nPertussis - UK (02): background 20120608.1161130\nPertussis - UK 20120607.1159983\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.aporrea.org/internacionales/n217707.html\n\n\nWhooping cough [pertussis], a highly contagious infectious disease that can be prevented with vaccination in children, resurfaced in Bogota and this year [2012] has already caused the deaths of 23 children younger than 5 years. The District Department of Health [SDS by its Spanish initials] confirmed that this number almost doubles the 14 fatal cases recorded in 2011. Most of the victims were younger than one year, according to SDS epidemiologist Patricia Arce.\n\nThe National Institute of Health [INS by its Spanish initials] in turn reported that between January and September 2012, 589 cases of pertussis were confirmed in Bogota, 21 percent of all cases diagnosed in the country. Bogota is 2nd to Antioquia, with the most confirmed cases, mostly in children under 5 years.\n\nThe concern of health authorities is that pertussis is easily transmitted by saliva droplets when you cough or sneeze.\n\nIn Bogota, most sick children were infected by their parents. \"Newborns are most susceptible to infection because their immune system still does not have enough defenses against disease,\" explained Arce.\n\nSome health experts questioned the reemergence of pertussis, since a vaccine has been available for 50 years, and there are teams in the city which supposedly visit households to identify children requiring completion of their vaccination schedule. [But many were in children who were too young to be vaccinated. - Mod.JW].\n\nPertussis is caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_. It is transmitted by the respiratory route, has an incubation period of 6 to 20 days, and can last an average of 7 weeks or more. It begins with a catarrhal phase, and its characteristic symptom is persistent cough or wheezing with noise, which makes breathing difficult. In children, it can lead to breathing difficulties that last [for several] seconds, making them turn blue or purple and requiring urgent care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[2012 has been a dramatic year for pertussis throughout most of the world. Although there is some evidence for genetic changes in the strains, it is clear that the less reactogenic acellular pertussis vaccine has a shorter length of protection than the older whole cell, killed vaccine.\n\nAs is reported in this posting, much of the morbidity and mortality with this infection is in infants less than one year of age, especially less than 6 months, when they are not yet protected by active immunization. To protect this susceptible cohort, all care givers should have been given a TDap booster, and the pregnant mother should also be immunized in the 2nd or 3rd trimester to transplacentally provide maternal antibody. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1l0z.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - UK (03) 20120710.1196457\nPertussis - New Zealand (03): update 20120706.1190855\nPertussis - Argentina (03): (MZ) 20120703.1188519\nPertussis - UK (02): background 20120608.1161130\nPertussis - UK 20120607.1159983\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. [But many were in children who were too young to be vaccinated. - Mod.JW].\n\nPertussis is caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_. It begins with a catarrhal phase, and its characteristic symptom is persistent cough or wheezing with noise, which makes breathing difficult. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.aporrea.org/internacionales/n217707.html\n\n\nWhooping cough [pertussis], a highly contagious infectious disease that can be prevented with vaccination in children, resurfaced in Bogota and this year [2012] has already caused the deaths of 23 children younger than 5 years. The District Department of Health [SDS by its Spanish initials] confirmed that this number almost doubles the 14 fatal cases recorded in 2011. Most of the victims were younger than one year, according to SDS epidemiologist Patricia Arce.\n\nThe National Institute of Health [INS by its Spanish initials] in turn reported that between January and September 2012, 589 cases of pertussis were confirmed in Bogota, 21 percent of all cases diagnosed in the country. Bogota is 2nd to Antioquia, with the most confirmed cases, mostly in children under 5 years.\n\nThe concern of health authorities is that pertussis is easily transmitted by saliva droplets when you cough or sneeze.\n\nIn Bogota, most sick children were infected by their parents. \"Newborns are most susceptible to infection because their immune system still does not have enough defenses against disease,\" explained Arce.\n\nSome health experts questioned the reemergence of pertussis, since a vaccine has been available for 50 years, and there are teams in the city which supposedly visit households to identify children requiring completion of their vaccination schedule. [But many were in children who were too young to be vaccinated. - Mod.JW].\n\nPertussis is caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_. It is transmitted by the respiratory route, has an incubation period of 6 to 20 days, and can last an average of 7 weeks or more. It begins with a catarrhal phase, and its characteristic symptom is persistent cough or wheezing with noise, which makes breathing difficult. In children, it can lead to breathing difficulties that last [for several] seconds, making them turn blue or purple and requiring urgent care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[2012 has been a dramatic year for pertussis throughout most of the world. Although there is some evidence for genetic changes in the strains, it is clear that the less reactogenic acellular pertussis vaccine has a shorter length of protection than the older whole cell, killed vaccine.\n\nAs is reported in this posting, much of the morbidity and mortality with this infection is in infants less than one year of age, especially less than 6 months, when they are not yet protected by active immunization. To protect this susceptible cohort, all care givers should have been given a TDap booster, and the pregnant mother should also be immunized in the 2nd or 3rd trimester to transplacentally provide maternal antibody. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1l0z.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - UK (03) 20120710.1196457\nPertussis - New Zealand (03): update 20120706.1190855\nPertussis - Argentina (03): (MZ) 20120703.1188519\nPertussis - UK (02): background 20120608.1161130\nPertussis - UK 20120607.1159983\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n.................................................sb/jw/mj/ll/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bogota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Sepik", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equatoria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1400201", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Colombia: alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1400201", "date": "2012-11-08 16:42:19", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - COLOMBIA: ALERT\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 7 Nov 2012\nSource: Aporrea.org [in Spanish, trans. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.aporrea.org/internacionales/n217707.html\n\n\nWhooping cough [pertussis], a highly contagious infectious disease that can be prevented with vaccination in children, resurfaced in Bogota and this year [2012] has already caused the deaths of 23 children younger than 5 years. The District Department of Health [SDS by its Spanish initials] confirmed that this number almost doubles the 14 fatal cases recorded in 2011. Most of the victims were younger than one year, according to SDS epidemiologist Patricia Arce.\n\nThe National Institute of Health [INS by its Spanish initials] in turn reported that between January and September 2012, 589 cases of pertussis were confirmed in Bogota, 21 percent of all cases diagnosed in the country. Bogota is 2nd to Antioquia, with the most confirmed cases, mostly in children under 5 years.\n\nThe concern of health authorities is that pertussis is easily transmitted by saliva droplets when you cough or sneeze.\n\nIn Bogota, most sick children were infected by their parents. \"Newborns are most susceptible to infection because their immune system still does not have enough defenses against disease,\" explained Arce.\n\nSome health experts questioned the reemergence of pertussis, since a vaccine has been available for 50 years, and there are teams in the city which supposedly visit households to identify children requiring completion of their vaccination schedule. [But many were in children who were too young to be vaccinated. - Mod.JW].\n\nPertussis is caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_. It is transmitted by the respiratory route, has an incubation period of 6 to 20 days, and can last an average of 7 weeks or more. It begins with a catarrhal phase, and its characteristic symptom is persistent cough or wheezing with noise, which makes breathing difficult. In children, it can lead to breathing difficulties that last [for several] seconds, making them turn blue or purple and requiring urgent care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[2012 has been a dramatic year for pertussis throughout most of the world. Although there is some evidence for genetic changes in the strains, it is clear that the less reactogenic acellular pertussis vaccine has a shorter length of protection than the older whole cell, killed vaccine.\n\nAs is reported in this posting, much of the morbidity and mortality with this infection is in infants less than one year of age, especially less than 6 months, when they are not yet protected by active immunization. To protect this susceptible cohort, all care givers should have been given a TDap booster, and the pregnant mother should also be immunized in the 2nd or 3rd trimester to transplacentally provide maternal antibody. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1l0z.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - UK (03) 20120710.1196457\nPertussis - New Zealand (03): update 20120706.1190855\nPertussis - Argentina (03): (MZ) 20120703.1188519\nPertussis - UK (02): background 20120608.1161130\nPertussis - UK 20120607.1159983\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. There are outbreaks in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph, Perth, Oxford, Elgin-St. Thomas, Haldimand-Norfolk and the Windsor-Essex areas. People in the households of the local kids involved and high-risk contacts have been offered preventative treatment with antibiotics.\n\nThe release was issued to remind people that immunization is the best protection against whooping cough or pertussis, health unit spokesman Drew Ferguson said.\n\nOne to 3 deaths from pertussis occur each year in Canada, usually in infants too young to have begun their immunization and in partially immunized infants. The Ontario outbreaks occurred among people who were not immunized, typically among Mennonites, Ferguson said. Locally though, the health unit has had success bringing immunization clinics to local Mennonites, he said.\n\n[Byline: Scott Dunn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unlike most if the outbreaks that have been posted on ProMED, it seems that much of the pertussis burden in Ontario, Canada has been occurring in a religious cohort in the province that had not been immunized. - Mod.LL\n\nOntario, Canada, can be located using the HealthMap/ProMEDmail interactive map at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1*Y3. - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPertussis - UK (02): background 20120608.1161130\nPertussis - UK 20120607.1159983\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\nPertussis - Canada (04): (NB) 20120523.1142647\nPertussis - Canada (03): (YT) 20120502.1120666\nPertussis - Canada (02): (ON) unimmunized group 20120410.1094957\nPertussis - Chile (02): background 20120409.1094968\nPertussis - Chile: increased morbidity & mortality 20120404.1090350\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. There are outbreaks in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph, Perth, Oxford, Elgin-St. Thomas, Haldimand-Norfolk and the Windsor-Essex areas. People in the households of the local kids involved and high-risk contacts have been offered preventative treatment with antibiotics.\n\nThe release was issued to remind people that immunization is the best protection against whooping cough or pertussis, health unit spokesman Drew Ferguson said.\n\nOne to 3 deaths from pertussis occur each year in Canada, usually in infants too young to have begun their immunization and in partially immunized infants. The Ontario outbreaks occurred among people who were not immunized, typically among Mennonites, Ferguson said. Locally though, the health unit has had success bringing immunization clinics to local Mennonites, he said.\n\n[Byline: Scott Dunn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unlike most if the outbreaks that have been posted on ProMED, it seems that much of the pertussis burden in Ontario, Canada has been occurring in a religious cohort in the province that had not been immunized. - Mod.LL\n\nOntario, Canada, can be located using the HealthMap/ProMEDmail interactive map at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1*Y3. - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPertussis - UK (02): background 20120608.1161130\nPertussis - UK 20120607.1159983\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\nPertussis - Canada (04): (NB) 20120523.1142647\nPertussis - Canada (03): (YT) 20120502.1120666\nPertussis - Canada (02): (ON) unimmunized group 20120410.1094957\nPertussis - Chile (02): background 20120409.1094968\nPertussis - Chile: increased morbidity & mortality 20120404.1090350\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. There are outbreaks in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph, Perth, Oxford, Elgin-St. Thomas, Haldimand-Norfolk and the Windsor-Essex areas. People in the households of the local kids involved and high-risk contacts have been offered preventative treatment with antibiotics.\n\nThe release was issued to remind people that immunization is the best protection against whooping cough or pertussis, health unit spokesman Drew Ferguson said.\n\nOne to 3 deaths from pertussis occur each year in Canada, usually in infants too young to have begun their immunization and in partially immunized infants. The Ontario outbreaks occurred among people who were not immunized, typically among Mennonites, Ferguson said. Locally though, the health unit has had success bringing immunization clinics to local Mennonites, he said.\n\n[Byline: Scott Dunn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unlike most if the outbreaks that have been posted on ProMED, it seems that much of the pertussis burden in Ontario, Canada has been occurring in a religious cohort in the province that had not been immunized. - Mod.LL\n\nOntario, Canada, can be located using the HealthMap/ProMEDmail interactive map at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1*Y3. - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPertussis - UK (02): background 20120608.1161130\nPertussis - UK 20120607.1159983\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\nPertussis - Canada (04): (NB) 20120523.1142647\nPertussis - Canada (03): (YT) 20120502.1120666\nPertussis - Canada (02): (ON) unimmunized group 20120410.1094957\nPertussis - Chile (02): background 20120409.1094968\nPertussis - Chile: increased morbidity & mortality 20120404.1090350\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. There are outbreaks in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph, Perth, Oxford, Elgin-St. Thomas, Haldimand-Norfolk and the Windsor-Essex areas. People in the households of the local kids involved and high-risk contacts have been offered preventative treatment with antibiotics.\n\nThe release was issued to remind people that immunization is the best protection against whooping cough or pertussis, health unit spokesman Drew Ferguson said.\n\nOne to 3 deaths from pertussis occur each year in Canada, usually in infants too young to have begun their immunization and in partially immunized infants. The Ontario outbreaks occurred among people who were not immunized, typically among Mennonites, Ferguson said. Locally though, the health unit has had success bringing immunization clinics to local Mennonites, he said.\n\n[Byline: Scott Dunn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unlike most if the outbreaks that have been posted on ProMED, it seems that much of the pertussis burden in Ontario, Canada has been occurring in a religious cohort in the province that had not been immunized. - Mod.LL\n\nOntario, Canada, can be located using the HealthMap/ProMEDmail interactive map at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1*Y3. - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPertussis - UK (02): background 20120608.1161130\nPertussis - UK 20120607.1159983\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\nPertussis - Canada (04): (NB) 20120523.1142647\nPertussis - Canada (03): (YT) 20120502.1120666\nPertussis - Canada (02): (ON) unimmunized group 20120410.1094957\nPertussis - Chile (02): background 20120409.1094968\nPertussis - Chile: increased morbidity & mortality 20120404.1090350\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. Canada (05): (ON), unimmunized cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1170399", "date": "2012-06-16 18:31:32", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA (05): ONTARIO, UNIMMUNIZED CASES\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jun 2012\nSource: Owen Sound Sun-Times (ON) [edited]\nhttp://www.owensoundsuntimes.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=3585096\n\n\nAn infant and a young child living in southern Grey-Bruce are expected to make full recoveries from pertussis (whooping cough), a contagious bacterial respiratory illness, a Grey-Bruce Health Unit news release said Wed 13 Jun 2012.\n\nThe separate, lab-confirmed cases are not believed to be part of the outbreak in parts of southwestern Ontario, the health unit says. There are outbreaks in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph, Perth, Oxford, Elgin-St. Thomas, Haldimand-Norfolk and the Windsor-Essex areas. People in the households of the local kids involved and high-risk contacts have been offered preventative treatment with antibiotics.\n\nThe release was issued to remind people that immunization is the best protection against whooping cough or pertussis, health unit spokesman Drew Ferguson said.\n\nOne to 3 deaths from pertussis occur each year in Canada, usually in infants too young to have begun their immunization and in partially immunized infants. The Ontario outbreaks occurred among people who were not immunized, typically among Mennonites, Ferguson said. Locally though, the health unit has had success bringing immunization clinics to local Mennonites, he said.\n\n[Byline: Scott Dunn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unlike most if the outbreaks that have been posted on ProMED, it seems that much of the pertussis burden in Ontario, Canada has been occurring in a religious cohort in the province that had not been immunized. - Mod.LL\n\nOntario, Canada, can be located using the HealthMap/ProMEDmail interactive map at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1*Y3. - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPertussis - UK (02): background 20120608.1161130\nPertussis - UK 20120607.1159983\nPertussis - New Zealand (02): background 20120606.1158351\nPertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland) 20120605.1157147\nPertussis - Canada (04): (NB) 20120523.1142647\nPertussis - Canada (03): (YT) 20120502.1120666\nPertussis - Canada (02): (ON) unimmunized group 20120410.1094957\nPertussis - Chile (02): background 20120409.1094968\nPertussis - Chile: increased morbidity & mortality 20120404.1090350\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n.................................................sb/ll/ejp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Perth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Sepik", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wellington - Dufferin - Guelph", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equatoria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1161299", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (10)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1161299", "date": "2012-05-20 23:08:22", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - ARGENTINA (02)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 15 May 2012\nSource: La Voz [machine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.lavoz.com.ar/ciudadanos/2012-crecieron-90-casos-tos-convulsa\n\n\nIn spite of the fact that there are vaccines to prevent whooping cough, the infection has become a re-emerging disease, which today is one of the major causes of morbidity and mortality in children. The main victims of this acute respiratory infection caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_ (whooping cough), are infants younger than 6 months, usually acquired from their parents or teenage siblings, or even a member of the health care team. In infants, pertussis can be a serious disease that can lead to severe complications or even death, unlike what happens in adults or older children. The reemergence of the whooping cough or pertussis can be observed in the numbers of cases in the country.\n\nUp until 30 April 2012 597 cases of pertussis were confirmed by laboratory testing. In the same period of 2011, there were 315 cases: [this is] 90 percent more. The data comes from the National Reference Laboratory for_Bordetella pertussis_ of Argentina.\n\nThe cases reported in that period were in turn 1028 in 2011 and 2399 in 2012, which means an increase of 133 percent, perhaps explained by the deepening of the epidemiological surveillance that would result in greater reporting of suspect cases.\n\nThe Ministry of Health of Argentina reported thatin 2011 the cases reported were more than expected, a situation similar to that recorded in other countries of the region, such as Chile, Uruguay, Cuba and the USA, which also had outbreaks of the disease. In 2012, the situation has not changed, warned this week the head of the National Program for Control of vaccine-preventable diseases, Carla Vizzotti, who pointed out that the figures \"indicate a level of suspect cases confirms that we are in an outbreak, as happened in 2011.\"\n\n\n[Byline: Marcela Fernandez]\n\n--\nCoomunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA as in Argentina, recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines have continued to expand in efforts to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized, like the ones described in this report. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women to provide passive immunity is a further expansion of these recommendations. It is likely, given the limited number of contacts small infants have, that the source for the infant is a family member.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility of older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical \"whoop,\" after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but it is increasingly clear that _Bordetella pertussis_ clones are being selected by the acellular vaccine, against which we are no longer as well protected by the current vaccines.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yJb.\n- Mod. The main victims of this acute respiratory infection caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_ (whooping cough), are infants younger than 6 months, usually acquired from their parents or teenage siblings, or even a member of the health care team. In infants, pertussis can be a serious disease that can lead to severe complications or even death, unlike what happens in adults or older children. The reemergence of the whooping cough or pertussis can be observed in the numbers of cases in the country.\n\nUp until 30 April 2012 597 cases of pertussis were confirmed by laboratory testing. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women to provide passive immunity is a further expansion of these recommendations. It is likely, given the limited number of contacts small infants have, that the source for the infant is a family member.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility of older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical \"whoop,\" after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but it is increasingly clear that _Bordetella pertussis_ clones are being selected by the acellular vaccine, against which we are no longer as well protected by the current vaccines.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yJb.\n- Mod. LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Argentina 20120504.1122722\nPertussis - Australia (05): (WA) 20120418.1105456\nPertussis - Chile (02): background 20120409.1094968\nPertussis - Chile: increased morbidity & mortality 20120404.1090350\nPertussis - USA (04) 20120325.1080223\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n.................................................sb/ll/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-05-15 00:00:00", "2012-04-30 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1028-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2399-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Sepik", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equatoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1157147", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - New Zealand: (Auckland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1157147", "date": "2012-05-20 23:08:22", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - ARGENTINA (02)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 15 May 2012\nSource: La Voz [machine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.lavoz.com.ar/ciudadanos/2012-crecieron-90-casos-tos-convulsa\n\n\nIn spite of the fact that there are vaccines to prevent whooping cough, the infection has become a re-emerging disease, which today is one of the major causes of morbidity and mortality in children. The main victims of this acute respiratory infection caused by the bacterium _Bordetella pertussis_ (whooping cough), are infants younger than 6 months, usually acquired from their parents or teenage siblings, or even a member of the health care team. In infants, pertussis can be a serious disease that can lead to severe complications or even death, unlike what happens in adults or older children. The reemergence of the whooping cough or pertussis can be observed in the numbers of cases in the country.\n\nUp until 30 April 2012 597 cases of pertussis were confirmed by laboratory testing. In the same period of 2011, there were 315 cases: [this is] 90 percent more. The data comes from the National Reference Laboratory for_Bordetella pertussis_ of Argentina.\n\nThe cases reported in that period were in turn 1028 in 2011 and 2399 in 2012, which means an increase of 133 percent, perhaps explained by the deepening of the epidemiological surveillance that would result in greater reporting of suspect cases.\n\nThe Ministry of Health of Argentina reported thatin 2011 the cases reported were more than expected, a situation similar to that recorded in other countries of the region, such as Chile, Uruguay, Cuba and the USA, which also had outbreaks of the disease. In 2012, the situation has not changed, warned this week the head of the National Program for Control of vaccine-preventable diseases, Carla Vizzotti, who pointed out that the figures \"indicate a level of suspect cases confirms that we are in an outbreak, as happened in 2011.\"\n\n\n[Byline: Marcela Fernandez]\n\n--\nCoomunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA as in Argentina, recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines have continued to expand in efforts to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized, like the ones described in this report. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women to provide passive immunity is a further expansion of these recommendations. It is likely, given the limited number of contacts small infants have, that the source for the infant is a family member.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility of older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical \"whoop,\" after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but it is increasingly clear that _Bordetella pertussis_ clones are being selected by the acellular vaccine, against which we are no longer as well protected by the current vaccines.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yJb.\n- Mod. It is likely, given the limited number of contacts small infants have, that the source for the infant is a family member.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility of older children and adults to pertussis, usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical \"whoop,\" after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem, but it is increasingly clear that _Bordetella pertussis_ clones are being selected by the acellular vaccine, against which we are no longer as well protected by the current vaccines.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yJb.\n- Mod. LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Argentina 20120504.1122722\nPertussis - Australia (05): (WA) 20120418.1105456\nPertussis - Chile (02): background 20120409.1094968\nPertussis - Chile: increased morbidity & mortality 20120404.1090350\nPertussis - USA (04) 20120325.1080223\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n.................................................sb/ll/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-05-15 00:00:00", "2012-04-30 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1028-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2399-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Sepik", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equatoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1122809", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (08)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1122809", "date": "2012-04-10 12:20:02", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - CANADA: (ONTARIO) UNIMMUNIZED GROUP\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 6 Apr 2012\nSource: Guelph (ON) Mercury [edited]\nhttp://www.guelphmercury.com/news/local/article/700524--whooping-cough-outbreak-among-mennonites\n\n\nA pertussis outbreak in the Low German-speaking Mennonite population of the region is proving challenging for public health officials to contain. The issue was raised this week during a board meeting of Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health.\n\nPertussis, commonly referred to as whooping cough, is highly contagious. Its presence was first confirmed in the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph area on 15 Feb 2012, but the outbreak was declared elsewhere in late January 2012. The local health unit is one of 7 dealing with the problem.\n\nDr Nicola Mercer, medical officer of health, told board members that since the Low German Mennonite population generally does not seek medical attention or vaccination, fighting the outbreak is extremely difficult. She said public health officials are confident there are many other cases of whooping cough among the population. Immunization clinics have been set up, but are poorly attended.\n\nSo far 4 children have been hospitalized throughout the 7 health units. The family in the one case in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph was provided access to antibiotic medications to treat the disease. The family refused immunization.\n\nAn outbreak roughly 2 years ago among the same Mennonite population left a number of people very sick. \"They continue to have an under-immunized population, so we likely will continue to have outbreaks,\" Mercer said, adding that whooping cause can cause death. The most vulnerable are the very young. She added that an 85 percent immunization rate is generally what is needed to have a serious impact on a disease.\n\nThe hardest hit area so far is within the Elgin-St Thomas health unit, where there are 64 cases. Of the 82 confirmed cases within the district of the 7 health units, the median age of infection is 7 years.\n\nThe outbreak is occurring among members of the same religious community, who attend the same schools and churches.\n\n[Byline: Rob O'Flanagan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the ProMED-mail postings regarding pertussis have been related to outbreaks in immunized populations. When an outbreak occurs in a population that does not access vaccinations for religious reasons, the manifestations of the outbreak can be more severe and these individuals can serve as vehicles for transmission to others outside the religious community. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/29My.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Chile (02): background 20120409.1094968\nPertussis - Chile: increased morbidity & mortality 20120404.1090350\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. The issue was raised this week during a board meeting of Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health.\n\nPertussis, commonly referred to as whooping cough, is highly contagious. Its presence was first confirmed in the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph area on 15 Feb 2012, but the outbreak was declared elsewhere in late January 2012. The local health unit is one of 7 dealing with the problem.\n\nDr Nicola Mercer, medical officer of health, told board members that since the Low German Mennonite population generally does not seek medical attention or vaccination, fighting the outbreak is extremely difficult. She said public health officials are confident there are many other cases of whooping cough among the population. Immunization clinics have been set up, but are poorly attended.\n\nSo far 4 children have been hospitalized throughout the 7 health units. The family in the one case in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph was provided access to antibiotic medications to treat the disease. The family refused immunization.\n\nAn outbreak roughly 2 years ago among the same Mennonite population left a number of people very sick. \"They continue to have an under-immunized population, so we likely will continue to have outbreaks,\" Mercer said, adding that whooping cause can cause death. The most vulnerable are the very young. She added that an 85 percent immunization rate is generally what is needed to have a serious impact on a disease.\n\nThe hardest hit area so far is within the Elgin-St Thomas health unit, where there are 64 cases. Of the 82 confirmed cases within the district of the 7 health units, the median age of infection is 7 years.\n\nThe outbreak is occurring among members of the same religious community, who attend the same schools and churches.\n\n[Byline: Rob O'Flanagan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the ProMED-mail postings regarding pertussis have been related to outbreaks in immunized populations. The issue was raised this week during a board meeting of Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health.\n\nPertussis, commonly referred to as whooping cough, is highly contagious. Its presence was first confirmed in the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph area on 15 Feb 2012, but the outbreak was declared elsewhere in late January 2012. The local health unit is one of 7 dealing with the problem.\n\nDr Nicola Mercer, medical officer of health, told board members that since the Low German Mennonite population generally does not seek medical attention or vaccination, fighting the outbreak is extremely difficult. She said public health officials are confident there are many other cases of whooping cough among the population. Immunization clinics have been set up, but are poorly attended.\n\nSo far 4 children have been hospitalized throughout the 7 health units. The family in the one case in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph was provided access to antibiotic medications to treat the disease. The family refused immunization.\n\nAn outbreak roughly 2 years ago among the same Mennonite population left a number of people very sick. \"They continue to have an under-immunized population, so we likely will continue to have outbreaks,\" Mercer said, adding that whooping cause can cause death. The most vulnerable are the very young. She added that an 85 percent immunization rate is generally what is needed to have a serious impact on a disease.\n\nThe hardest hit area so far is within the Elgin-St Thomas health unit, where there are 64 cases. Of the 82 confirmed cases within the district of the 7 health units, the median age of infection is 7 years.\n\nThe outbreak is occurring among members of the same religious community, who attend the same schools and churches.\n\n[Byline: Rob O'Flanagan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the ProMED-mail postings regarding pertussis have been related to outbreaks in immunized populations. The issue was raised this week during a board meeting of Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health.\n\nPertussis, commonly referred to as whooping cough, is highly contagious. Its presence was first confirmed in the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph area on 15 Feb 2012, but the outbreak was declared elsewhere in late January 2012. The local health unit is one of 7 dealing with the problem.\n\nDr Nicola Mercer, medical officer of health, told board members that since the Low German Mennonite population generally does not seek medical attention or vaccination, fighting the outbreak is extremely difficult. She said public health officials are confident there are many other cases of whooping cough among the population. Immunization clinics have been set up, but are poorly attended.\n\nSo far 4 children have been hospitalized throughout the 7 health units. The family in the one case in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph was provided access to antibiotic medications to treat the disease. The family refused immunization.\n\nAn outbreak roughly 2 years ago among the same Mennonite population left a number of people very sick. \"They continue to have an under-immunized population, so we likely will continue to have outbreaks,\" Mercer said, adding that whooping cause can cause death. The most vulnerable are the very young. She added that an 85 percent immunization rate is generally what is needed to have a serious impact on a disease.\n\nThe hardest hit area so far is within the Elgin-St Thomas health unit, where there are 64 cases. The issue was raised this week during a board meeting of Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health.\n\nPertussis, commonly referred to as whooping cough, is highly contagious. Its presence was first confirmed in the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph area on 15 Feb 2012, but the outbreak was declared elsewhere in late January 2012. The local health unit is one of 7 dealing with the problem.\n\nDr Nicola Mercer, medical officer of health, told board members that since the Low German Mennonite population generally does not seek medical attention or vaccination, fighting the outbreak is extremely difficult. She said public health officials are confident there are many other cases of whooping cough among the population. Immunization clinics have been set up, but are poorly attended.\n\nSo far 4 children have been hospitalized throughout the 7 health units. The family in the one case in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph was provided access to antibiotic medications to treat the disease. The family refused immunization.\n\nAn outbreak roughly 2 years ago among the same Mennonite population left a number of people very sick. \"They continue to have an under-immunized population, so we likely will continue to have outbreaks,\" Mercer said, adding that whooping cause can cause death. The most vulnerable are the very young. She added that an 85 percent immunization rate is generally what is needed to have a serious impact on a disease.\n\nThe hardest hit area so far is within the Elgin-St Thomas health unit, where there are 64 cases. Of the 82 confirmed cases within the district of the 7 health units, the median age of infection is 7 years.\n\nThe outbreak is occurring among members of the same religious community, who attend the same schools and churches.\n\n[Byline: Rob O'Flanagan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the ProMED-mail postings regarding pertussis have been related to outbreaks in immunized populations. When an outbreak occurs in a population that does not access vaccinations for religious reasons, the manifestations of the outbreak can be more severe and these individuals can serve as vehicles for transmission to others outside the religious community. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/29My.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - Chile (02): background 20120409.1094968\nPertussis - Chile: increased morbidity & mortality 20120404.1090350\nPertussis - Australia (04): newly emerging clones, discussion 20120322.1078115\nPertussis - Australia (03): newly emerging clones 20120321.1076103\nPertussis - Australia (02): (QL) 20120316.1071497\nPertussis - Canada: (BC) 20120229.1055490\nPertussis - Australia: (WA) 20120111.1007036\n2011\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Chile: (BI) 20111206.3541\nPertussis - New Zealand 20111030.3227\n2010\n----\nPertussis - Australia: (QL) 20101021.3809\nPertussis - New Zealand: (CA) 20100626.2133\nPertussis - Congo DR: (KO) 20100428.1372\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2006\n----\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\n2005\n----\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n----\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): conf. The issue was raised this week during a board meeting of Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health.\n\nPertussis, commonly referred to as whooping cough, is highly contagious. Its presence was first confirmed in the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph area on 15 Feb 2012, but the outbreak was declared elsewhere in late January 2012. The local health unit is one of 7 dealing with the problem.\n\nDr Nicola Mercer, medical officer of health, told board members that since the Low German Mennonite population generally does not seek medical attention or vaccination, fighting the outbreak is extremely difficult. She said public health officials are confident there are many other cases of whooping cough among the population. Immunization clinics have been set up, but are poorly attended.\n\nSo far 4 children have been hospitalized throughout the 7 health units. The family in the one case in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph was provided access to antibiotic medications to treat the disease. The family refused immunization.\n\nAn outbreak roughly 2 years ago among the same Mennonite population left a number of people very sick. \"They continue to have an under-immunized population, so we likely will continue to have outbreaks,\" Mercer said, adding that whooping cause can cause death. The most vulnerable are the very young. She added that an 85 percent immunization rate is generally what is needed to have a serious impact on a disease.\n\nThe hardest hit area so far is within the Elgin-St Thomas health unit, where there are 64 cases. Of the 82 confirmed cases within the district of the 7 health units, the median age of infection is 7 years.\n\nThe outbreak is occurring among members of the same religious community, who attend the same schools and churches.\n\n[Byline: Rob O'Flanagan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the ProMED-mail postings regarding pertussis have been related to outbreaks in immunized populations. The issue was raised this week during a board meeting of Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health.\n\nPertussis, commonly referred to as whooping cough, is highly contagious. Its presence was first confirmed in the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph area on 15 Feb 2012, but the outbreak was declared elsewhere in late January 2012. The local health unit is one of 7 dealing with the problem.\n\nDr Nicola Mercer, medical officer of health, told board members that since the Low German Mennonite population generally does not seek medical attention or vaccination, fighting the outbreak is extremely difficult. She said public health officials are confident there are many other cases of whooping cough among the population. Immunization clinics have been set up, but are poorly attended.\n\nSo far 4 children have been hospitalized throughout the 7 health units. The family in the one case in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph was provided access to antibiotic medications to treat the disease. The family refused immunization.\n\nAn outbreak roughly 2 years ago among the same Mennonite population left a number of people very sick. \"They continue to have an under-immunized population, so we likely will continue to have outbreaks,\" Mercer said, adding that whooping cause can cause death. The most vulnerable are the very young. She added that an 85 percent immunization rate is generally what is needed to have a serious impact on a disease.\n\nThe hardest hit area so far is within the Elgin-St Thomas health unit, where there are 64 cases. Of the 82 confirmed cases within the district of the 7 health units, the median age of infection is 7 years.\n\nThe outbreak is occurring among members of the same religious community, who attend the same schools and churches.\n\n[Byline: Rob O'Flanagan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most of the ProMED-mail postings regarding pertussis have been related to outbreaks in immunized populations. The issue was raised this week during a board meeting of Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health.\n\nPertussis, commonly referred to as whooping cough, is highly contagious. Its presence was first confirmed in the Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph area on 15 Feb 2012, but the outbreak was declared elsewhere in late January 2012. The local health unit is one of 7 dealing with the problem.\n\nDr Nicola Mercer, medical officer of health, told board members that since the Low German Mennonite population generally does not seek medical attention or vaccination, fighting the outbreak is extremely difficult. She said public health officials are confident there are many other cases of whooping cough among the population. Immunization clinics have been set up, but are poorly attended.\n\nSo far 4 children have been hospitalized throughout the 7 health units. The family in the one case in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph was provided access to antibiotic medications to treat the disease. The family refused immunization.\n\nAn outbreak roughly 2 years ago among the same Mennonite population left a number of people very sick. \"They continue to have an under-immunized population, so we likely will continue to have outbreaks,\" Mercer said, adding that whooping cause can cause death. The most vulnerable are the very young. She added that an 85 percent immunization rate is generally what is needed to have a serious impact on a disease.\n\nThe hardest hit area so far is within the Elgin-St Thomas health unit, where there are 64 cases. Health officials say 156 cases involved children aged 10 and younger.\n\nA pair of 2 month old infants were hospitalized but have recovered.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Wisconsin (Chippewa county)\nDate: Sat 10 Mar 2012\nSource: Chippewa Herald [edited]\nhttp://chippewa.com/news/local/whooping-cough-confirmed-at-southview/article_ce7f8cbc-6a61-11e1-9be9-0019bb2963f4.html\n\n\nA student at Southview Elementary is the county\u2019s latest confirmed case of whooping cough. The Chippewa County Department of Public Health confirmed to school district parents and employees on Wednesday, 7 Mar 2012, that the student was infected with the pertussis bacterium, more commonly known as whooping cough.\n\nNeither school district staff nor county public health director Jean Durch would disclose the age or grade level of the infected student, citing the confidentiality of a single case. Durch said this is the 5th case of whooping cough the county has recorded since the beginning of 2012.\n\n\"A majority of those cases have links to Eau Claire,\" Durch said, citing students open enrolling for Eau Claire schools.\n\nBut increased whooping cough cases aren\u2019t limited to this region. Durch said the state\u2019s reported cases of whooping coughs have been at their highest levels since 2004.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] New York (Suffolk county)\nDate: Fri 9 Mar 2012\nSource: Commack Patch [edited]\nhttp://commack.patch.com/articles/commack-district-reports-fifth-whooping-cough-case\n\n\nA 5th person within the Commack School District has been diagnosed with pertussis, also known as whooping cough, superintendent Donald James confirmed in a statement on the district website. The individual is from Indian Hollow Primary, and will return to school once they are treated, James said. In Feb 2012, it was announced an individual at Burr Intermediate had been diagnosed.\n\nIn January, a person from Sawmill Intermediate was diagnosed with the disease. The 1st case was confirmed at Commack High School in December. Though only 5 cases have been confirmed so far, James noted the disease is highly contagious and may spread.\n\n\"Pertussis is highly contagious. Therefore, it is possible that subsequent cases will be diagnosed,\" James said.\n\n[byline: Kaitlyn Piccoli]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Washington (Clark county)\nDate: Fri 9 Mar 2012\nSource: KBND [edited]\nhttp://www.kbnd.com/page.php?page_id=60248&article_id=11966\n\n\nHealth officials say pertussis, also known as whooping cough, has become widespread in Clark County, Washington. Officials say 18 cases have been recorded throughout the county since January 2012, but there could be quite a few more cases that haven't been reported. The County Public Health Department says at least 5 school districts have confirmed cases of whooping cough. The Health Department recommends vaccinations as one of the best ways to avoid contracting pertussis.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA continue to expand in efforts of continue to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these recommendations.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical \"whoop\" after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem but other issues may be at work.\n\nFrom the moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post Pertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573:\n\n\"Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and adults are generally attributed to waning immunity without considering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. As pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which show that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in the _B. pertussis_ population. Most recently, we have shown that more virulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly) responsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. The P3 strains have emerged worldwide. Any discussion on the causes of sudden upsurges in infectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen population. This is even true for pertussis.\n\nReference\n---------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al. _Bordetella pertussis_ strains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis resurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009 Aug; 15(8): 1206-13. The full paper is available at http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/8/1206.htm.\" - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA 20120229.1055492\n2011\n---\nPertussis - Chile: increased morbidity & mortality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1090350", "date": "2012-03-10 19:39:50", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (02)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Illinois (McHenry county)\nDate: Wed 7 Mar 2012\nSource: WLS-TV [edited]\nhttp://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?section=news/local/illinois&id=8572713\n\n\n313 cases of whooping cough have been confirmed in McHenry County since an outbreak began in August 2011. Health officials say 156 cases involved children aged 10 and younger.\n\nA pair of 2 month old infants were hospitalized but have recovered.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Wisconsin (Chippewa county)\nDate: Sat 10 Mar 2012\nSource: Chippewa Herald [edited]\nhttp://chippewa.com/news/local/whooping-cough-confirmed-at-southview/article_ce7f8cbc-6a61-11e1-9be9-0019bb2963f4.html\n\n\nA student at Southview Elementary is the county\u2019s latest confirmed case of whooping cough. The Chippewa County Department of Public Health confirmed to school district parents and employees on Wednesday, 7 Mar 2012, that the student was infected with the pertussis bacterium, more commonly known as whooping cough.\n\nNeither school district staff nor county public health director Jean Durch would disclose the age or grade level of the infected student, citing the confidentiality of a single case. Durch said this is the 5th case of whooping cough the county has recorded since the beginning of 2012.\n\n\"A majority of those cases have links to Eau Claire,\" Durch said, citing students open enrolling for Eau Claire schools.\n\nBut increased whooping cough cases aren\u2019t limited to this region. Durch said the state\u2019s reported cases of whooping coughs have been at their highest levels since 2004.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] New York (Suffolk county)\nDate: Fri 9 Mar 2012\nSource: Commack Patch [edited]\nhttp://commack.patch.com/articles/commack-district-reports-fifth-whooping-cough-case\n\n\nA 5th person within the Commack School District has been diagnosed with pertussis, also known as whooping cough, superintendent Donald James confirmed in a statement on the district website. The individual is from Indian Hollow Primary, and will return to school once they are treated, James said. In Feb 2012, it was announced an individual at Burr Intermediate had been diagnosed.\n\nIn January, a person from Sawmill Intermediate was diagnosed with the disease. The 1st case was confirmed at Commack High School in December. Though only 5 cases have been confirmed so far, James noted the disease is highly contagious and may spread.\n\n\"Pertussis is highly contagious. Therefore, it is possible that subsequent cases will be diagnosed,\" James said.\n\n[byline: Kaitlyn Piccoli]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Washington (Clark county)\nDate: Fri 9 Mar 2012\nSource: KBND [edited]\nhttp://www.kbnd.com/page.php?page_id=60248&article_id=11966\n\n\nHealth officials say pertussis, also known as whooping cough, has become widespread in Clark County, Washington. Officials say 18 cases have been recorded throughout the county since January 2012, but there could be quite a few more cases that haven't been reported. The County Public Health Department says at least 5 school districts have confirmed cases of whooping cough. The Health Department recommends vaccinations as one of the best ways to avoid contracting pertussis.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA continue to expand in efforts of continue to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these recommendations.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical \"whoop\" after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem but other issues may be at work.\n\nFrom the moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post Pertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573:\n\n\"Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and adults are generally attributed to waning immunity without considering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. As pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which show that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in the _B. pertussis_ population. Most recently, we have shown that more virulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly) responsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. The P3 strains have emerged worldwide. Any discussion on the causes of sudden upsurges in infectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen population. This is even true for pertussis.\n\nReference\n---------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al. _Bordetella pertussis_ strains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis resurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009 Aug; 15(8): 1206-13.
