USA (MA) 20061102.3137\n.................................................sb/ll/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McHenry County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1076102", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1076102", "date": "2012-03-10 19:39:50", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (02)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Illinois (McHenry county)\nDate: Wed 7 Mar 2012\nSource: WLS-TV [edited]\nhttp://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?section=news/local/illinois&id=8572713\n\n\n313 cases of whooping cough have been confirmed in McHenry County since an outbreak began in August 2011. Health officials say 156 cases involved children aged 10 and younger.\n\nA pair of 2 month old infants were hospitalized but have recovered.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Wisconsin (Chippewa county)\nDate: Sat 10 Mar 2012\nSource: Chippewa Herald [edited]\nhttp://chippewa.com/news/local/whooping-cough-confirmed-at-southview/article_ce7f8cbc-6a61-11e1-9be9-0019bb2963f4.html\n\n\nA student at Southview Elementary is the county\u2019s latest confirmed case of whooping cough. The Chippewa County Department of Public Health confirmed to school district parents and employees on Wednesday, 7 Mar 2012, that the student was infected with the pertussis bacterium, more commonly known as whooping cough.\n\nNeither school district staff nor county public health director Jean Durch would disclose the age or grade level of the infected student, citing the confidentiality of a single case. Durch said this is the 5th case of whooping cough the county has recorded since the beginning of 2012.\n\n\"A majority of those cases have links to Eau Claire,\" Durch said, citing students open enrolling for Eau Claire schools.\n\nBut increased whooping cough cases aren\u2019t limited to this region. Durch said the state\u2019s reported cases of whooping coughs have been at their highest levels since 2004.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] New York (Suffolk county)\nDate: Fri 9 Mar 2012\nSource: Commack Patch [edited]\nhttp://commack.patch.com/articles/commack-district-reports-fifth-whooping-cough-case\n\n\nA 5th person within the Commack School District has been diagnosed with pertussis, also known as whooping cough, superintendent Donald James confirmed in a statement on the district website. The individual is from Indian Hollow Primary, and will return to school once they are treated, James said. In Feb 2012, it was announced an individual at Burr Intermediate had been diagnosed.\n\nIn January, a person from Sawmill Intermediate was diagnosed with the disease. The 1st case was confirmed at Commack High School in December. Though only 5 cases have been confirmed so far, James noted the disease is highly contagious and may spread.\n\n\"Pertussis is highly contagious. Therefore, it is possible that subsequent cases will be diagnosed,\" James said.\n\n[byline: Kaitlyn Piccoli]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Washington (Clark county)\nDate: Fri 9 Mar 2012\nSource: KBND [edited]\nhttp://www.kbnd.com/page.php?page_id=60248&article_id=11966\n\n\nHealth officials say pertussis, also known as whooping cough, has become widespread in Clark County, Washington. Officials say 18 cases have been recorded throughout the county since January 2012, but there could be quite a few more cases that haven't been reported. The County Public Health Department says at least 5 school districts have confirmed cases of whooping cough. The Health Department recommends vaccinations as one of the best ways to avoid contracting pertussis.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA continue to expand in efforts of continue to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these recommendations.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical \"whoop\" after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem but other issues may be at work.\n\nFrom the moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post Pertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573:\n\n\"Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and adults are generally attributed to waning immunity without considering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. As pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which show that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in the _B. pertussis_ population. Most recently, we have shown that more virulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly) responsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. The P3 strains have emerged worldwide. Any discussion on the causes of sudden upsurges in infectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen population. This is even true for pertussis.\n\nReference\n---------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al. _Bordetella pertussis_ strains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis resurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009 Aug; 15(8): 1206-13. The full paper is available at http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/8/1206.htm.\" - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA 20120229.1055492\n2011\n---\nPertussis - USA 20111029.3221\n2010\n---\nPertussis - USA 20100827.3037\nPertussis - USA (03) 20100725.2493\nPertussis - USA (02) 20100722.2458\nPertussis, fatal - USA: (CA) 20100626.2130\nPertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573\n2009\n---\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2008\n---\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n---\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - The Chippewa County Department of Public Health confirmed to school district parents and employees on Wednesday, 7 Mar 2012, that the student was infected with the pertussis bacterium, more commonly known as whooping cough.\n\nNeither school district staff nor county public health director Jean Durch would disclose the age or grade level of the infected student, citing the confidentiality of a single case. Durch said this is the 5th case of whooping cough the county has recorded since the beginning of 2012.\n\n\"A majority of those cases have links to Eau Claire,\" Durch said, citing students open enrolling for Eau Claire schools.\n\nBut increased whooping cough cases aren\u2019t limited to this region. In Feb 2012, it was announced an individual at Burr Intermediate had been diagnosed.\n\nIn January, a person from Sawmill Intermediate was diagnosed with the disease. Officials say 18 cases have been recorded throughout the county since January 2012, but there could be quite a few more cases that haven't been reported. The Health Department recommends vaccinations as one of the best ways to avoid contracting pertussis.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA continue to expand in efforts of continue to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem but other issues may be at work.\n\nFrom the moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post Pertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573:\n\n\"Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and adults are generally attributed to waning immunity without considering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. Any discussion on the causes of sudden upsurges in infectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen population. This is even true for pertussis.\n\nReference\n---------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al. _Bordetella pertussis_ strains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis resurgence. USA (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1066817", "date": "2012-03-10 19:39:50", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (02)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Illinois (McHenry county)\nDate: Wed 7 Mar 2012\nSource: WLS-TV [edited]\nhttp://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?section=news/local/illinois&id=8572713\n\n\n313 cases of whooping cough have been confirmed in McHenry County since an outbreak began in August 2011. Health officials say 156 cases involved children aged 10 and younger.\n\nA pair of 2 month old infants were hospitalized but have recovered.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Wisconsin (Chippewa county)\nDate: Sat 10 Mar 2012\nSource: Chippewa Herald [edited]\nhttp://chippewa.com/news/local/whooping-cough-confirmed-at-southview/article_ce7f8cbc-6a61-11e1-9be9-0019bb2963f4.html\n\n\nA student at Southview Elementary is the county\u2019s latest confirmed case of whooping cough. The Chippewa County Department of Public Health confirmed to school district parents and employees on Wednesday, 7 Mar 2012, that the student was infected with the pertussis bacterium, more commonly known as whooping cough.\n\nNeither school district staff nor county public health director Jean Durch would disclose the age or grade level of the infected student, citing the confidentiality of a single case. Durch said this is the 5th case of whooping cough the county has recorded since the beginning of 2012.\n\n\"A majority of those cases have links to Eau Claire,\" Durch said, citing students open enrolling for Eau Claire schools.\n\nBut increased whooping cough cases aren\u2019t limited to this region. Durch said the state\u2019s reported cases of whooping coughs have been at their highest levels since 2004.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] New York (Suffolk county)\nDate: Fri 9 Mar 2012\nSource: Commack Patch [edited]\nhttp://commack.patch.com/articles/commack-district-reports-fifth-whooping-cough-case\n\n\nA 5th person within the Commack School District has been diagnosed with pertussis, also known as whooping cough, superintendent Donald James confirmed in a statement on the district website. The individual is from Indian Hollow Primary, and will return to school once they are treated, James said. In Feb 2012, it was announced an individual at Burr Intermediate had been diagnosed.\n\nIn January, a person from Sawmill Intermediate was diagnosed with the disease. The 1st case was confirmed at Commack High School in December. Though only 5 cases have been confirmed so far, James noted the disease is highly contagious and may spread.\n\n\"Pertussis is highly contagious. Therefore, it is possible that subsequent cases will be diagnosed,\" James said.\n\n[byline: Kaitlyn Piccoli]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Washington (Clark county)\nDate: Fri 9 Mar 2012\nSource: KBND [edited]\nhttp://www.kbnd.com/page.php?page_id=60248&article_id=11966\n\n\nHealth officials say pertussis, also known as whooping cough, has become widespread in Clark County, Washington. Officials say 18 cases have been recorded throughout the county since January 2012, but there could be quite a few more cases that haven't been reported. The County Public Health Department says at least 5 school districts have confirmed cases of whooping cough. The Health Department recommends vaccinations as one of the best ways to avoid contracting pertussis.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Recommendations on the use of acellular pertussis vaccines in the USA continue to expand in efforts of continue to cocoon susceptible neonates to prevent the substantial morbidity and mortality in infants who have not been yet adequately immunized. The use of the vaccine in pregnant women further expands these recommendations.\n\nThe increasing susceptibility in older children and adults to pertussis usually manifesting as chronic cough without the typical \"whoop\" after appropriate primary immunization continues to be increasingly reported. Waning immunity is generally thought to be the cause of the problem but other issues may be at work.\n\nFrom the moderator LL's comments in a prior ProMED post Pertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573:\n\n\"Cases of pertussis in previously vaccinated older children and adults are generally attributed to waning immunity without considering potential differences in _Bordetella pertussis_ strains. As pointed out in 2009 by Dr Frits Mooi (ProMED-mail Pertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876): There are now many studies which show that outbreaks of pertussis are often associated with changes in the _B. pertussis_ population. Most recently, we have shown that more virulent (P3) strains have appeared which we believe to be (partly) responsible for the outbreak in the Netherlands. The P3 strains have emerged worldwide. Any discussion on the causes of sudden upsurges in infectious diseases should include changes in the pathogen population. This is even true for pertussis.\n\nReference\n---------\nMooi FR, van Loo IHM, van Gent M, et al. _Bordetella pertussis_ strains with increased toxin production associated with pertussis resurgence. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009 Aug; 15(8): 1206-13. The full paper is available at http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/8/1206.htm.\" - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA 20120229.1055492\n2011\n---\nPertussis - USA 20111029.3221\n2010\n---\nPertussis - USA 20100827.3037\nPertussis - USA (03) 20100725.2493\nPertussis - USA (02) 20100722.2458\nPertussis, fatal - USA: (CA) 20100626.2130\nPertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573\n2009\n---\nPertussis - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\n.................................................sb/ll/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McHenry County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clark county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1055492", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1055492", "date": "2010-08-27 16:00:05", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (04)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington state\n[2] Pennsylvania\n[3] Michigan\n[4] California\n[5] Missouri\n\n*****\n[1] Washington state\nDate: Thu 26 Aug 2010\nSource: The Wenatchee World [edited]\n<http://www.wenatcheeworld.com/news/2010/aug/26/grant-county-baby-dies-from-whooping-cough/>\n\n\nA Grant County baby has died from whooping cough [pertussis] and\nanother is recovering from the highly contagious bacterial disease,\nGrant County health officials say.\n\nThe infant died Tuesday night, 24 Aug 2010, at Children's Hospital\nand Medical Center in Seattle, Washington, according to Theresa\nFuller, public information officer for the Grant County Health\nDistrict. The other child is recovering at home. There appears to be\nno connection between the cases, she said.\n\nHealth officials are working with health-care providers of children\nand adults who may have been exposed to the sick children, Fuller\nsaid. In some cases, those people may need antibiotics.\n\nAccording to the CDC, 8000 to 25 000 cases of pertussis, are reported\neach year in the USA.\n\nDuring the last decade, pertussis has re-emerged as one of the most\npressing public health issues due to increasing numbers of cases and\nlower vaccination rates, Fuller said.\n\nRecently, multiple outbreaks of pertussis have been investigated in\nthe USA, including cases in California and Idaho, said Jeff Ketchel,\nhealth district administrator. From 2005 to 2009, Washington state\nhad 2636 cases of whooping cough. During this same time period, Grant\nCounty had 17 cases.\n\nAbout 1 in 20 infants with pertussis get pneumonia, said Dr Alexander\nBrzezny, Grant County health officer. About 1 in 100 infants will\nhave convulsions. In rare cases, pertussis can be deadly, especially\nin infants under 1 year old. Nearly all infants with pertussis get\nthe infection from an infected adult.\n\n[Byline: Dee Riggs]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County can be seen on the map of Washington state at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania\nDate: Wed 25 Aug 2010\nSource: VaccineNewsDaily.com, Philly.com report [edited]\n<http://vaccinenewsdaily.com/news/214853-philadelphia-whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise>\n\n\nA rise in reported cases of pertussis in causing concern in the\ngreater Philadelphia area, health officials say. The suburban\ncounties of southeastern Pennsylvania have witnessed increased\noccurrences of the infection, which can be fatal in infants,\nPhilly.com reports. Delaware County saw the largest increase in\ncases, jumping from 5 cases to 44 within a 3 month period.\n\nThe 2nd highest increase in whooping cough cases was in Montgomery\nCounty, Philly.com reports, where 39 new cases were tallied between\nApril and June 2010, compared to 8 new cases in the 3 months preceding.\n\n[Byline: Malik Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The counties mentioned can be seen on the map of Pennsylvania at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/pennsylvania.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Michigan\nDate: Tue 24 Aug 2010\nSource: Gaylord Herald Times [edited]\n<http://www.gaylordheraldtimes.com/articles/2010/08/24/news/local_news/doc4c740c3a8f597802151863.txt>\n\n\nAccording to a report from Dr Joshua Meyerson, the medical director\nof the Health Department of Northwest Michigan, 25 cases of pertussis\nhave been discovered in the 4 counties, Antrim, Charlevoix, Emmet,\nand Otsego, served by Northwest. The outbreak is 5 times the typical\nnumber. There have been cases so far in Otsego County in 2010, a\nchild and an adult.\n\nMeyerson states that 10-15 percent of children have not been\nvaccinated. \"In some ways these vaccinations are victims of the\ninitial success of the vaccine,\" said Jane Sundmacher, public\ninformation officer of Northwest. \"Before the vaccine was introduced\nin the 1940s, pertussis was the major cause of serious illness and\ndeath in infants and young children.\"\n\nThe alarm being sounded about the outbreak is particularly important\nin Michigan. California and Michigan lead the country in the\npercentage of children not vaccinated. California has suffered 10\ndeaths and Michigan one.\n\n\"Be really careful about who's around an infant,\" Sundmacher said. \"A\nreally common report we hear is that an adult has a cough, but\ndoesn't feel that sick, and ends up passing pertussis on to a baby or\nyoung child. Even if an infant has started the series of shots\nusually given at 2, 4, and 6 months, if they haven't completed the\nseries, their parents and anyone else who cares for them should get\nimmunized. Booster shots are available for ages 7 to 64.\"\n\nWendy Phillips, public information officer of Northeast Health\nDepartment, reports there have been no identified cases of pertussis\nin 2010 in Montmorency County. There are, however, 2 cases in both\nAlpena and Cheboygan, and the 2 in Otsego suggests it's only a matter\nof time before it spreads to Montmorency.\n\n[Byline: Lorene Parshall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The counties mentioned can be seen on the map of Michigan at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/michigan.shtml>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] California\nDate: Mon 16 Aug 2010\nSource: The Bakersfield Californian, Kern County Department of Public\nHealth Services (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.bakersfield.com/news/local/x1415296021/Number-of-whooping-cough-cases-up-to-227>\n\n\nAn additional 17 cases of whooping cough were reported last week\n[week of 9 Aug 2010] in Kern County, bringing the total to 227 for\n2010, according to the Kern County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe monthly rate of cases of whooping cough, also known as pertussis,\nin Kern County has been going up and up in 2010, though no deaths\nhave been reported. The weekly rate has, since 23 May 2010, ranged\nfrom 5 between 30 May and 5 Jun 2010 to 33 between 27 Jun and 3 Jul\n2010, according to Public Health. Of the 227 Kern cases, 182 were\nreported in Bakersfield.\n\nThe reason for the uptick is unclear but it's happening across the\nstate so health officials are just trying to get the word out about\nthe need for vaccination, said Denise Smith, Public Health's\nassistant director of disease control.\n\nOfficials have said the incidence of whooping cough is cyclical. In\nKern there were 6 reported cases in all of 2009 and 8 in 2008,\naccording to Public Health.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kern County can be seen on the map of California at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] Missouri\nDate: Sun 22 Aug 2010\nSource: St Louis Today [edited]\n<http://www.stltoday.com/news/national/article_fd578e9f-0af5-55f9-85b1-4ee13e39a699.html>\n\n\nMissouri has reported 82 confirmed cases of pertussis in the last\nmonth. One-quarter of those involved infants under a year old.\n\nNo one knows exactly why this is happening. In the 1920s and '30s,\npertussis was a feared childhood killer, with an annual toll as high\nas 250 000 cases and 9000 deaths, according to the CDC. In the 1940s,\nhealth authorities introduced a combined vaccine against diphtheria,\npertussis, and tetanus (often called DPT or DTaP), and by 1976\npertussis was virtually eliminated, with just 1010 reported cases.\n\nRecent research has shown that the protection provided by the vaccine\nwears off over time, Aaron Miller wrote in an article posted on St.\nLouis Children's Hospital's website. Miller, a pediatrician at the\nhospital and an instructor of pediatrics at Washington University\nSchool of Medicine, added that the CDC now recommends that all\nchildren receive a booster shot at 11 or 12 and that adults receive\nthe same booster.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Missouri can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the US at <http://healthmap.org/r/03UJ>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (03) 20100725.2493\nPertussis - USA (02) 20100722.2458\nPertussis, fatal - USA: (CA) 20100626.2130\nPertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2008\n----\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n----\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n----\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\n...................................sb/ll/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Canada: (BC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1055490", "date": "2010-08-27 16:00:05", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (04)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington state\n[2] Pennsylvania\n[3] Michigan\n[4] California\n[5] Missouri\n\n*****\n[1] Washington state\nDate: Thu 26 Aug 2010\nSource: The Wenatchee World [edited]\n<http://www.wenatcheeworld.com/news/2010/aug/26/grant-county-baby-dies-from-whooping-cough/>\n\n\nA Grant County baby has died from whooping cough [pertussis] and\nanother is recovering from the highly contagious bacterial disease,\nGrant County health officials say.\n\nThe infant died Tuesday night, 24 Aug 2010, at Children's Hospital\nand Medical Center in Seattle, Washington, according to Theresa\nFuller, public information officer for the Grant County Health\nDistrict. The other child is recovering at home. There appears to be\nno connection between the cases, she said.\n\nHealth officials are working with health-care providers of children\nand adults who may have been exposed to the sick children, Fuller\nsaid. In some cases, those people may need antibiotics.\n\nAccording to the CDC, 8000 to 25 000 cases of pertussis, are reported\neach year in the USA.\n\nDuring the last decade, pertussis has re-emerged as one of the most\npressing public health issues due to increasing numbers of cases and\nlower vaccination rates, Fuller said.\n\nRecently, multiple outbreaks of pertussis have been investigated in\nthe USA, including cases in California and Idaho, said Jeff Ketchel,\nhealth district administrator. From 2005 to 2009, Washington state\nhad 2636 cases of whooping cough. During this same time period, Grant\nCounty had 17 cases.\n\nAbout 1 in 20 infants with pertussis get pneumonia, said Dr Alexander\nBrzezny, Grant County health officer. About 1 in 100 infants will\nhave convulsions. In rare cases, pertussis can be deadly, especially\nin infants under 1 year old. Nearly all infants with pertussis get\nthe infection from an infected adult.\n\n[Byline: Dee Riggs]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County can be seen on the map of Washington state at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania\nDate: Wed 25 Aug 2010\nSource: VaccineNewsDaily.com, Philly.com report [edited]\n<http://vaccinenewsdaily.com/news/214853-philadelphia-whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise>\n\n\nA rise in reported cases of pertussis in causing concern in the\ngreater Philadelphia area, health officials say. The suburban\ncounties of southeastern Pennsylvania have witnessed increased\noccurrences of the infection, which can be fatal in infants,\nPhilly.com reports. Delaware County saw the largest increase in\ncases, jumping from 5 cases to 44 within a 3 month period.\n\nThe 2nd highest increase in whooping cough cases was in Montgomery\nCounty, Philly.com reports, where 39 new cases were tallied between\nApril and June 2010, compared to 8 new cases in the 3 months preceding.\n\n[Byline: Malik Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The counties mentioned can be seen on the map of Pennsylvania at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/pennsylvania.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Michigan\nDate: Tue 24 Aug 2010\nSource: Gaylord Herald Times [edited]\n<http://www.gaylordheraldtimes.com/articles/2010/08/24/news/local_news/doc4c740c3a8f597802151863.txt>\n\n\nAccording to a report from Dr Joshua Meyerson, the medical director\nof the Health Department of Northwest Michigan, 25 cases of pertussis\nhave been discovered in the 4 counties, Antrim, Charlevoix, Emmet,\nand Otsego, served by Northwest. The outbreak is 5 times the typical\nnumber. There have been cases so far in Otsego County in 2010, a\nchild and an adult.\n\nMeyerson states that 10-15 percent of children have not been\nvaccinated. \"In some ways these vaccinations are victims of the\ninitial success of the vaccine,\" said Jane Sundmacher, public\ninformation officer of Northwest. \"Before the vaccine was introduced\nin the 1940s, pertussis was the major cause of serious illness and\ndeath in infants and young children.\"\n\nThe alarm being sounded about the outbreak is particularly important\nin Michigan. California and Michigan lead the country in the\npercentage of children not vaccinated. California has suffered 10\ndeaths and Michigan one.\n\n\"Be really careful about who's around an infant,\" Sundmacher said. \"A\nreally common report we hear is that an adult has a cough, but\ndoesn't feel that sick, and ends up passing pertussis on to a baby or\nyoung child. Even if an infant has started the series of shots\nusually given at 2, 4, and 6 months, if they haven't completed the\nseries, their parents and anyone else who cares for them should get\nimmunized. Booster shots are available for ages 7 to 64.\"\n\nWendy Phillips, public information officer of Northeast Health\nDepartment, reports there have been no identified cases of pertussis\nin 2010 in Montmorency County. There are, however, 2 cases in both\nAlpena and Cheboygan, and the 2 in Otsego suggests it's only a matter\nof time before it spreads to Montmorency.\n\n[Byline: Lorene Parshall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The counties mentioned can be seen on the map of Michigan at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/michigan.shtml>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] California\nDate: Mon 16 Aug 2010\nSource: The Bakersfield Californian, Kern County Department of Public\nHealth Services (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.bakersfield.com/news/local/x1415296021/Number-of-whooping-cough-cases-up-to-227>\n\n\nAn additional 17 cases of whooping cough were reported last week\n[week of 9 Aug 2010] in Kern County, bringing the total to 227 for\n2010, according to the Kern County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe monthly rate of cases of whooping cough, also known as pertussis,\nin Kern County has been going up and up in 2010, though no deaths\nhave been reported. The weekly rate has, since 23 May 2010, ranged\nfrom 5 between 30 May and 5 Jun 2010 to 33 between 27 Jun and 3 Jul\n2010, according to Public Health. Of the 227 Kern cases, 182 were\nreported in Bakersfield.\n\nThe reason for the uptick is unclear but it's happening across the\nstate so health officials are just trying to get the word out about\nthe need for vaccination, said Denise Smith, Public Health's\nassistant director of disease control.\n\nOfficials have said the incidence of whooping cough is cyclical. In\nKern there were 6 reported cases in all of 2009 and 8 in 2008,\naccording to Public Health.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kern County can be seen on the map of California at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] Missouri\nDate: Sun 22 Aug 2010\nSource: St Louis Today [edited]\n<http://www.stltoday.com/news/national/article_fd578e9f-0af5-55f9-85b1-4ee13e39a699.html>\n\n\nMissouri has reported 82 confirmed cases of pertussis in the last\nmonth. One-quarter of those involved infants under a year old.\n\nNo one knows exactly why this is happening. In the 1920s and '30s,\npertussis was a feared childhood killer, with an annual toll as high\nas 250 000 cases and 9000 deaths, according to the CDC. In the 1940s,\nhealth authorities introduced a combined vaccine against diphtheria,\npertussis, and tetanus (often called DPT or DTaP), and by 1976\npertussis was virtually eliminated, with just 1010 reported cases.\n\nRecent research has shown that the protection provided by the vaccine\nwears off over time, Aaron Miller wrote in an article posted on St.\nLouis Children's Hospital's website. Miller, a pediatrician at the\nhospital and an instructor of pediatrics at Washington University\nSchool of Medicine, added that the CDC now recommends that all\nchildren receive a booster shot at 11 or 12 and that adults receive\nthe same booster.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Missouri can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the US at <http://healthmap.org/r/03UJ>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (03) 20100725.2493\nPertussis - USA (02) 20100722.2458\nPertussis, fatal - USA: (CA) 20100626.2130\nPertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2008\n----\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n----\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n----\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\n...................................sb/ll/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-08-24 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2636-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-05-23 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:30", "1976-03-16 00:00:00", "1010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Otsego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montmorency County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brzezny", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Theresa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kern County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bakersfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1007036", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia: (WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1007036", "date": "2010-08-27 16:00:05", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (04)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington state\n[2] Pennsylvania\n[3] Michigan\n[4] California\n[5] Missouri\n\n*****\n[1] Washington state\nDate: Thu 26 Aug 2010\nSource: The Wenatchee World [edited]\n<http://www.wenatcheeworld.com/news/2010/aug/26/grant-county-baby-dies-from-whooping-cough/>\n\n\nA Grant County baby has died from whooping cough [pertussis] and\nanother is recovering from the highly contagious bacterial disease,\nGrant County health officials say.\n\nThe infant died Tuesday night, 24 Aug 2010, at Children's Hospital\nand Medical Center in Seattle, Washington, according to Theresa\nFuller, public information officer for the Grant County Health\nDistrict. The other child is recovering at home. There appears to be\nno connection between the cases, she said.\n\nHealth officials are working with health-care providers of children\nand adults who may have been exposed to the sick children, Fuller\nsaid. In some cases, those people may need antibiotics.\n\nAccording to the CDC, 8000 to 25 000 cases of pertussis, are reported\neach year in the USA.\n\nDuring the last decade, pertussis has re-emerged as one of the most\npressing public health issues due to increasing numbers of cases and\nlower vaccination rates, Fuller said.\n\nRecently, multiple outbreaks of pertussis have been investigated in\nthe USA, including cases in California and Idaho, said Jeff Ketchel,\nhealth district administrator. From 2005 to 2009, Washington state\nhad 2636 cases of whooping cough. During this same time period, Grant\nCounty had 17 cases.\n\nAbout 1 in 20 infants with pertussis get pneumonia, said Dr Alexander\nBrzezny, Grant County health officer. About 1 in 100 infants will\nhave convulsions. In rare cases, pertussis can be deadly, especially\nin infants under 1 year old. Nearly all infants with pertussis get\nthe infection from an infected adult.\n\n[Byline: Dee Riggs]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County can be seen on the map of Washington state at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania\nDate: Wed 25 Aug 2010\nSource: VaccineNewsDaily.com, Philly.com report [edited]\n<http://vaccinenewsdaily.com/news/214853-philadelphia-whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise>\n\n\nA rise in reported cases of pertussis in causing concern in the\ngreater Philadelphia area, health officials say. The suburban\ncounties of southeastern Pennsylvania have witnessed increased\noccurrences of the infection, which can be fatal in infants,\nPhilly.com reports. Delaware County saw the largest increase in\ncases, jumping from 5 cases to 44 within a 3 month period.\n\nThe 2nd highest increase in whooping cough cases was in Montgomery\nCounty, Philly.com reports, where 39 new cases were tallied between\nApril and June 2010, compared to 8 new cases in the 3 months preceding.\n\n[Byline: Malik Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The counties mentioned can be seen on the map of Pennsylvania at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/pennsylvania.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Michigan\nDate: Tue 24 Aug 2010\nSource: Gaylord Herald Times [edited]\n<http://www.gaylordheraldtimes.com/articles/2010/08/24/news/local_news/doc4c740c3a8f597802151863.txt>\n\n\nAccording to a report from Dr Joshua Meyerson, the medical director\nof the Health Department of Northwest Michigan, 25 cases of pertussis\nhave been discovered in the 4 counties, Antrim, Charlevoix, Emmet,\nand Otsego, served by Northwest. The outbreak is 5 times the typical\nnumber. There have been cases so far in Otsego County in 2010, a\nchild and an adult.\n\nMeyerson states that 10-15 percent of children have not been\nvaccinated. \"In some ways these vaccinations are victims of the\ninitial success of the vaccine,\" said Jane Sundmacher, public\ninformation officer of Northwest. \"Before the vaccine was introduced\nin the 1940s, pertussis was the major cause of serious illness and\ndeath in infants and young children.\"\n\nThe alarm being sounded about the outbreak is particularly important\nin Michigan. California and Michigan lead the country in the\npercentage of children not vaccinated. California has suffered 10\ndeaths and Michigan one.\n\n\"Be really careful about who's around an infant,\" Sundmacher said. \"A\nreally common report we hear is that an adult has a cough, but\ndoesn't feel that sick, and ends up passing pertussis on to a baby or\nyoung child. Even if an infant has started the series of shots\nusually given at 2, 4, and 6 months, if they haven't completed the\nseries, their parents and anyone else who cares for them should get\nimmunized. Booster shots are available for ages 7 to 64.\"\n\nWendy Phillips, public information officer of Northeast Health\nDepartment, reports there have been no identified cases of pertussis\nin 2010 in Montmorency County. There are, however, 2 cases in both\nAlpena and Cheboygan, and the 2 in Otsego suggests it's only a matter\nof time before it spreads to Montmorency.\n\n[Byline: Lorene Parshall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The counties mentioned can be seen on the map of Michigan at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/michigan.shtml>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] California\nDate: Mon 16 Aug 2010\nSource: The Bakersfield Californian, Kern County Department of Public\nHealth Services (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.bakersfield.com/news/local/x1415296021/Number-of-whooping-cough-cases-up-to-227>\n\n\nAn additional 17 cases of whooping cough were reported last week\n[week of 9 Aug 2010] in Kern County, bringing the total to 227 for\n2010, according to the Kern County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe monthly rate of cases of whooping cough, also known as pertussis,\nin Kern County has been going up and up in 2010, though no deaths\nhave been reported. The weekly rate has, since 23 May 2010, ranged\nfrom 5 between 30 May and 5 Jun 2010 to 33 between 27 Jun and 3 Jul\n2010, according to Public Health. Of the 227 Kern cases, 182 were\nreported in Bakersfield.\n\nThe reason for the uptick is unclear but it's happening across the\nstate so health officials are just trying to get the word out about\nthe need for vaccination, said Denise Smith, Public Health's\nassistant director of disease control.\n\nOfficials have said the incidence of whooping cough is cyclical. In\nKern there were 6 reported cases in all of 2009 and 8 in 2008,\naccording to Public Health.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kern County can be seen on the map of California at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] Missouri\nDate: Sun 22 Aug 2010\nSource: St Louis Today [edited]\n<http://www.stltoday.com/news/national/article_fd578e9f-0af5-55f9-85b1-4ee13e39a699.html>\n\n\nMissouri has reported 82 confirmed cases of pertussis in the last\nmonth. One-quarter of those involved infants under a year old.\n\nNo one knows exactly why this is happening. In the 1920s and '30s,\npertussis was a feared childhood killer, with an annual toll as high\nas 250 000 cases and 9000 deaths, according to the CDC. In the 1940s,\nhealth authorities introduced a combined vaccine against diphtheria,\npertussis, and tetanus (often called DPT or DTaP), and by 1976\npertussis was virtually eliminated, with just 1010 reported cases.\n\nRecent research has shown that the protection provided by the vaccine\nwears off over time, Aaron Miller wrote in an article posted on St.\nLouis Children's Hospital's website. Miller, a pediatrician at the\nhospital and an instructor of pediatrics at Washington University\nSchool of Medicine, added that the CDC now recommends that all\nchildren receive a booster shot at 11 or 12 and that adults receive\nthe same booster.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Missouri can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the US at <http://healthmap.org/r/03UJ>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (03) 20100725.2493\nPertussis - USA (02) 20100722.2458\nPertussis, fatal - USA: (CA) 20100626.2130\nPertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2008\n----\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n----\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n----\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\n...................................sb/ll/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. One-quarter of those involved infants under a year old.\n\nNo one knows exactly why this is happening. In the 1920s and '30s,\npertussis was a feared childhood killer, with an annual toll as high\nas 250 000 cases and 9000 deaths, according to the CDC. In the 1940s,\nhealth authorities introduced a combined vaccine against diphtheria,\npertussis, and tetanus (often called DPT or DTaP), and by 1976\npertussis was virtually eliminated, with just 1010 reported cases.\n\nRecent research has shown that the protection provided by the vaccine\nwears off over time, Aaron Miller wrote in an article posted on St.\nLouis Children's Hospital's website. Miller, a pediatrician at the\nhospital and an instructor of pediatrics at Washington University\nSchool of Medicine, added that the CDC now recommends that all\nchildren receive a booster shot at 11 or 12 and that adults receive\nthe same booster.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Missouri can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the US at <http://healthmap.org/r/03UJ>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (03) 20100725.2493\nPertussis - USA (02) 20100722.2458\nPertussis, fatal - USA: (CA) 20100626.2130\nPertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2008\n----\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n----\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n----\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\n...................................sb/ll/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-08-24 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2636-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-05-23 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:30", "1976-03-16 00:00:00", "1010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Otsego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montmorency County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brzezny", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Theresa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kern County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bakersfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "928658", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=928658", "date": "2010-08-27 16:00:05", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (04)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington state\n[2] Pennsylvania\n[3] Michigan\n[4] California\n[5] Missouri\n\n*****\n[1] Washington state\nDate: Thu 26 Aug 2010\nSource: The Wenatchee World [edited]\n<http://www.wenatcheeworld.com/news/2010/aug/26/grant-county-baby-dies-from-whooping-cough/>\n\n\nA Grant County baby has died from whooping cough [pertussis] and\nanother is recovering from the highly contagious bacterial disease,\nGrant County health officials say.\n\nThe infant died Tuesday night, 24 Aug 2010, at Children's Hospital\nand Medical Center in Seattle, Washington, according to Theresa\nFuller, public information officer for the Grant County Health\nDistrict. The other child is recovering at home. There appears to be\nno connection between the cases, she said.\n\nHealth officials are working with health-care providers of children\nand adults who may have been exposed to the sick children, Fuller\nsaid. In some cases, those people may need antibiotics.\n\nAccording to the CDC, 8000 to 25 000 cases of pertussis, are reported\neach year in the USA.\n\nDuring the last decade, pertussis has re-emerged as one of the most\npressing public health issues due to increasing numbers of cases and\nlower vaccination rates, Fuller said.\n\nRecently, multiple outbreaks of pertussis have been investigated in\nthe USA, including cases in California and Idaho, said Jeff Ketchel,\nhealth district administrator. From 2005 to 2009, Washington state\nhad 2636 cases of whooping cough. During this same time period, Grant\nCounty had 17 cases.\n\nAbout 1 in 20 infants with pertussis get pneumonia, said Dr Alexander\nBrzezny, Grant County health officer. About 1 in 100 infants will\nhave convulsions. In rare cases, pertussis can be deadly, especially\nin infants under 1 year old. Nearly all infants with pertussis get\nthe infection from an infected adult.\n\n[Byline: Dee Riggs]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County can be seen on the map of Washington state at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania\nDate: Wed 25 Aug 2010\nSource: VaccineNewsDaily.com, Philly.com report [edited]\n<http://vaccinenewsdaily.com/news/214853-philadelphia-whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise>\n\n\nA rise in reported cases of pertussis in causing concern in the\ngreater Philadelphia area, health officials say. The suburban\ncounties of southeastern Pennsylvania have witnessed increased\noccurrences of the infection, which can be fatal in infants,\nPhilly.com reports. Delaware County saw the largest increase in\ncases, jumping from 5 cases to 44 within a 3 month period.\n\nThe 2nd highest increase in whooping cough cases was in Montgomery\nCounty, Philly.com reports, where 39 new cases were tallied between\nApril and June 2010, compared to 8 new cases in the 3 months preceding.\n\n[Byline: Malik Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The counties mentioned can be seen on the map of Pennsylvania at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/pennsylvania.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Michigan\nDate: Tue 24 Aug 2010\nSource: Gaylord Herald Times [edited]\n<http://www.gaylordheraldtimes.com/articles/2010/08/24/news/local_news/doc4c740c3a8f597802151863.txt>\n\n\nAccording to a report from Dr Joshua Meyerson, the medical director\nof the Health Department of Northwest Michigan, 25 cases of pertussis\nhave been discovered in the 4 counties, Antrim, Charlevoix, Emmet,\nand Otsego, served by Northwest. The outbreak is 5 times the typical\nnumber. There have been cases so far in Otsego County in 2010, a\nchild and an adult.\n\nMeyerson states that 10-15 percent of children have not been\nvaccinated. \"In some ways these vaccinations are victims of the\ninitial success of the vaccine,\" said Jane Sundmacher, public\ninformation officer of Northwest. \"Before the vaccine was introduced\nin the 1940s, pertussis was the major cause of serious illness and\ndeath in infants and young children.\"\n\nThe alarm being sounded about the outbreak is particularly important\nin Michigan. California and Michigan lead the country in the\npercentage of children not vaccinated. California has suffered 10\ndeaths and Michigan one.\n\n\"Be really careful about who's around an infant,\" Sundmacher said. \"A\nreally common report we hear is that an adult has a cough, but\ndoesn't feel that sick, and ends up passing pertussis on to a baby or\nyoung child. Even if an infant has started the series of shots\nusually given at 2, 4, and 6 months, if they haven't completed the\nseries, their parents and anyone else who cares for them should get\nimmunized. Booster shots are available for ages 7 to 64.\"\n\nWendy Phillips, public information officer of Northeast Health\nDepartment, reports there have been no identified cases of pertussis\nin 2010 in Montmorency County. There are, however, 2 cases in both\nAlpena and Cheboygan, and the 2 in Otsego suggests it's only a matter\nof time before it spreads to Montmorency.\n\n[Byline: Lorene Parshall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The counties mentioned can be seen on the map of Michigan at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/michigan.shtml>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] California\nDate: Mon 16 Aug 2010\nSource: The Bakersfield Californian, Kern County Department of Public\nHealth Services (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.bakersfield.com/news/local/x1415296021/Number-of-whooping-cough-cases-up-to-227>\n\n\nAn additional 17 cases of whooping cough were reported last week\n[week of 9 Aug 2010] in Kern County, bringing the total to 227 for\n2010, according to the Kern County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe monthly rate of cases of whooping cough, also known as pertussis,\nin Kern County has been going up and up in 2010, though no deaths\nhave been reported. The weekly rate has, since 23 May 2010, ranged\nfrom 5 between 30 May and 5 Jun 2010 to 33 between 27 Jun and 3 Jul\n2010, according to Public Health. Of the 227 Kern cases, 182 were\nreported in Bakersfield.\n\nThe reason for the uptick is unclear but it's happening across the\nstate so health officials are just trying to get the word out about\nthe need for vaccination, said Denise Smith, Public Health's\nassistant director of disease control.\n\nOfficials have said the incidence of whooping cough is cyclical. In\nKern there were 6 reported cases in all of 2009 and 8 in 2008,\naccording to Public Health.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kern County can be seen on the map of California at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] Missouri\nDate: Sun 22 Aug 2010\nSource: St Louis Today [edited]\n<http://www.stltoday.com/news/national/article_fd578e9f-0af5-55f9-85b1-4ee13e39a699.html>\n\n\nMissouri has reported 82 confirmed cases of pertussis in the last\nmonth. One-quarter of those involved infants under a year old.\n\nNo one knows exactly why this is happening. In the 1920s and '30s,\npertussis was a feared childhood killer, with an annual toll as high\nas 250 000 cases and 9000 deaths, according to the CDC. In the 1940s,\nhealth authorities introduced a combined vaccine against diphtheria,\npertussis, and tetanus (often called DPT or DTaP), and by 1976\npertussis was virtually eliminated, with just 1010 reported cases.\n\nRecent research has shown that the protection provided by the vaccine\nwears off over time, Aaron Miller wrote in an article posted on St.\nLouis Children's Hospital's website. Miller, a pediatrician at the\nhospital and an instructor of pediatrics at Washington University\nSchool of Medicine, added that the CDC now recommends that all\nchildren receive a booster shot at 11 or 12 and that adults receive\nthe same booster.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Missouri can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the US at <http://healthmap.org/r/03UJ>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (03) 20100725.2493\nPertussis - USA (02) 20100722.2458\nPertussis, fatal - USA: (CA) 20100626.2130\nPertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2008\n----\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n----\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n----\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\n...................................sb/ll/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. One-quarter of those involved infants under a year old.\n\nNo one knows exactly why this is happening. In the 1920s and '30s,\npertussis was a feared childhood killer, with an annual toll as high\nas 250 000 cases and 9000 deaths, according to the CDC. In the 1940s,\nhealth authorities introduced a combined vaccine against diphtheria,\npertussis, and tetanus (often called DPT or DTaP), and by 1976\npertussis was virtually eliminated, with just 1010 reported cases.\n\nRecent research has shown that the protection provided by the vaccine\nwears off over time, Aaron Miller wrote in an article posted on St.\nLouis Children's Hospital's website. Miller, a pediatrician at the\nhospital and an instructor of pediatrics at Washington University\nSchool of Medicine, added that the CDC now recommends that all\nchildren receive a booster shot at 11 or 12 and that adults receive\nthe same booster.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Missouri can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the US at <http://healthmap.org/r/03UJ>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (03) 20100725.2493\nPertussis - USA (02) 20100722.2458\nPertussis, fatal - USA: (CA) 20100626.2130\nPertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2008\n----\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n----\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n----\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\n...................................sb/ll/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-08-24 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2636-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-02-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-05-23 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:30", "1976-03-16 00:00:00", "1010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Otsego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montmorency County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brzezny", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Theresa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kern County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bakersfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "556793", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia: (QL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=556793", "date": "2010-08-27 16:00:05", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (04)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Washington state\n[2] Pennsylvania\n[3] Michigan\n[4] California\n[5] Missouri\n\n*****\n[1] Washington state\nDate: Thu 26 Aug 2010\nSource: The Wenatchee World [edited]\n<http://www.wenatcheeworld.com/news/2010/aug/26/grant-county-baby-dies-from-whooping-cough/>\n\n\nA Grant County baby has died from whooping cough [pertussis] and\nanother is recovering from the highly contagious bacterial disease,\nGrant County health officials say.\n\nThe infant died Tuesday night, 24 Aug 2010, at Children's Hospital\nand Medical Center in Seattle, Washington, according to Theresa\nFuller, public information officer for the Grant County Health\nDistrict. The other child is recovering at home. There appears to be\nno connection between the cases, she said.\n\nHealth officials are working with health-care providers of children\nand adults who may have been exposed to the sick children, Fuller\nsaid. In some cases, those people may need antibiotics.\n\nAccording to the CDC, 8000 to 25 000 cases of pertussis, are reported\neach year in the USA.\n\nDuring the last decade, pertussis has re-emerged as one of the most\npressing public health issues due to increasing numbers of cases and\nlower vaccination rates, Fuller said.\n\nRecently, multiple outbreaks of pertussis have been investigated in\nthe USA, including cases in California and Idaho, said Jeff Ketchel,\nhealth district administrator. From 2005 to 2009, Washington state\nhad 2636 cases of whooping cough. During this same time period, Grant\nCounty had 17 cases.\n\nAbout 1 in 20 infants with pertussis get pneumonia, said Dr Alexander\nBrzezny, Grant County health officer. About 1 in 100 infants will\nhave convulsions. In rare cases, pertussis can be deadly, especially\nin infants under 1 year old. Nearly all infants with pertussis get\nthe infection from an infected adult.\n\n[Byline: Dee Riggs]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grant County can be seen on the map of Washington state at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Pennsylvania\nDate: Wed 25 Aug 2010\nSource: VaccineNewsDaily.com, Philly.com report [edited]\n<http://vaccinenewsdaily.com/news/214853-philadelphia-whooping-cough-cases-on-the-rise>\n\n\nA rise in reported cases of pertussis in causing concern in the\ngreater Philadelphia area, health officials say. The suburban\ncounties of southeastern Pennsylvania have witnessed increased\noccurrences of the infection, which can be fatal in infants,\nPhilly.com reports. Delaware County saw the largest increase in\ncases, jumping from 5 cases to 44 within a 3 month period.\n\nThe 2nd highest increase in whooping cough cases was in Montgomery\nCounty, Philly.com reports, where 39 new cases were tallied between\nApril and June 2010, compared to 8 new cases in the 3 months preceding.\n\n[Byline: Malik Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The counties mentioned can be seen on the map of Pennsylvania at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/pennsylvania.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Michigan\nDate: Tue 24 Aug 2010\nSource: Gaylord Herald Times [edited]\n<http://www.gaylordheraldtimes.com/articles/2010/08/24/news/local_news/doc4c740c3a8f597802151863.txt>\n\n\nAccording to a report from Dr Joshua Meyerson, the medical director\nof the Health Department of Northwest Michigan, 25 cases of pertussis\nhave been discovered in the 4 counties, Antrim, Charlevoix, Emmet,\nand Otsego, served by Northwest. The outbreak is 5 times the typical\nnumber. There have been cases so far in Otsego County in 2010, a\nchild and an adult.\n\nMeyerson states that 10-15 percent of children have not been\nvaccinated. \"In some ways these vaccinations are victims of the\ninitial success of the vaccine,\" said Jane Sundmacher, public\ninformation officer of Northwest. \"Before the vaccine was introduced\nin the 1940s, pertussis was the major cause of serious illness and\ndeath in infants and young children.\"\n\nThe alarm being sounded about the outbreak is particularly important\nin Michigan. California and Michigan lead the country in the\npercentage of children not vaccinated. California has suffered 10\ndeaths and Michigan one.\n\n\"Be really careful about who's around an infant,\" Sundmacher said. \"A\nreally common report we hear is that an adult has a cough, but\ndoesn't feel that sick, and ends up passing pertussis on to a baby or\nyoung child. Even if an infant has started the series of shots\nusually given at 2, 4, and 6 months, if they haven't completed the\nseries, their parents and anyone else who cares for them should get\nimmunized. Booster shots are available for ages 7 to 64.\"\n\nWendy Phillips, public information officer of Northeast Health\nDepartment, reports there have been no identified cases of pertussis\nin 2010 in Montmorency County. There are, however, 2 cases in both\nAlpena and Cheboygan, and the 2 in Otsego suggests it's only a matter\nof time before it spreads to Montmorency.\n\n[Byline: Lorene Parshall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The counties mentioned can be seen on the map of Michigan at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/michigan.shtml>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[4] California\nDate: Mon 16 Aug 2010\nSource: The Bakersfield Californian, Kern County Department of Public\nHealth Services (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.bakersfield.com/news/local/x1415296021/Number-of-whooping-cough-cases-up-to-227>\n\n\nAn additional 17 cases of whooping cough were reported last week\n[week of 9 Aug 2010] in Kern County, bringing the total to 227 for\n2010, according to the Kern County Department of Public Health.\n\nThe monthly rate of cases of whooping cough, also known as pertussis,\nin Kern County has been going up and up in 2010, though no deaths\nhave been reported. The weekly rate has, since 23 May 2010, ranged\nfrom 5 between 30 May and 5 Jun 2010 to 33 between 27 Jun and 3 Jul\n2010, according to Public Health. Of the 227 Kern cases, 182 were\nreported in Bakersfield.\n\nThe reason for the uptick is unclear but it's happening across the\nstate so health officials are just trying to get the word out about\nthe need for vaccination, said Denise Smith, Public Health's\nassistant director of disease control.\n\nOfficials have said the incidence of whooping cough is cyclical. In\nKern there were 6 reported cases in all of 2009 and 8 in 2008,\naccording to Public Health.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Kern County can be seen on the map of California at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/california.shtml>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[5] Missouri\nDate: Sun 22 Aug 2010\nSource: St Louis Today [edited]\n<http://www.stltoday.com/news/national/article_fd578e9f-0af5-55f9-85b1-4ee13e39a699.html>\n\n\nMissouri has reported 82 confirmed cases of pertussis in the last\nmonth. One-quarter of those involved infants under a year old.\n\nNo one knows exactly why this is happening. In the 1920s and '30s,\npertussis was a feared childhood killer, with an annual toll as high\nas 250 000 cases and 9000 deaths, according to the CDC. In the 1940s,\nhealth authorities introduced a combined vaccine against diphtheria,\npertussis, and tetanus (often called DPT or DTaP), and by 1976\npertussis was virtually eliminated, with just 1010 reported cases.\n\nRecent research has shown that the protection provided by the vaccine\nwears off over time, Aaron Miller wrote in an article posted on St.\nLouis Children's Hospital's website. Miller, a pediatrician at the\nhospital and an instructor of pediatrics at Washington University\nSchool of Medicine, added that the CDC now recommends that all\nchildren receive a booster shot at 11 or 12 and that adults receive\nthe same booster.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Missouri can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the US at <http://healthmap.org/r/03UJ>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (03) 20100725.2493\nPertussis - USA (02) 20100722.2458\nPertussis, fatal - USA: (CA) 20100626.2130\nPertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2008\n----\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n----\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n----\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\n...................................sb/ll/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. One-quarter of those involved infants under a year old.\n\nNo one knows exactly why this is happening. In the 1920s and '30s,\npertussis was a feared childhood killer, with an annual toll as high\nas 250 000 cases and 9000 deaths, according to the CDC. In the 1940s,\nhealth authorities introduced a combined vaccine against diphtheria,\npertussis, and tetanus (often called DPT or DTaP), and by 1976\npertussis was virtually eliminated, with just 1010 reported cases.\n\nRecent research has shown that the protection provided by the vaccine\nwears off over time, Aaron Miller wrote in an article posted on St.\nLouis Children's Hospital's website. Miller, a pediatrician at the\nhospital and an instructor of pediatrics at Washington University\nSchool of Medicine, added that the CDC now recommends that all\nchildren receive a booster shot at 11 or 12 and that adults receive\nthe same booster.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Missouri can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the US at <http://healthmap.org/r/03UJ>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (03) 20100725.2493\nPertussis - USA (02) 20100722.2458\nPertussis, fatal - USA: (CA) 20100626.2130\nPertussis - USA: (MN) 20100514.1573\n2009\n----\nPertussis - Australia (02): (SA) 20091108.3876\nPertussis - Australia: (SA) 20091107.3842\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI 20090404.1306\n2008\n----\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n----\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n----\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\n...................................sb/ll/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
