USA (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=475118", "date": "2009-11-07 04:00:03", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA: (SOUTH AUSTRALIA)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2009\nSource: Adelaide Now [edited]\n<http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,26306408-5006301,00.html>\n\n\nSouth Australia is experiencing its worst whooping cough [pertussis]\noutbreak on record and babies are the main victims of the potentially fatal\nand highly infectious disease. Babies are most vulnerable as they are too\nyoung to be [fully] immunized, and rely upon \"herd immunity\", the high\nimmunisation of those around them.\n\nSA Health has received almost 3500 reports in 2009, compared with 859 at\nthe same time in 2008 and 318 in 2007. National statistics show the rate in\nSouth Australia is twice as high as the national average. A 4 week old NSW\nbaby who died in March 2009 was the 1st fatality from the disease in a\ndecade. Since then it is understood 2 other children have died.\n\nSA Health Communicable Disease Control branch director Dr Ann Koehler said\nnationally there had been a \"big wave\" of infections. She said SA had the\nhighest rate, although it was not clear why. Dr Koehler said more cases\nwere being diagnosed as people were tested for swine flu. She said SA had\nrecorded the highest number of notifications since records started being\nkept in 1991, and warned that people needed to be vigilant about\nvaccinations to protect vulnerable children.\n\n\"The highest rates of infection we're seeing are children who are too young\nto be vaccinated,\" Dr Koehler said. \"With children, brain damage can be a\nreally serious complication. While they're trying to cough, they stop\nbreathing. Little children also get hernias and might need surgery to fix\nthat.\"\n\nAbout 95 per cent of SA children are immunized, but Dr Koehler said SA\nHealth was concerned about some people's resistance to or complacency about\nvaccinating children. She warned homeopathic \"vaccines\" did not work.\n\"That's wasting your money ... you're putting yourself, your children and\nother people's children at risk,\" she said.\n\n[byline: Tory Shepard]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In assessing the durability of pertussis vaccination in children, some\nresearchers noted that \"Reported cases and outbreaks in older children and\nyoung adults may reflect a less durable vaccine-induced protection than\nseen in natural disease (Cherry JD, Brunell PA, Golden GA, Karzon, DT.\nReport of the task force on pertussis and pertussis immunization - 1988.\nPediatrics 1988; 81(June Suppl): 955). The duration of protection has\nvaried in several studies, depending on the epidemiological setting; that\nis, prevalence of natural disease as well as the vaccine product used. A\nstudy in Michigan showed an efficacy of 80 per cent 3 years after the last\ndose, 50 per cent between 4 and 7 years, and virtually none after 12 years.\nBreakthrough disease noted in this study was usually mild.\"\n\nBecause of these and similar findings, it is now recommended to reimmunize\nteenagers and give adults between 19 and 64 year old a TdaP [tetanus, low\ndose diphtheria, acellular pertussis] booster substituted for one of the\nevery 10 year Td vaccines [detailed adult immunisation practices vary\nworldwide. - Mod.SH]. - Mod.LL\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for South Australia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00N_> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI\n20090404.1306\n2008\n---\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n---\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n---\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\nPertussis - Canada (ON) 20060209.0431\n2005\n---\nPertussis, adult vaccine - USA 20050614.1669\nPertussis, adolescent vaccine - USA 20050511.1293\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n---\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. (02) 20031004.2499\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. 20031003.2488\n2000\n---\nPertussis - Australia (New South Wales) 20001105.1930\n1997\n---\nPertussis - Australia (05) 19971213.2478\nPertussis - Australia 19971208.2447\n\n..................ll/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Babies are most vulnerable as they are too\nyoung to be [fully] immunized, and rely upon \"herd immunity\", the high\nimmunisation of those around them.\n\nSA Health has received almost 3500 reports in 2009, compared with 859 at\nthe same time in 2008 and 318 in 2007. National statistics show the rate in\nSouth Australia is twice as high as the national average. A 4 week old NSW\nbaby who died in March 2009 was the 1st fatality from the disease in a\ndecade. Since then it is understood 2 other children have died.\n\nSA Health Communicable Disease Control branch director Dr Ann Koehler said\nnationally there had been a \"big wave\" of infections. She said SA had the\nhighest rate, although it was not clear why. Dr Koehler said more cases\nwere being diagnosed as people were tested for swine flu. She said SA had\nrecorded the highest number of notifications since records started being\nkept in 1991, and warned that people needed to be vigilant about\nvaccinations to protect vulnerable children.\n\n\"The highest rates of infection we're seeing are children who are too young\nto be vaccinated,\" Dr Koehler said. \"With children, brain damage can be a\nreally serious complication. While they're trying to cough, they stop\nbreathing. Little children also get hernias and might need surgery to fix\nthat.\"\n\nAbout 95 per cent of SA children are immunized, but Dr Koehler said SA\nHealth was concerned about some people's resistance to or complacency about\nvaccinating children. She warned homeopathic \"vaccines\" did not work.\n\"That's wasting your money ... you're putting yourself, your children and\nother people's children at risk,\" she said.\n\n[byline: Tory Shepard]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In assessing the durability of pertussis vaccination in children, some\nresearchers noted that \"Reported cases and outbreaks in older children and\nyoung adults may reflect a less durable vaccine-induced protection than\nseen in natural disease (Cherry JD, Brunell PA, Golden GA, Karzon, DT.\nReport of the task force on pertussis and pertussis immunization - 1988.\nPediatrics 1988; 81(June Suppl): 955). The duration of protection has\nvaried in several studies, depending on the epidemiological setting; that\nis, prevalence of natural disease as well as the vaccine product used. A\nstudy in Michigan showed an efficacy of 80 per cent 3 years after the last\ndose, 50 per cent between 4 and 7 years, and virtually none after 12 years.\nBreakthrough disease noted in this study was usually mild.\"\n\nBecause of these and similar findings, it is now recommended to reimmunize\nteenagers and give adults between 19 and 64 year old a TdaP [tetanus, low\ndose diphtheria, acellular pertussis] booster substituted for one of the\nevery 10 year Td vaccines [detailed adult immunisation practices vary\nworldwide. - Mod.SH]. - Mod.LL\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for South Australia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00N_> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI\n20090404.1306\n2008\n---\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n---\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n---\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\nPertussis - Canada (ON) 20060209.0431\n2005\n---\nPertussis, adult vaccine - USA 20050614.1669\nPertussis, adolescent vaccine - USA 20050511.1293\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n---\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. (02) 20031004.2499\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. 20031003.2488\n2000\n---\nPertussis - Australia (New South Wales) 20001105.1930\n1997\n---\nPertussis - Australia (05) 19971213.2478\nPertussis - Australia 19971208.2447\n\n..................ll/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Babies are most vulnerable as they are too\nyoung to be [fully] immunized, and rely upon \"herd immunity\", the high\nimmunisation of those around them.\n\nSA Health has received almost 3500 reports in 2009, compared with 859 at\nthe same time in 2008 and 318 in 2007. National statistics show the rate in\nSouth Australia is twice as high as the national average. A 4 week old NSW\nbaby who died in March 2009 was the 1st fatality from the disease in a\ndecade. Since then it is understood 2 other children have died.\n\nSA Health Communicable Disease Control branch director Dr Ann Koehler said\nnationally there had been a \"big wave\" of infections. She said SA had the\nhighest rate, although it was not clear why. Dr Koehler said more cases\nwere being diagnosed as people were tested for swine flu. She said SA had\nrecorded the highest number of notifications since records started being\nkept in 1991, and warned that people needed to be vigilant about\nvaccinations to protect vulnerable children.\n\n\"The highest rates of infection we're seeing are children who are too young\nto be vaccinated,\" Dr Koehler said. \"With children, brain damage can be a\nreally serious complication. She warned homeopathic \"vaccines\" did not work.\n\"That's wasting your money ... you're putting yourself, your children and\nother people's children at risk,\" she said.\n\n[byline: Tory Shepard]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In assessing the durability of pertussis vaccination in children, some\nresearchers noted that \"Reported cases and outbreaks in older children and\nyoung adults may reflect a less durable vaccine-induced protection than\nseen in natural disease (Cherry JD, Brunell PA, Golden GA, Karzon, DT.\nReport of the task force on pertussis and pertussis immunization - 1988.\nPediatrics 1988; 81(June Suppl): 955). A\nstudy in Michigan showed an efficacy of 80 per cent 3 years after the last\ndose, 50 per cent between 4 and 7 years, and virtually none after 12 years.\nBreakthrough disease noted in this study was usually mild.\"\n\nBecause of these and similar findings, it is now recommended to reimmunize\nteenagers and give adults between 19 and 64 year old a TdaP [tetanus, low\ndose diphtheria, acellular pertussis] booster substituted for one of the\nevery 10 year Td vaccines [detailed adult immunisation practices vary\nworldwide. - Mod.SH]. - Mod.LL\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for South Australia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00N_> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI\n20090404.1306\n2008\n---\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n---\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n---\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\nPertussis - Canada (ON) 20060209.0431\n2005\n---\nPertussis, adult vaccine - USA 20050614.1669\nPertussis, adolescent vaccine - USA 20050511.1293\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n---\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. The duration of protection has\nvaried in several studies, depending on the epidemiological setting; that\nis, prevalence of natural disease as well as the vaccine product used. A\nstudy in Michigan showed an efficacy of 80 per cent 3 years after the last\ndose, 50 per cent between 4 and 7 years, and virtually none after 12 years.\nBreakthrough disease noted in this study was usually mild.\"\n\nBecause of these and similar findings, it is now recommended to reimmunize\nteenagers and give adults between 19 and 64 year old a TdaP [tetanus, low\ndose diphtheria, acellular pertussis] booster substituted for one of the\nevery 10 year Td vaccines [detailed adult immunisation practices vary\nworldwide. - Mod.SH]. - Mod.LL\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for South Australia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00N_> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI\n20090404.1306\n2008\n---\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n---\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n---\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\nPertussis - Canada (ON) 20060209.0431\n2005\n---\nPertussis, adult vaccine - USA 20050614.1669\nPertussis, adolescent vaccine - USA 20050511.1293\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n---\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. (02) 20031004.2499\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. 20031003.2488\n2000\n---\nPertussis - Australia (New South Wales) 20001105.1930\n1997\n---\nPertussis - Australia (05) 19971213.2478\nPertussis - Australia 19971208.2447\n\n..................ll/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1988-03-16 00:00:00", "1988-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Sepik", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TdaP", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equatoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Karzon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "326798", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Australia: (SA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=326798", "date": "2009-11-07 04:00:03", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - AUSTRALIA: (SOUTH AUSTRALIA)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2009\nSource: Adelaide Now [edited]\n<http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,26306408-5006301,00.html>\n\n\nSouth Australia is experiencing its worst whooping cough [pertussis]\noutbreak on record and babies are the main victims of the potentially fatal\nand highly infectious disease. Babies are most vulnerable as they are too\nyoung to be [fully] immunized, and rely upon \"herd immunity\", the high\nimmunisation of those around them.\n\nSA Health has received almost 3500 reports in 2009, compared with 859 at\nthe same time in 2008 and 318 in 2007. National statistics show the rate in\nSouth Australia is twice as high as the national average. A 4 week old NSW\nbaby who died in March 2009 was the 1st fatality from the disease in a\ndecade. Since then it is understood 2 other children have died.\n\nSA Health Communicable Disease Control branch director Dr Ann Koehler said\nnationally there had been a \"big wave\" of infections. She said SA had the\nhighest rate, although it was not clear why. Dr Koehler said more cases\nwere being diagnosed as people were tested for swine flu. She said SA had\nrecorded the highest number of notifications since records started being\nkept in 1991, and warned that people needed to be vigilant about\nvaccinations to protect vulnerable children.\n\n\"The highest rates of infection we're seeing are children who are too young\nto be vaccinated,\" Dr Koehler said. \"With children, brain damage can be a\nreally serious complication. While they're trying to cough, they stop\nbreathing. Little children also get hernias and might need surgery to fix\nthat.\"\n\nAbout 95 per cent of SA children are immunized, but Dr Koehler said SA\nHealth was concerned about some people's resistance to or complacency about\nvaccinating children. She warned homeopathic \"vaccines\" did not work.\n\"That's wasting your money ... you're putting yourself, your children and\nother people's children at risk,\" she said.\n\n[byline: Tory Shepard]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail and HealthMap\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In assessing the durability of pertussis vaccination in children, some\nresearchers noted that \"Reported cases and outbreaks in older children and\nyoung adults may reflect a less durable vaccine-induced protection than\nseen in natural disease (Cherry JD, Brunell PA, Golden GA, Karzon, DT.\nReport of the task force on pertussis and pertussis immunization - 1988.\nPediatrics 1988; 81(June Suppl): 955). The duration of protection has\nvaried in several studies, depending on the epidemiological setting; that\nis, prevalence of natural disease as well as the vaccine product used. A\nstudy in Michigan showed an efficacy of 80 per cent 3 years after the last\ndose, 50 per cent between 4 and 7 years, and virtually none after 12 years.\nBreakthrough disease noted in this study was usually mild.\"\n\nBecause of these and similar findings, it is now recommended to reimmunize\nteenagers and give adults between 19 and 64 year old a TdaP [tetanus, low\ndose diphtheria, acellular pertussis] booster substituted for one of the\nevery 10 year Td vaccines [detailed adult immunisation practices vary\nworldwide. - Mod.SH]. - Mod.LL\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for South Australia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00N_> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nPertussis, atypical cases - USA: (CO), RFI 20090825.2996\nUndiagnosed resp. deaths - Nicaragua: (JI), pertussis, susp., RFI\n20090404.1306\n2008\n---\nPertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD) 20081107.3501\n2007\n---\nPertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI) 20071111.3662\nPertussis, school district - USA: (OH) 20071106.3610\nPertussis - USA (MS): RFI 20070819.2709\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02) 20070714.2261\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n---\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\nPertussis - Papua New Guinea (East Sepik) 20060612.1641\nPertussis - Canada (ON) 20060209.0431\n2005\n---\nPertussis, adult vaccine - USA 20050614.1669\nPertussis, adolescent vaccine - USA 20050511.1293\nPertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi) 20050125.0274\n2003\n---\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. (02) 20031004.2499\nPertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp. 20031003.2488\n2000\n---\nPertussis - Australia (New South Wales) 20001105.1930\n1997\n---\nPertussis - Australia (05) 19971213.2478\nPertussis - Australia 19971208.2447\n\n..................ll/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA: (CO), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=277501", "date": "2007-07-14 11:00:03", "main_text": "BORDETELLA HOLMESII, PERTUSSIS-LIKE ILLNESS - CANADA (ONTARIO) (02)\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 13 Jul 2007\nFrom: David Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>, Tracey Clatworthy\n<tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\n\nRe: Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nWe appreciate ProMED-mail's posting of our initial report, and also\nappreciate the Moderator's (Dr. Levison's) interesting questions and comments.\nWith respect to the question of whether our isolation of _B.\nholmesii_ is related to the presence or absence of cephalexin in\nculture or transport media, we think this unlikely. Indeed, all 5\nisolates initially identified at the Ontario Central Public Health\nLaboratory grew on Regan-Lowe charcoal agar with 20 ug/ml cephalexin,\nand we have been able to grow all 6 isolates (a 6th isolate was\nforwarded to us for reference identification) in the presence of up\nto 40 ug/ml cephalexin. As such, our experience differs from that\ndescribed in Massachusetts (reference: Mazengia E, et al, J Clin\nMicro 2000; 38(6): 2330-3).\n\nThe Moderator notes that Toronto has seen a marked increase in\npertussis rates since 2005, though the fact that most cases are IS481\nPCR-positive but culture negative, and clinically quite mild (no\npertussis-related hospitalizations noted at the region's major\nchildren's hospital) suggests that increased sensitivity of\nlaboratory methods may have led to the identification of individuals\nwith relatively mild infection and low organism burden. Nonetheless,\nof 1340 specimens that tested positive for pertussis between January\n2005 and March 2007, 104 (7.8 percent) were culture positive for _B.\npertussis_. In contrast, only 5 _B. holmesii_ isolates were\nidentified during the same period. As such, we think it unlikely that\n_B. holmesii_ is a major contributor to increased local pertussis\nrates. We recently presented a laboratory-based assessment of\npertussis epidemiology in the Greater Toronto Area at the meeting of\nthe Pediatric Academic Societies meeting; the abstract can be accessed at\n<http://www.pas-meeting.org/2007Toronto/Abstracts/LB%20Sessions%2007.pdf>.\n--\nDavid N. Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\nTracey Clatworthy <tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\nHospital for Sick Children (SickKids)\nUniversity of Toronto\nCanada\n[Many thanks for the additional data from Dr. Fisman and Ms.\nClatworthy. The _B. pertussis_ assay that targets insertion sequence\nIS481 has been found to cross-react with isolates of _B. holmesii_\n(see Reischl U, et al, J Clin Microbiol 2001; 39: 1963-6). Indeed,\nFisman and Jamieson reported that 4 of the actual nasopharyngeal\nspecimens that were culture-positive for _B. holmesii_ gave a\npositive result by the PCR assay for IS481 (see ProMED-mail\n_Bordetella holmesii_, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)\n20070711.2215). However, the prevalence of _B. holmesii_ in the upper\nrespiratory tract of healthy individuals and its clinical\nsignificance in patients with cough remain to be evaluated. In the\nmeantime, since the PCR assay for IS461 is not specific for _B.\npertussis_, other diagnostic tests would seem to be necessary. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n----\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (03): correct dx? 20061228.3636\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\nPertussis - Canada (ON) 20060209.0431\n2005\n----\nPertussis, adult vaccine - USA 20050614.1669\nPertussis, adolescent vaccine - USA 20050511.1293\n2004\n----\nPertussis - USA (multistate) 20040923.2626\n2003\n----\nPertussis - USA (South Carolina) 20030716.1750\nPertussis - USA (WA, NY) 20030624.1554\nPertussis, adults - USA (Ill) (02): chemoprophylaxis 20030112.0102\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n----\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n----\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n...................................mpp/ml/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\nTracey Clatworthy <tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\nHospital for Sick Children (SickKids)\nUniversity of Toronto\nCanada\n[Many thanks for the additional data from Dr. Fisman and Ms.\nClatworthy. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2330-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1340-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1963-06-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Regan - Lowe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "125863", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, schoolchildren - USA: (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=125863", "date": "2007-07-14 11:00:03", "main_text": "BORDETELLA HOLMESII, PERTUSSIS-LIKE ILLNESS - CANADA (ONTARIO) (02)\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 13 Jul 2007\nFrom: David Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>, Tracey Clatworthy\n<tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\n\nRe: Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nWe appreciate ProMED-mail's posting of our initial report, and also\nappreciate the Moderator's (Dr. Levison's) interesting questions and comments.\nWith respect to the question of whether our isolation of _B.\nholmesii_ is related to the presence or absence of cephalexin in\nculture or transport media, we think this unlikely. Indeed, all 5\nisolates initially identified at the Ontario Central Public Health\nLaboratory grew on Regan-Lowe charcoal agar with 20 ug/ml cephalexin,\nand we have been able to grow all 6 isolates (a 6th isolate was\nforwarded to us for reference identification) in the presence of up\nto 40 ug/ml cephalexin. As such, our experience differs from that\ndescribed in Massachusetts (reference: Mazengia E, et al, J Clin\nMicro 2000; 38(6): 2330-3).\n\nThe Moderator notes that Toronto has seen a marked increase in\npertussis rates since 2005, though the fact that most cases are IS481\nPCR-positive but culture negative, and clinically quite mild (no\npertussis-related hospitalizations noted at the region's major\nchildren's hospital) suggests that increased sensitivity of\nlaboratory methods may have led to the identification of individuals\nwith relatively mild infection and low organism burden. Nonetheless,\nof 1340 specimens that tested positive for pertussis between January\n2005 and March 2007, 104 (7.8 percent) were culture positive for _B.\npertussis_. In contrast, only 5 _B. holmesii_ isolates were\nidentified during the same period. As such, we think it unlikely that\n_B. holmesii_ is a major contributor to increased local pertussis\nrates. We recently presented a laboratory-based assessment of\npertussis epidemiology in the Greater Toronto Area at the meeting of\nthe Pediatric Academic Societies meeting; the abstract can be accessed at\n<http://www.pas-meeting.org/2007Toronto/Abstracts/LB%20Sessions%2007.pdf>.\n--\nDavid N. Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\nTracey Clatworthy <tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\nHospital for Sick Children (SickKids)\nUniversity of Toronto\nCanada\n[Many thanks for the additional data from Dr. Fisman and Ms.\nClatworthy. The _B. pertussis_ assay that targets insertion sequence\nIS481 has been found to cross-react with isolates of _B. holmesii_\n(see Reischl U, et al, J Clin Microbiol 2001; 39: 1963-6). Indeed,\nFisman and Jamieson reported that 4 of the actual nasopharyngeal\nspecimens that were culture-positive for _B. holmesii_ gave a\npositive result by the PCR assay for IS481 (see ProMED-mail\n_Bordetella holmesii_, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)\n20070711.2215). However, the prevalence of _B. holmesii_ in the upper\nrespiratory tract of healthy individuals and its clinical\nsignificance in patients with cough remain to be evaluated. In the\nmeantime, since the PCR assay for IS461 is not specific for _B.\npertussis_, other diagnostic tests would seem to be necessary. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n----\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (03): correct dx? 20061228.3636\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\nPertussis - Canada (ON) 20060209.0431\n2005\n----\nPertussis, adult vaccine - USA 20050614.1669\nPertussis, adolescent vaccine - USA 20050511.1293\n2004\n----\nPertussis - USA (multistate) 20040923.2626\n2003\n----\nPertussis - USA (South Carolina) 20030716.1750\nPertussis - USA (WA, NY) 20030624.1554\nPertussis, adults - USA (Ill) (02): chemoprophylaxis 20030112.0102\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n----\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n----\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n...................................mpp/ml/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2330-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1340-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1963-06-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Regan - Lowe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "36287", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, school district - USA (02): (WI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=36287", "date": "2007-07-14 11:00:03", "main_text": "BORDETELLA HOLMESII, PERTUSSIS-LIKE ILLNESS - CANADA (ONTARIO) (02)\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 13 Jul 2007\nFrom: David Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>, Tracey Clatworthy\n<tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\n\nRe: Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nWe appreciate ProMED-mail's posting of our initial report, and also\nappreciate the Moderator's (Dr. Levison's) interesting questions and comments.\nWith respect to the question of whether our isolation of _B.\nholmesii_ is related to the presence or absence of cephalexin in\nculture or transport media, we think this unlikely. Indeed, all 5\nisolates initially identified at the Ontario Central Public Health\nLaboratory grew on Regan-Lowe charcoal agar with 20 ug/ml cephalexin,\nand we have been able to grow all 6 isolates (a 6th isolate was\nforwarded to us for reference identification) in the presence of up\nto 40 ug/ml cephalexin. As such, our experience differs from that\ndescribed in Massachusetts (reference: Mazengia E, et al, J Clin\nMicro 2000; 38(6): 2330-3).\n\nThe Moderator notes that Toronto has seen a marked increase in\npertussis rates since 2005, though the fact that most cases are IS481\nPCR-positive but culture negative, and clinically quite mild (no\npertussis-related hospitalizations noted at the region's major\nchildren's hospital) suggests that increased sensitivity of\nlaboratory methods may have led to the identification of individuals\nwith relatively mild infection and low organism burden. Nonetheless,\nof 1340 specimens that tested positive for pertussis between January\n2005 and March 2007, 104 (7.8 percent) were culture positive for _B.\npertussis_. In contrast, only 5 _B. holmesii_ isolates were\nidentified during the same period. As such, we think it unlikely that\n_B. holmesii_ is a major contributor to increased local pertussis\nrates. We recently presented a laboratory-based assessment of\npertussis epidemiology in the Greater Toronto Area at the meeting of\nthe Pediatric Academic Societies meeting; the abstract can be accessed at\n<http://www.pas-meeting.org/2007Toronto/Abstracts/LB%20Sessions%2007.pdf>.\n--\nDavid N. Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\nTracey Clatworthy <tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\nHospital for Sick Children (SickKids)\nUniversity of Toronto\nCanada\n[Many thanks for the additional data from Dr. Fisman and Ms.\nClatworthy. The _B. pertussis_ assay that targets insertion sequence\nIS481 has been found to cross-react with isolates of _B. holmesii_\n(see Reischl U, et al, J Clin Microbiol 2001; 39: 1963-6). Indeed,\nFisman and Jamieson reported that 4 of the actual nasopharyngeal\nspecimens that were culture-positive for _B. holmesii_ gave a\npositive result by the PCR assay for IS481 (see ProMED-mail\n_Bordetella holmesii_, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)\n20070711.2215). However, the prevalence of _B. holmesii_ in the upper\nrespiratory tract of healthy individuals and its clinical\nsignificance in patients with cough remain to be evaluated. In the\nmeantime, since the PCR assay for IS461 is not specific for _B.\npertussis_, other diagnostic tests would seem to be necessary. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n----\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (03): correct dx? 20061228.3636\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\nPertussis - Canada (ON) 20060209.0431\n2005\n----\nPertussis, adult vaccine - USA 20050614.1669\nPertussis, adolescent vaccine - USA 20050511.1293\n2004\n----\nPertussis - USA (multistate) 20040923.2626\n2003\n----\nPertussis - USA (South Carolina) 20030716.1750\nPertussis - USA (WA, NY) 20030624.1554\nPertussis, adults - USA (Ill) (02): chemoprophylaxis 20030112.0102\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n----\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n----\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n...................................mpp/ml/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\nTracey Clatworthy <tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\nHospital for Sick Children (SickKids)\nUniversity of Toronto\nCanada\n[Many thanks for the additional data from Dr. Fisman and Ms.\nClatworthy. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2330-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1340-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1963-06-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Regan - Lowe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209639", "headline": "PRO/ERR> Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) (02): corr.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209639", "date": "2007-07-14 11:00:03", "main_text": "BORDETELLA HOLMESII, PERTUSSIS-LIKE ILLNESS - CANADA (ONTARIO) (02)\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 13 Jul 2007\nFrom: David Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>, Tracey Clatworthy\n<tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\n\nRe: Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nWe appreciate ProMED-mail's posting of our initial report, and also\nappreciate the Moderator's (Dr. Levison's) interesting questions and comments.\nWith respect to the question of whether our isolation of _B.\nholmesii_ is related to the presence or absence of cephalexin in\nculture or transport media, we think this unlikely. Indeed, all 5\nisolates initially identified at the Ontario Central Public Health\nLaboratory grew on Regan-Lowe charcoal agar with 20 ug/ml cephalexin,\nand we have been able to grow all 6 isolates (a 6th isolate was\nforwarded to us for reference identification) in the presence of up\nto 40 ug/ml cephalexin. As such, our experience differs from that\ndescribed in Massachusetts (reference: Mazengia E, et al, J Clin\nMicro 2000; 38(6): 2330-3).\n\nThe Moderator notes that Toronto has seen a marked increase in\npertussis rates since 2005, though the fact that most cases are IS481\nPCR-positive but culture negative, and clinically quite mild (no\npertussis-related hospitalizations noted at the region's major\nchildren's hospital) suggests that increased sensitivity of\nlaboratory methods may have led to the identification of individuals\nwith relatively mild infection and low organism burden. Nonetheless,\nof 1340 specimens that tested positive for pertussis between January\n2005 and March 2007, 104 (7.8 percent) were culture positive for _B.\npertussis_. In contrast, only 5 _B. holmesii_ isolates were\nidentified during the same period. As such, we think it unlikely that\n_B. holmesii_ is a major contributor to increased local pertussis\nrates. We recently presented a laboratory-based assessment of\npertussis epidemiology in the Greater Toronto Area at the meeting of\nthe Pediatric Academic Societies meeting; the abstract can be accessed at\n<http://www.pas-meeting.org/2007Toronto/Abstracts/LB%20Sessions%2007.pdf>.\n--\nDavid N. Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\nTracey Clatworthy <tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\nHospital for Sick Children (SickKids)\nUniversity of Toronto\nCanada\n[Many thanks for the additional data from Dr. Fisman and Ms.\nClatworthy. The _B. pertussis_ assay that targets insertion sequence\nIS481 has been found to cross-react with isolates of _B. holmesii_\n(see Reischl U, et al, J Clin Microbiol 2001; 39: 1963-6). Indeed,\nFisman and Jamieson reported that 4 of the actual nasopharyngeal\nspecimens that were culture-positive for _B. holmesii_ gave a\npositive result by the PCR assay for IS481 (see ProMED-mail\n_Bordetella holmesii_, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)\n20070711.2215). However, the prevalence of _B. holmesii_ in the upper\nrespiratory tract of healthy individuals and its clinical\nsignificance in patients with cough remain to be evaluated. In the\nmeantime, since the PCR assay for IS461 is not specific for _B.\npertussis_, other diagnostic tests would seem to be necessary. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nBordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON) 20070711.2215\n2006\n----\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (03): correct dx? 20061228.3636\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) (02) 20061109.3219\nPertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA) 20061102.3137\nPertussis - Canada (ON) 20060209.0431\n2005\n----\nPertussis, adult vaccine - USA 20050614.1669\nPertussis, adolescent vaccine - USA 20050511.1293\n2004\n----\nPertussis - USA (multistate) 20040923.2626\n2003\n----\nPertussis - USA (South Carolina) 20030716.1750\nPertussis - USA (WA, NY) 20030624.1554\nPertussis, adults - USA (Ill) (02): chemoprophylaxis 20030112.0102\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n----\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n----\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n...................................mpp/ml/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. As such, our experience differs from that\ndescribed in Massachusetts (reference: Mazengia E, et al, J Clin\nMicro 2000; 38(6): 2330-3).\n\nThe Moderator notes that Toronto has seen a marked increase in\npertussis rates since 2005, though the fact that most cases are IS481\nPCR-positive but culture negative, and clinically quite mild (no\npertussis-related hospitalizations noted at the region's major\nchildren's hospital) suggests that increased sensitivity of\nlaboratory methods may have led to the identification of individuals\nwith relatively mild infection and low organism burden. Nonetheless,\nof 1340 specimens that tested positive for pertussis between January\n2005 and March 2007, 104 (7.8 percent) were culture positive for _B.\npertussis_. In contrast, only 5 _B. holmesii_ isolates were\nidentified during the same period. As such, we think it unlikely that\n_B. holmesii_ is a major contributor to increased local pertussis\nrates. We recently presented a laboratory-based assessment of\npertussis epidemiology in the Greater Toronto Area at the meeting of\nthe Pediatric Academic Societies meeting; the abstract can be accessed at\n<http://www.pas-meeting.org/2007Toronto/Abstracts/LB%20Sessions%2007.pdf>.\n--\nDavid N. Fisman <david.fisman@sickkids.ca>\nTracey Clatworthy <tracey.clatworthy@sickkids.ca>\nHospital for Sick Children (SickKids)\nUniversity of Toronto\nCanada\n[Many thanks for the additional data from Dr. Fisman and Ms.\nClatworthy. The _B. pertussis_ assay that targets insertion sequence\nIS481 has been found to cross-react with isolates of _B. holmesii_\n(see Reischl U, et al, J Clin Microbiol 2001; 39: 1963-6). Indeed,\nFisman and Jamieson reported that 4 of the actual nasopharyngeal\nspecimens that were culture-positive for _B. holmesii_ gave a\npositive result by the PCR assay for IS481 (see ProMED-mail\n_Bordetella holmesii_, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)\n20070711.2215). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2330-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1340-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1963-06-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Regan - Lowe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "17048", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Bordetella holmesii, pertussis-like illness - Canada (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=17048", "date": "2005-05-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, ADOLESCENT VACCINE - USA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 3 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FDA.gov [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/ANSWERS/2005/ANS01354.html>\n\nCombination vaccine approved to protect adolescents against whooping cough\n---------------------------------------------------\nThe United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) today, 3 May 2005,\napproved the 1st combination vaccine that provides a booster immunization\nagainst pertussis (whooping cough) in combination with tetanus and\ndiphtheria for adolescents. The vaccine will be marketed as Boostrix by\nGlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Philadelphia, PA.\nPertussis is a highly communicable disease of the respiratory tract that\ncan be especially serious for infants under 1 year old, and may even be\nfatal. Pertussis can cause spells of coughing and choking that make\nbreathing difficult. The disease is generally less severe in adolescents,\nbut it is thought that they might transmit the disease to susceptible\ninfants and other family members. In the last 20 years, rates of pertussis\ninfection have been increasing in very young infants who have not received\nall their immunizations and in adolescents and adults.\nBoostrix is a tetanus toxoid (T), reduced diphtheria toxoid (d) and\nacellular pertussis vaccine (ap), adsorbed. Although booster vaccines for\nadolescents containing T and d are currently licensed and marketed for use\nin this age group, none contains a pertussis component. Boostrix has the\nsame components as Infanrix, a DTaP vaccine for infants and young children,\nbut in reduced quantities. Boostrix is indicated for use as a single\nbooster dose to adolescents 10-18 years of age.\nThe efficacy of the vaccine was measured by looking at the immune response\nto the vaccine, as measured by antibody concentrations. The response to the\nT and d components was at least as good as the response to a licensed Td\nvaccine. Boostrix also induced an antibody response to the pertussis\ncomponent of the vaccine. The response to the pertussis component was\ncompared to the response induced by a 3-dose series of Infanrix given to\ninfants in a previous study. The response of adolescents to Boostrix was\nconsidered adequate. It is not known how long immunity to pertussis will\nlast. Adolescents who received Boostrix experienced pain, redness, and\nswelling at the injection site. The frequency of redness and swelling after\nBoostrix was similar to what is expected following the administration of a\nTd vaccine. However, pain reactions at the injection site were more\nfrequent with those who received Boostrix. Other side effects included\nheadaches, fever and fatigue for a short period of time after the injection.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, 10 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Channel 36 Austin, TX [edited]\n<http://www.kxan.com/Global/story.asp?S=3327321&nav=0s3dZhYd>\n\nWhooping cough cases increasing\n-------------------------------\nThere have been 58 confirmed cases of whooping cough in Travis County\nschools in 2005. 100 more are suspected. \"In 2004, we had 300 cases\nreported in to us in the whole year, and we've already had more than 50\npercent of that number reported to us, just in the last 6 weeks,\" Dr Adolfo\nValadez, of the Travis County Health Department, said.\nWhooping cough looks like a regular cold or influenza in the beginning, but\ngradually gets worse, becoming especially dangerous for children with\nasthma. The coughing can become so severe it can close off [airways],\nespecially tiny ones. But doctors say those shots wear off when kids get a\nlittle older. The greatest danger is when school-age kids catch what looks\nlike a cold and bring it home to their baby brother or sister. \"When you\nsee that adolescent or adult with a cough history, test for pertussis\nbecause we can treat it,\" Valadez said.\nA 6 week old baby died in 2003 from whooping cough.\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri, 6 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource Fort Madison Daily Democrat (IA) [edited]\n<http://www.dailydem.com/articles/2005/05/06/news/news1.txt>\n\nArea whooping cough numbers climb\n----------------------------------\nIt's been determined to be an outbreak, with 17 confirmed cases of whooping\ncough in Lee County since mid-April 2005. Of the 17 cases, 16 are in the\nCentral Lee Community School District.\nCentral Lee superintendent Chuck Reighard said the school has responded to\nthe outbreak by determining who had close contact with the infected student\nand then making contact with the families of those who may have been\nexposed to urge seeking treatment with the family doctor. Reighard said\nthat now that the Lee County Health Department has become involved, the\nschool will determine close contacts, and the health department will take\non the role of contacting families.\nReighard said the majority of the 16 cases at Central Lee are among\nstudents in the middle school, although he said there have been a few at\nthe elementary and high school levels.\nThis isn't the 1st time that whooping cough has hit the area. This past\nwinter, 2004-2005, several confirmed cases were reported among students in\nthe Fort Madison Community School District. Lee County Health Department\nExecutive Director Julie Schilling said the department had 31 confirmed\ncases of whooping cough from Nov 2004 through Jan 2005, with the majority\nof those cases in the Fort Madison Public School system.\nA release of information concerning the outbreak from the Lee County Health\nDepartment did not indicate that there were incidents of whooping cough in\nFort Madison this time. Schilling said whooping cough has been in Iowa\nsince last summer [2004] but usually shows up in the fall. \"But it can\noccur at any time,\" Schilling said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although ProMED-mail does not cover pertussis regularly, regular outbreaks\nof the disease have continued to occur in the USA and elsewhere despite\naggressive universal childhood immunization programs. The development of a\npertussis vaccine consisting of pertussis toxoids as opposed to the older\nvaccine -- which was a killed, whole-cell product -- has improved tolerance\nbut not immunogenicity. This product, DTaP, has been used in the pediatric\nvaccination sequence for some time. As noted above, the Tdap variation is\nnow approved in adolescents and contains lower amounts of both diphtheria\nand pertussis components than the pediatric vaccine. Vaccination in\nadolescence should prolong immunity, but an additional booster will\nprobably be needed later in life. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n---\nPertussis - USA (multistate) 20040923.2626\n2003\n---\nPertussis - USA (South Carolina) 20030716.1750\nPertussis - USA (WA, NY) 20030624.1554\nPertussis, adults - USA (Ill) (02):chemoprophylaxis 20030112.0102\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n---\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n---\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n..................ll/pg/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-05-03 00:00:00", "2005-05-03 00:00:00", "2005-05-10 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-06 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Travis County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lee County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6195", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA)(03): correct dx?", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6195", "date": "2005-05-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, ADOLESCENT VACCINE - USA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 3 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FDA.gov [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/ANSWERS/2005/ANS01354.html>\n\nCombination vaccine approved to protect adolescents against whooping cough\n---------------------------------------------------\nThe United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) today, 3 May 2005,\napproved the 1st combination vaccine that provides a booster immunization\nagainst pertussis (whooping cough) in combination with tetanus and\ndiphtheria for adolescents. The vaccine will be marketed as Boostrix by\nGlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Philadelphia, PA.\nPertussis is a highly communicable disease of the respiratory tract that\ncan be especially serious for infants under 1 year old, and may even be\nfatal. Pertussis can cause spells of coughing and choking that make\nbreathing difficult. The disease is generally less severe in adolescents,\nbut it is thought that they might transmit the disease to susceptible\ninfants and other family members. In the last 20 years, rates of pertussis\ninfection have been increasing in very young infants who have not received\nall their immunizations and in adolescents and adults.\nBoostrix is a tetanus toxoid (T), reduced diphtheria toxoid (d) and\nacellular pertussis vaccine (ap), adsorbed. Although booster vaccines for\nadolescents containing T and d are currently licensed and marketed for use\nin this age group, none contains a pertussis component. Boostrix has the\nsame components as Infanrix, a DTaP vaccine for infants and young children,\nbut in reduced quantities. Boostrix is indicated for use as a single\nbooster dose to adolescents 10-18 years of age.\nThe efficacy of the vaccine was measured by looking at the immune response\nto the vaccine, as measured by antibody concentrations. The response to the\nT and d components was at least as good as the response to a licensed Td\nvaccine. Boostrix also induced an antibody response to the pertussis\ncomponent of the vaccine. The response to the pertussis component was\ncompared to the response induced by a 3-dose series of Infanrix given to\ninfants in a previous study. The response of adolescents to Boostrix was\nconsidered adequate. It is not known how long immunity to pertussis will\nlast. Adolescents who received Boostrix experienced pain, redness, and\nswelling at the injection site. The frequency of redness and swelling after\nBoostrix was similar to what is expected following the administration of a\nTd vaccine. However, pain reactions at the injection site were more\nfrequent with those who received Boostrix. Other side effects included\nheadaches, fever and fatigue for a short period of time after the injection.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, 10 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Channel 36 Austin, TX [edited]\n<http://www.kxan.com/Global/story.asp?S=3327321&nav=0s3dZhYd>\n\nWhooping cough cases increasing\n-------------------------------\nThere have been 58 confirmed cases of whooping cough in Travis County\nschools in 2005. 100 more are suspected. \"In 2004, we had 300 cases\nreported in to us in the whole year, and we've already had more than 50\npercent of that number reported to us, just in the last 6 weeks,\" Dr Adolfo\nValadez, of the Travis County Health Department, said.\nWhooping cough looks like a regular cold or influenza in the beginning, but\ngradually gets worse, becoming especially dangerous for children with\nasthma. The coughing can become so severe it can close off [airways],\nespecially tiny ones. But doctors say those shots wear off when kids get a\nlittle older. The greatest danger is when school-age kids catch what looks\nlike a cold and bring it home to their baby brother or sister. \"When you\nsee that adolescent or adult with a cough history, test for pertussis\nbecause we can treat it,\" Valadez said.\nA 6 week old baby died in 2003 from whooping cough.\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri, 6 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource Fort Madison Daily Democrat (IA) [edited]\n<http://www.dailydem.com/articles/2005/05/06/news/news1.txt>\n\nArea whooping cough numbers climb\n----------------------------------\nIt's been determined to be an outbreak, with 17 confirmed cases of whooping\ncough in Lee County since mid-April 2005. Of the 17 cases, 16 are in the\nCentral Lee Community School District.\nCentral Lee superintendent Chuck Reighard said the school has responded to\nthe outbreak by determining who had close contact with the infected student\nand then making contact with the families of those who may have been\nexposed to urge seeking treatment with the family doctor. Reighard said\nthat now that the Lee County Health Department has become involved, the\nschool will determine close contacts, and the health department will take\non the role of contacting families.\nReighard said the majority of the 16 cases at Central Lee are among\nstudents in the middle school, although he said there have been a few at\nthe elementary and high school levels.\nThis isn't the 1st time that whooping cough has hit the area. This past\nwinter, 2004-2005, several confirmed cases were reported among students in\nthe Fort Madison Community School District. Lee County Health Department\nExecutive Director Julie Schilling said the department had 31 confirmed\ncases of whooping cough from Nov 2004 through Jan 2005, with the majority\nof those cases in the Fort Madison Public School system.\nA release of information concerning the outbreak from the Lee County Health\nDepartment did not indicate that there were incidents of whooping cough in\nFort Madison this time. Schilling said whooping cough has been in Iowa\nsince last summer [2004] but usually shows up in the fall. \"But it can\noccur at any time,\" Schilling said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although ProMED-mail does not cover pertussis regularly, regular outbreaks\nof the disease have continued to occur in the USA and elsewhere despite\naggressive universal childhood immunization programs. The development of a\npertussis vaccine consisting of pertussis toxoids as opposed to the older\nvaccine -- which was a killed, whole-cell product -- has improved tolerance\nbut not immunogenicity. This product, DTaP, has been used in the pediatric\nvaccination sequence for some time. As noted above, the Tdap variation is\nnow approved in adolescents and contains lower amounts of both diphtheria\nand pertussis components than the pediatric vaccine. Vaccination in\nadolescence should prolong immunity, but an additional booster will\nprobably be needed later in life. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n---\nPertussis - USA (multistate) 20040923.2626\n2003\n---\nPertussis - USA (South Carolina) 20030716.1750\nPertussis - USA (WA, NY) 20030624.1554\nPertussis, adults - USA (Ill) (02):chemoprophylaxis 20030112.0102\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n---\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n---\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n..................ll/pg/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-05-03 00:00:00", "2005-05-03 00:00:00", "2005-05-10 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-06 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Travis County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lee County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4444", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, hospital employees - USA (MA)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4444", "date": "2005-05-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, ADOLESCENT VACCINE - USA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 3 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FDA.gov [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/ANSWERS/2005/ANS01354.html>\n\nCombination vaccine approved to protect adolescents against whooping cough\n---------------------------------------------------\nThe United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) today, 3 May 2005,\napproved the 1st combination vaccine that provides a booster immunization\nagainst pertussis (whooping cough) in combination with tetanus and\ndiphtheria for adolescents. The vaccine will be marketed as Boostrix by\nGlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Philadelphia, PA.\nPertussis is a highly communicable disease of the respiratory tract that\ncan be especially serious for infants under 1 year old, and may even be\nfatal. Pertussis can cause spells of coughing and choking that make\nbreathing difficult. The disease is generally less severe in adolescents,\nbut it is thought that they might transmit the disease to susceptible\ninfants and other family members. In the last 20 years, rates of pertussis\ninfection have been increasing in very young infants who have not received\nall their immunizations and in adolescents and adults.\nBoostrix is a tetanus toxoid (T), reduced diphtheria toxoid (d) and\nacellular pertussis vaccine (ap), adsorbed. Although booster vaccines for\nadolescents containing T and d are currently licensed and marketed for use\nin this age group, none contains a pertussis component. Boostrix has the\nsame components as Infanrix, a DTaP vaccine for infants and young children,\nbut in reduced quantities. Boostrix is indicated for use as a single\nbooster dose to adolescents 10-18 years of age.\nThe efficacy of the vaccine was measured by looking at the immune response\nto the vaccine, as measured by antibody concentrations. The response to the\nT and d components was at least as good as the response to a licensed Td\nvaccine. Boostrix also induced an antibody response to the pertussis\ncomponent of the vaccine. The response to the pertussis component was\ncompared to the response induced by a 3-dose series of Infanrix given to\ninfants in a previous study. The response of adolescents to Boostrix was\nconsidered adequate. It is not known how long immunity to pertussis will\nlast. Adolescents who received Boostrix experienced pain, redness, and\nswelling at the injection site. The frequency of redness and swelling after\nBoostrix was similar to what is expected following the administration of a\nTd vaccine. However, pain reactions at the injection site were more\nfrequent with those who received Boostrix. Other side effects included\nheadaches, fever and fatigue for a short period of time after the injection.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, 10 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Channel 36 Austin, TX [edited]\n<http://www.kxan.com/Global/story.asp?S=3327321&nav=0s3dZhYd>\n\nWhooping cough cases increasing\n-------------------------------\nThere have been 58 confirmed cases of whooping cough in Travis County\nschools in 2005. 100 more are suspected. \"In 2004, we had 300 cases\nreported in to us in the whole year, and we've already had more than 50\npercent of that number reported to us, just in the last 6 weeks,\" Dr Adolfo\nValadez, of the Travis County Health Department, said.\nWhooping cough looks like a regular cold or influenza in the beginning, but\ngradually gets worse, becoming especially dangerous for children with\nasthma. The coughing can become so severe it can close off [airways],\nespecially tiny ones. But doctors say those shots wear off when kids get a\nlittle older. The greatest danger is when school-age kids catch what looks\nlike a cold and bring it home to their baby brother or sister. \"When you\nsee that adolescent or adult with a cough history, test for pertussis\nbecause we can treat it,\" Valadez said.\nA 6 week old baby died in 2003 from whooping cough.\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri, 6 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource Fort Madison Daily Democrat (IA) [edited]\n<http://www.dailydem.com/articles/2005/05/06/news/news1.txt>\n\nArea whooping cough numbers climb\n----------------------------------\nIt's been determined to be an outbreak, with 17 confirmed cases of whooping\ncough in Lee County since mid-April 2005. Of the 17 cases, 16 are in the\nCentral Lee Community School District.\nCentral Lee superintendent Chuck Reighard said the school has responded to\nthe outbreak by determining who had close contact with the infected student\nand then making contact with the families of those who may have been\nexposed to urge seeking treatment with the family doctor. Reighard said\nthat now that the Lee County Health Department has become involved, the\nschool will determine close contacts, and the health department will take\non the role of contacting families.\nReighard said the majority of the 16 cases at Central Lee are among\nstudents in the middle school, although he said there have been a few at\nthe elementary and high school levels.\nThis isn't the 1st time that whooping cough has hit the area. This past\nwinter, 2004-2005, several confirmed cases were reported among students in\nthe Fort Madison Community School District. Lee County Health Department\nExecutive Director Julie Schilling said the department had 31 confirmed\ncases of whooping cough from Nov 2004 through Jan 2005, with the majority\nof those cases in the Fort Madison Public School system.\nA release of information concerning the outbreak from the Lee County Health\nDepartment did not indicate that there were incidents of whooping cough in\nFort Madison this time. Schilling said whooping cough has been in Iowa\nsince last summer [2004] but usually shows up in the fall. \"But it can\noccur at any time,\" Schilling said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although ProMED-mail does not cover pertussis regularly, regular outbreaks\nof the disease have continued to occur in the USA and elsewhere despite\naggressive universal childhood immunization programs. The development of a\npertussis vaccine consisting of pertussis toxoids as opposed to the older\nvaccine -- which was a killed, whole-cell product -- has improved tolerance\nbut not immunogenicity. This product, DTaP, has been used in the pediatric\nvaccination sequence for some time. As noted above, the Tdap variation is\nnow approved in adolescents and contains lower amounts of both diphtheria\nand pertussis components than the pediatric vaccine. Vaccination in\nadolescence should prolong immunity, but an additional booster will\nprobably be needed later in life. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n---\nPertussis - USA (multistate) 20040923.2626\n2003\n---\nPertussis - USA (South Carolina) 20030716.1750\nPertussis - USA (WA, NY) 20030624.1554\nPertussis, adults - USA (Ill) (02):chemoprophylaxis 20030112.0102\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n---\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n---\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n..................ll/pg/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. However, pain reactions at the injection site were more\nfrequent with those who received Boostrix. Other side effects included\nheadaches, fever and fatigue for a short period of time after the injection.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, 10 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Channel 36 Austin, TX [edited]\n<http://www.kxan.com/Global/story.asp?S=3327321&nav=0s3dZhYd>\n\nWhooping cough cases increasing\n-------------------------------\nThere have been 58 confirmed cases of whooping cough in Travis County\nschools in 2005. 100 more are suspected. \"In 2004, we had 300 cases\nreported in to us in the whole year, and we've already had more than 50\npercent of that number reported to us, just in the last 6 weeks,\" Dr Adolfo\nValadez, of the Travis County Health Department, said.\nWhooping cough looks like a regular cold or influenza in the beginning, but\ngradually gets worse, becoming especially dangerous for children with\nasthma. The coughing can become so severe it can close off [airways],\nespecially tiny ones. But doctors say those shots wear off when kids get a\nlittle older. The greatest danger is when school-age kids catch what looks\nlike a cold and bring it home to their baby brother or sister. \"When you\nsee that adolescent or adult with a cough history, test for pertussis\nbecause we can treat it,\" Valadez said.\nA 6 week old baby died in 2003 from whooping cough.\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri, 6 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource Fort Madison Daily Democrat (IA) [edited]\n<http://www.dailydem.com/articles/2005/05/06/news/news1.txt>\n\nArea whooping cough numbers climb\n----------------------------------\nIt's been determined to be an outbreak, with 17 confirmed cases of whooping\ncough in Lee County since mid-April 2005. Of the 17 cases, 16 are in the\nCentral Lee Community School District.\nCentral Lee superintendent Chuck Reighard said the school has responded to\nthe outbreak by determining who had close contact with the infected student\nand then making contact with the families of those who may have been\nexposed to urge seeking treatment with the family doctor. Reighard said\nthat now that the Lee County Health Department has become involved, the\nschool will determine close contacts, and the health department will take\non the role of contacting families.\nReighard said the majority of the 16 cases at Central Lee are among\nstudents in the middle school, although he said there have been a few at\nthe elementary and high school levels.\nThis isn't the 1st time that whooping cough has hit the area. This past\nwinter, 2004-2005, several confirmed cases were reported among students in\nthe Fort Madison Community School District. Lee County Health Department\nExecutive Director Julie Schilling said the department had 31 confirmed\ncases of whooping cough from Nov 2004 through Jan 2005, with the majority\nof those cases in the Fort Madison Public School system.\nA release of information concerning the outbreak from the Lee County Health\nDepartment did not indicate that there were incidents of whooping cough in\nFort Madison this time. Schilling said whooping cough has been in Iowa\nsince last summer [2004] but usually shows up in the fall. \"But it can\noccur at any time,\" Schilling said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although ProMED-mail does not cover pertussis regularly, regular outbreaks\nof the disease have continued to occur in the USA and elsewhere despite\naggressive universal childhood immunization programs. The development of a\npertussis vaccine consisting of pertussis toxoids as opposed to the older\nvaccine -- which was a killed, whole-cell product -- has improved tolerance\nbut not immunogenicity. This product, DTaP, has been used in the pediatric\nvaccination sequence for some time. As noted above, the Tdap variation is\nnow approved in adolescents and contains lower amounts of both diphtheria\nand pertussis components than the pediatric vaccine. Vaccination in\nadolescence should prolong immunity, but an additional booster will\nprobably be needed later in life. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n---\nPertussis - USA (multistate) 20040923.2626\n2003\n---\nPertussis - USA (South Carolina) 20030716.1750\nPertussis - USA (WA, NY) 20030624.1554\nPertussis, adults - USA (Ill) (02):chemoprophylaxis 20030112.0102\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n---\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n---\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n..................ll/pg/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
