For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-05-03 00:00:00", "2005-05-03 00:00:00", "2005-05-10 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-06 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Travis County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lee County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209266", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Canada (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209266", "date": "2005-05-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, ADOLESCENT VACCINE - USA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 3 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FDA.gov [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/ANSWERS/2005/ANS01354.html>\n\nCombination vaccine approved to protect adolescents against whooping cough\n---------------------------------------------------\nThe United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) today, 3 May 2005,\napproved the 1st combination vaccine that provides a booster immunization\nagainst pertussis (whooping cough) in combination with tetanus and\ndiphtheria for adolescents. The vaccine will be marketed as Boostrix by\nGlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Philadelphia, PA.\nPertussis is a highly communicable disease of the respiratory tract that\ncan be especially serious for infants under 1 year old, and may even be\nfatal. Pertussis can cause spells of coughing and choking that make\nbreathing difficult. The disease is generally less severe in adolescents,\nbut it is thought that they might transmit the disease to susceptible\ninfants and other family members. In the last 20 years, rates of pertussis\ninfection have been increasing in very young infants who have not received\nall their immunizations and in adolescents and adults.\nBoostrix is a tetanus toxoid (T), reduced diphtheria toxoid (d) and\nacellular pertussis vaccine (ap), adsorbed. Although booster vaccines for\nadolescents containing T and d are currently licensed and marketed for use\nin this age group, none contains a pertussis component. Boostrix has the\nsame components as Infanrix, a DTaP vaccine for infants and young children,\nbut in reduced quantities. Boostrix is indicated for use as a single\nbooster dose to adolescents 10-18 years of age.\nThe efficacy of the vaccine was measured by looking at the immune response\nto the vaccine, as measured by antibody concentrations. The response to the\nT and d components was at least as good as the response to a licensed Td\nvaccine. Boostrix also induced an antibody response to the pertussis\ncomponent of the vaccine. The response to the pertussis component was\ncompared to the response induced by a 3-dose series of Infanrix given to\ninfants in a previous study. The response of adolescents to Boostrix was\nconsidered adequate. It is not known how long immunity to pertussis will\nlast. Adolescents who received Boostrix experienced pain, redness, and\nswelling at the injection site. The frequency of redness and swelling after\nBoostrix was similar to what is expected following the administration of a\nTd vaccine. However, pain reactions at the injection site were more\nfrequent with those who received Boostrix. Other side effects included\nheadaches, fever and fatigue for a short period of time after the injection.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, 10 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Channel 36 Austin, TX [edited]\n<http://www.kxan.com/Global/story.asp?S=3327321&nav=0s3dZhYd>\n\nWhooping cough cases increasing\n-------------------------------\nThere have been 58 confirmed cases of whooping cough in Travis County\nschools in 2005. 100 more are suspected. \"In 2004, we had 300 cases\nreported in to us in the whole year, and we've already had more than 50\npercent of that number reported to us, just in the last 6 weeks,\" Dr Adolfo\nValadez, of the Travis County Health Department, said.\nWhooping cough looks like a regular cold or influenza in the beginning, but\ngradually gets worse, becoming especially dangerous for children with\nasthma. The coughing can become so severe it can close off [airways],\nespecially tiny ones. But doctors say those shots wear off when kids get a\nlittle older. The greatest danger is when school-age kids catch what looks\nlike a cold and bring it home to their baby brother or sister. \"When you\nsee that adolescent or adult with a cough history, test for pertussis\nbecause we can treat it,\" Valadez said.\nA 6 week old baby died in 2003 from whooping cough.\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri, 6 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource Fort Madison Daily Democrat (IA) [edited]\n<http://www.dailydem.com/articles/2005/05/06/news/news1.txt>\n\nArea whooping cough numbers climb\n----------------------------------\nIt's been determined to be an outbreak, with 17 confirmed cases of whooping\ncough in Lee County since mid-April 2005. Of the 17 cases, 16 are in the\nCentral Lee Community School District.\nCentral Lee superintendent Chuck Reighard said the school has responded to\nthe outbreak by determining who had close contact with the infected student\nand then making contact with the families of those who may have been\nexposed to urge seeking treatment with the family doctor. Reighard said\nthat now that the Lee County Health Department has become involved, the\nschool will determine close contacts, and the health department will take\non the role of contacting families.\nReighard said the majority of the 16 cases at Central Lee are among\nstudents in the middle school, although he said there have been a few at\nthe elementary and high school levels.\nThis isn't the 1st time that whooping cough has hit the area. This past\nwinter, 2004-2005, several confirmed cases were reported among students in\nthe Fort Madison Community School District. Lee County Health Department\nExecutive Director Julie Schilling said the department had 31 confirmed\ncases of whooping cough from Nov 2004 through Jan 2005, with the majority\nof those cases in the Fort Madison Public School system.\nA release of information concerning the outbreak from the Lee County Health\nDepartment did not indicate that there were incidents of whooping cough in\nFort Madison this time. Schilling said whooping cough has been in Iowa\nsince last summer [2004] but usually shows up in the fall. \"But it can\noccur at any time,\" Schilling said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although ProMED-mail does not cover pertussis regularly, regular outbreaks\nof the disease have continued to occur in the USA and elsewhere despite\naggressive universal childhood immunization programs. The development of a\npertussis vaccine consisting of pertussis toxoids as opposed to the older\nvaccine -- which was a killed, whole-cell product -- has improved tolerance\nbut not immunogenicity. This product, DTaP, has been used in the pediatric\nvaccination sequence for some time. As noted above, the Tdap variation is\nnow approved in adolescents and contains lower amounts of both diphtheria\nand pertussis components than the pediatric vaccine. Vaccination in\nadolescence should prolong immunity, but an additional booster will\nprobably be needed later in life. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n---\nPertussis - USA (multistate) 20040923.2626\n2003\n---\nPertussis - USA (South Carolina) 20030716.1750\nPertussis - USA (WA, NY) 20030624.1554\nPertussis, adults - USA (Ill) (02):chemoprophylaxis 20030112.0102\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n---\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n---\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n..................ll/pg/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Other side effects included\nheadaches, fever and fatigue for a short period of time after the injection.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, 10 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Channel 36 Austin, TX [edited]\n<http://www.kxan.com/Global/story.asp?S=3327321&nav=0s3dZhYd>\n\nWhooping cough cases increasing\n-------------------------------\nThere have been 58 confirmed cases of whooping cough in Travis County\nschools in 2005. 100 more are suspected. \"In 2004, we had 300 cases\nreported in to us in the whole year, and we've already had more than 50\npercent of that number reported to us, just in the last 6 weeks,\" Dr Adolfo\nValadez, of the Travis County Health Department, said.\nWhooping cough looks like a regular cold or influenza in the beginning, but\ngradually gets worse, becoming especially dangerous for children with\nasthma. The coughing can become so severe it can close off [airways],\nespecially tiny ones. But doctors say those shots wear off when kids get a\nlittle older. The greatest danger is when school-age kids catch what looks\nlike a cold and bring it home to their baby brother or sister. \"When you\nsee that adolescent or adult with a cough history, test for pertussis\nbecause we can treat it,\" Valadez said.\nA 6 week old baby died in 2003 from whooping cough.\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri, 6 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource Fort Madison Daily Democrat (IA) [edited]\n<http://www.dailydem.com/articles/2005/05/06/news/news1.txt>\n\nArea whooping cough numbers climb\n----------------------------------\nIt's been determined to be an outbreak, with 17 confirmed cases of whooping\ncough in Lee County since mid-April 2005. Of the 17 cases, 16 are in the\nCentral Lee Community School District.\nCentral Lee superintendent Chuck Reighard said the school has responded to\nthe outbreak by determining who had close contact with the infected student\nand then making contact with the families of those who may have been\nexposed to urge seeking treatment with the family doctor. Reighard said\nthat now that the Lee County Health Department has become involved, the\nschool will determine close contacts, and the health department will take\non the role of contacting families.\nReighard said the majority of the 16 cases at Central Lee are among\nstudents in the middle school, although he said there have been a few at\nthe elementary and high school levels.\nThis isn't the 1st time that whooping cough has hit the area. This past\nwinter, 2004-2005, several confirmed cases were reported among students in\nthe Fort Madison Community School District. Lee County Health Department\nExecutive Director Julie Schilling said the department had 31 confirmed\ncases of whooping cough from Nov 2004 through Jan 2005, with the majority\nof those cases in the Fort Madison Public School system.\nA release of information concerning the outbreak from the Lee County Health\nDepartment did not indicate that there were incidents of whooping cough in\nFort Madison this time. Schilling said whooping cough has been in Iowa\nsince last summer [2004] but usually shows up in the fall. \"But it can\noccur at any time,\" Schilling said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although ProMED-mail does not cover pertussis regularly, regular outbreaks\nof the disease have continued to occur in the USA and elsewhere despite\naggressive universal childhood immunization programs. The development of a\npertussis vaccine consisting of pertussis toxoids as opposed to the older\nvaccine -- which was a killed, whole-cell product -- has improved tolerance\nbut not immunogenicity. This product, DTaP, has been used in the pediatric\nvaccination sequence for some time. As noted above, the Tdap variation is\nnow approved in adolescents and contains lower amounts of both diphtheria\nand pertussis components than the pediatric vaccine. Vaccination in\nadolescence should prolong immunity, but an additional booster will\nprobably be needed later in life. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n---\nPertussis - USA (multistate) 20040923.2626\n2003\n---\nPertussis - USA (South Carolina) 20030716.1750\nPertussis - USA (WA, NY) 20030624.1554\nPertussis, adults - USA (Ill) (02):chemoprophylaxis 20030112.0102\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n---\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n---\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n..................ll/pg/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-05-03 00:00:00", "2005-05-03 00:00:00", "2005-05-10 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-06 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Travis County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tdap", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lee County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207242", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis, fatal - Afghanistan (Daykundi)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207242", "date": "2003-01-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, ADULTS - USA (ILLINOIS) (02):CHEMOPROPHYLAXIS\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 10 Jan 2003 06:43:12 +0000\nFrom: Badri Badrinath <badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n\nUK guidelines on erythromycin chemoprophylaxis in persons exposed to\npertussis have been published recently.\nDodhia H, Crowcroft NS, Bramley JC, Miller E: UK guidelines for use of\nerythromycin chemoprophylaxis in persons exposed to pertussis. J Pub Health\nMed 2002;24:200-206\nAbstract from:<http://pubmed.oupjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/24/3/200>\nPertussis is well controlled in the UK as a result of an effective\nvaccination program. Nevertheless, the disease has not been eliminated, and\ncases still occur in the most vulnerable group of young infants.\nErythromycin chemoprophylaxis has been advocated for use in contacts to\nprevent secondary cases, but the evidence for its use is weak. These\nguidelines are based on a review of the evidence and aim to help clinicians\nmake more rational decisions on the use of erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nfor pertussis. Erythromycin has well-established side effects, and so its\nuse should be limited to situations in which it is likely to be of greatest\nbenefit.\nIf a clinically suspected or confirmed case of pertussis is identified who\nis also in household contact with someone at greatest risk from pertussis\n-- young infants, especially neonates -- then erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nshould be considered. The aim is to protect those at greatest risk from\npertussis by offering chemoprophylaxis to them, to all their household\ncontacts who are unimmunized, and to contacts who are 5 years or older if\nthey did not receive a preschool pertussis booster (not given to those born\nbefore 1996 in the United Kingdom). There is no evidence of any benefit\nfrom chemoprophylaxis given more than 21 days from the date of onset of the\nprimary case. Unimmunized or partially immunized cases and contacts should\ncomplete their course of vaccine.\nI thought this might be of interest to ProMED-mail Readers.\n--\nDr.P.Badrinath M.D,MPH,PhD\nSuffolk Public Health Network & University of Cambridge\nSt.Clement's Hospital\nIpswich, UK\n<badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n[These UK guidelines discuss in more detail the use of macrolide\nchemoprophylaxis which, in the absence of a licensed pertussis vaccine in\nadults, remains the basis of stemming a pertussis outbreak in the adult\npopulation. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n----\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n----\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n.............mpp/ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. J Pub Health\nMed 2002;24:200-206\nAbstract from:<http://pubmed.oupjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/24/3/200>\nPertussis is well controlled in the UK as a result of an effective\nvaccination program. Nevertheless, the disease has not been eliminated, and\ncases still occur in the most vulnerable group of young infants.\nErythromycin chemoprophylaxis has been advocated for use in contacts to\nprevent secondary cases, but the evidence for its use is weak. These\nguidelines are based on a review of the evidence and aim to help clinicians\nmake more rational decisions on the use of erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nfor pertussis. Erythromycin has well-established side effects, and so its\nuse should be limited to situations in which it is likely to be of greatest\nbenefit.\nIf a clinically suspected or confirmed case of pertussis is identified who\nis also in household contact with someone at greatest risk from pertussis\n-- young infants, especially neonates -- then erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nshould be considered. The aim is to protect those at greatest risk from\npertussis by offering chemoprophylaxis to them, to all their household\ncontacts who are unimmunized, and to contacts who are 5 years or older if\nthey did not receive a preschool pertussis booster (not given to those born\nbefore 1996 in the United Kingdom). There is no evidence of any benefit\nfrom chemoprophylaxis given more than 21 days from the date of onset of the\nprimary case. Unimmunized or partially immunized cases and contacts should\ncomplete their course of vaccine.\nI thought this might be of interest to ProMED-mail Readers.\n--\nDr.P.Badrinath M.D,MPH,PhD\nSuffolk Public Health Network & University of Cambridge\nSt.Clement's Hospital\nIpswich, UK\n<badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n[These UK guidelines discuss in more detail the use of macrolide\nchemoprophylaxis which, in the absence of a licensed pertussis vaccine in\nadults, remains the basis of stemming a pertussis outbreak in the adult\npopulation. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n----\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n----\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n.............mpp/ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. J Pub Health\nMed 2002;24:200-206\nAbstract from:<http://pubmed.oupjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/24/3/200>\nPertussis is well controlled in the UK as a result of an effective\nvaccination program. Nevertheless, the disease has not been eliminated, and\ncases still occur in the most vulnerable group of young infants.\nErythromycin chemoprophylaxis has been advocated for use in contacts to\nprevent secondary cases, but the evidence for its use is weak. These\nguidelines are based on a review of the evidence and aim to help clinicians\nmake more rational decisions on the use of erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nfor pertussis. Erythromycin has well-established side effects, and so its\nuse should be limited to situations in which it is likely to be of greatest\nbenefit.\nIf a clinically suspected or confirmed case of pertussis is identified who\nis also in household contact with someone at greatest risk from pertussis\n-- young infants, especially neonates -- then erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nshould be considered. Unimmunized or partially immunized cases and contacts should\ncomplete their course of vaccine.\nI thought this might be of interest to ProMED-mail Readers.\n--\nDr.P.Badrinath M.D,MPH,PhD\nSuffolk Public Health Network & University of Cambridge\nSt.Clement's Hospital\nIpswich, UK\n<badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n[These UK guidelines discuss in more detail the use of macrolide\nchemoprophylaxis which, in the absence of a licensed pertussis vaccine in\nadults, remains the basis of stemming a pertussis outbreak in the adult\npopulation. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n----\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n----\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n.............mpp/ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Nevertheless, the disease has not been eliminated, and\ncases still occur in the most vulnerable group of young infants.\nErythromycin chemoprophylaxis has been advocated for use in contacts to\nprevent secondary cases, but the evidence for its use is weak. These\nguidelines are based on a review of the evidence and aim to help clinicians\nmake more rational decisions on the use of erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nfor pertussis. Erythromycin has well-established side effects, and so its\nuse should be limited to situations in which it is likely to be of greatest\nbenefit.\nIf a clinically suspected or confirmed case of pertussis is identified who\nis also in household contact with someone at greatest risk from pertussis\n-- young infants, especially neonates -- then erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nshould be considered. Unimmunized or partially immunized cases and contacts should\ncomplete their course of vaccine.\nI thought this might be of interest to ProMED-mail Readers.\n--\nDr.P.Badrinath M.D,MPH,PhD\nSuffolk Public Health Network & University of Cambridge\nSt.Clement's Hospital\nIpswich, UK\n<badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n[These UK guidelines discuss in more detail the use of macrolide\nchemoprophylaxis which, in the absence of a licensed pertussis vaccine in\nadults, remains the basis of stemming a pertussis outbreak in the adult\npopulation. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n----\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n----\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n.............mpp/ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-01-10 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ILLINOIS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204663", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - Sudan (Equatoria): susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204663", "date": "2003-01-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, ADULTS - USA (ILLINOIS) (02):CHEMOPROPHYLAXIS\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 10 Jan 2003 06:43:12 +0000\nFrom: Badri Badrinath <badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n\nUK guidelines on erythromycin chemoprophylaxis in persons exposed to\npertussis have been published recently.\nDodhia H, Crowcroft NS, Bramley JC, Miller E: UK guidelines for use of\nerythromycin chemoprophylaxis in persons exposed to pertussis. J Pub Health\nMed 2002;24:200-206\nAbstract from:<http://pubmed.oupjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/24/3/200>\nPertussis is well controlled in the UK as a result of an effective\nvaccination program. Nevertheless, the disease has not been eliminated, and\ncases still occur in the most vulnerable group of young infants.\nErythromycin chemoprophylaxis has been advocated for use in contacts to\nprevent secondary cases, but the evidence for its use is weak. These\nguidelines are based on a review of the evidence and aim to help clinicians\nmake more rational decisions on the use of erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nfor pertussis. Erythromycin has well-established side effects, and so its\nuse should be limited to situations in which it is likely to be of greatest\nbenefit.\nIf a clinically suspected or confirmed case of pertussis is identified who\nis also in household contact with someone at greatest risk from pertussis\n-- young infants, especially neonates -- then erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nshould be considered. The aim is to protect those at greatest risk from\npertussis by offering chemoprophylaxis to them, to all their household\ncontacts who are unimmunized, and to contacts who are 5 years or older if\nthey did not receive a preschool pertussis booster (not given to those born\nbefore 1996 in the United Kingdom). There is no evidence of any benefit\nfrom chemoprophylaxis given more than 21 days from the date of onset of the\nprimary case. Unimmunized or partially immunized cases and contacts should\ncomplete their course of vaccine.\nI thought this might be of interest to ProMED-mail Readers.\n--\nDr.P.Badrinath M.D,MPH,PhD\nSuffolk Public Health Network & University of Cambridge\nSt.Clement's Hospital\nIpswich, UK\n<badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n[These UK guidelines discuss in more detail the use of macrolide\nchemoprophylaxis which, in the absence of a licensed pertussis vaccine in\nadults, remains the basis of stemming a pertussis outbreak in the adult\npopulation. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n----\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n----\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n.............mpp/ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-01-10 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ILLINOIS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204167", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (South Carolina)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204167", "date": "2003-01-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, ADULTS - USA (ILLINOIS) (02):CHEMOPROPHYLAXIS\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 10 Jan 2003 06:43:12 +0000\nFrom: Badri Badrinath <badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n\nUK guidelines on erythromycin chemoprophylaxis in persons exposed to\npertussis have been published recently.\nDodhia H, Crowcroft NS, Bramley JC, Miller E: UK guidelines for use of\nerythromycin chemoprophylaxis in persons exposed to pertussis. J Pub Health\nMed 2002;24:200-206\nAbstract from:<http://pubmed.oupjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/24/3/200>\nPertussis is well controlled in the UK as a result of an effective\nvaccination program. Nevertheless, the disease has not been eliminated, and\ncases still occur in the most vulnerable group of young infants.\nErythromycin chemoprophylaxis has been advocated for use in contacts to\nprevent secondary cases, but the evidence for its use is weak. These\nguidelines are based on a review of the evidence and aim to help clinicians\nmake more rational decisions on the use of erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nfor pertussis. Erythromycin has well-established side effects, and so its\nuse should be limited to situations in which it is likely to be of greatest\nbenefit.\nIf a clinically suspected or confirmed case of pertussis is identified who\nis also in household contact with someone at greatest risk from pertussis\n-- young infants, especially neonates -- then erythromycin chemoprophylaxis\nshould be considered. The aim is to protect those at greatest risk from\npertussis by offering chemoprophylaxis to them, to all their household\ncontacts who are unimmunized, and to contacts who are 5 years or older if\nthey did not receive a preschool pertussis booster (not given to those born\nbefore 1996 in the United Kingdom). There is no evidence of any benefit\nfrom chemoprophylaxis given more than 21 days from the date of onset of the\nprimary case. Unimmunized or partially immunized cases and contacts should\ncomplete their course of vaccine.\nI thought this might be of interest to ProMED-mail Readers.\n--\nDr.P.Badrinath M.D,MPH,PhD\nSuffolk Public Health Network & University of Cambridge\nSt.Clement's Hospital\nIpswich, UK\n<badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n[These UK guidelines discuss in more detail the use of macrolide\nchemoprophylaxis which, in the absence of a licensed pertussis vaccine in\nadults, remains the basis of stemming a pertussis outbreak in the adult\npopulation. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis, adults - USA (Illinois) 20030109.0073\n2002\n----\nPertussis - USA (Texas) (02) 20020926.5404\nPertussis - USA (Texas) 20020925.5396\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n1998\n----\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\n.............mpp/ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The disease has been\ncontracted by 23 pupils at Stathern School in the Vale of Belvoir. Several\nother children also have the early symptoms of infection. All the pupils\nand staff at the school are being given antimicrobials and a full\nimmunization program is being carried out.\nThe outbreak first came to light last week and officials from\nLeicestershire Health Authority were sent in to investigate. Dr Philip\nMonk, consultant in communicable disease control, said: \"Within the school\nthere are currently a total of 23 confirmed and probable cases of whooping\ncough. In addition a number of children have early symptoms which are\nsuggestive of the disease.\"\n\"We visited the school last Thursday (23 May 2002) to carry out tests and\ngave all the children and teachers antimicrobial treatment to control the\nspread of the disease. In addition, all the children at Stathern Primary\nSchool have been given a booster vaccination against whooping cough to\nfurther protect them.\"\nAuthorities also report that the entire school is being cultured for\n_Bordetella pertussis_.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Reports of clusters of pertussis continue to occur in various parts of the\ndeveloped world. The age of the affected students is not stated but,\nassuming adherence to standard immunization protocols [94 per cent of\nchildren aged 2 years in England and Wales have received three doses of\npertussis vaccine. -Mod.SH], it is likely that the cluster is related to\nwaning immunity from primary immunization. No mention is made of cases in\nadults with household contact to the students either as a primary or\nsecondary case. Immunization of contacts with the acellular pertussis\nvaccine should be effective in this outbreak, but it is likely that\nclusters such as this one will continue until boosters of the vaccine are\nnot in short supply and given routinely every 10 years with adult Td toxoid\nvaccine. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n2000\n---\nPertussis - Australia (New South Wales) 20001105.1930\nPertussis - New Zealand: background 20000425.0616\n1998\n---\nPertussis - USA (Utah) (05) 19980924.1911\nPertussis - USA (Utah) 19980913.1841\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\nPertussis - USA (California) 19980705.1249\nPertussis - USA (Arizona) (02) 19980701.1217\nPertussis - USA Arizona) 19980628.1199\n...................ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The disease has been\ncontracted by 23 pupils at Stathern School in the Vale of Belvoir. Several\nother children also have the early symptoms of infection. All the pupils\nand staff at the school are being given antimicrobials and a full\nimmunization program is being carried out.\nThe outbreak first came to light last week and officials from\nLeicestershire Health Authority were sent in to investigate. Dr Philip\nMonk, consultant in communicable disease control, said: \"Within the school\nthere are currently a total of 23 confirmed and probable cases of whooping\ncough. In addition a number of children have early symptoms which are\nsuggestive of the disease.\"\n\"We visited the school last Thursday (23 May 2002) to carry out tests and\ngave all the children and teachers antimicrobial treatment to control the\nspread of the disease. In addition, all the children at Stathern Primary\nSchool have been given a booster vaccination against whooping cough to\nfurther protect them.\"\nAuthorities also report that the entire school is being cultured for\n_Bordetella pertussis_.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Reports of clusters of pertussis continue to occur in various parts of the\ndeveloped world. The age of the affected students is not stated but,\nassuming adherence to standard immunization protocols [94 per cent of\nchildren aged 2 years in England and Wales have received three doses of\npertussis vaccine. -Mod.SH], it is likely that the cluster is related to\nwaning immunity from primary immunization. No mention is made of cases in\nadults with household contact to the students either as a primary or\nsecondary case. Immunization of contacts with the acellular pertussis\nvaccine should be effective in this outbreak, but it is likely that\nclusters such as this one will continue until boosters of the vaccine are\nnot in short supply and given routinely every 10 years with adult Td toxoid\nvaccine. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n2000\n---\nPertussis - Australia (New South Wales) 20001105.1930\nPertussis - New Zealand: background 20000425.0616\n1998\n---\nPertussis - USA (Utah) (05) 19980924.1911\nPertussis - USA (Utah) 19980913.1841\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\nPertussis - USA (California) 19980705.1249\nPertussis - USA (Arizona) (02) 19980701.1217\nPertussis - USA Arizona) 19980628.1199\n...................ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The disease has been\ncontracted by 23 pupils at Stathern School in the Vale of Belvoir. Several\nother children also have the early symptoms of infection. All the pupils\nand staff at the school are being given antimicrobials and a full\nimmunization program is being carried out.\nThe outbreak first came to light last week and officials from\nLeicestershire Health Authority were sent in to investigate. Dr Philip\nMonk, consultant in communicable disease control, said: \"Within the school\nthere are currently a total of 23 confirmed and probable cases of whooping\ncough. In addition a number of children have early symptoms which are\nsuggestive of the disease.\"\n\"We visited the school last Thursday (23 May 2002) to carry out tests and\ngave all the children and teachers antimicrobial treatment to control the\nspread of the disease. In addition, all the children at Stathern Primary\nSchool have been given a booster vaccination against whooping cough to\nfurther protect them.\"\nAuthorities also report that the entire school is being cultured for\n_Bordetella pertussis_.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Reports of clusters of pertussis continue to occur in various parts of the\ndeveloped world. The age of the affected students is not stated but,\nassuming adherence to standard immunization protocols [94 per cent of\nchildren aged 2 years in England and Wales have received three doses of\npertussis vaccine. -Mod.SH], it is likely that the cluster is related to\nwaning immunity from primary immunization. No mention is made of cases in\nadults with household contact to the students either as a primary or\nsecondary case. Immunization of contacts with the acellular pertussis\nvaccine should be effective in this outbreak, but it is likely that\nclusters such as this one will continue until boosters of the vaccine are\nnot in short supply and given routinely every 10 years with adult Td toxoid\nvaccine. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n2000\n---\nPertussis - Australia (New South Wales) 20001105.1930\nPertussis - New Zealand: background 20000425.0616\n1998\n---\nPertussis - USA (Utah) (05) 19980924.1911\nPertussis - USA (Utah) 19980913.1841\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\nPertussis - USA (California) 19980705.1249\nPertussis - USA (Arizona) (02) 19980701.1217\nPertussis - USA Arizona) 19980628.1199\n...................ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The disease has been\ncontracted by 23 pupils at Stathern School in the Vale of Belvoir. Several\nother children also have the early symptoms of infection. All the pupils\nand staff at the school are being given antimicrobials and a full\nimmunization program is being carried out.\nThe outbreak first came to light last week and officials from\nLeicestershire Health Authority were sent in to investigate. Dr Philip\nMonk, consultant in communicable disease control, said: \"Within the school\nthere are currently a total of 23 confirmed and probable cases of whooping\ncough. In addition a number of children have early symptoms which are\nsuggestive of the disease.\"\n\"We visited the school last Thursday (23 May 2002) to carry out tests and\ngave all the children and teachers antimicrobial treatment to control the\nspread of the disease. In addition, all the children at Stathern Primary\nSchool have been given a booster vaccination against whooping cough to\nfurther protect them.\"\nAuthorities also report that the entire school is being cultured for\n_Bordetella pertussis_.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Reports of clusters of pertussis continue to occur in various parts of the\ndeveloped world. The age of the affected students is not stated but,\nassuming adherence to standard immunization protocols [94 per cent of\nchildren aged 2 years in England and Wales have received three doses of\npertussis vaccine. -Mod.SH], it is likely that the cluster is related to\nwaning immunity from primary immunization. No mention is made of cases in\nadults with household contact to the students either as a primary or\nsecondary case. Immunization of contacts with the acellular pertussis\nvaccine should be effective in this outbreak, but it is likely that\nclusters such as this one will continue until boosters of the vaccine are\nnot in short supply and given routinely every 10 years with adult Td toxoid\nvaccine. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology (04) 20020506.4119\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\n2000\n---\nPertussis - Australia (New South Wales) 20001105.1930\nPertussis - New Zealand: background 20000425.0616\n1998\n---\nPertussis - USA (Utah) (05) 19980924.1911\nPertussis - USA (Utah) 19980913.1841\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA (02) 19980828.1709\nPertussis in adults, current trends - USA 19980827.1699\nPertussis - USA: Review, case study & comment 19980706.1270\nPertussis - USA (California) 19980705.1249\nPertussis - USA (Arizona) (02) 19980701.1217\nPertussis - USA Arizona) 19980628.1199\n...................ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. In addition a number of children have early symptoms which are\nsuggestive of the disease.\"\n\"We visited the school last Thursday (23 May 2002) to carry out tests and\ngave all the children and teachers antimicrobial treatment to control the\nspread of the disease. The age of the affected students is not stated but,\nassuming adherence to standard immunization protocols [94 per cent of\nchildren aged 2 years in England and Wales have received three doses of\npertussis vaccine. -Mod.SH], it is likely that the cluster is related to\nwaning immunity from primary immunization. No mention is made of cases in\nadults with household contact to the students either as a primary or\nsecondary case. Simulations of pertussis epidemiology in the United\nStates: effects of adult booster vaccinations. Math Biosci 1999;\n158:47-73. [This paper from the University of Iowa uses a computer\nsimulation of the effects of pertussis immunization schedules in\nadults. The author concludes that his models suggest that a\nonce-per-decade pertussis booster would decrease the disease in\nadults but would have only a modest effect on the incidence in young\nchildren. - Mod.LL\nvan Boven M, de Melker HE, Schellekens JF, Kretzschmar M. Waning\nimmunity and sub-clinical infection in an epidemic model:\nimplications for pertussis in The Netherlands. Math Biosci 2000;\n164:161-82. [This contribution analyzes outbreaks of pertussis in\nHolland and suggests that the contribution of pertussis in adults to\noutbreaks cannot be neglected. - Mod.LL\nCodeco CT, Luz PM. Is pertussis actually reemerging? Insights from an\nindividual-based model. Cad Saude Publica 2001; 17:491-500. [In this\nmodel of pertussis dynamics in a small population from Brazil, the\nauthors analyze a number of potential factors. - Mod.LL\nCordova SP, Gilles MT, Beers MY. The outbreak that had to happen:\nBordetella pertussis in north-west Western Australia in 1999. Commun\nDis Intell 2000; 24:375-79. [In analyzing an outbreak of pertussis in\na small town in Australia, the authors conclude that periodic\npertussis outbreaks can be inevitable given an incomplete vaccine\nefficacy and waning immunity and urge the consideration of the\ninfection in anyone with a persistent cough regardless of age or\nimmunization status. - Mod.LL\nGarcia-Corbeira P, Dal-Re R, Aguilar L, Garcia-de-Lomas J.\nSeroepidemiology of Bordetella pertussis infections in the Spanish\npopulation: a cross-sectional study. Vaccine 2000; 18:2173-76. [In\nthis seroepidemiological study from Spain, the increasing prevalence\nof pertussis antibodies through adulthood suggested that pertussis\ninfection in Spanish adults may be common, suggesting the\nconsideration of the use of acellular pertussis vaccine boosters in\nadults.- Mod.LL\n--\nDr.P.Badrinath M.D,M.Phil,(Epid)PhD(Cantab)DFPHM(UK),MPH(Distinc)\nClinical Assistant Professor & Hon Consultant in Preventive Medicine,\nDepartment of Community Medicine,\nUAE University, PO Box 17666, Al Ain,\nUnited Arab Emirates.\n<badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n[The editors would like to thank Dr. Badrinath for his contribution\nto this series regarding changes in the epidemiology of pertussis. -\nMod.LL\n....................ll/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. [In analyzing an outbreak of pertussis in\na small town in Australia, the authors conclude that periodic\npertussis outbreaks can be inevitable given an incomplete vaccine\nefficacy and waning immunity and urge the consideration of the\ninfection in anyone with a persistent cough regardless of age or\nimmunization status. - Mod.LL\nGarcia-Corbeira P, Dal-Re R, Aguilar L, Garcia-de-Lomas J.\nSeroepidemiology of Bordetella pertussis infections in the Spanish\npopulation: a cross-sectional study. Vaccine 2000; 18:2173-76. [In\nthis seroepidemiological study from Spain, the increasing prevalence\nof pertussis antibodies through adulthood suggested that pertussis\ninfection in Spanish adults may be common, suggesting the\nconsideration of the use of acellular pertussis vaccine boosters in\nadults.- Mod.LL\n--\nDr.P.Badrinath M.D,M.Phil,(Epid)PhD(Cantab)DFPHM(UK),MPH(Distinc)\nClinical Assistant Professor & Hon Consultant in Preventive Medicine,\nDepartment of Community Medicine,\nUAE University, PO Box 17666, Al Ain,\nUnited Arab Emirates.\n<badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n[The editors would like to thank Dr. Badrinath for his contribution\nto this series regarding changes in the epidemiology of pertussis. -\nMod.LL\n....................ll/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201742", "date": "2002-05-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS, WORLDWIDE INCREASE, CHANGE IN EPIDEMIOLOGY (02)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nPertussis, worldwide increase, change in epidemiology 20020503.4084\nDate: 4 May 2002\nFrom: Padmanabhan Badrinath <badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n\nWith reference to the above posting the following references on\npertussis may be of interest to ProMed readers:\nHethcote HW. Simulations of pertussis epidemiology in the United\nStates: effects of adult booster vaccinations. Math Biosci 1999;\n158:47-73. [This paper from the University of Iowa uses a computer\nsimulation of the effects of pertussis immunization schedules in\nadults. The author concludes that his models suggest that a\nonce-per-decade pertussis booster would decrease the disease in\nadults but would have only a modest effect on the incidence in young\nchildren. - Mod.LL\nvan Boven M, de Melker HE, Schellekens JF, Kretzschmar M. Waning\nimmunity and sub-clinical infection in an epidemic model:\nimplications for pertussis in The Netherlands. Math Biosci 2000;\n164:161-82. [This contribution analyzes outbreaks of pertussis in\nHolland and suggests that the contribution of pertussis in adults to\noutbreaks cannot be neglected. - Mod.LL\nCodeco CT, Luz PM. Is pertussis actually reemerging? Insights from an\nindividual-based model. Cad Saude Publica 2001; 17:491-500. [In this\nmodel of pertussis dynamics in a small population from Brazil, the\nauthors analyze a number of potential factors. - Mod.LL\nCordova SP, Gilles MT, Beers MY. The outbreak that had to happen:\nBordetella pertussis in north-west Western Australia in 1999. Commun\nDis Intell 2000; 24:375-79. [In analyzing an outbreak of pertussis in\na small town in Australia, the authors conclude that periodic\npertussis outbreaks can be inevitable given an incomplete vaccine\nefficacy and waning immunity and urge the consideration of the\ninfection in anyone with a persistent cough regardless of age or\nimmunization status. - Mod.LL\nGarcia-Corbeira P, Dal-Re R, Aguilar L, Garcia-de-Lomas J.\nSeroepidemiology of Bordetella pertussis infections in the Spanish\npopulation: a cross-sectional study. Vaccine 2000; 18:2173-76. [In\nthis seroepidemiological study from Spain, the increasing prevalence\nof pertussis antibodies through adulthood suggested that pertussis\ninfection in Spanish adults may be common, suggesting the\nconsideration of the use of acellular pertussis vaccine boosters in\nadults.- Mod.LL\n--\nDr.P.Badrinath M.D,M.Phil,(Epid)PhD(Cantab)DFPHM(UK),MPH(Distinc)\nClinical Assistant Professor & Hon Consultant in Preventive Medicine,\nDepartment of Community Medicine,\nUAE University, PO Box 17666, Al Ain,\nUnited Arab Emirates.\n<badrishanthi@hotmail.com>\n[The editors would like to thank Dr. Badrinath for his contribution\nto this series regarding changes in the epidemiology of pertussis. -\nMod.LL\n....................ll/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Because the\nvaccinations wear off after five to 10 years, adults and adolescents\nimmunized as infants can catch whooping cough and pass it along to others.\"\nThis is what many health care providers believe, and therefore, they think\nimmunized children cannot get whooping cough. I sometimes feel like a\nsnake-oil salesman trying to convince the providers to take the situation\nseriously if the kids have had the shots! Even after I have phoned ahead\nto let the provider know that a child has had face to face exposure with a\nculture-confirmed case in the past 21 days, they may check the immunization\nrecord and simply tell the parent not to worry (because immunizations are\ncurrent).\nWe must be careful about the language we use. Changing the health care\ncommunity's understanding of whooping cough in a highly immunized\npopulation is an arduous task for those of us who deal with it daily. I\nsometimes find the lay public more open to the current epidemiology of\npertussis than some doctors and nurses. This immunization is not like\nmeasles vaccine, where 95% of those receiving the vaccine develop measles\nIgG and are then immune to measles.\nAs an example, prophylactic antibiotics for an asymptomatic immunized child\nwith a known exposure can be important. Pertussis in an immunized child\ncan present as a few days of cold symptoms with a slight night cough. But\nthey may still be contagious. The immunized child could expose an infant\ntoo young for immunization. And that infant could die from pertussis\ndisease.\n--\nChas De Bolt, RN MPH\nVaccine-preventable diseases epidemiologist\nPrevention division\nSeattle King County Department of Public Health\n999 Third Avenue, Suite 900\nSeattle, Washington 98104-4099\nPhone: (206) 296-4774\nFax: (206) 296-4803\ne-mail: chas.debolt@metrokc.gov\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Because the\nvaccinations wear off after five to 10 years, adults and adolescents\nimmunized as infants can catch whooping cough and pass it along to others.\"\nThis is what many health care providers believe, and therefore, they think\nimmunized children cannot get whooping cough. I sometimes feel like a\nsnake-oil salesman trying to convince the providers to take the situation\nseriously if the kids have had the shots! Even after I have phoned ahead\nto let the provider know that a child has had face to face exposure with a\nculture-confirmed case in the past 21 days, they may check the immunization\nrecord and simply tell the parent not to worry (because immunizations are\ncurrent).\nWe must be careful about the language we use. Changing the health care\ncommunity's understanding of whooping cough in a highly immunized\npopulation is an arduous task for those of us who deal with it daily. I\nsometimes find the lay public more open to the current epidemiology of\npertussis than some doctors and nurses. This immunization is not like\nmeasles vaccine, where 95% of those receiving the vaccine develop measles\nIgG and are then immune to measles.\nAs an example, prophylactic antibiotics for an asymptomatic immunized child\nwith a known exposure can be important. Pertussis in an immunized child\ncan present as a few days of cold symptoms with a slight night cough. But\nthey may still be contagious. The immunized child could expose an infant\ntoo young for immunization. And that infant could die from pertussis\ndisease.\n--\nChas De Bolt, RN MPH\nVaccine-preventable diseases epidemiologist\nPrevention division\nSeattle King County Department of Public Health\n999 Third Avenue, Suite 900\nSeattle, Washington 98104-4099\nPhone: (206) 296-4774\nFax: (206) 296-4803\ne-mail: chas.debolt@metrokc.gov\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2197690", "headline": "PRO> Pertussis - New Zealand: background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2197690", "date": "1998-09-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (UTAH) (02)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (Utah) 980913101922\nDate: Mon, 14 Sep 1998 16:30:25 -0700\nFrom: DeBolt, Chas <Chas.DeBolt@METROKC.GOV>\n\nI am writing to remark about the following language in the 9/13/98\nPertussis USA (Utah) posting [980913101922 cited above:\n\"Whooping cough in children can be prevented by a series of shots given at\n2, 4, 6 and 15 months and again when the child enters school. Because the\nvaccinations wear off after five to 10 years, adults and adolescents\nimmunized as infants can catch whooping cough and pass it along to others.\"\nThis is what many health care providers believe, and therefore, they think\nimmunized children cannot get whooping cough. I sometimes feel like a\nsnake-oil salesman trying to convince the providers to take the situation\nseriously if the kids have had the shots! Even after I have phoned ahead\nto let the provider know that a child has had face to face exposure with a\nculture-confirmed case in the past 21 days, they may check the immunization\nrecord and simply tell the parent not to worry (because immunizations are\ncurrent).\nWe must be careful about the language we use. Changing the health care\ncommunity's understanding of whooping cough in a highly immunized\npopulation is an arduous task for those of us who deal with it daily. I\nsometimes find the lay public more open to the current epidemiology of\npertussis than some doctors and nurses. This immunization is not like\nmeasles vaccine, where 95% of those receiving the vaccine develop measles\nIgG and are then immune to measles.\nAs an example, prophylactic antibiotics for an asymptomatic immunized child\nwith a known exposure can be important. Pertussis in an immunized child\ncan present as a few days of cold symptoms with a slight night cough. But\nthey may still be contagious. The immunized child could expose an infant\ntoo young for immunization. And that infant could die from pertussis\ndisease.\n--\nChas De Bolt, RN MPH\nVaccine-preventable diseases epidemiologist\nPrevention division\nSeattle King County Department of Public Health\n999 Third Avenue, Suite 900\nSeattle, Washington 98104-4099\nPhone: (206) 296-4774\nFax: (206) 296-4803\ne-mail: chas.debolt@metrokc.gov\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Because the\nvaccinations wear off after five to 10 years, adults and adolescents\nimmunized as infants can catch whooping cough and pass it along to others.\"\nThis is what many health care providers believe, and therefore, they think\nimmunized children cannot get whooping cough. Even after I have phoned ahead\nto let the provider know that a child has had face to face exposure with a\nculture-confirmed case in the past 21 days, they may check the immunization\nrecord and simply tell the parent not to worry (because immunizations are\ncurrent).\nWe must be careful about the language we use. Changing the health care\ncommunity's understanding of whooping cough in a highly immunized\npopulation is an arduous task for those of us who deal with it daily. I\nsometimes find the lay public more open to the current epidemiology of\npertussis than some doctors and nurses. This immunization is not like\nmeasles vaccine, where 95% of those receiving the vaccine develop measles\nIgG and are then immune to measles.\nAs an example, prophylactic antibiotics for an asymptomatic immunized child\nwith a known exposure can be important. Pertussis in an immunized child\ncan present as a few days of cold symptoms with a slight night cough. But\nthey may still be contagious. The immunized child could expose an infant\ntoo young for immunization. And that infant could die from pertussis\ndisease.\n--\nChas De Bolt, RN MPH\nVaccine-preventable diseases epidemiologist\nPrevention division\nSeattle King County Department of Public Health\n999 Third Avenue, Suite 900\nSeattle, Washington 98104-4099\nPhone: (206) 296-4774\nFax: (206) 296-4803\ne-mail: chas.debolt@metrokc.gov\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "pertussis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2194325", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Pertussis - USA (Utah) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194325", "date": "1998-09-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "PERTUSSIS - USA (UTAH) (02)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nPertussis - USA (Utah) 980913101922\nDate: Mon, 14 Sep 1998 16:30:25 -0700\nFrom: DeBolt, Chas <Chas.DeBolt@METROKC.GOV>\n\nI am writing to remark about the following language in the 9/13/98\nPertussis USA (Utah) posting [980913101922 cited above:\n\"Whooping cough in children can be prevented by a series of shots given at\n2, 4, 6 and 15 months and again when the child enters school. Because the\nvaccinations wear off after five to 10 years, adults and adolescents\nimmunized as infants can catch whooping cough and pass it along to others.\"\nThis is what many health care providers believe, and therefore, they think\nimmunized children cannot get whooping cough. I sometimes feel like a\nsnake-oil salesman trying to convince the providers to take the situation\nseriously if the kids have had the shots! Even after I have phoned ahead\nto let the provider know that a child has had face to face exposure with a\nculture-confirmed case in the past 21 days, they may check the immunization\nrecord and simply tell the parent not to worry (because immunizations are\ncurrent).\nWe must be careful about the language we use. Changing the health care\ncommunity's understanding of whooping cough in a highly immunized\npopulation is an arduous task for those of us who deal with it daily. I\nsometimes find the lay public more open to the current epidemiology of\npertussis than some doctors and nurses. This immunization is not like\nmeasles vaccine, where 95% of those receiving the vaccine develop measles\nIgG and are then immune to measles.\nAs an example, prophylactic antibiotics for an asymptomatic immunized child\nwith a known exposure can be important. Pertussis in an immunized child\ncan present as a few days of cold symptoms with a slight night cough. But\nthey may still be contagious. The immunized child could expose an infant\ntoo young for immunization. And that infant could die from pertussis\ndisease.\n--\nChas De Bolt, RN MPH\nVaccine-preventable diseases epidemiologist\nPrevention division\nSeattle King County Department of Public Health\n999 Third Avenue, Suite 900\nSeattle, Washington 98104-4099\nPhone: (206) 296-4774\nFax: (206) 296-4803\ne-mail: chas.debolt@metrokc.gov\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Because the\nvaccinations wear off after five to 10 years, adults and adolescents\nimmunized as infants can catch whooping cough and pass it along to others.\"\nThis is what many health care providers believe, and therefore, they think\nimmunized children cannot get whooping cough. I sometimes feel like a\nsnake-oil salesman trying to convince the providers to take the situation\nseriously if the kids have had the shots! Even after I have phoned ahead\nto let the provider know that a child has had face to face exposure with a\nculture-confirmed case in the past 21 days, they may check the immunization\nrecord and simply tell the parent not to worry (because immunizations are\ncurrent).\nWe must be careful about the language we use. Changing the health care\ncommunity's understanding of whooping cough in a highly immunized\npopulation is an arduous task for those of us who deal with it daily. I\nsometimes find the lay public more open to the current epidemiology of\npertussis than some doctors and nurses. This immunization is not like\nmeasles vaccine, where 95% of those receiving the vaccine develop measles\nIgG and are then immune to measles.\nAs an example, prophylactic antibiotics for an asymptomatic immunized child\nwith a known exposure can be important. Pertussis in an immunized child\ncan present as a few days of cold symptoms with a slight night cough. But\nthey may still be contagious. The immunized child could expose an infant\ntoo young for immunization. And that infant could die from pertussis\ndisease.\n--\nChas De Bolt, RN MPH\nVaccine-preventable diseases epidemiologist\nPrevention division\nSeattle King County Department of Public Health\n999 Third Avenue, Suite 900\nSeattle, Washington 98104-4099\nPhone: (206) 296-4774\nFax: (206) 296-4803\ne-mail: chas.debolt@metrokc.gov\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Because the\nvaccinations wear off after five to 10 years, adults and adolescents\nimmunized as infants can catch whooping cough and pass it along to others.\"\nThis is what many health care providers believe, and therefore, they think\nimmunized children cannot get whooping cough. I sometimes feel like a\nsnake-oil salesman trying to convince the providers to take the situation\nseriously if the kids have had the shots! Even after I have phoned ahead\nto let the provider know that a child has had face to face exposure with a\nculture-confirmed case in the past 21 days, they may check the immunization\nrecord and simply tell the parent not to worry (because immunizations are\ncurrent).\nWe must be careful about the language we use. Changing the health care\ncommunity's understanding of whooping cough in a highly immunized\npopulation is an arduous task for those of us who deal with it daily. I\nsometimes find the lay public more open to the current epidemiology of\npertussis than some doctors and nurses. This immunization is not like\nmeasles vaccine, where 95% of those receiving the vaccine develop measles\nIgG and are then immune to measles.\nAs an example, prophylactic antibiotics for an asymptomatic immunized child\nwith a known exposure can be important. Pertussis in an immunized child\ncan present as a few days of cold symptoms with a slight night cough. But\nthey may still be contagious. The immunized child could expose an infant\ntoo young for immunization. And that infant could die from pertussis\ndisease.\n--\nChas De Bolt, RN MPH\nVaccine-preventable diseases epidemiologist\nPrevention division\nSeattle King County Department of Public Health\n999 Third Avenue, Suite 900\nSeattle, Washington 98104-4099\nPhone: (206) 296-4774\nFax: (206) 296-4803\ne-mail: chas.debolt@metrokc.gov\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Because the\nvaccinations wear off after five to 10 years, adults and adolescents\nimmunized as infants can catch whooping cough and pass it along to others.\"\nThis is what many health care providers believe, and therefore, they think\nimmunized children cannot get whooping cough. Even after I have phoned ahead\nto let the provider know that a child has had face to face exposure with a\nculture-confirmed case in the past 21 days, they may check the immunization\nrecord and simply tell the parent not to worry (because immunizations are\ncurrent).\nWe must be careful about the language we use. Changing the health care\ncommunity's understanding of whooping cough in a highly immunized\npopulation is an arduous task for those of us who deal with it daily. I\nsometimes find the lay public more open to the current epidemiology of\npertussis than some doctors and nurses. This immunization is not like\nmeasles vaccine, where 95% of those receiving the vaccine develop measles\nIgG and are then immune to measles.\nAs an example, prophylactic antibiotics for an asymptomatic immunized child\nwith a known exposure can be important. Pertussis in an immunized child\ncan present as a few days of cold symptoms with a slight night cough. But\nthey may still be contagious. The immunized child could expose an infant\ntoo young for immunization. And that infant could die from pertussis\ndisease.\n--\nChas De Bolt, RN MPH\nVaccine-preventable diseases epidemiologist\nPrevention division\nSeattle King County Department of Public Health\n999 Third Avenue, Suite 900\nSeattle, Washington 98104-4099\nPhone: (206) 296-4774\nFax: (206) 296-4803\ne-mail: chas.debolt@metrokc.gov\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Although only 9 persons have died of the disease, this\nnumber is almost half of the number of fatalities over the previous 20\nyears. In the Australian Capitol Territory (Canberra) there has been a\ndoubling of pertussis cases since 1996, despite health ministry programs\nurging parents to get their children immunized.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[Several weeks ago, we had a discussion of a strain of _Bordetella\npertussis_ that has exhibited an antigenic shift that could result in\ndecreased vaccine efficacy. See reference: Pertussis outbreak -\nNetherlands (02), response, cited above. It would be of interest to know\nwhether scientists from Australia were in communication with those from the\nNetherlands who have done this work. Although only 9 persons have died of the disease, this\nnumber is almost half of the number of fatalities over the previous 20\nyears. In the Australian Capitol Territory (Canberra) there has been a\ndoubling of pertussis cases since 1996, despite health ministry programs\nurging parents to get their children immunized.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[Several weeks ago, we had a discussion of a strain of _Bordetella\npertussis_ that has exhibited an antigenic shift that could result in\ndecreased vaccine efficacy. See reference: Pertussis outbreak -\nNetherlands (02), response, cited above. It would be of interest to know\nwhether scientists from Australia were in communication with those from the\nNetherlands who have done this work. If any such collaboration is ongoing,\nwe would be pleased to hear about it. - Mod.ES\n...................................dp/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
